name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the joint debate on the progress report on renewable energy sources (2016/2041(INI)) (A8-0196/2016) and – the report by Markus Pieper on behalf of the Committee on Industry, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and energy on the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU) (2015/2232(INI)) (A8-0199/2016).

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it has been just over two months since we presented the first draft report on renewable energy situation in the European Union, and I would like to thank the other groups and the Secretariat for their speed and willingness to make today's vote possible.  I welcome the high degree of consensus we reached at many of the points in the report, even if the agreement could not be complete in the final vote of the committee.  Parliament should guide the Commission in its assessment of those States which will fail, if they do not change their policies, the renewable development targets by 2020, but it must also help prepare the proposal for a new Renewables Directive until 2030 to maintain the binding targets and strengthen them in order to meet the climate change commitments made in COP 21.  The same proposal for the future appears in the Pieper energy efficiency report. It is no coincidence, since the development of renewables has the same objective as energy savings and efficiency proposals, and encounters the same obstacles in the Member States. And that objective is to contribute to an energy transition to a more sovereign, greener and more democratic model in the face of the interests of the oligopolies that dominate the energy sector today. You do not have to remind the Commissioner, Mr Arias Cañete, of which policies have most adversely affected the development of renewables, as they were carried out by the Government of which he was a part.  First, we must ensure that renewable support systems are stable in the long run and serve as a counterweight to the market in the development of more efficient and sustainable renewable energy. The retroactive elimination of these support models can only hit new investments in energy generation and distribution.  Preferential treatment of renewables cannot be called into question, since the environmental externalities of other energies – and especially the alternatives promoted by the European Union such as nuclear or gas – are discounted, this is an efficient and competitive bet.  Secondly, we must promote generation mechanisms that promote democratic control of energy over large energy oligopolies. To this end, we must support the right to self-consumption and strengthen mechanisms for public participation and planning in the development of renewables, as well as collective systems for generation, distribution and efficiency in energy consumption, both in electricity and heating and cooling systems.  We believe that in the past the Directive has been a useful instrument, although with some unwanted effects that should be corrected. One of them: the negative effects on global sustainability that accelerated bioenergy development has had, be it biomass to burn or biofuel for transport. This is a clear example that the market is not always a good mechanism for ensuring the good use of resources, as seen in competition for agricultural land or the progressive decoupling of transport and production networks from final consumption.  Ended. The energy transition is not only a technological challenge, it is also a social challenge. As we advocate in an amendment, which we hope will be adopted, we cannot allow a disorganized transition to lower labour standards or sever the potential for job creation in the energy sector. That is why, as we have highlighted in the report, it is important to move forward with the social partners in defining a new energy model.  Renewables should also be an opportunity to alleviate energy poverty, adapting market rules and providing social guarantees for those households that cannot access a basic right such as energy.  I hope that the debate will allow bridges to be re-built and support for a report of undoubted importance strengthened.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has It is a memorable day today: a British referendum. Incidentally, this is also about subsidiarity and cutting red tape, and we will certainly have to discuss that here today. Improving energy efficiency is a win-win situation. For the environment, more energy efficiency means less emissions of pollutants and CO2, with equal energy input, and for consumers more energy efficiency means less costs, for energy security more energy efficiency means more security of supply. In this respect, the Energy Efficiency Directive is an investment in Europe's future, if properly addressed. The result so far is correct. We will achieve 20% energy savings by 2020, not only because of European regulation, which is not properly implemented everywhere, but also because of the self-interest of businesses and consumers in reducing energy consumption. Thank you very much to the citizens and businesses of Europe for this. The European environmental record in general is a success story. We are world champions in terms of CO2 savings, the expansion of renewable energies and energy saving. However, consumers and businesses also pay a high price for this. Firstly, electricity prices for commercial and private customers are among the highest in the world. Decades of excessive feed-in tariffs are having an effect in many Member States. Secondly, energy-intensive industries are struggling to survive in Europe. New investments have long been made only outside the EU. Thirdly, bureaucracy is sprawling – ecodesign labeling, pollution control laws, ETS, emission reduction, building directive and so on. Of course, any legislation is justified, but we neglect the interactions, including, incidentally, with the uncoordinated national energy policies. The result is a lot of bureaucracy, but there is also an influence on, for example, the price of allowances in emissions trading. We deplore their decline and then punish companies for the mistakes we have made, including companies with ever-increasing costs. This cannot continue. I have taken this on board with the example of the Energy Efficiency Directive and I am grateful that many points have also remained in the report, namely that we need to move more towards innovation for efficiency and not just rely on the need to save, that the flexibility of the directive remains, so that the Member States have incentives for new measures. The reporting bureaucracy and the need for more coherent legislation are also indicated, at least in the report. Until then, we will agree with the majority in Parliament. What we – or what I do, as rapporteur – do not support at all is a 40% savings regulation, in other words, savings obligations for energy consumption. This is not about efficiency, it is about banning the consumption of energy. We could do that if Europe were in a bad position, but the facts speak a different language. Greenhouse gas emissions have been reduced by just over 25 percent since 1990, while Europe's gross national product has increased by almost 50 percent. With 25 percent fewer pollutants, we have generated 50 percent more. If that is not an efficient balance sheet! So anyone who wants a 40 percent ban on consumption now is absolutely supplanting the realities. That is why I would like to ask again, my urgent request to my colleagues in the S&D and the Liberals: support our amendment by which we want a target corridor of 30 to 40 per cent, but not as coercion, but as orientation. If we fail to follow the road, we can still follow up with legal measures, but first of all we want to give people and businesses a confidence boost: the EU is the world champion of the environment, and we all want to help to develop this position!

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a satisfaction to be before you today to take part in this debate on two of the most important pillars of energy union: energy efficiency and renewable energy. In addition, addressing them at the same time reflects the important role they both play in meeting the ambitious climate commitments made during the last Paris Summit. And the debate takes place at a very appropriate time, when we are finalizing the revision of energy efficiency and renewable energy legislation, which will see the light in the second half of the year. Let me begin by thanking the two rapporteurs for their excellent work on these important initiative reports. I shall begin with Mr Pieper's report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. As you know, we are preparing revisions to the Energy Efficiency and Energy Efficiency Directives in buildings. The purpose is to set energy efficiency targets by 2030 and to ensure that we have at our disposal the right framework and measures to achieve them and, by focusing on buildings in particular, we are prioritizing sectors with the greatest energy saving potential. The report reaches a number of conclusions which we will take into account in the preparation of the revisions I have just mentioned. I fully agree with the conclusion of the Pieper report on the need to systematically include the principle of energy efficiency first in our energy and climate policies. Let me also tell you that Europe needs an explicit target by 2030 that is integrated into the legislation. It will be important when sending a positive signal to investors and legislators and for boosting the long-term investments we need to meet our goals. But the revision of our energy legislation needs to go far beyond an end goal. We need to take compliance and enforcement seriously. In this regard, let me underline the fact that the revision of the Energy Efficiency Directive will address Article Seventh, energy-saving obligations. The recent evaluation showed that Member States have taken this policy seriously, taken necessary measures and established control and verification systems to achieve the savings needed by 2020. It is hoped that by 2020 this article will be able to contribute about half of the savings of the Energy Efficiency Directive. We can say that it has been an effective instrument, but we now need to align it in line with the overall framework for 2030, so that it can contribute to the ambitious emission reduction targets defined at the European Council in October 2014. It will also be important to encourage private investment in our buildings, a sector with enormous savings potential, a key sector not only to achieve our energy efficiency goals, but also to address energy poverty, reduce high energy bills and reduce health risks. The revision of the Energy Efficiency Directive in buildings will pay particular attention to these objectives. I would once again like to thank the rapporteur for having incorporated these important issues into his report, and we have to work closely on these legislative proposals. Of course, this is also true for the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive. This is a policy that has worked well. With a share of renewables of 16% of final energy consumption in 2014, the European Union and a majority of Member States are moving well towards the 2020 targets. All but one country is ahead of their indicative trajectory and nine have already reached their 2020 targets. This has allowed us to cut our fossil fuel imports, reduce emissions and develop a competitive renewables industry. However, some Member States need to increase their efforts to live up to the intense trajectory we need to maintain in the coming years. That is why we are fully focused on the implementation of the Renewable Energy Directive and I know that this is fundamental to the European Parliament. But, as the report rightly points out, we also need to look to the post-2020 period. The revision of the Renewable Energy Directive will be the central pillar of these efforts and will be reinforced by the redesign of the electricity market and the Energy Union's governance initiative. As many of you have asked, we want to put on the table a robust legal framework that gives stability to investors and helps achieve our goals efficiently. Our ambition is that revision of the Renewables Directive, the new design of the electricity market and the strengthened emissions trading system are key drivers to boost new investments in renewables that help Europe become number one in this sector. In the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive we aim to address many of the concerns reflected in its amendments. For example, how to better harness the potential of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector and how to incentivize the role of the consumer. We are also dealing with removing administrative and institutional barriers that delay investment in Europe. Let me give you an idea of the elements we're considering. First, on goals we need to build on the progress made by 2020. That's why we're exploring setting the 2020 national targets as a starting point. Secondly, the Directive will focus on three sectors which will help us achieve our objectives: electricity, heating and cooling, and transport. In particular, we share your concern about slow progress in the transport sector. Thirdly, another key point will be the role of renewable support schemes. In our proposal we will consolidate the shift towards a market-based system for renewable support mechanisms and towards the convergence of national support schemes. As I mentioned, we plan to move towards better market design, which, together with a strengthened emissions trading system, will make it easier for renewable energy generators to make the most of the market profit. And finally, we have seen in this report that the issue of bioenergy sustainability criteria is of considerable interest. The Commission is working on an improved sustainability policy for biofuels and biomass. Biomass is the main source of renewable energy in the European Union and we are looking for a pragmatic approach that ensures significant emission savings, avoids risks of significant environmental impacts and avoids unnecessary administrative burdens, especially for small power plants and small forest owners. Ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude by stressing the importance to me of this debate and the European Parliament's contribution in the preparation of future legislative proposals. I would like to mention one last aspect which I think is of great importance in achieving the objectives we have set ourselves. I am referring to the need to mobilize investments in these sectors. The European Fund for Strategic Investments has opened the door to new possibilities that we must make an intelligence use of, and I would like to call on local, regional and national authorities to make greater use of this instrument. I will conclude by saying that the Commission is very grateful for these two reports. I assure you that in the forthcoming legislative proposals we will be ambitious and ensure that energy efficiency and renewable energy are the key drivers of our Paris commitments and our transition to the decarbonisation of our energy system, and I look forward to working closely with the European Parliament to make this noble cause possible.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Rapporteur on the opinion of the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee. Mr. President, I congratulate the rapporteur on her report and thank her for her cooperation. The European Union and the Member States are well on their way to achieving the binding target by achieving a share of renewable energy in final gross consumption of 20% by 2020. Expected progress is being made in the heating and cooling sector, but I am concerned about the lack of progress in the transport sector.  The lack of progress in this area is caused by the uncertainty of investing in biofuel production, so I expect the Commission to give a clear perspective to producers of advanced biofuels through a new legislative proposal on renewables for the post-2020 period.  I regret that the Environment Committee's position on the need to assess the positive role of European forests as a carbon sink and the sector's full potential in achieving future objectives did not enter the final report. Harnessing the full potential of the agricultural and forestry sectors through investments in the production of advanced biofuels can contribute to the creation of 146 000 permanent and another 162 000 temporary jobs, which would significantly contribute to the revival of our rural areas and the stay of people in the countryside.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, COP21 highlighted the fundamental role of regions and cities in the transition to low-carbon societies. For our Committee on Regional Development, cohesion policy funds can further contribute to achieving the renewable energy development targets.  Our Committee regrets above all that the mobilization of cohesion policy funds for renewable energy has increased from only 1.1% over the period 2007-2013 to 1.4% for the period 2014-2020. That is why we call on European cities and regions to mobilise all the instruments and to redouble their efforts.  With regard to the outermost regions, we believe that it is possible to set an ambitious target for energy autonomy.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, I would like to thank the Many thanks to Markus Pieper and all those who helped to draw up this report. We have many similarities between ITRE and ENVI. We want flexibility, especially with the measures in Article 7, we want planning certainty. The essential elements of the directive must be extended not only until 2030, but also beyond. There has been a great deal of discussion in both committees on the objective. Both committees voted by a majority in favour of the 40%. Personally, I am campaigning for a compromise that the PPE-DE has tabled. I myself supported the 40%, but I do not think they are realistic any more. However, the PPE-DE clearly demands at least 30%, and I believe that we must appeal to the Commission. I hear that there are discussions in the Commission as to whether we should go beyond 27%. I even hear that the President of the Commission is not in favour. This can't be! Jean-Claude Juncker has promised here in the European Parliament before the election that he is in favour of at least 30%. What was said before the election must also apply after the election!

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: ppe group. Mr President! My speech is about the report and the progress report on renewable energy. I would like to thank López Bermejo for good and constructive cooperation in the negotiations, which have not been easy. There are some clear dividing lines between the political groups on this issue. On the one hand, there is the more realistic wing, which recognises that objectives must be achieved, otherwise they are worth nothing. On the other hand, there are the unrealistic ones who simply want higher targets at all costs and believe that an own-initiative report by the European Parliament will move by the agreed objectives.  I think we should recognise that the Heads of State or Government have set themselves sensible, impactful objectives that they have committed themselves to achieving. I would have liked it higher, but the 27% renewable energy by 2030 is a great commitment and shows our investors that the EU and its Member States have ambitions and will deliver on them. I hope that my colleagues in the European Parliament across political groups will remember this when voting on the matter today.  I would like to stress that the EPP fully supports the diversification of EU energy sources with renewable energy centrally placed to achieve a more sustainable energy mix in Europe and deliver on our agreed objectives. We recognise and support renewable energy as a prerequisite for achieving sustainability, growth, competitiveness and creating more European jobs. In the EPP, we think it is important to find long-term and durable solutions. We are working to ensure that renewable energy works on market conditions and we reduce the cost of renewable energy. This is necessary to bring energy prices down, benefit European businesses and energy consumers. I have noted with satisfaction that a number of the PPE's priorities have been included in the report. This includes respecting member states' competences to determine energy mixes, the need for cost reduction and reasonable market conditions, including the gradual phasing out of State aid to market-mature technologies. There are still a handful of elements in the report and some amendments which are both unrealistic and inappropriate. I hope that we can achieve some good objectives with this report today.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: on the part of the S&D Group.  The current directive is a good basis for achieving our energy and climate objectives, including those ambitious commitments from Paris. However, this will only be achieved if some of its shortcomings are remedied, in my view, in particular by excessive flexibility. As a result, we are lagging behind the targets set and, if nothing changes, we will not be able to achieve energy efficiency by 20 percent by 2020. I believe that MEPs within the ITRE Committee have made it clear that a more effective framework is needed.  I would like to mention at least a few points that I consider important in this report. First and foremost, it is a question of a binding 40% energy efficiency target. I believe that Parliament should repeatedly and clearly support this commitment, because if we make it a discount, we will close the way to higher savings, to promote innovation, and also to strengthen our independence from fossil fuel imports.  Secondly, I would like to mention the issue of energy poverty, which was practically neglected by the original proposal. I am glad that the report is now paying close attention to energy poverty. The report appeals not only to the Commission, but also to the Member States, as both the Commission and the Member States have so far been very distant on this issue. In this sense, we call for the strengthening of Article 7 and also propose that clear targets be set in national energy efficiency action plans.  Finally, I would like to mention an important issue of contradictory legislation. Parliament is currently discussing a revision of the Emissions Trading System (ETS), which is linked to energy efficiency legislation and other legislation and where significant overlaps are currently taking place. Instead of competing with these regulations, there must be some synergy, because there is one common goal behind them all. In this respect, I consider it absolutely essential that the mutual effects are analysed and that the Commission come up with a proposal that will deal effectively with this situation. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), blue card question. Mr President, these days I am really concerned about whether the climate, environmental objectives are identical to those of energy.  (The speaker is interrupted because of a microphone problem) – I am convinced that climate, environmental objectives are identical to energy. We cannot just focus on energy issues and leave the environment out, and because my country these days has suffered an unprecedented ecological, environmental disaster from uncontrolled fires, resulting in the death of human lives of forest firefighters who fell during duty, there must absolutely be... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), blue card question. – How can we, as the European Union, mobilise both the funds and the objectives of the European Union, so that together with the energy objectives we can also implement the environmental and be able to protect our forests and restore them when they are damaged, as was the case with Cyprus at the moment?

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I have talked about this, and I think Commissioner Cañete mentioned it, and investment under the European Investment Fund must also be part of our fight against climate change. It is this binding target of 40% that should help to make more use of renewables. But I don't know what this has to do with the fires in Cyprus.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Today we are voting on two important energy reports. On the one hand, the report on energy efficiency and, on the other hand, the report on renewable energy. While the Member States agree on the objectives to be achieved, we are in danger of causing concern to the European Parliament by setting the bar unrealistically high.  First, it is important that we try to do it with less energy. And there is still a great deal of potential here in the European Union. Almost half of our energy goes to heating and cooling. But this energy is still lost far too often, literally through windows and doors. Moreover, by focusing primarily on energy efficiency, we are ensuring that citizens themselves can reap the benefits of the investments they make in the environmental field.  As far as renewable energy is concerned, we in Parliament should not set targets that are unachievable. Yes, we must be ambitious, but let us also remain realistic. This is not the binding national targets proposed by the rapporteur in the field of renewable energy. It is clear that certain Member States will have to look beyond their own borders in order to achieve their renewable energy targets. And why then advocate binding national targets? Let us work together here above all in Europe.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me start with two energy reports that were published recently. The first one says wind and solar are crushing fossil fuels, and it says that in 2015 energy investments in renewables were twice as much as in fossil fuels. Two huge energy bids in Mexico and Morocco were won by renewable programmes – not because they were renewable, but because they promised the cheapest energy, and that was renewable. The other report says that Europe is losing its reputation as a renewable energy leader, and that is a very, very worrying report. Last year, investments in renewable energy in Europe plummeted by 21%, while spending in the rest of the world boomed. That is what this report is saying and that is extremely worrying. What we are witnessing in the world is a global race for cheap and secure energy, and that is renewable energy. The wonderful side-effect of that global race is that it is also clean. A wonderful side-effect. But the main focus is to get cheap and clean renewable energy. The last thing that we need here is conservatism. We need a much stronger European focus with ambitious, binding targets and I am calling upon the Commission, when it is working on its proposals for September, please come with very strong, ambitious, binding targets. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – Indeed, I believe that a colleague has said very correctly about the need to regulate. But, on the other hand, today we know that the Nord Stream II project is taking place in parallel and, in practice, the farther away, the more it is gaining momentum. And I read today that Mrs Merkel is as if she are in favour of this project. So won't it be like our beautiful dreams will remain only in beautiful protocols? And when the Nord Stream II project comes to Europe, renewable language will be very slight.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, I totally agree with my colleague. I don’t think that Nord Stream is a very smart project to undertake, but what is even more worrying is that progress towards a true European energy union is being slowed down by our Member States. We have 28 energy unions today. We need one energy union – one combined focus on the transition towards cheap, secure and clean energy, and that is the main focus we should have in Europe.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, before I talk about energy, I will say that it is a pleasant surprise to have you here today, in this House, the same House to which lately it is so difficult to make it come; the same house in which the "grand coalition" allows him not to have to explain why his name appears in more and more cases of revolving doors, tax fraud, corruption... A long etcetera to which, unfortunately, the People's Party, its party, has us accustomed.  Next time you come to this House, please do the favor of coming to open accountability and answering the questions of the Groups, because appearing behind closed doors with the revised questions does not dispel any doubts, on the contrary—and this is advice—: it increases them.  Good thing this Sunday, in the Spanish state, we're going to take another step so that people without accounts in Panama and without brothers-in-law in oil companies will finally rule. And why? Because we need action within the framework of really ambitious energy that is up to the climate urgency we face.  Energy efficiency should therefore be a binding priority for all States. That is why, too, we need a Renewables Directive which will create a stable and conducive framework for the development of this energy, contrary to what the Government of my country does with its sun tax, which criminalizes investment, as was reported yesterday in the Committee on Petitions in this House.  We need democratic regeneration as much as an energy transition.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I would like to welcome the first group of the Sakharov Fellowship to us. The Sakharov Fellowship was established by the European Parliament. Fourteen human rights defenders are taking part in this programme and are attending today's plenary session. These fellows come from a wide range of countries, such as Belarus, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Guatemala, Iran, Jordan or Kazakhstan. They follow a two-week intensive course in human rights at the European Parliament in Brussels and at the European Inter-University Centre for Human Rights and Democratisation in Venice. (Applause) This new programme, organised by the Sakharov Network, aims to enhance the skills of people who stand up for human rights. Congratulations to you all! I hope that your time in the European Parliament is a valuable experience.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We are now continuing our joint debate on the report by Paloma Lopez Bermejo (A8-0196/2016) and the report by Markus Pieper (2012/27/EU) (A8-0199/2016).

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I have to say thank you to both rapporteurs for those files. We have had important and difficult discussions regarding the renewable energy progress report and the energy efficiency implementation report. To be honest, in the end, I believe that what we achieved at the level of the ITRE committee is really promising, and I can support the report as it was voted in the ITRE committee. Of course, there are a lot of important issues, and some of them have already been mentioned by the rapporteur, Mr Pieper, and my colleagues as shadows. I agree with them regarding the importance of the full implementation of the existing current legislation, and also better reporting from the Member States, the importance of research and innovation, a consumer-centric approach, and so on. But instead of going through all the relevant issues, I would like to point out only one very important topic: the question of targets. I believe that what has really happened in Europe and what we have achieved in Europe in renewable energy and energy efficiency in the last couple of years has absolutely been the consequence of ambitious binding targets. If we lose this framework from the energy market in Europe for the climate policy in Europe, for energy efficiency and renewable energy in Europe, then anything which is said about our goals regarding renewables, energy efficiency and climate are nothing but wishful thinking. It is not a programme, it is not a European contribution to the global effort, it is just wishful thinking. So, what we need is ambitious binding targets on the EU level for energy efficiency, and also targets on the national level. Without them, we cannot achieve what we have to achieve according to the Paris Agreement.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today I will begin by telling you an unprecedented story in these classrooms. Ten years ago, in Rome, the first group of what later became the 5 Star Movement was given a name: "Utopia and reality". In Italy they were all making fun of us, saying; "you will never make it, without money, without newspapers..."; everything and everyone was against us. Yet in Italy, after only ten years, the same people now tell us: "you were right, hold on, continue, represent hope". The wind of change that, at the time, we bravely proposed now blows hard in our country. Maybe you sensed it too. But we, ladies and gentlemen, do not want to stop at Italy, we want to bring the utopia of change to Europe, to these classrooms, to all the Member States. Energy is today's theme. We want the Eu ropean Union to set binding targets of 40 % for energy efficiency and at least 30 % for renewables, which are translated into specific national targets. We want a chapter on prosumers to be identified, which will no longer leave them at the mercy of the dancing moods of the various governments, identifying a shared definition of the term, the rights of self-handling, self-consumption, storage and sale of excess energy, forms of support, investment and the elimination of the main administrative and market obstacles. We simply want the energy union to really have its citizens at its heart and to allow Europeans to escape forever from the constraints of energy geopolitics. We want to respect the Paris agreements and leave fossil fuels under the ground, which is the only guarantee to prevent climate catastrophe. None of us can predict today's vote and, above all, our future, but we know for a fact that nature is giving us signals: floods, droughts, migration, competition for resources. Technological innovation and social innovation will bring about the necessary changes. Politics and the economy will sooner or later have to bow their heads to change and adapt to the facts. That's a certainty, because that's always been the case. But we do not want, as Europe and as a humanity, to be late. We have to be the flywheel, the human flywheel... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner Caete, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work It is clear, of course, that the previous speaker has a great deal of talk about the outcome in Rome and Italy, but the things we have to discuss today are just as important, namely the two reports before us, which are intended to show the state of implementation in the field of renewable energy and energy efficiency. This level of implementation is quite different. Indeed, if Member States are well on track to meet the 2020 targets in the field of renewables – with a share of 15.3 percent in 2014 – the level of implementation of energy efficiency will be less good. Here we see that 27 out of 28 Member States have an infringement procedure pending, that the level of implementation varies widely between Member States and that the 2020 targets in the area of energy efficiency are unlikely to be met. Against this background, I do not know whether it was a good thing to reduce the flexibility provided for in Article 7. Member States were free to choose their mix of measures in the field of energy efficiency in the past, which is no longer possible to this extent. Exceptions should be quantified, phasing-in and early-action measures should no longer be valid. I also consider it unrealistic to increase the efficiency target to 40 percent. It is better to take this amendment with you and then provide for the corridor. We should not set ourselves unrealistic targets. The fact that Member States are still not being asked to expect the same means and the same data collection procedures is also a weakness. Another point: I also consider the mandatory refurbishment of all public buildings, not just government buildings, to be unrealistic. We should remain realistic, energy efficiency is important, but realism is also important.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, in 1968, even before a small step was taken for man and a big step for humanity, researchers warned the American Petroleum Institute that carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels could lead to global environmental changes. 48 years later and, while science and technology have made strides, appropriate technologies are still not being applied to make the best use of renewable energy sources. We wondered why? The conscious concealment of scientific findings, the cover-up of information and the deliberate misleading of public opinion have imposed the short-sighted policy of temporary profitability of large companies at the expense of corresponding viable choices.  Oil giants and trade groups spend $115 million annually blocking climate policies. At the same time, they are pushing for natural gas to emerge as the key technology by which Europe will economically reduce carbon dioxide emissions, and the European Union is addressing the situation by setting low targets and pursuing moderate policies. We are being criminaled not only against the environment but above all at the expense of our children. Do not allow the political underhand of the centres of economic power and obscene profitability to be made. First, an apology must be made. Essentially support the development and implementation of renewable energy sources and punish those responsible.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Two reports, two directives – a very serious global problem. I congratulate these reports because they are implementation reports. We should have more and more such reports, because we need to know what is going on with the provisions that we are adopting. Climate is a global problem, and that's how you have to look at it. I believe that the european Union's current raising of climate targets and the setting of new binding targets are counterproductive. Why? Because it causes internal tensions between the Member States, between us and we have a great task to do. Namely, we would like the Paris commitments to be implemented worldwide. They do not have an international legal basis today, so they need to be monitored. This should be strongly focused on the Union as a whole. We should not cause internal tensions about our climate targets, which are still the most ambitious in the world. One comment on RES (renewable energy sources). Indeed, there are countries that do not attach sufficient importance to aid to renewable energy, to support and also to pro-consumer energy. This should be made clear, but I think it is probably premature four years before the deadline for achieving our 2020 target to designate specific countries without full justification. On the other hand, I believe that what we are doing in this area is now the most important thing for the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You have analysed at length the issue of the commitment. Indeed, there are the Paris commitments, there are the EU commitments and the national commitments. But wouldn't it be more sensible to turn this rhetoric into not talking about obligations, but about opportunities for innovation?

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "I don't mind saying that. I totally agree with you. I would just like to stress that the European Union today has the most far-reaching objectives in terms of global scale, global, because the problem is global. And the most important thing today is to look at how it is implemented on a global scale. We are sure, I am convinced, we will meet our targets by 2020 and by 2030. We have internal commitments between member states and we stick to that, but globally we know what it was like with the Kyoto Protocol. We were practically alone. The idea is to really try internationally as one body, 28 countries, so that others also keep their Paris commitments.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Norway, one of the world's largest oil and gas countries, has announced a ban on diesel and petrol cars from 2025. Saudi Arabia, which has the world's largest oil resources, is currently executing the world's most ambitious solar energy program. It is not difficult, therefore, to see the direction in which the world is moving forward. We do not need to be fanatical environmentalists to understand why renewable energies are needed in Europe. You don't have to love this, but you have to love the economic growth that is taking place in Europe because of renewable energies. You can love the millions of new jobs that have been created in this industry, and of course you have to love the technological innovation or energy independence that renewable energies bring to Europe.  It is therefore timely to talk about the progress of European renewable energy policies. But since we see, and there has been agreement in this chamber, that we will certainly achieve the 2020 targets, because we are making good progress, it is worth looking back after 2020. That is why we have proposed to maintain mandatory renewable energy targets not only at European level but also at Member State level after 2020, because this is the only one that means predictability for industry, and at the same time the only instrument that has shown that, if any, we will achieve our targets in this area. And the other very important thing is that we need to remove all obstacles to renewable energy investment. There are an astonishing amount of administrative and bureaucratic obstacles in Europe today. Parliament's task is to propose to the Member States the abolition of these bureaucratic obstacles.  Europe must be at the forefront of this change. As oil and gas replaced the former coal world in the 20th century, the world of renewable energy replaced the world of fossil energy and nuclear energy. Europe must be at the forefront of this.

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Mr President, Conservative MEPs support increasing the amount of energy coming from renewable sources. We want to do this in a way that does not unduly burden consumers and businesses and export jobs outside of Europe. Contrary to the Commission’s 2015 renewable energy progress report, I am happy to note that the UK is ahead of our mid-term target and that we remain on track to reach our goal of 30% of electricity from renewable sources by 2020. We recognise the importance of energy efficiency both for reducing dependence on imports as well as for overall consumption. We do not support the rapporteur’s desire to see an increased role for the Commission in monitoring Member States’ action via enhanced oversight. We do not support binding efficiency and renewable targets. These skew investment decisions and are not the best way for Member States to spend taxpayer money effectively. These reports seek to enhance the role of the Commission and the EU, and for those reasons we shall vote against both of them.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Mr President! Energy efficiency can benefit us all. We can reduce dependence on fossil fuels, reduce dependence on imports from Russia and provide cheaper energy for consumers and businesses. However, the report shows that many Member States have not taken the necessary steps. This is not in line with the objectives of the Energy Union and we must show the world, and not least the European Union, that we are united on sustainable solutions and that the European Union must be a leader, both in terms of energy efficiency and renewable energy.  I am pleased that we introduced a point in the report to meet the cop21 targets already agreed, and I think it is important to state that the green transition does not have to hamper either the economy or industry. Just look at big good companies like Danfoss, Vestas, Velux and Grundfos, which are big companies that are all based on green ambitions and on innovation. They bring money to my home country with their large exports and at the same time make energy cheaper for the consumer. And so experience shows that energy efficiency is both economically viable and greener and cheaper for the benefit of all of us.  That is why I look forward to the revision of the directive we are facing, and I hope and will work for some very ambitious and binding objectives for this.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for the very good work she has done. The report rightly ed that the development of renewable energy sources must be recognised as a fundamental pillar of our energy policy. Indeed, if we are honest about the objectives we set for combating climate change, tackling energy poverty and developing a productive energy model for the benefit of society, it is very important to promote an ambitious and realistic integrated renewable energy strategy. This is the only way to achieve the relevant targets we have set for 2020 and 2030. But in order to create an energy model based on identifiable energy sources, it is important to strengthen public investment to promote the necessary infrastructure. It is equally important to promote instruments to support small producers of renewable energy sources as well as measures to ensure that renewables are boosted at the lowest possible cost to consumers. In this process, democratic control and collective management, as rightly called for in the report, are essential elements to ensure better service to the needs and interests of society, so that energy is guaranteed as a social good to which all peoples have equal and cheap access.

name: Claude TURMES
text: – Mr President, I will concentrate on the renewables report, which is a good report apart from one bad sentence in paragraph 9. The question is that wind and solar have become much cheaper and more mature. Does that mean that we can invest in renewable energy without any support? That depends on the markets and the status of the markets. Today we have, because of the failure of EU ETS, very low CO2 prices, which means that we have a huge overcapacity in Europe given that the coal power plants remain in the market. How can wind and solar be invested in if power prices are, in large parts of Europe, at EUR 20-25 per megawatt-hour? And do not forget that as long as we have not made major changes to market design, each time the wind blows and the sun shines wind and solar will cost less than the average power prices. So please vote with the Greens on our split vote on paragraph 9. We cannot make renewable investments without having a revenue stream for renewables in this market.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: "Today, when I refer to the progress report on the use of renewable energy, I should stress that investment in renewable energy is insufficient. Moreover, they have a tendency to decline in recent years. In the fifteenth year, they fell by almost a fifth compared to the 14th.  Support at local, regional, national, European level for these investments is clearly too low. The involvement of all stakeholders involved, including politicians, is insufficient. The renovation volumes should also be significantly higher. And the potential for wind generation in the North Sea or the North Sea region is also poorly exploited.  We will not make any progress in the use of renewable energy if the European Energy Strategy does not, through action, rather than words, essentially establish a unified energy policy and does not speak with one voice.  Gentlemen, what do we want to deceive – whether ourselves or society? When we talk about renewable energy in the morning, and in the afternoon, we are in favour and will go head-to-head for the fossil fuel lobby who have come to protect each other's project? And another note. The cost of energy from renewable sources must not be much more expensive for the final consumer, but cheaper, with part of that price subsidised.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it was as an energy-saving and new energy campaigner that I was appointed, at a very young age, in 1980, for my first post as a civil servant, head of the regional energy department in Alsace. So I'll speak as a technician. We can give ourselves goals, but targets of 20, 30, 40% are useless if there are no means. Both the Commission and the report do not pinpoint the means. What is needed is a proactive policy, indeed, with a public policy, because the market does not see long-term over 10 to 15 years. What is needed is long-term funding. 10% of energy savings on imports represents about, with a 10-year return on investment, 400 billion investments. If you add what needs to be done for new energy or transfer, count 500 billion. You don't give an answer on the means.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – I read the reports, listen to what the Commissioner says, listen to this statement in the Chamber and i am horrified. You are complete dilettletants. The average, any person working in the energy industry has much more knowledge than us. You're guessing complete nonsense! People working in nuclear, fossil or other energy are taking off their skin to do everything as cheaply and as best as possible, because competition forces them to do so. Any interference by politicians can only harm them. What we do harms the energy industry. I will say once again: democratically we can control the meercastic population in congo, perhaps it will succeed, and the paws are down from the energy industry. Such an important area as energy cannot be controlled democratically, because politicians and bureaucrats have no idea how it really works. Thank you for your attention.  More besides, I think that the European Union should be destroyed, because it is doing things that are bad for energy.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Mr President. Commissioner, welcome once again from the many occasions on which you have been able to participate and discuss with us in plenary and also in the Energy and Environment Committees. So it can never be said that you are not an absolutely available person for all the debates that are within your competence. From here, I wanted to conclude that we have had the opportunity for these two debates and this whole process in Parliament — not only today — both in terms of energy efficiency and renewable energy, two key elements in achieving the objectives set out in Paris, and I believe that what substantively needs to be done is to achieve those objectives. We are talking about 20% in terms of renewable energy by 2020 and 30% in energy efficiency. Nothing produces more frustration, nothing causes more disaffection towards representative institutions and political institutions in general than promising the unattainable and not achieving what one has really committed onese. So I'm very pleased that we're actually on that path and that's how we have to go on. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Do you not think the fact that the European Council decided to abandon the binding national targets and set a relatively low target of 27% for 2030 is highly disappointing and is going to jeopardise the European Union’s renewable energy progress, and that this target should have been established at 40% by the Commission?

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Frunzulic, I believe, as I said, is that realistic objectives must be achieved. The 30% target, as proposed, is a much more realistic objective.  The future will say what other goals can be set quite later, but 2020 is near and by 2030 there is still a time to go, and what we have to do is make it a reality to achieve that 30% goal.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: blue-card question. – I completely agree with your ambition to have realistic goals. My problem with this is that we already have a huge amount of renewable energy that we are not transmitting and therefore not using. There is a case in Spain where we have an enormous amount of renewable energy that is not passing over the border of France. Do you not think that the Commission should put much stronger effort into transmitting renewable energy?

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Selimovic, yes, of course, as regards not only renewable energy, but the need for interconnections, the Committee has never really led the need to make such connections. In some cases, for example, that of Spain and that of the Iberian peninsula in general, through the Pyrenees, and in others, then among other countries.  I do not think it can be said that this Commissioner and this Commission are not really at the forefront of developing these interconnections.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, energy efficiency and renewable energies have triggered many positive developments in most Member States. These two components of the Energy Union, renewable energies, together with energy efficiency, are essential elements for reducing the European Union's energy dependency and improving energy security. The establishment of the energy mix must remain a national competence, so that each Member State chooses to develop its own form of renewable energy. In future interim reports on renewable energy, I hope to find an assessment of their impact on costs and prices, in particular prices for household consumers. Transparency in full and detailed data on the breakdown of costs and subsidies for various technologies in the energy sector would provide a more detailed picture of the energy market. I believe that reducing the energy bill for consumers should also be one of the binding targets, and transparency would be a step in that direction. We are also waiting, Commissioner, for the first measures to supply electricity to the first electric cars in the European Union.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Commissioner, welcome! You know that I highly appreciate your work and have personally spoken about these topics. When it comes to renewable energy and low-carbon emissions, there are also cases like Bulgaria. On the one hand, we have long exceeded the percentage of energy from renewable sources, and this has led to an increase in the price of electricity and the decline of a traditional industry – coal mining. However, countries such as those in Eastern Europe are lagging behind in energy efficiency. On the other hand, increasing the percentage of green energy in the mix did not solve the problem of the poorest Member State of the European Union – our energy dependence on Russia. The destruction of the coal industry made Bulgaria even more dependent on Russia. Instead of solid fuel, own production or imports from Ukraine import more gas from just one source.  Even the issue of stopping South Stream didn't solve the problem. Commissioner Canete, you and the European Commission understand our problem perfectly. But how do we strike the balance between protecting the climate and respecting the Political Independence of the European Union from third countries? That's the main question.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I think that the political message of the report is clear. We have targets that ought to be achieved as concerns efficiency and renewables. But who will make it happen? Industry and investors. So I am quite happy that both reports focus on the question of administrative procedures, cutting red tape, and of course having regulatory stability. We need clear rules, we need stability and, in this respect, I would like to emphasise something that maybe has not been emphasised that much so far. Where renewables are concerned, I think I would also refer to the energy market design. I think that what is absolutely clear today is that we need to integrate renewables. On subsidies, I am not a great fan of subsidies as such and I think that where subsidies for energy are concerned that applies twice over. I do understand that in order to give renewables a start, subsidies were necessary. But at the moment I think we should be phasing them out, and definitely with regard to mature technologies. My last remark would apply to EFSI. I think that some of our colleagues have already mentioned this, but if I look at the implementation of EFSI today, the one thing that I am really missing is meeting the goal of financing especially innovative projects, and that of course applies to energy as well. So I think we should have a higher share of EIB-backed investment with high risk.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: – Mr President, achieving the EU's co2 reduction target requires the activity of all energy production and use sectors. Energy efficiency is one of the best ways to reduce CO2 emissions. Energy efficiency must be invested in the construction sector, transport, services and various production methods, not forgetting energy production.  When it comes to renewable energy, it should be stressed that it can also be produced sustainably, small-scale and locally, thus helping Europe on the road to growth. More investment is therefore needed in research and product development of renewable energy alternatives, so that small and medium-sized enterprises can also take advantage of them. The EU's dependence on fossil fuel produced outside must be reduced in every way and subsidies must be targeted at supporting sustainable energy.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Tackling energy and climate issues is one of the most important things we have to do during this parliamentary term.  We must make what we promised each other in Paris, and then we must ensure that subsidies for fossil energy are phased out and instead focus policies on promoting a conversion to 100% renewable energy.  One way of doing this is to strengthen the interconnection between our various energy systems in Europe. We Greens want to remove unnecessary bureaucratic obstacles that prevent this and make major strong investments to achieve our interconnection goals. And we stress that increased regional cooperation can increase the cost-effectiveness of the systems and help ensure that when the sun is not shining in one country, we can use the energy from wind power in another country or the hydropower of a third.  Renewable energy requires a more decentralised system, and we need to do more to create it now.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the (The microphone turns on too late.) .... Unhappy conditions to make it more difficult to manage the economy, in addition to road transport, provide buildings with the crucial opportunity to achieve further energy savings and to achieve efficiency targets. We should therefore encourage architects and builders to rely on traditional building concepts and materials adapted to the region and the climate instead of building glass energy-destroying machines. Instead of regulatory rage – I am thinking with horror of the vacuum cleaner regulation – incentives should be used instead of bans. For centuries, people have learned to live with the adversity of nature and to optimize energy consumption. The knowledge must therefore be used. I think that modern elements should also be incorporated here. For example, facade greening offers a very useful addition, as you can see in America. By the way, ladies and gentlemen, the Union's institutions should also lead by example. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Claude TURMES
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". You are now saying that we have regulatory fury in the case of vacuum cleaners. Vacuum cleaners consume electricity. How can we do anything other than set a standard in Europe for Chinese, European, Turkish – or whoever makes vacuum cleaners? And that's what we do. This is the easiest regulation that can be done, and it is also extremely business-friendly, because it is friendly to the internal market. I understand (the microphone is turned off.)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for the question, which I understood acoustically, but not quite in terms of content. I said that it should not be about the small, detail-loving things in Europe, but about the big things. And if we read through the reports, we know that there are large components here – road traffic, but also buildings – that would bring much more to renovate, which would be better equipped. And I believe that it has been of particular benefit to industry to standardise uniform standards here.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the debate on the production of energy from renewable sources and energy efficiency is a debate that is very passionate and unfortunately often has a strong potential for rhetorical decay. , having said that the environment must be protected, they say that jobs come first. Then we should find a balance, a balance that these two reports are tentatively trying to achieve. But beware of some risks. The first is that Europe has historically achieved excellent levels of sustainability in the context of economic development that can also protect the environment, without the need for the gun pointed at its temple. It did so because it is in our entrepreneurial culture – with the peace of the opponents of liberal culture – to build a model of development around man, certainly with flaws, but this is how our entrepreneurs work. So be careful to place absolute constraints on individual countries, because in Europe we have countries like my own, Italy, which can respect those constraints without problems, but we also have other countries that are trying to make a difficult start. So let us give a reasoning to Europe that is able to talk about true sustainability, that is, held over time by investments. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Colleagues, to be honest, I did not understand whether you support or do not support the objectives of the Commission and the Council, but I ask you very clearly: do you think that we can suddenly stop the production of fossil fuel energy without investing and that we can blow up hundreds of thousands of jobs by lacking modern technologies and without providing resources from the European Fund for Strategic Investments for Modern Technology in Energy Production?

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I believe that the objectives that have been set are correct, but that they are sometimes unrealistic. The subsidies that states normally decide to allocate to the production of energy from renewable sources are normally good, but sometimes lapse. Italy, for example, has been spending six and a half billion euros for years to support photovoltaics. Today that money is a cost to the citizens, to a sector that... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr Salini, the good news is that solar energy today is fully profitable in itself. That's good, so we just have to do that. I think it's good to have these reports. I think it's important to reflect once. We have legislation, and we as a Parliament need to see how we apply it. So I think these are two important reports.  What I want to pay extra attention to today is obvious. Commissioner, we saw each other in Paris, and it is important that in everything we are going to decide in the future on energy efficiency, on renewable energy, on renewable energy – these debates are coming up very quickly – we do one thing and agree on it, which is to fully implement the Paris objectives. That means we have to be ambitious. The whole debate on enforceable energy efficiency standards is becoming extremely important. Because if these standards are not enforceable and remain non-binding, then we cannot fulfil our obligations under the Paris Agreement.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, it has been said that a global energy revolution is under way, with renewable energies taking over the market. I am pleased that investments in solar energy have started and the capacity of solar power has also been doubled in my country, Finland, in 2015. Companies in the sector have also promised a significant increase in capacity in the next few years. A few cities have taken it on board, but companies, energy companies, farms and single-family house residents have also acquired solar power plants. I have given a great deal of thought to whether the slow progress towards renewable energies is due to the olites of the traditional energy market? One might well ask whether policymakers and big energy players have been in too long and too close a relationship with each other? Be that as it may, future energy policy must be done on the terms of the environment, jobs and consumers.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, energy efficiency is about economic efficiency and reducing emissions, not about reducing our economies. I think it is important to remember that, because sometimes in these discussions it sounds as if we think that just by setting a target then we will solve the problem. That is not the case and that belief would undermine our ability to reach our objective. The magnitude of change lies of course in reforming our markets in order to make them open and secure so that we get new generations of technology. I think there are some key issues that we need to think about. First of all, open markets – open for new and renewable energies, but also open for competition, pressing prices, but also securing the best way of using the energy we have. Market prices, because otherwise there will be no opportunity for the new emerging energy sources to be successful. We will need to secure economic growth to invest in new generations of technology, and we need to rely also on nuclear power. But our watchword is, of course, less fossil fuels and less heavy infrastructure investments that make, for example, natural gas cheaper than it really is, especially when it comes from monopolies. So the whole issue, Mr Commissioner, about Nordstream 2 is also part of achieving energy efficiency in the European Union and a functioning energy union.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the debates on energy efficiency and renewable energy remind me of the person who begs God on a daily basis to win the lottery. And God, tired, finally answers him: "But play, at least, if you want me to win you!". That is our problem: we are only making incantations. No one can afford his ambitions anymore. Everyone is hesitant to bet on the ticket that will be a winner for sure. For example, nothing in the Juncker investment plan, and yet these ambitions are noble. They make sense, they have economic interest. It's good for households, it's good for businesses, it's good for jobs. These ambitions are also and above all of interest to the well-being of the planet, because the least polluting and most economical energy is the one that is not consumed.  So, enough austerity, today's investments will be the savings of tomorrow! If we want to win, let's focus on energy efficiency, it's renewable. Bingo!

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, unfortunately there are still politicians who question the negative effects of climate change. What we see today happening in Europe, as climate phenomena, as in the world, shows us that we don't have much time left to decarbonise the world economy. That is why I will support both reports, because they point the right way. On the one hand, the development of renewable energy, on the other hand, energy saving. I would like to tell you that Romania has already met the renewable energy target for 2020. I would also like to point out an important idea: normally, strategies on energy investment should be restructured immediately, in order to stop investment in the development of fossil fuel-based energy capacities and, obviously, to direct investment towards renewable energy, but also towards research—development, especially in the area of electricity storage. Any subsidy for fossil fuels should also be waived.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the focus on renewable energy and energy efficiency are the two pillars of the Energy Union and, at a time when the European Union seems to hesitate between leading the new cycle of globalisation or fragmenting and becoming globally irrelevant, the debate we are having here today has a very high practical and symbolic significance. It is a debate about our ability to value endogenous resources in the strategic field as is energy, a situation that is possible, as the example of Portugal illustrates well. It is essential that we have ambitious targets, in line with the Paris Agreement, to produce more clean and renewable energy, because that means creating wealth, employment, reducing energy dependence on external suppliers. But it is also essential to take on ambitious energy efficiency targets, because it improves the competitiveness of companies, this combats energy poverty in households, reduces emissions and generates opportunities for new investments.  We need to produce more renewable energy, which is used efficiently in the framework of an interconnected and transparent European market.  These are priorities like these that make a difference and give meaning to our claim to a common political and economic area. A space that we have to consolidate...  (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my support for these two reports, in which we are advocating greater ambition in the objectives of the European Union both in the field of renewables and in the field of energy efficiency. In the Bermejo report, we call on the Commission to avoid retroactive changes in renewable support mechanisms and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. This is because in Spain there are thousands of families ruined after investing in renewables, as a result of retroactive measures taken by the Government. Without any compensation, against the expectations generated, against the renewables market, against self-consumption, against legal certainty and against legitimate citizen confidence. We are not talking about speculators or large power companies, but about citizens who trusted institutions that broke their commitments, and we must enforce them. That is why I would like to call on the Commission, Commissioner, and the Council to address the legitimate requests of these citizens.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, quite a few key points from this report on renewable energy. Firstly, subsidies for renewable energy have come to the fore here. They are quite a problem for the entire European energy market at the moment. The energy market is a mess and, in fact, no one is investing in energy now without receiving long-term production aid or a guaranteed price. We should get rid of this now. It is justified that subsidies can be directed at renewable energy research, product development and investment, but if renewable energy is based on receiving ongoing support, it is not sustainable. We see that last year Europe invested the least in renewable energy in nine years and that investment fell by 20%. It shows that we need to have more perseverance and that investors also know which way we are going.  The second question relates to the sustainability criteria that we want to speed up here with regard to biomass. It is important that we manage Europe's forests sustainably, but this must not bring more red tape to forest owners. It is important that we already make use of the certification systems that we currently have.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, my support for the rapporteurs of the two reports because I fully agree with the need to establish stable and cost-effective systems to support renewable energy, to attract investment, and, of course, that it is also appropriate to gradually reduce subsidies for consolidated renewable technologies.  However, support systems cannot depend solely on the will and good management of national governments.  Although the Union as a whole is on track to achieve the 2020 targets, some countries do not do their homework, as is the case with the Government of Spain, the Government of Mr Rajoy, whose results have worsened. A Government that has changed renewable energy support systems up to ten times; which it has done without consultation with the parties, retroactively and, of course, by breaking two fundamental principles of any rule of law: the principle of legal certainty and legitimate expectations in the State.  In addition, it has imposed a tax on the sun, taking into account that Brussels has had more photovoltaic power capacity in 2015 than Spain as a whole. Do you think...? (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, increasing energy efficiency and renewable energy sources is a social and ecological priority. However, the achievement of the objectives in these areas must not conflict with the basic needs of citizens. In Greece of memoranda and austerity, energy poverty affects 36% of the population. Unfortunately, however, despite the fact that Greek GDP per capita has slumped below 60% of the European average, the country has not been relieved of the obligations arising from the emissions trading scheme.  In addition, both reports recognise the need to support ecological energy solutions. Especially the plundered Greek economy needs resources to make the necessary investments in the field of GDP. But Greece has been excluded from the fund to support modernisation of energy systems and improvement of energy efficiency. That is why I have tabled amendments to Regulation 2003/87/EC and I call on colleagues to support them.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the two reports we are debating this morning show that it is also urgent to end the fragmentation of the energy market in Europe and that it is essential to have a stable and well-known regulatory framework in order to encourage the investments with which the essential change in the energy model must be pushed. We share the objectives of both reports, which are reflected in the Plan and the objectives of Basque energy policy for the next decade. Progressive decarbonisation, improving energy efficiency, promoting decentralized generation and self-generation, and consolidating European technological leadership in renewable energy production is essential to be able to comply with the Paris Summit agreements and combat energy poverty. In this context, we strongly call on the Commission, Commissioner, to remedy the damage caused in Spain to more than 65 000 families, who are victims of a retroactive decision on renewable support programmes in that Member State, which undermines this European objective, as those affected have denounced this week before the Committee on Petitions of this Parliament. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, what the Commission intends to do.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 5-Star Movement considers it essential to achieve a rapid abandonment of dependence on fossil fuels in order to facilitate widespread self-production and energy self-sufficiency based precisely on renewables. The European Union's commitment to reducing CO2 emissions, but also the urgent need to take action to drastically reduce the level of pollutants, such as heavy metals and dioxins in air, water and soil, should oblige all States to implement effective measures in good time. Our health and our environment are at the heart of our health, but our financial resources are also at risk, given the health and social costs of an environment devastated precisely by dependence on fossil sources such as oil, coal and gas. In order to ensure that the transition is rapid, a great effort is needed, which can be supported by research, innovation and the effective and effective use of all available European funds, in order to increase energy efficiency and the production of energy from renewable sources. An effort that should in no way be held back, as we have unfortunately seen in countries such as my own, by so-called structural reforms that in fact result in policies of ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, having attended COP 21 on behalf of Parliament, I am very pleased with the way matters are progressing and indeed with the leadership shown, in particular by Commissioner Arias Cañete since he took office. I think we are moving in a very practical and sensible manner and at the same time – as Mr Marias mentioned a few minutes ago – we can do so in an environmentally friendly way, meet our targets and, at the same time, not damage our economy. Yesterday I had a meeting with our own new minister, Minister Naughten. I think he has a very firm grasp of what we need to do in Ireland, and I am quite sure the same applies to all other Member States. On Tuesday night here I was at a meeting where we were discussing decarbonising the transport sector, so the market signals are quite clear. I think the industry is moving in the right direction and therefore what we have to do is to guide them along, make sure the targets are set, that there is no escape for anybody, and we can meet the COP 21 targets which we set out to do. I think the Commission is moving in the right direction and I support it in that.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
