text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current combination of binding national targets, national action plans for renewable energy and biennial control has been the driving force behind the development of renewable energy capacity in the Member States. However, the Commission should ensure the full implementation of the 2020 renewable energy targets and should present an ambitious regulatory framework for the next period. In this respect, we need a stable long-term regulatory framework, including renewable energy targets at national and EU level. The production of electricity from renewable sources should be integrated into distribution systems. Unfortunately, in many Member States, networks are simply unsuitable for receiving electricity generated from variable renewable sources. Modernisation of energy networks is therefore essential. It is therefore essential to achieve our energy efficiency targets by abandoning fossil energy sources and gradually eliminating subsidies for these fuels.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Members and rapporteurs, I think we must realise that in Paris we achieved an historic success, but we have a very ambitious commitment, which is to fight global warming to keep the global temperature increase to well below 2 degrees and pursue efforts towards 1.5 degrees, which is a major challenge. In order to achieve that challenge we do not have so many tools. We have to produce energy in another, different way, and that is renewables, and we have to consume less energy and that is energy efficiency. Those policies work together, and we have to the deliver new policies. In the past, we had regulations in cars, we have many targets, in the past we had national binding targets. The October 2014 Council decided other things on global targets, binding targets in renewables, but at European Union level, non-binding targets in energy efficiency – so now we have to take our responsibilities and deliver the legislation to achieve our Paris objective. For that, we have work in all the areas simultaneously, and Mr Turmes was right: the first thing we must set right is a market design for electricity which is fit for renewables because the current market does not give price signals, it is not fit for renewables, there are not enough interconnections so we must first of all have a new market design which is fit for renewables. Then we have to deliver a renewables legislation which is ambitious and with all the incentives for Member States to go for renewables, with all the innovation support under Horizon 2020 in order to set programmes for the European Union to deliver new technologies and higher performance. 60% of the package of renewables are made in the European Union. We have to have that leadership in technology in the future also, and we have to have ambitious governance to deliver our objectives. In energy efficiency, directives are the most difficult to implement. It is the area in which more infringements are launched in the Commission because the first thing the Commission is doing is enforcing the current legislation to make sure we achieve our 2020 targets. In renewables, we are achieving our targets. Many countries are in their trajectory. It is true that some countries will have to make additional efforts, but we are on track for 2020. For 2030, we have to make many additional efforts with a more difficult framework because we do not have national targets which are binding. So we will have a major challenge, and I appreciate all the support of this Parliament because the debate has been extremely constructive and the members of the Parliament are asking the Commission to deliver ambitious initiatives. The Commission will work on that pattern and I am pretty sure there will be scope for very good cooperation amongst us. Some Spanish Members have addressed the issue of the remuneration regime for renewables. The Commission's purpose is to design a more market-oriented renewables remuneration regime, an electricity market that sees favourable price signals for renewables; access to renewable energy production and distributed production and self-consumption to networks with good harmonised regulation; approaches to more market-oriented remuneration systems. And, therefore, we will work on regimes that are predictable, signal to investors and ensure legal certainty.  I must say that in the current system, Member States have a wide freedom to decide how they support renewables, provided that they meet the objective set out in the Directive. The Commission is currently finally completing its analysis of the reform of the remuneration regime for renewables in the case of Spain and will undertake a dialogue with the Spanish authorities if it identifies a breach of European law.  In this analysis, the Commission is also taking into account the recent rulings of the Spanish Supreme and Constitutional Courts, which have endorsed the decisions taken in turn by the Government.  With regard to State aid, the Spanish authorities have informed the Directorate-General of Competition of both the old and the new remuneration regime for renewables. The Commission has a legal obligation to examine whether they are compatible with internal market rules, and the Directorate-General for Competition is currently at that stage of compatibility analysis.  As regards Mr Benito's speech, I must state — and Mrs del Castillo said this — that I have always been willing to appear before the House, before the committees, as long as I have been invited; and it is true that the Committee on Legal Affairs of this Parliament invited me on 12 July and I will be happy to appear before it.  In my arraignment I will have the opportunity to demonstrate that innuendos and affirmations which Mr. Benedict does towards me are unfounded; and I can assure Mr Benito that, in all the public positions I have held, I have always acted with full dedication, with complete transparency, with respect for legality, with integrity, independently, always defending the public interest and, now, the European interest, developing an ambitious climate policy with a sustainable energy policy.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I am once again grateful for the tone of the debate and the contributions of my colleagues. I want to expand one of the points of my initial speech. The issue of the development of renewable energy is also a matter of energy sovereignty. Europe cannot assume a growing bill for its energy imports and expose the Globe's fossil resources. On the contrary, it must improve energy efficiency and savings and promote energy production on the continent itself. In these circumstances, conventional European fossils play a supporting role in the energy transition, but it must undoubtedly pivot on the development of renewable energy. It is also a challenge that is also essential to face for reasons of ecological sustainability, and at this point and these problems, well reflected in today's debate, we are trying to respond in this report. Commissioner, I disagree with your optimism that by 2020 some countries will be able to achieve the stated objectives and the objectives set. And by 2030 we will not give up anything fixed by the European Parliament. Among other things, because this House is sovereign with regard to the Council. First of all, we have tried to give coherence to Parliament's past requests on the development of renewables with the reality of the Member States. But what we cannot tolerate is, under any circumstances, less ambition than has been demonstrated so far. The current Renewables Directive must be implemented in its entirety, and by 2030 we need more ambitious targets than those set by the Commission and the Council. In addition, mechanisms that have proven their efficiency to facilitate investment in renewables and their preferential market entry, as well as greater energy democracy in the self-consumption of public investment, should be promoted. This must be the message that comes out of Parliament today.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thanks also to my colleagues for the very interesting contributions. We all want more energy efficiency. Some by increasing the need for savings, the others by preserving the flexible approach of the directive. Today, the vote is taking place in The United Kingdom, and we know what the people of Brussels like least: this is a European patronage bureaucracy. If a 40 percent ban on the consumption of energy comes through, everyone will notice this not only through rising rents, because the apartments for the socially weak are then energetically really luxury. No, please explain to me how we are to bring about the change to electromobility: we will soon need a gigantic amount of electricity for this, and most of this electricity will soon come from renewable energies – as Mr Caéete has mentioned, the importance of the expansion. But we are now saying: energy saving also for energies that do not pollute the climate at all. That does not go into my mind as to how one can be for such a line, and where should the additional electricity needed in huge quantities come from, for example in Denmark, Sweden, if they want to switch to electromobility? Yes, from the socket, the Greens are familiar with that, And I know that. But I have to make it so clear: anyone who is in favour of a 40% energy ban is against innovation, against growth, is going to the glue of the critics of globalisation. That is why I still hope for appropriate majorities, for a flexible target corridor. Let's invest in energy efficiency, with fun on the project and not prescribed by coercion!

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – With the Paris climate agreement, we have all set the decarbonisation of our economies on track. Energy efficiency is one of the pillars of this ambition. It makes Europe more competitive, less dependent on energy imports, creates jobs and protects the environment. Especially our houses and buildings can improve. Isolating and efficient lighting creates jobs and means that we have to pay less for energy. We must therefore encourage massive investment in insulation and energy efficiency. The government must fully promote this trend through fiscal measures, through wider access to renovation loans and through the use of energy-efficient services. But we also need to make big strides in the transport sector. For example, by introducing CO2 standards for trucks, we can achieve huge savings. The US and Japan have already done this to us. The EU must take the lead in this, otherwise we will lose our frontrunner position. By being ambitious in terms of renewable energy and energy efficiency, we can give European industry more breathing space to meet the CO2 reduction targets. We save the most efficient companies in the EU with additional climate costs and give them the space to fully commit to clean technology.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – I believe that one way to achieve this is also to exploit new European energy sources. So, if the EU really means that it has the political will and determination to become energy self-sufficient in the future and at the same time to reduce both energy dependencies and energy costs, it has only one way to go in a way that is consistent and consistent: to make use of and develop European Energy Sources as a matter of priority.  Cyprus and possibly other European countries currently have energy sources and an energy perspective. The EU must support not only in theory but in practice with energy infrastructure and investments Cyprus and the Eastern Mediterranean. This will primarily benefit the EU, European citizens and European designs. The promotion of competitive alternative forms of energy and the exploitation of Renewable Energy Sources, focusing on the comparative advantages of countries with increased sunshine, air, biofuels, etc. are an effective move with multiple benefits for both energy and the environment. In today's circumstances, certain forms of RES are now offered at low and competitive prices and can reach the ordinary citizen by also combating energy poverty.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – Renewable energy sources are a response to climate change. At the same time, their development will reduce the dependence of the European economy on the energy sources of third countries, thus creating jobs in the European market struggling to recover from the economic crisis. The coming years will be particularly crucial in terms of achieving the binding target of 20% on final energy consumption by 2020, as set out in Directive 2009/28/EC, but also the corresponding 27% by 2030. Individual countries are far from achieving their individual objective, and there are also large differences between the areas of activity. Thus, in the electricity sector the target for the use of renewable energy sources seems to be achieved, but in the heating-cooling and transport sectors delays are highlighted which make it doubtful that the targets will be met by 2020.  In order to meet the challenges of the future, with respect for the environment and a human-centred approach, coordinated policies and increased support systems are needed to make certain renewable energy technologies competitive. It is essential to try to further develop and use renewable energy sources, as well as an integrated design that addresses the issue of energy poverty, in order to meet international commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted against this report because, unfortunately, the compromise reached with targets of energy savings of 30-40% could not be achieved. Strict regulations from the EU are not always the right way forward. Binding energy savings of 40%, as the Greens and Socialists demand, are damaging growth and innovation in Europe. As a former mayor, the new regulations, such as .B. the renovation rate, were also a problem for me, because they are an imposition on municipalities.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – I fully support the inclusion of the issue of energy poverty in the Directive. Especially in countries like Bulgaria, this is a major infrastructure issue. At the same time, there are recommended targets, i.e. the 40% target for renewable sourcing, etc. We need to improve infrastructures in terms of heating, electricity, etc., as is the case in my Member State, for example, in order to be able to achieve the pre-defined objectives.  While it is important to provide guidance and push for change, we need better regional cooperation and support for struggling regions through better and more targeted use of European investment funds and a more differentiated approach in general. Energy efficiency and strategic policy orientation go hand in hand. While some projects, such as Nord Stream, are constantly under discussion, other projects have been abandoned entirely, such as South Stream. Eastern European countries will benefit greatly from such projects and improve the situation as a whole, not only in terms of dependence on fossil fuels, but also in terms of infrastructure and diversification.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – Increasing energy efficiency is a huge issue, particularly for countries such as Portugal, with a huge energy deficit and significant dependence on the outside world. But this issue cannot be addressed in a fruitful way, in all its size and complexity, within the strict and reducing framework of the so-called Energy Union and the liberalising and deregulatory vision that governs it. A certain recent positive development in relation to the slowdown in greenhouse gas emissions results more from the economic crisis than necessary – but still to be achieved – the transition of the energy paradigm. We diverge from market approaches and denounce their perversities. The framework for liberalization and privatisation of the energy sector has brought with it high energy prices for average industrial consumers and households, to sustain the profits of private monopolies and oligopolies in the sector, compromising the investments needed to increase energy efficiency. We therefore stress the need for public and democratic control of the energy sector, which means its public ownership and management, as an indispensable means of achieving desired and proclaimed economic, social and environmental objectives.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "As it turns out, the optimal solution for wind power plants is their flexible cooperation with highly efficient gas turbines (not to be confused with gas boilers). This association at the macro-scale, i.e. for large energy networks, may soon be the basis for the creation of the most forward-looking and efficient electricity production systems in the world. This solution requires more gas supply to the EU market, and although it significantly reduces CO2 emissions, it does not eliminate it. Unfortunately, clean technology, which is associated with the accumulation of a large amount of electricity, is still inef effective. A certain alternative to large networks is small, pro-consumer installations, working mainly for local needs. On the other hand, progress towards better use of renewable sources in autonomous heating and cooling systems is insufficient. More intensive development of daily heat storage techniques and appropriate structures is needed, as well as free cooling installations that would be available on the market. The potential of geothermal energy and heat pumps is huge, but I think it is underutilised and requires more research to reduce the cost of these technologies. It requires consumer access to the market for relevant equipment and apparatus.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – Energy and energy sources are important themes. Obviously, we have to take into account how we use our natural energy sources and how decarbonisation takes place. I am pleased that my country, Romania, has achieved its 2020 targets, being in the top 3 of the countries in terms of the percentage of green energy in total energy. Unfortunately, the Commission did not take into account the reality of each country and tried to suspend national powers on the energy mix. The solution is not to eliminate energy sources, but to invest in modern technologies, in research, to increase the safety of these energy sources and for decarbonisation. The EFSI and the Structural Funds in the field of energy, transport and energy efficiency have not been used optimally. We must not forget consumers, who have unfortunately taken over the costs of green energy and need to rethink the subsidy system for energy producers. Renewable energy needs to go hand in hand with energy efficiency, leading to lower consumption and lower costs for consumers.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Between 1990 and 2014, the European Union's GDP increased by 46%, while greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23%. Businesses and individual users are increasingly under-burdened with economic growth, with EU directives aimed at improving energy efficiency, reducing CO2 emissions and supporting renewable energy production. It is to be welcomed that the Commission is making further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level, and to set even more ambitious targets. Although the report contains many important and useful proposals, the mandatory 40% energy efficiency savings target for 2030 imposes excessive and difficult burdens on Member States. I cannot support the unrealistic objective of an otherwise good report, which affects the sovereignty of the Member States to such an extent.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Who of us, having a treasure in the house that allows us to live long, would agree to bury it and take credit for life? This is what the ITRE Committee proposes to us in the report. The green revolution is for my homeland, for Polish, the exclusion of coal and the transition to renewable energy sources. Thus, debt is being pumped into technologies that have not yet confirmed their effectiveness. That is why I will vote against it. Just as I am against the whole energy and climate package and the green revolution served by the EU bureaucracy. 85% of Polish energy is produced from coal. No one should impose change on us. It is our decision and only ours, as a sovereign country. 50 years ago, this Union was a union of coal and steel. Today, europe produces almost no steel, and the Member States want to be punished for coal. There is no permission for this.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I want to stress the importance of renewables as a clear future for EU energy independence. The cost of producing energy from renewable sources is still too high and only continuous long-term investments are a prerequisite for achieving the goals set very ambitiously. I draw attention again to the potential that Southeast Europe has in hydropower and biomass. We need to include in all our plans and this part of Europe that can significantly contribute to creating an efficient energy mix in the Single European Energy Market.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% between 1990 and 2014. At the same time, EU GDP grew by 46%. With less and less climate burden, businesses and citizens are achieving greater economic growth, creating more jobs and generating tax revenues. The European Union is on track to meet its 2020 targets of 20% less CO2 emissions. This proves that there is no need to drastically sharpen climate policy, which proves to be an obstacle to the reindustrialisation of the EU. It is therefore worth recalling that the EU assumed that by 2020 the industry's share of EU GDP should be 20%. Bureaucratic energy reporting and high energy prices for medium-sized enterprises and private households are of concern.  The Energy Efficiency Directive should play a key role in EU energy policy. It should be noted, however, that the European Union has achieved its 20% efficiency target by 2020, even without fully implementing the Directive in most Member States. This demonstrates the strength of the market and the ability to shape an independent energy policy on the part of the Member States. The European Union should therefore not be tempted to promote climate and energy policy without reflection at the expense of industrial policy.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. – The Energy Efficiency Directive is based on an interesting theory. On the one hand, it assumes that, regardless of the costs incurred and the local climate, it is worthwhile for everyone across the EU to implement the maximum possible energy efficiency measures at all times. It is not known why the whole report is based on the thesis "the free market is the best solution to all problems". In several places, this claim is "softened" by social considerations. A significant part of the proposal deals with improving reporting and promoting technical progress. On some points, however, there are very few realistic claims that assume virtually zero energy demands on all buildings in the relatively near future. A very weak point in the whole text is the assumption of possible elimination of CO2 emissions even for a substantial part of industrial production. Which is theoretically possible, but virtually unrealistic in today's knowledge of the best technologies. Despite these reservations, the report contains a number of interesting initiatives that can make a significant contribution to energy savings. This combination of unrealistic objectives in the relatively short term, market fundamentalism and social elements, together with unrealistic expectations of rapid technical progress, are the reason why I cannot unequivocally support or reject the proposals under assessment.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The coherence between the ETS and energy policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions needs to be strengthened in order to really contribute to improving energy efficiency. The European Fund for Strategic Investments under the EU Investment Plan is an instrument that can make an important short-term contribution to energy efficiency investments, and which could have significant effects on the internal energy market. The Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund must be used to stimulate investment in energy efficiency, in the development of sustainable low-carbon energy technologies. Investments must be fully integrated into national energy efficiency strategies. Renewable energy production must, however, be linked to the need to ensure continuity of conventional energy production as a prerequisite for sustainability. The Modernisation Fund, recently proposed by the Commission, is another tool that will be able to be used to modernise energy systems and improve energy efficiency in low-income EU Member States. It is important that this future fund has an appropriate governance structure to increase its effectiveness according to the specific characteristics of each Member State.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Writing. – A sustainable energy policy should focus on economic and safe energy production that combines security of supply and climate protection. Conventional energy sources remain an important component in ensuring security of supply. Energy savings, increased energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy should be the main pillars of a sustainable energy policy. Our aim must be to ensure a reliable, environmentally friendly and competitive energy supply throughout the European Union. This is an important prerequisite for growth and prosperity. Only with a sustainable energy supply can jobs be safeguarded and the challenges of our time can be met. The expansion of wind energy, especially offshore wind energy, plays a central role in this process. In order to enable the necessary billions of investments in this future technology, more money must be invested in coastal regions. This could create thousands of jobs. The expansion of renewable energies also requires the expansion of the distribution and transmission network as well as the improvement of the framework conditions for energy storage.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Energy is the source of development. Europe needs a policy designed to ensure energy efficiency, sustainability of production and protection of disadvantaged consumers. In order to do that, we need first of all to make sure that we invest in the latest technologies that are capable of raising energy efficiency while taking care of our development needs. Furthermore we need to develop a pan-European energy production and distribution plan that takes care of the particularities of each Member State and region while at the same time focusing on job creation, training for new skills and the need to ensure energy independence for Europe.  Therefore the energy sector needs an organised investment plan that ensures the modernisation of the industry allowing prices to be kept low for consumers. The modernisation of the industry needs to be inclusive in integrating all the needs of the stakeholders and the Member States.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. - In 2014, the EU spent EUR 358 billion on energy imports. This is almost EUR 1 billion per day, more than Greece's total deficit (EUR 317 billion) and almost as much as the total turnover of the German automotive industry (EUR 367.9 billion) in 2014. We are aware that European retail electricity prices for small and medium-sized industrial and trade customers and private consumers are high in many Member States. We also know that high energy prices in the EU cause differences in energy prices between Member States and our main competitors in many parts of the world, which represents a significant competitive disadvantage. No one disputes that increasing energy efficiency and energy savings are important factors for protecting the environment and climate, strengthening economic competitiveness, creating jobs and a secure energy supply. Yet not much has changed since I was shadow rapporteur on the Energy Efficiency Directive in 2011. For example, I have personally advocated a provision in Article 7 under which Member States may request that a certain part of energy efficiency improvement measures be implemented as a matter of priority in households affected by energy poverty or in the area of social housing. Unfortunately, only two Member States from the 28th ED200 have made use of this option so far. More needs to be done.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – In the face of the challenge of decarbonisation and the Climate Agreements, no country can be allowed to go back on the path of implementing renewable energy. As the presence of renewable energy increases globally, in countries such as Spain it is 4% per year. The Spanish government has torpedoed any investment in renewable energy, with retroactive legislation, which ruined investors, SMEs and Spanish industry in the sector. It is against the promotion of renewable energies to penalize self-consumption, imposing the tax on the Sun or prohibiting collective self-consumption as is also the case in Spain. Action against renewables acts against energy independence and security and the fight to prevent climate change. On the other hand, the renewables sector is a technological sector with skilled workers. In Spain its attack has resulted in the loss of more than 80,000 jobs, and this when job opportunities in this sector are increased in the rest of the world. Part of the blame for this setback is uns ambitious targets, so it should be reviewed by the new targets to achieve 40% introduction of renewables in Europe by 2030.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – The European Union takes the right position that energy efficiency improvements and the use of renewable energy must go in parallel, because in today's world it is impossible without each other. This understanding is demonstrated by the EU, both at global level, when it has actively supported the ambitious Paris Climate Change Agreement and in its legislation by strengthening its commitment to reducing consumption and making it 'more environmentally friendly'.  In practice, however, the situation is more complex because the Energy Efficiency Directive, which is expected to reach the 20% efficiency barrier by 2020, is still not fully implemented in many Member States and is unlikely to achieve the target. Therefore, the proposals in the report that the updated directive should raise the 40% efficiency target for 2030 are ahead of reality and can only remain 'paper'. We must take into account the current situation, because the energy efficiency target cannot turn into an end in itself– we must maintain the EU's competitiveness on the global market.  The development of renewable energy sources is necessary and it is important that the EU set ambitious targets. I am pleased that the report on the evaluation of progress in this area included important proposals from the EPP Group, in particular as regards the diversification of energy resources and the preservation of states' competences to choose the most appropriate palette of energy resources used for it.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – The transport sector contributes significantly to high energy and fuel consumption. It is even the only sector in the European Union where greenhouse gas emissions have increased since 1990. However, the measures taken must be sustainable in the long term and should not create other undesirable phenomena – for example, the negative impact of the promotion of biofuels on food production is notorious. Much more attention must be paid to the overall coordination and planning of logistics and their real sustainability. I therefore supported this report, which also calls for a more comprehensive approach to improving the energy efficiency of the entire transport system.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – The European Union's energy model requires a new approach. We can avoid serious environmental consequences if there is regulation and democratic participation.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Increasing energy efficiency is a key factor for protecting the environment, strengthening economic competitiveness, and combating energy poverty. In the case of renewable energy, which is currently cheaper than some conventional energy sources, we are talking about new jobs, growth and the development of technology. If we manage to increase energy efficiency, we will also be able to reduce our dependence on expensive energy imports and contribute to the protection of the environment. This measure provides for supply flexibility and sustainability, which would bring additional benefits to the European Union, in particular in construction and transport. In this respect, I believe that EU states need to make more effort in the full implementation of the 2020 climate and energy framework strategy, which provides for reducing CO2 emissions, increasing the share of renewable energy sources, and increasing energy efficiency. At the same time, it is clear that, in the context that energy poverty is currently affecting more than 50 million European citizens, the implementation of the legislation must also take into account the needs of this segment. I hope that Romania too will be able to participate in this joint effort and achieve the objectives set out by the Commission.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The development of renewable energies requires a new approach that would make them the cornerstone of the European Union's energy model. Our fundamental responsibility is to combat climate change, a historic task that we must carry out. We must also reduce our dependence on energy resources from the rest of the world if we aspire to structure our production model, create quality jobs and spearhead the development of the strategic technologies underlying our energy transition.  The transition to a sustainable long-term energy production model is a social priority that cannot be left to the market alone. On the contrary, we must understand that regulation and democratic participation are essential if serious social and environmental externalities are to be avoided. We must prevent energy oligopolies from dictating Europe's energy future.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. –  We should not increase our dependency on Russian gas by doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline. Doing so would be extremely detrimental to our energy security since Russia has demonstrated on countless occasions that it is not a reliable partner to the European Union, and that it does not hesitate in wielding energy as a political weapon.  Furthermore, Russia has a long history of not abiding by rules or by what has been agreed upon. The latest example of this kind of behaviour is state-sponsored doping that has led to the disqualification of the entire Russian track and field team from the Rio Olympics. On several previous occasions, Russia has demonstrated that it does not hesitate to infringe upon international law, or the territorial integrity of its neighbours, which is exactly why we cannot rely on Russia or naively believe that things have changed, at least under the current regime. We should be creating more effective energy interconnections within the EU, as well as diversifying our sources.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union has set a target of achieving a 20% share of renewable energy for total energy consumption by 2020. I believe that those countries that have not yet achieved europe's target should fully focus on the complete introduction of the recommended EU rules in order to achieve the desired results. The priority is to attract investors to the renewable energy market. Moreover, foreign and national companies and regional authorities of individual countries must be encouraged to make use of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I believe that the market should have an easily accessible support system for producers of renewable fuels, as this will maximise the benefits. It is essential to strengthen consumer market share. They should have greater opportunities for self-generation and use of energy. The transition from oligopolistic to more democratic policy will be a more beneficial change, as market integration will increase, which will result in the development of renewable energy and cost reduction.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Today we have the great honour of welcoming President Mahmoud Abbas to our house. Mr Abbas, I would like to thank you once again for following the invitation of the European Parliament today. I warmly welcome you to the European Parliament! (Applause) Good relations with Palestine are of great importance to us in the European Union. The EU is Palestine's main partner in financial, economic and humanitarian cooperation. But a stable and functioning Palestine is also a moral task for all of us. Mr President Abbas, I would like to thank President Abbas for his You have dedicated your life to a mission: the non-violent commitment to freedom and the recognition of Palestine. You were one of the architects of the Madrid Peace Conference and the Oslo Accords, which are still a milestone in the Middle East peace process. Your presence today, Mr President, is a strong signal in this House yesterday, following the speech by the President of Israel, Reuven Rivlin, that the will for a sustainable peace between Israel and Palestine remains alive. In this context, I also appreciate the tireless work of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and Vice-President of the Commission, Federica Mogherini, who is with us this morning, as he did yesterday. Welcome to you, Mrs Mogherini! (Applause) In September 2015, the European Parliament voted in favour of a two-state solution based on the 1967 borders with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this two-state solution, a state of Israel that lives in safety – as I emphasised here yesterday – and an independent, democratic, cohesive and living and viable state of Palestine – I would like to emphasise this today – should live peacefully and safely side by side. To guarantee this, there must first be an end to the violence. No political objective justifies blind hatred, hatred or even terrorism. This is not the first time that the European Parliament has condemned the continued expansion of Israeli settlements and the rocket fire of Israeli areas by militant groups. In its resolutions, it called for an end to the blockade of the Gaza Strip and for reconciliation among the Palestinians. Mr President Abbas, I would like to thank President Abbas for his excellent work on this It is precisely this reconciliation – the willingness to forgive and empathize with both the Palestinians and the Palestinians and the Israelis – that is an elementary part of the peace process that you are advocating. Once again, on behalf of all my fellow Members of the European Parliament, I warmly welcome you and I am happy to give you the floor. Please very much, Mr President. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: President of the Palestinian National Authority. (The following is a transcription of the interpretation of the original speech from Arabic into English.)  – Mr President, in the name of Allah, the most merciful, may I first of all thank you for this invitation to address you in your Assembly.  First of all, let me express my admiration for the democratic model you have constructed, the diversity of cultures and languages and different governments. For us, this is a mirror which reflects great civilisation, great culture and reflects the human principles represented by your European peoples.  I would like to express our respect for you and our thanks to you for the positions you have taken up which honour you. You have taken up positions which militate in favour of the restoration of justice and peace in my country, Palestine. For my people, I would like to convey their greetings, and I would like to take advantage of this opportunity to give you a number of pointers for you to think about in your various committees in this Parliament, so that you have some guidelines in thinking about our situation as we seek peace in our part of the world.  I would also like to thank you all for all the different kinds of aid you have given, aiding us in institution-building and helping us establish the bases for a democratic regime which will be stable in the future and which will be able to comply with international criteria for democracy, and in particular we want to establish a proper rule of law and proper respect for human rights.  So once again, our thanks to this Parliament for the recognition you have given our country. Thank you so much for recognising the State of Palestine. I would also like to thank all the national parliaments which, for their part, have recommended to their governments that they should recognise the State of Palestine.  I would also say this. When talking about a two-state solution, if you believe in a two-state solution you have to recognise both states and not just one of them. A hundred years have passed since the Balfour Declaration back in 1917. Sixty-eight years have passed since al-Nakbah, the catastrophe which we suffered when in 1948 the Israeli forces were guilty of slaughter and massacre in our part world, and this led to hundreds of thousands of our citizens having to migrate. This turned these hundreds of thousands of people into refugees. More than 485 of our villages were simply flattened, villages where our people were living peacefully and had lived peacefully for thousands of years. In 1967, Israel occupied East Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza and once again, thousands of our people were forced to migrate from Gaza and from the West Bank. So the least you can say when looking at Palestine is this: Palestine as a country, and as a people, we have a history, an identity. We are a country, we are a geopolitical entity and this country has suffered a series of historic massacres. We have suffered unprecedented occupation, the sort of occupation of a country we have not seen elsewhere in the world in the 20th century or in the 21st century. And all this in full view of the international community and in full view of the international authorities.  We have been through so many black periods throughout history, and we are still going through a black period. Our Palestinian people are suffering from occupation, from suppression. We are suffering from arbitrary action by the Israelis. We are suffering from racism, hateful racism, and our people are living abroad as refugees. They are living in poverty, in a very precarious situation.  Now we have decided to resist. We have decided to remain in our country, on our land. We have decided to continue our efforts to put an end to Israeli occupation by using political, diplomatic and peaceful means. We have been successful in these efforts at international level, but we are not making progress in terms of our relations with Israel.  We have used every effort in order to implement the agreements which have been signed. We have complied with our commitments, and we are calling on the Israelis to comply with their commitments, but the Israelis refuse to respect these commitments and continue to oppress us and to dominate us in every area of life.  The Israelis are trying to change the situation in the City of Jerusalem. They are trying to change its historic identity. They are infringing holy places – Christian and Islamic and Muslim. They are continuing to build their colonies by confiscating our territory, by flattening our houses. Israel is still imprisoning thousands of our people.  Today, Israel is still a violent state. Every day we see cases of extreme violence for which the Israelis are guilty. We have seen the colonists have burned down houses only recently in which people were living. In particular, a young man died in the latest attack from the Israelis when his house was burnt down. Every day we see murders, extra-judicial killings. And this Israeli attitude, this Israeli behaviour is such that some Israeli politicians have started criticising their own government, for example, Mr Herzog, leader of the opposition, or Ya’alon, a former Army leader, and Ehud Barak, and a former head of the armed forces, and journalists. All these people – Israelis – announcing that the Israeli Government’s behaviour is fascist and racist, and I am quoting them there.  Resolution 181 of the United Nations divided the historic territory of Palestine into two states in a more or less fair sharing out of the land, but since then Israel has used force of arms to occupy 78% of historic Palestinian territory. This was back in 1948, but that was not good enough for Israel. It occupied the rest of our territory in 1967. People still quote that United Nations Resolution– Resolution 181 – today and they say that this resolution should not be interpreted literally all the way through, but only certain paragraphs should be implemented. I would say that United Nations Resolution 181 has to be applied in its totality.  Despite international resolutions, United Nations resolutions and the efforts of the international community to find a solution, a two-state solution, despite all these efforts our state is still not independent, despite the fact that we are now a member state of the United Nations, and that since 2012. And we are now a member of a great number of international organisations, as well as the United Nations organisation. We have ratified a great number of international conventions, we are recognised by 138 states around the world.  In order to make progress towards peace and to put an end to our years of suffering, we have now accepted the establishment of the State of Palestine on an area which is less than a quarter of the area of historic Palestine; 22% of our historic territory. We have accepted that as a state, respecting the 1967 borders, and that is an enormous sacrifice.  Since the Madrid Conference and since the Oslo Agreements we have made no further progress. We are going round in circles in negotiations. We are just negotiating for negotiation’s sake at the moment. And this is being imposed upon us by Israel. They are trying to gain time in this process so that they can change things on the ground, which will make it less and less possible for us to find a two-state solution.  Today Israel is carrying on with its colonisation. It is continuing to expropriate our land. It is building walls and all this is also being done on a racist basis. Under our other United Nations resolutions calling on Israel to put an end to colonisation, these resolutions have called on Israel to do away with colonisation, to reverse it, but nevertheless, Israel is carrying on with these projects. We are calling on Israel simply to freeze this colonisation so that negotiations can properly start, but Israel still does not stop colonising. It is carrying on.  Furthermore, over the last six years, Israel has started at least three wars in Gaza. It has killed thousands of people. Israel has killed dozens of Palestinian families. There are hundreds of families which have quite simply disappeared. There is no longer a record of them in our civil registers. These families have quite simply disappeared because of the three wars waged by Israel in Gaza in the last six years. Israel has destroyed houses. It has destroyed factories and since the occupation I can tell you this: one million Palestinians have been jailed by Israel at some time or another. At the moment we have 7 000 of our people held as prisoners of war. That is the bitter reality and the dangerous reality we are facing and is it not time to put an end to the Israeli occupation of Palestine? Why is international law not being applied?  (Applause) Why is international law not being implemented in the case of Israel? You have here a state attacking another state. When that happens normally the whole world stands up and punishes the aggressor, except in the case of Israel. Israel seems free to attack us with impunity. Why have the United Nations resolutions been ignored in the case of Palestine and the rights of the Palestinian people? How long is Israel going to continue to benefit from this impunity? How long is Israel going to continue rejecting peace? How long is Israel going to continue ignoring the historic sufferings of the Palestinian people? How long is Israel going to accept the injustice it has inflicted upon the Palestinian people?  Our people want to live in peace and dignity on our territory, like any other nation in the world. Our people do not accept this colonisation. We do not accept this invasion. And we will continue to make sacrifices and to suffer until this situation is righted. That is why we are calling on you to help us. You are our friends. Help us. Help us alleviate this situation. Help us remove the desperation our people are suffering from. Help us put an end to the longest occupation in contemporary history. There are no other such lengthy occupations I am aware of. Help us put an end to this occupation.  It is so wrong that our Palestinian people – one of the most ancient peoples in the region and of the world, with its ancient culture – it is so wrong that this situation continues and that we do not have our own state. Is it not time for our people to be able to live in freedom, to live without checkpoints, to live without controls, to live without walls, to live without checkpoints again I say, the checkpoint set up by the Israeli army on an entirely arbitrary basis? It is time all this came to an end.  Israel has turned our country into an open air prison and our people are living in it. Here in this European Parliament, I would like to repeat: we do not want to wipe any other country off the map. Some people want to wipe our country off the map. This should not be allowed. No country should be allowed to wipe another country off the map. We certainly do not want to. On the other hand, all we want to do is exist, and we will not allow anybody to wipe our country off the map and confiscate our rights. We are still denied our rights, and this only serves to encourage our extremists. That leads to terrorism, that leads to violence. And this gives violent people and terrorists a pretext for doing what they do.  I appeal to you: do not make it possible for the Palestinian cause to continue to be used by these extremists and terrorists. We have to put an end to extremism. We have to encourage them to seek a way of life whereby we can all live in peace and fairness under rule of law, enjoying human rights, so I appeal to the European Parliament and to the European institutions to pursue your efforts, continue your efforts, at political and diplomatic level, so that we can come up with a fair and just solution to the problems of our region , and that means we need a two-state solution using the 1967 borders as your President suggested, and by respecting international resolutions and UN resolutions.  Israel and Palestine have both got close links with the European Union. We both have Association Agreements, we are both members of the Union for the Mediterranean, which means that the European Union is a major actor for us. And this is to the benefit of all parties, to all sides.  I want to be very frank with you. I am normally frank with whomsoever I have to deal and in being frank I would like to try and reply to some questions you may have for me. First of all, we are in favour of a two-state solution. We want to create the State of Palestine on all the territories of the West Bank, respecting the borders of 4 June 1967, with our capital being Jerusalem East, which is currently occupied. We are not against exchanging certain pieces of land as long as they are of equal value, within certain limits. There is also a need to deal with the problem of refugees and there we have to implement Resolution 194 on the basis of the Arab peace proposal, which calls for a fair, just and negotiated solution to the problem of refugees. This is an Arab country proposal which has produced a roadmap based on Resolution 1515.  Do not forget that the PLO has recognised Israel. The PLO recognised Israel back in 1993. So we want peace for everybody in our region and we have accepted that there should be a third territory between the Israeli territory and the future Palestinian territory. This would be in the interests of regional security. But we completely reject the provisional solutions which have been proposed, because we believe that they are a complete waste of time and we do not accept a Palestinian State with provisional borders. Our wish is for the Arab Peace Initiative, which was adopted in Beirut in 2002, to be implemented unamended, the Arab peace proposal.  The Israelis often talk about provocation. Well, I would say that Israeli provocation is never-ending. The colonists are still on our territory and to put an end to any provocation at all, including by extremists, we would like the Tripartite Commission involving Israel, Palestine and the United States to be brought back to life.  This Tripartite Commission was set up in Wye River in 1998 in order to resolve all the problems associated with the mutual proof of provocation on both sides and the United States were seeking to be the arbitrator. We are in favour of this Tripartite Commission being brought back to life with the membership of the European Union as a fourth member.  This would, I believe, show clearly that we are against incitation to violence, against provocation, we are against extremism. And we need somebody to arbitrate here, we think, in this particular situation. If you continue to say that the Palestinians are continuing to provoke and incite violence, we do not agree. The Israelis are doing this as well and somebody has to arbitrate and sort out these mutual accusations. The Tripartite Commission, I think, should be brought back to life and joined by the European Union.  I would also like to say that certain rabbis in Israel have said very clearly, and they have said it very clearly to their government, that our water should be poisoned in order to have Palestinians killed. Now that is provocation, that is an incitation to commit a crime. And we are against this sort of call for violence, this kind of provocation, this kind of incitation. Mr President, I would like to say this. The Palestinian nation would like to live with full sovereignty. This could be achieved very quickly; we could put an end to the occupation very quickly, and if we can achieve this, I think that will be a very positive thing for the world community if we could establish a Palestinian state. A full, independent, unoccupied Palestinian state. We could be a responsible actor on the world stage.  We would have a Palestinian state with Jerusalem as capital. Jerusalem would be an open city, open to all faiths, especially the three major faiths in the region: Judaism, Christianity and the Muslim faith. We would all have Jerusalem as a capital, as an open city, respecting the three main religions of the region, with free expression for all of them in Jerusalem: Jerusalem which would remain a free open city.  In this way our country could be responsible for its own management, its own government, its own development, its own natural resources. But to do this, we need to regain 70% of our territory and then it will be able to exploit and use all these resources, including our human resources, as for the time being these areas, 60% of our territories, are since the Oslo Agreement inaccessible to us, that is to say we cannot do anything with it. We cannot cultivate that land, we cannot establish industry on that land, it is categorised as a ‘C region’ – Region C – occupied by Israel since the Oslo Agreements.  And in that region Israel has been implementing an illegal project since 1993. Now if we can get that land back, that territory back, I believe we can perform miracles in agriculture, in industry and tourism, and I am wondering why the Israelis are insisting on keeping that land; I really am.  If we could do this, we could develop industry on this territory, develop agriculture, we could create jobs for tens of thousands of young people, we could exploit our own national resources: oil, gas, for example. We could generate clean electricity. We could develop the Jordan Valley. We could develop the Dead Sea region.  We could develop tourist projects, and of course you should not forget the importance of tourism – a pilgrimage in our country, for example, to Bethlehem, to Jerusalem – and in order to do that, we do not need a lot of assistance because we would have all these assets.  And in this situation, I have to say that, so far, the European Union has assisted us, has helped us. You have helped us create an embryo Palestinian state. Now we are going to continue with our efforts to develop a Palestinian state, so that we can enjoy full self-determination and that should not depend on negotiations with Israel. The right to self-determination should not be negotiable. It is a natural right.  So we need your assistance in this situation. We have dozens of educational institutions, universities, all of which are at a very high level. And these assets will allow us to develop and to further develop basic education, organise campaigns for literacy. These institutions will help us do our own research. We can become involved in joint projects with other educational institutions and do not forget, we are a free society, where women are equal to men. They have the same rights and the same duties.  On 3 June, a ministerial meeting was held in Paris. This was on the initiative of the French Government. Twenty-eight states were involved and three international organisations. We are grateful for this noble effort and this will now lead to a further conference on international law and international equality based on the relevant resolutions of the Security Council and on the basis of the Arab Peace Initiative which was adopted at the Beirut Summit in 2002. This conference will also be using the roadmap which has been developed by the Arab Peace Initiative.  Now if this major international conference is held, there should be very clear deadlines associated with it. Negotiations cannot start without some deadlines being set, and any agreements should also be subject to a schedule, to deadlines. And then, there should be a follow-up to these agreements, a monitoring arrangement for these agreements athat will be reached, similar to what happened in the case of Iran when you had the 5 Plus One Group, which solved an enormous number of problems in association with Iran.  So we would have to have a 5 Plus 2 or a 7 Plus 2 arrangement, that is to say a monitoring group to monitor the results of this major international conference which I would like to see take place with a view to achieving a settlement in the Middle East.  The European Council at its last meeting adopted a final communiqué to the conference held in Paris on 3 June. And let me say this: I and my colleagues, we support this French initiative. The President of the French Republic, Mr François Hollande, told me some days ago that France was determined to pursue its efforts so that this international peace conference can take place before the end of the year.  He said that the preparatory work should begin soon in order to make sure this international conference is a success. The civil servants and Sherpas, he said, should get to work as soon as possible, and I have to say, as a Palestinian and as an Arab, we Arabs are with you in this initiative. We are with you as well when it comes to combating terrorism and extremism. Here, we are on the same page. What is happening in the Middle East has also happened in Europe, in Brussels, in Paris, and in the United States. We are against terrorism – let me make this perfectly clear – whatever form it may take and whoever carries it out. We are against terrorism.  (Applause) However, in order to overcome terrorism we also need to end Israeli occupation by creating a Palestinian state within the 1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as its capital, so that Palestine can live in peace and security, side by side with Israel, and that will be a step towards ending terrorism. If this does not happen, we will still be giving pretexts to those who commit terrorism in the name of religion, but once this occupation ends those pretexts will disappear and extremism will be overcome, as will terrorism. There will be no more terrorism in the Middle East nor elsewhere in the world.  The beginning of the problem of terrorism is the problems that exist in Palestine. So the non-existence of the Palestinian state simply perpetuates the problem and that will only play into the hands of the extremists – the violence, terrorists – and many countries in our region and elsewhere have suffered at the hands of these violent extremists.  This terrorism has given rise to a wave of refugees that have fled now to Europe. Among them there are Palestinian refugees fleeing from this situation and we would ask you to treat Palestinian refugees in the same way as you treat other refugees, those who have fled from war, massacres and terrorism, and we condemn that terrorism.  Terrorism gives rise to waves of refugees. But among those refugees there are Palestinian refugees. Of course these internal conflicts that happen in the region are not our fault but when they happen we suffer from them as well. When Palestinian refugees arrive in refugee camps they have to be given the same rights as other refugees. My question is: put yourself in the shoes of a Palestinian refugee. That refugee is the same as any other refugee. They need help and they need support.  Regarding the internal situation in Palestine, I would like to say that we would like to manage our country properly. Currently there is a blockade in Gaza. We would like to put an end to the internal Palestinian blockade and division through an international governance agreement respecting the PLO commitments and international and regional commitments that have been undertaken regarding this region. We would like to create a Palestinian government involving all stakeholders in a national unity government, with all necessary elements in place to meet the commitments we have undertaken.  We have to meet all of the commitments that have been taken on and we are willing to form a national unity government with a view to establishing legislative and then presidential elections in order to overcome the current division and I would like to take this opportunity to once again assert my thanks to the European Union and to all of its Member States for all of the help they have contributed in putting an end to the Israeli occupation of Gaza and the attempts to rebuild the area.  More than 10 000 people have been killed, 100 000 people injured, many thousands of houses were destroyed during the Israeli bombings of the region and all of that was condemned here in the European Union and we have to acknowledge our thanks for that expression of support.  Please allow me to send out a message to the people of Israel from this podium, to the Israeli Government and its political parties. Our hands are extended with a desire for peace. We have the political will to achieve peace and we would ask you: do you have the same desire? Do you have the same political will to achieve peace and to acknowledge the historic injustice that your state has exacted on our country?  You have your history and we have ours. Our history has been, frankly, one of a continued existence in this territory since the dawn of civilization until now. We have constant ongoing rights in our territory, in a sacred place for Christians and Muslims alike. Peace and reconciliation will involve the acknowledgment of our rights and the need for reparation and compensation for damage.  This political struggle has been transformed into a religious struggle. That is an extremely dangerous element for our region. We have to remove religion from this conflict. It is a political struggle and the solution to it has to be political. Using a religious pretext is a genuine threat. It is a danger which we all face.  Peace is in everybody’s interests and I hope that you, Israelis, neighbours, believe in that too. Let us build a peace which does not involve hegemony or colonisation or aggression. Peace and coexistence on the basis of justice, law, respect and dignity for all parties involved, on an equal footing. That peace will be a genuine guarantee of security, stability and a promising future for our generations to come.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your welcome. We are counting on your noble efforts to help us restore peace in our region. Long live Euro-Palestinian friendship that lets the holy land of Palestine be one of peace, stability and security for the Palestinians, for its neighbours and for the whole of the world.  We have a specific interest today for what is happening in Great Britain. We are very closely accompanying what is happening in Great Britain and we would express our support for that process. (Applause) *Disclaimer: The interpretation does not constitute an authentic record of proceedings.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Thank you very much, President Abbas. Thank you for your words. Yesterday, the Israeli President ended his speech in Arabic with an appeal for peace. You have responded here today with an offer of peace. I would recommend that both of you start at this very point and start the dialogue. What we can do to help you do that, we will do. Thank you very much!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I resume the meeting. Hello to all of you. I greet members of the Ukrainian Parliament, the Faithful Council, together with the President of the Ukrainian Space Agency.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the vote.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Member of the Commission. – The Commission expresses concern that the limited powers delegated to it by the co-legislators may hinder the timely implementation in EU law of measures taken by ICCAT in the future that revise or update the control scheme of this Organisation. The Commission therefore declares that it considers this Regulation to be without prejudice to any future position of the institution as regards the recourse to Articles 290 and 291 TFEU for the transposition of Regional Fisheries Management Organisation measures. The Commission furthermore reserves the right to propose amendments to the Regulation increasing the number of measures which should be adopted by delegated or implementing acts in case the transposition through the ordinary legislative procedure leads to delays which would jeopardise the EU’s ability to comply with its international obligations.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Member of the Commission. – When proposing and adopting delegated acts under the regionalisation provisions of this plan, the Commission will comply with the framework set out in the Basic Regulation (in particular Article 18), and the practice established under the Basic Regulation in implementing the regionalisation process will continue as it has since 2014.

name: József SZÁJER
text: – Mr President, I would like to excuse myself. There is a mistake in the EPP voting list. In paragraph 86 all the splits are positive. That is the right answer and I am sorry for the other colleagues.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry into money laundering and tax avoidance and evasion, as well as the appointment of its members. After scandals such as the Panama Papers have come to light, which have made public not only the passivity of European governments in the face of such practices, but the direct involvement of different rulers, this type of Commission is of great importance if there is really a willingness to reverse such situations.  For this purpose, the committee of inquiry cannot serve only for the purification of political responsibilities, but must propose effective measures to end such crimes both through offshore companies and in the case of Panama and within our own continent. That is why we welcome the creation of this committee and hope that it will be allowed to work unrestrictedly and its conclusions will be taken into account.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concerned appointments to a special Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers. My colleague Matt Carthy has been nominated to represent the GUE/NGL European political grouping on this Committee. This Committee of Inquiry will investigate possible contraventions and maladministration in the application of the law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. A number of Irish companies, business people, property developers and other individuals have been implicated in this scandal. It is vital that this Committee has sufficient powers of inquiry to investigate the Panama Papers scandal effectively in order to identify the loopholes that need to be closed. The Committee will have 12 months to report back.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Since 8 April, I have been campaigning for the establishment of a European Commission of Inquiry to shed light on these unbearable cases, especially for the millions of citizens who cannot make ends meet and who pay their taxes. This special committee should lead the EU to take stronger action against fraudsters, tax evasion and money laundering. Trade sanctions must be taken not only at European level but also at the global level. Finally, there is an urgent need to end tax havens and introduce a financial transaction tax to cut the grass off these practices of another age.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In order to investigate the crimes of money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, the new Committee of Inquiry is necessary to examine similar infringements of Union law. I have therefore approved the proposal to appoint 65 full members.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the appointment by Parliament of the 65 members of the Commission of Inquiry on Tax Evasion and Money Laundering, which includes Gilles Lebreton, a member of the ENL group.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This text was approved without a vote by Parliament.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of the 65 members who will make up the commission of inquiry into the so-called "Panama Papers" revelations, in connection with tax evasion and money laundering. I will be part of this committee to continue the fight against money laundering and tax evasion

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We are in favour of the creation of this special committee, designed in the wake of the Panama Papers scandal to investigate possible omissions by the Commission and the Member States to transpose European Union directives to effectively combat tax evasion and money laundering. We consider that the information contained in the Panama Papers is a serious question of the effectiveness and even willingness of the European authorities to effectively combat tax evasion, and we consider that it is Parliament's duty to investigate this until its last consequences.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This vote concerns the appointment of the members of the new Commission of Inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. I abstained on that point.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. As a result of the scandal caused by the disclosure of the existence of thousands of opaque bank accounts for tax avoidance in Panama, the European Socialists are calling for the establishment of a commission of inquiry, since European citizens have been very meaningful involved in this network, and the Union's financial interests may also have been damaged.  This Commission will investigate, inter alia, whether Member States have correctly implemented the Anti-Money Laundering Directive to prevent money laundering through the creation of offshore undertakings, if they cooperated in relation to the automatic exchange of information, whether the laws in the audit sector have been well implemented to avoid conflicts of interest , and also prevent them from being involved in tax havens and whether banking legislation (CRD IV) has also been well implemented. In order to finalize the establishment of this Committee of Inquiry, I voted in favour of the list of Members of this house who will integrate it, including, and I congratulate myself on that, my colleagues Ramón Jáuregui and Juan Fernando López Aguilar.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 By this vote, the European Parliament has appointed members to its Committee of Inquiry to investigate allegations of breaches of Union law and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation between member states' tax authorities is more important than ever in order to reduce tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. The global economic and financial crisis of recent years has highlighted the importance and enforcement of joint burden-sharing. It is estimated that member states will be lost billions of euros in revenue as a a reason for corporate tax avoidance. I therefore supported the establishment of the committee in the last plenary session and now the definition of its personal composition.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which concerned appointments to a special Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers. My colleague Matt Carthy has been nominated to represent the GUE/NGL European political grouping on this Committee. This Committee of Inquiry will investigate possible contraventions and maladministration in the application of the law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. A number of Irish companies, business people, property developers and other individuals have been implicated in this scandal. It is vital that this Committee has sufficient powers of inquiry to investigate the Panama Papers scandal effectively in order to identify the loopholes that need to be closed. The Committee will have 12 months to report back.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Any infringement of Union law and any case of money laundering or tax evasion must be punished and punished as quickly as possible. The maintenance of a democratic system depends on respect for the rules and on the ability of its institutions to act: we are all called upon, ethically and politically, to act to ensure that the Union enforces the rules and prosecutes those who break them.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Panama Papers revealed real dysfunctions in European and international tax systems. We must not allow individuals or companies to use offshore companies based in tax havens to reduce their taxes or launder money. Parliament has decided to investigate violations of EU tax and money laundering law. Businesses and individuals must pay their taxes fairly. I voted for the membership of this commission of inquiry, of which I am an alternate member.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the appointments of members of the Parliamentary Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged cases of infringement and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and evasion. The European Parliament decided to set up this committee in the wake of the scandal of the so-called "Panama Papers", the millions of documents leaked in the international media that would reveal the existence of a gigantic mass of money diverted from international law firms and banks to tax havens on behalf of political leaders, criminals, intelligence officials and SPORTS and entertainment VIPs. The documents refer to transactions ranging from 1977 until the end of 2015 and, if confirmed to be true, would offer an unprecedented look at the management of large flows of money through the global financial system.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these appointments to the European Parliament’s Committee of Inquiry into the revelations made in the Panama Papers leak by a whistle-blower. I am one of four GUE/NGL MEPs who have been appointed to the inquiry.  This Committee of Inquiry will investigate possible contraventions and maladministration in the application of the law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. It will begin its work in September and have a year to report. The Panama Papers revelations released by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists caused shockwaves around the world, including resignations from office by political figures implicated in the scandal. I take my appointment to this inquiry very seriously and hope we can shine a light into the secret world of tax-dodging, money laundering and criminality through the use of offshore tax havens. Most importantly, we need to identify the legal loopholes that allow this to happen in order to propose international reforms to end this activity.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the list of members who will sit on the committee tasked with investigating alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. This committee has been set up as a response to the Panama Papers revelations. I believe that even with the tougher EU anti-money laundering laws adopted last year the manoeuvring in particular of politicians strongly suspected of corruption and money laundering would have remained undetected without the Panama Papers leak. Addressing these loopholes must be the focus of this committee.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed appointments to the Committee of Inquiry into alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Tax evasion does not only affect the economic and financial sphere of our societies: it concerns the fairness and political and social balances of our countries. Every year, tax evasion and avoidance in Europe loses between EUR 50 billion and EUR 70 billion.
