The "Panama Papers" have shed light on the non-European dimension of the phenomenon: more than 200 thousand companies, 550 banks and 14,000 customers are suspected of having evaded or evaded taxes and laundered money. Practices and behaviour of this kind are no longer tolerable. Hence the commitment of the S&D Group to the creation of a parliamentary committee of inquiry to investigate and understand whether current European legislation is adequate to manage the phenomenon.  It is the committee's task to draw up the necessary recommendations to improve the existing legislative framework not only on tax avoidance but also on money laundering, and to see whether action will be needed to amend European legislation. It will also be an opportunity to investigate whether states have implemented existing directives and to see how the Commission has acted against EU states to enforce the existing body of legislation effectively. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the composition of the Committee of Inquiry.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and await the final report of the committee of inquiry to Parliament.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the appointment of members of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged violations and maladministration in the implementation of EU legislation in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion concerns a particularly important area. Combating the issues mentioned will help to correct Europe's dysfunctions but also to get justice, which European citizens demand. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the establishment of this committee.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry into money laundering and tax avoidance and evasion, as well as the appointment of its members. After scandals such as the Panama Papers have come to light, which have made public not only the passivity of European governments in the face of such practices, but the direct involvement of different rulers, this type of Commission is of great importance if there is really a willingness to reverse such situations.  For this purpose, the committee of inquiry cannot serve only for the purification of political responsibilities, but must propose effective measures to end such crimes both through offshore companies and in the case of Panama and within our own continent. That is why we welcome the creation of this committee and hope that it will be allowed to work unrestrictedly and its conclusions will be taken into account.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 In response to the recent Panama document scandals, the fight against tax evasion and avoidance is a priority battle. To this end, all measures must be taken to minimise these situations and to ensure greater tax justice. The setting up of the Parliamentary Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged cases of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and evasion, I believe can help to achieve this.  That is why I voted in favour of its constitution. This committee is only one of the instruments at European level and will complement the other measures taken by the Commission in the field of taxation. In twelve months we will produce a report which will examine complaints about Member States' non-compliance with taxation, State aid and the Commission's errors in ensuring that the relevant legislation is properly applied at national level. It is essential that there is loyal cooperation between the Member States, and this committee of inquiry will ensure that certain injustices are properly combated.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Given the importance of the problem, I voted in favour. Any issues relating to tax evasion and avoidance should be clarified.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointments to the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration. It is now up to the Committee to ensure a fair process which properly addresses the allegations of maladministration of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged breaches and ill-administration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion and expressed a desire to be its member, as I strongly oppose this type of crime. Tax evasion and tax fraud are a serious problem for Member States and for the EU as a whole, harming the budget annually with a significant amount of money. Funds that can be invested in combating the challenges we face, such as the migrant crisis, for example. The mandate of the committee of inquiry shall be adequately defined in order to achieve the objectives set. I look forward to the start of the work of the new committee and believe that in 12 months we will achieve good results and express our opinion and recommendations to improve the situation.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We do not believe that the committee of inquiry can perform with these members.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has decided to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or maladministration by the Commission or the Member States in the application of European rules on money laundering and tax avoidance and tax evasion. I've been elected to this Committee of Inquiry. The Panama Papers represent a unique opportunity to act on european union level. I am sure that in this Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers, we will have enormous convergence on the part of all political groups.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate the scandals revealed by the Panama Papers was in our vote in favour. However, we must point out that the recent past, with the succession of tax scandals, leads us to conclude that we are in the presence of a structural problem and not just conjuncture. This committee, regardless of the fact-made facts about the protagonists of these practices, be they consultancy firms, multinationals or national governments, should give rise to a broad reflection on the deeper causes that have created the conditions for these practices, which are common and are generalised to most large multinationals, with the connivance of several EU Member States. And these root causes are naturally associated with the deregulation of the financial system and the lifting of all restrictions on the movement of capital. It is to be hoped that these matters will not be the subject of the work of this committee. We regret that the committee's mandate does not reflect this need. Having made possible the constitution of this committee, we denounce what seem to us to be its limits and, in a way, some perversity that may be associated with it: to give the idea that something is done so that something changes, and, in fact, everything is the same.  So it was with the committee on the Luxleaks scandal.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not believe that the committee of inquiry can perform with these members and I am voting against their appointment.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ After the scandal of the Panama Papers, Parliament decided to set up a committee of inquiry in order to investigate the alleged failure of the Commission and the Member States regarding the application of several legislations in the field of taxation and money laundering. Parliament will now vote on the composition of this committee of inquiry. In addition, Parliament is due to finalise its work on the TAXE 2 Committee in July 2016 and outstanding issues remain unanswered. The Council and the Commission have not delivered the documents requested, ministers have not all had the opportunity to answer before the Committee and revelations related to, amongst other matters, the Panama Papers have raised further questions which require political dedication and further technical investigation, all of which the mandate of the Panama Committee of Inquiry would be responsible for. I am in favour of continuing the work on taxation issues, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the S&D Group and all my colleagues for the trust they wanted to give me by proposing my name as a member of the new extraordinary committee of inquiry charged with examining infringement complaints regarding money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. It will be my commitment to ensure an adequate deepening of the events known as the 'Panama Papers', with the aim of ensuring maximum transparency on the events that have taken place and preventing the recurrence of new episodes of circumvention and evasion against citizens and growth.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of the members of the 'Committee of Inquiry into alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in the application of it in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion', as I support any measure that fights for greater tax justice and transparency in the interests of our citizens and families.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We are in favour of the creation of this special committee, designed in the wake of the Panama Papers scandal to investigate possible omissions by the Commission and the Member States to transpose European Union directives to effectively combat tax evasion and money laundering. We consider that the information contained in the Panama Papers is a serious question of the effectiveness and even willingness of the European authorities to effectively combat tax evasion, and we consider that it is Parliament's duty to investigate this until its last consequences.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. It was decided to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 In the previous plenary we voted in favour of the establishment of a Parliament's committee of inquiry to investigate alleged violations and maladministration in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. In this case, we voted in favour of the members of the Committee of Inquiry. It is a question of examining it in its full depth and in this direction we will work as a group within the committee of inquiry.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the appointments put forward by all political groups to the new Committee of Inquiry into the alleged maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is vital that elected representatives have an opportunity to evaluate the tax practices of large multinationals and wealthy individuals to see if they paid the appropriate amount of tax on their earnings within the EU. It is also of vital importance to the integrity of the EU institutions that an investigation into the application of European Union law by the Commission and Member States is undertaken. Citizens need assurances that tax administrations correctly apply tax levels. Likewise, if tax rates are not being correctly applied this needs to be reviewed as tax not collected by administrations is funding lost for vital public services in local communities.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for appointments to the Commission of Inquiry to investigate alleged violations and irregularities in the application of Union legislation in the field of money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, as I believe that the Commission should start its work as soon as possible.  The Commission of Inquiry has 65 members and has a mandate of 12 months after which it is to submit its final report. In my view, sufficient time has been given to establish whether there has been a failure by the European Commission and the Member States. It is extremely important to identify what enables, and how, money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion in order to prevent and prevent such practices in the future, and therefore I support the appointments and the beginning of the Commission's work.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of appointing 65 MEPs to form the Panama Papers Commission of Inquiry. The commission was set up to investigate allegations of breaches of EU law in the areas of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion.  In the face of this global tax scandal that has shaken Europe, it is essential that Parliament provides a strong response and sheds light on the offences committed.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. – I strongly support the initiative of Parliament to appoint a committee of inquiry to examine contraventions and maladministration on issues related to tax fraud and money laundering. The Panama Papers and other related leaks that we have experienced in the near past dictate that we act promptly and protect the fiscal capacity of the EU as well as the citizens who find themselves entrapped by the constant tax base erosion.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. The European Parliament has appointed the 65 members of its committee of inquiry into the so-called Panama Papers revelations, in connection with tax evasion and money laundering, after approving his mandate on 8 June. I voted in favour of this designation, which confirms the beginning of the work of the Committee of Inquiry of which I am now a member.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I support the appointment of the members of the Commission of Inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. The ENL group will be represented by Gilles Lebreton, Barbara Kappel and Mario Borghezio. We have also appointed Bernard Monot, Lorenzo Fontana and Marcus Pretzell as alternate members.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry into money laundering and tax avoidance and evasion, as well as the appointment of its members. After scandals such as the Panama Papers have come to light, which have made public not only the passivity of European governments in the face of such practices, but the direct involvement of different rulers, this type of Commission is of great importance if there is really a willingness to reverse such situations.  For this purpose, the committee of inquiry cannot serve only for the purification of political responsibilities, but must propose effective measures to end such crimes both through offshore companies and in the case of Panama and within our own continent. That is why we welcome the creation of this committee and hope that it will be allowed to work unrestrictedly and its conclusions will be taken into account.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 June 2012, parliament held a vote that set up a Committee of Inquiry within the EP, whose members will analyse in detail both recent financial scandals (e.g. LuxLeaks and Panama Papers) and any other alleged violations and maladminimn of Union law on money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. It is quite a good thing that my colleagues, who have been appointed today in their posts in this committee, will work as actively and efficiently as possible in the necessary directions and will produce a report within a year that will help not only to understand more clearly the specificities of these and other scandals and the shortcomings of existing policies and legislation, but also to properly implement measures on a much wider scale in relation to such criminal transactions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of appointing members of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged violations and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the "Appointments to the Committee of Inquiry charged with investigating alleged cases of infringement and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and evasion". This is certainly one of the priorities which the European Union cannot ignore, which concerns the protection of all those citizens who comply with taxation regulations and payments. Being able to detect cases of maladministration reduces waste, increases the efficiency of the system and instis confidence in our European citizens, and that is precisely the aim.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the proposal with the names of the persons who will be part of the committee of inquiry that we decided to create a few weeks ago to determine whether there has been a violation of Community legislation on evasion and bleaching in relation to those known as 'Panama Papers'.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This committee of inquiry can be of great importance in combating money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is with great mission spirit that I will participate as an effective member of this committee, where I will do everything to contribute to the success of this committee.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these appointments and I am proud to form part of the Committee. It is critical to have a comprehensive and dedicated team of MEPs to examine violations of European Union law and alleged corrupt practices uncovered in several information leaks known as the ‘Panama Papers’.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The committee of inquiry was set up, its powers and the duration of its mandate decided by Parliament at its plenary session on 8 June. According to the decision adopted at the time, the panel is composed of 65 members. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The ENL Group will have 3 full members and three alternates, which will give it a satisfactory presence on the new 65-member commission.  The composition can be voted as it is.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The committee of inquiry into the so-called "Panama Papers" for the investigation of alleged misdemeanors or mismanagement in the application of Union law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion has a fundamental job of ensuring citizens' confidence in the institutions. The European Union must be guided by scrupulous compliance with existing rules and must take all necessary steps to ensure a policy of transparency and to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the composition of the commission of inquiry set up after the Panama Papers scandal. The mandate of this committee was voted on at the first plenary session in June 2016.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the establishment of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which concerned appointments to a special committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers. My colleague Matt Carthy has been nominated to represent the GUE/NGL European political grouping on this Committee.  This Committee of Inquiry will investigate possible contraventions and maladministration in the application of the law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. A number of Irish companies, business people, property developers and other individuals have been implicated in this scandal. It is vital that this Committee has sufficient powers of inquiry to investigate the Panama Papers scandal effectively in order to identify the loopholes that need to be closed. This committee will have 12 months to report back.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Tax avoidance inevitably affects the trust of EUROPEAN Union citizens in the proper functioning of legal institutions, both at national and European level. We cannot escape the fact that malfeasance in the area of the tax system is a common way of recklessly exploiting insufficient control or legal gaps in the system and do direct damage to any of its citizens who duly fulfil their obligations. However, deliberate violations of national laws and rules through money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, and violations and irregularities in the application of Union legislation leave a bitter taste in the average taxpayer and rightly raises the question of why the rules apply to someone and not to someone else. The disclosure of 11.5 million documents with detailed classified information for 214,418 offshore companies is unfortunately only a fraction of what actually happens. Detected fraud cases must be severely sanctioned and loopholes in existing laws and rules closed. I have supported the establishment and appointments of members of this commission of inquiry and wish them successful work. Only a fair attitude of government towards every taxpayer will strengthen citizens' trust, both in national and European institutions. And we need trust today if we are to continue to build the Union on a sound foundation.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has decided to set up a committee of inquiry to establish the truth about the suspicion that the Commission and the Member States have not applied the necessary legislation in the field of tax evasion and money laundering. Parliament is thus actively responding to the panama papers case. Parliament voted today on the composition of this committee, over which there was a general consensus.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the wake of the plenary vote at the beginning of June 2016, I renewed my support for the establishment of a commission of inquiry following the so-called Panama Papers revelations. Operating on the same model as the Commission of Inquiry on Vehicle Emissions (EMIS), of which I am a member, this committee will have to investigate possible infringements or the mismanagement of the application of European laws on money laundering and tax evasion. The 65 MEPs are now appointed and the committee will have 12 months to present its final report.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Following the so-called "Panama Papers" revelations about offshore companies and their beneficiaries, the European Parliament supports the formation of a commission of inquiry with its vote this lunchtime.   The Commission (PANA) will be responsible for investigating allegations of infringement and maladministration in the application by the European Commission or Member States of EU legislation on money laundering, evasion and tax avoidance.  According to the International Consortium for Investigative Journalism (ICIJ), the first revelations about the Panama Papers involve at least 12 heads of state and government around the world (six of whom are still active) and 128 high-ranking politicians or officials. These revelations also show the involvement of large banks in the creation of offshore companies in tax havens.  Additional data should be published by the ICIJ at a later date to facilitate the European Parliament's research into these activities. As a reminder, the European Parliament estimates that tax evasion and avoidance cost the European Union between 50 and 70 billion euros a year.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. Just as I welcomed the establishment on 8 June of this commission of inquiry following the Panama Papers revelations, I welcome the appointment of its 65 members as this means that the parliamentary work of this House will be able to begin on this subject. The commission will investigate allegations of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU laws on money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. My 65 colleagues will have 12 months to present their report, and I encourage them to shed light on the responsibilities involved in dealing with these unacceptable practices.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. As a result of the scandal known as PanaLeaks, which revealed the existence of thousands of opaque bank accounts for tax avoidance in Panama, the European Socialists are calling for the establishment of a commission of inquiry, since very meaningful European citizens have participated in this network, and the Union's financial interests may also have been damaged.  This Commission will investigate, inter alia, whether Member States have correctly implemented the Anti-Money Laundering Directive to prevent money laundering through the creation of offshore undertakings, if they cooperated in relation to the automatic exchange of information, whether the laws in the audit sector have been well implemented to avoid conflicts of interest , and also prevent them from being involved in tax havens and whether banking legislation (CRD IV) has also been well implemented. In order to finalize the establishment of this Committee of Inquiry, I voted in favour of the list of Members of this house who will integrate it, among which I congratulate myself, are my colleagues Ramón Jáuregui and Juan Fernando López Aguilar.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has appointed the 65 MEPs to form the Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal, which has highlighted the extent of assets hidden abroad through company arrangements. Unlike the Special Committee on Tax Rescripts (TAXE2), it will not only be MEPs from Parliament's Economic Affairs Committee, but also members of the Legal Affairs Committee, for example. At its first meeting, in principle in July, the Commission of Inquiry will appoint its chairman and vice-presidents. This committee intends to shed light - much needed - on alleged breaches of European law with regard to money laundering, tax evasion and avoidance. She will be on her feet for one year.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Long-named – Committee of Inquiry to investigate allegations of breaches of Union law and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion – is a very important eu framework for combating financial crime. We must therefore ensure that its members are of good repute. Equally important is their expertise in the financial field. I am convinced that all the political groups have delegated their best representatives to it, although, in fact, I have never seen that this reputation and expert ability be demonstrated in any way. I also miss the principle of representation of all Member States, which is not the case in the committee of representatives of some countries.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the support I gave to the European Parliament's decision to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or maladministration in the application of EU law relating to money laundering and tax avoidance and tax evasion, numerical composition and the duration of the mandate, I also agreed with the appointments of the 65 members who will carry out this task of presenting , within 12 months, a full report on this matter. I would also point out that, in this range of parliamentarians, there are three MEPs elected by Portugal, two of which are part of my political group, having recognized capacity and proven experience in this matter.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We are in favour of the creation of this special committee, designed in the wake of the Panama Papers scandal to investigate possible omissions by the Commission and the Member States to transpose European Union directives to effectively combat tax evasion and money laundering. We consider that the information contained in the Panama Papers is a serious question of the effectiveness and even willingness of the European authorities to effectively combat tax evasion, and we consider that it is Parliament's duty to investigate this until its last consequences.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for our colleagues who will investigate allegations of money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I am glad that this committee has been set up and I am confident that it will do a good job. Citizens need more transparency from the EU institutions and assurances that taxpayers' money is being properly used.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry into money laundering and tax avoidance and evasion, as well as the appointment of its members. After scandals such as the Panama Papers have come to light, which have made public not only the passivity of European governments in the face of such practices, but the direct involvement of different rulers, this type of Commission is of great importance if there is really a willingness to reverse such situations.  For this purpose, the committee of inquiry cannot serve only for the purification of political responsibilities, but must propose effective measures to end such crimes both through offshore companies and in the case of Panama and within our own continent. That is why we welcome the creation of this committee and hope that it will be allowed to work unrestrictedly and its conclusions will be taken into account.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax avoidance and tax evasion must be investigated and the consequences of the acts must be drawn thereafter. I support the appointment of new members to strengthen the Committee of Inquiry and help detect these crimes.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the list of members of the Committee of Inquiry on alleged breaches of European law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The Committee of Inquiry will investigate whether business owners in tax havens have breached European tax law. I welcome the appointment of members of the Committee of Inquiry, who will explore all dimensions of the Panama Papers affair with a strong mandate and full mandate. I hope or believe that the Committee of Inquiry will bring concrete results and that in this way we will end up with unfair tax practices.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The selection of persons for Committees for the Examination and Control of the Union Interest should be based on the integrity of their character and their proven activity with regard to the protection of public money in the broadest sense.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of members of the Committee of Inquiry into alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. As an MEP, I voted in favour of setting up a Panama Papers inquiry committee in the previous plenary session, which will look at offshore companies and their beneficiaries, as well as the alleged violations and perverse application of EU law on money laundering, tax evasion and evasion by The Member States and the European Commission. The 65 members of the board who have just been elected, as well as the alternates, have been given a very high degree of responsibility. We will have 12 months to uncover and report on alleged omissions and abuses that have paved the way and made it significantly easier for some companies and individuals to evad tax. The impact of money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion on society and the economy is extremely negative. However, even if our current systems help and encourage these illegal activities, we can expect fatal damage. The outcome of the committee members' inquiry will hopefully answer a number of questions and contribute to reducing money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion in the EU.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I have, of course, voted in favour of appointing the members of the Committee of Inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application in the areas of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. Hunting down fraudsters and cheats must be a top priority.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointment of 65 members who will make up the Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal, which revealed the scope of assets hidden overseas through corporate structures. I am confident that my ANO colleague Petr Ježek will do an excellent job for our Group on this important committee. The Committee intends to shed light on the presumed shortcomings in EU law regarding money laundering and tax evasion and avoidance. It will be in place for one year.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the decision to appoint the members of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged breaches and irregularities in the application of Union law related to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is necessary to investigate how the Commission and the Member States have implemented and enforced the Directive on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing and whether the authorities of the Member States have applied administrative penalties and other administrative measures in the cases of institutions found to be responsible for serious infringements of national provisions relating to that Directive. The exchange of information in the field of taxation is also important. The Commission should investigate the presumption that the authorities of the Member States have not been consistent in communicating tax information to other Member States on their own initiative if there are grounds for believing that there may be a loss of tax.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We are in favour of the creation of this special committee, designed in the wake of the Panama Papers scandal to investigate possible omissions by the Commission and the Member States to transpose European Union directives to effectively combat tax evasion and money laundering. We consider that the information contained in the Panama Papers is a serious question of the effectiveness and even willingness of the European authorities to effectively combat tax evasion, and we consider that it is Parliament's duty to investigate this until its last consequences.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the institution of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The Panama leaks and scandal must be investigated and we should make sure these abuses are not repeated. Parliament has its role to play as we represent the European citizens that are the victims of these frauds as most of them pay their taxes according to the law. It is morally wrong to avoid and evade taxes in a period when many European citizens, SMEs and most big companies pay their fair share of taxes and respect the rules. I am proud to be part of the Panama inquiry. My work will focus on all actions to combat economic fraud, capital outflow and money laundering.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We are in favour of the creation of this special committee, designed in the wake of the Panama Papers scandal to investigate possible omissions by the Commission and the Member States to transpose European Union directives to effectively combat tax evasion and money laundering. We consider that the information contained in the Panama Papers is a serious question of the effectiveness and even willingness of the European authorities to effectively combat tax evasion, and we consider that it is Parliament's duty to investigate this until its last consequences.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointments to the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I voted in favour because I believe that setting up a committee of inquiry into the ‘Panama Papers’ revelations of detailed information on offshore companies and their ultimate beneficiaries is of crucial importance.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By these appointments, this Parliament expresses its willingness to combat these practices. It is important that European citizens see us as part of the solution and not as part of the problem, so I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry into money laundering and tax avoidance and evasion, as well as the appointment of its members. After scandals such as the Panama Papers have come to light, which have made public not only the passivity of European governments in the face of such practices, but the direct involvement of different rulers, this type of Commission is of great importance if there is really a willingness to reverse such situations.  For this purpose, the committee of inquiry cannot serve only for the purification of political responsibilities, but must propose effective measures to end such crimes both through offshore companies and in the case of Panama and within our own continent. That is why we welcome the creation of this committee and hope that it will be allowed to work unrestrictedly and its conclusions will be taken into account.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the composition of this parliamentary committee of inquiry because I believe that further investigation is needed into the rogue application of European law or even its violations in the 'Panama case' in order to evade taxes and launder money. The European Parliament needs to carry out thorough research on this in order to rule this out in the future.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This vote concerned the appointment of the members of the various political groups to the new Committee of Inquiry to examine alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in the application of the latter in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The EP must take the lead in creating a more transparent business environment that limits the excess of speculation and greed that led to the global financial crisis of 2008. The effects of this crisis are being felt to this day, and we in the EP need to focus on legislative initiatives, but also on actions aimed at helping to change mindsets. It is true that the tax area is the exclusive competence of the Member States, but through cooperative actions of the regulatory and control authorities as well as through the example that the EP promotes even through the work of the newly created commission of inquiry we will be able to impose a model of conduct. Transparency is a key element in protecting citizens' interests, which is why the EP is entitled to impose itself as an initiator in this area.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of this Committee of Inquiry, of which I will be a member, on panama's so-called papers as it is yet another step by the European Parliament towards greater parence and accountability with regard to laundering, evasion and tax avoidance.  As a member of this committee, I would like to argue that it is an excellent opportunity to show the European citizen that his representatives, that is, we, want to be part of the solution and not part of the problem.  Together with my remaining 64 colleagues, we will work together to detect mistakes that may have been made both by action and by default.  Thanks a lot.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointments of the committee of inquiry by the European Parliament to investigate alleged misdemeanors or mismanagement in the application of EU law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, because I agree with the proposed list of names. I would like to highlight the fact that the European Parliament is the democratic body par excellence of the European institutions, and it therefore has a duty to investigate what has happened and to ascertain why the current tax avoidance and avoidance measures have not been effective. I would stress that, in the fulfilment of this mandate, Parliament should also propose, in its final report, measures to prevent the repetition of cases such as that of the Panama Papers. In addition to strengthening internal regulation of this matter, it is also essential to encourage third countries to apply minimum standards of good governance in tax matters and aggressive tax planning.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported the appointment of members of the Committee of Inquiry on alleged breaches of European law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I believe that the creation of an investigative committee will help to uncover alleged breaches and irregularities related to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion in the Panama Papers case.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. In view of the process of association of the Republic of Lebanon with the European Union, Parliament called for the conclusion of a protocol to facilitate the participation of the partner in European programmes. In line with the neighbourhood policies, the text aims to put in place all the necessary measures to support Lebanon in achieving the objectives and standards laid down in the Union. By establishing fruitful cooperation with Lebanon, the EU will be able to assist the new partner in the process of transition and harmonisation.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. These texts deal with the updating of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements, which are the southern part of the neighbourhood policy. They concern relations between the EU and Lebanon for the first and enlargement to the different incoming countries for the other two. I voted against these texts, which constitute interference by the European Union in the affairs of a state already facing the massive influx of refugees, the bloody incursions of the Islamic State or the ongoing marginalization of the country's Sunni minority. The EU has no international role to play.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote which was on a framework agreement between the EU and Lebanon through the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership (Euromed). This agreement promotes economic integration and democratic reform across 16 countries to the EU’s south. It seeks greater integration within the region and is linked to the European neighbourhood policy which is aimed at offering its neighbours a privileged relationship. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its Eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. As this agreement is foreseen to lead to future trade agreements, I was against it in principle. However, as the Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation. The European Union has strategic relations with Lebanon. We support the stability of this country and its security in a region of the world in the midst of severe turbulence. Lebanon's participation in EU programmes is a way to concretely support these strategic objectives.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This Recommendation, which I voted in favour of, concerns the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes. We now expect the Protocol to be communicated to the Commission, the Council, the national governments of the Member States and the Republic of Lebanon.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) will enable countries that do not have a prospect of accession to cooperate more closely with the EU. The aim is to provide incentives to modernise their policies, the economy and society. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing such cooperation between the EU and the Lebanese Republic entered into force on 1 April 2006. Lebanon thus makes a financial contribution to the EU's overall budget, the amount of which is based on the specific programmes in which Lebanon participates. The aim of the protocol is now to define precisely these financial and technical rules that allow Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. In order to continue to stop the ENP with Lebanon, I have agreed to the minutes.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The proposed text is an update of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements. It concerns EU-Lebanon relations for the first and the extension of these to the different incoming countries for the other two. Lebanon is now experiencing further destabilization with the mass influx of Syrian refugees (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees. It does not need the European Union as an additional problem to meddle in its affairs. The subtlety of the Lebanese political game completely escaped the Community oligarchy, I voted against the protocol.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This agreement, updating the southern part of the neighbourhood policy, concerns relations between the EU and Lebanon. I voted against this text, believing that the EU does not have to have an international role, especially when it comes to a country whose situation is threatened by the current events (syrian refugee influx) and that Brussels interference can only further destabilize.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this protocol to the EU-Lebanon Framework Agreement, which sets out the financial and technical rules for Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, particularly in the area of economic, financial and technical cooperation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Mănescu report approving the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community, with its Member States, and the Lebanese Republic. This is an important text defining a framework agreement between the EU and Lebanon on the general principles of the Lebanese Republic's participation in EU programmes.  This vote strengthens the neighbourhood policy, responding to two requirements: on the one hand, the 2013 request of the Middle Eastern state to have closer links with the Union will be met, and on the other hand, the reform processes and stability of a country that, occupying a strategic position in an area extremely at risk, represents a fundamental ally in the fight against Daesh and Islamic terrorism will be strengthened.  The framework agreement specifically defines a set of technical and financial rules to ensure Lebanon's access to a wide range of EU programmes.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon, including its framework agreement. It is the update of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements which are the southern part of the neighbourhood policy.  Lebanon is currently experiencing destabilization with a massive influx of Syrian refugees (more than 1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees. Moreover, the repeated incursions of the Islamic State and the marginalization of the ongoing Sunni minority are not encouraging signs.  The EU does not have to meddle in such conflicts, which still flout the sovereignty of European states, in an attempt to make it look like European diplomacy that is solely a matter of national policies. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I find the Manescu report unbalanced and i do not agree with it, so I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have abstained on the framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon. On the one hand, it is a question of some of the programmes being able to give Lebanon a meaningful exchange. I am in favour of that. But in the long run, there is the objective of a free trade agreement. I am opposed to the way in which the EU formulates these agreements today vis-à-vis third countries, as they do not promote economic development and social justice. That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution by which the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement creating an Association between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the Lebanese Republic's participation in the Union's programmes. This agreement, and the two protocols that have been voted on in this plenary session, lay down economic, financial and technical rules to enable Lebanon to participate in certain European Union programmes. The specific terms and conditions for Lebanon's participation in each particular programme shall be determined by the negotiation of agreements between the Commission and the competent authorities in Lebanon.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to establish financial and technical rules in order to enable the Republic of Lebanon to participate in certain european Union programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol sets out the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and may be supported by the Republic of Lebanon from the Union under those programmes, including financial assistance. That system shall apply only to European Union programmes where the relevant founding legislation provides for the possibility of participation of the Republic of Lebanon. The conclusion of the Protocol therefore does not confer the sectoral policy powers of the various sectoral policies carried out under the programmes, which are used for the establishment of programmes.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The enlargement of the European Union requires that the agreements in force reflect the real situation, so I voted in favour of the adoption of the amendment.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Lebanon does not need the EU to meddle in its affairs; it has enough problems related to the mass influx of Syrian refugees in addition to Palestinian refugees.   Added to this is that the EU does not have to have an international role. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I abstained on this vote which was on a framework agreement between the EU and Lebanon through the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership (Euromed). This agreement promotes economic integration and democratic reform across 16 countries to the EU’s south. It seeks greater integration within the region and is linked to the European neighbourhood policy which is aimed at offering its neighbours a privileged relationship. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its Eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. As this agreement is foreseen to lead to future trade agreements, I was against it in principle. However, as the Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with third countries. This has often produced positive results for citizens on both sides and increased the range of influence of soft power in the European Union.  Lebanon, in particular, is one of the few countries in the Near East where the social and political system holds up despite the enormous problems to which it is exposed: an exceptional case of welcome and tenacity that looks to the West and to the development of the rule of law despite the still serious structural shortcomings, its internal social problems, the difficult relationship with minorities and jihadist militias still active in many areas of the country.  Overall, Europe can see the Republic of Lebanon as a friendly democracy, present in a key area, which we must support, ensuring its territorial integrity and political survival, and enabling it to stabilise under appropriate conditions, and gradually to enter the area of joint cooperation and co-management of the Middle East crisis.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to update the Euro-Mediterranean agreements, ratified within the framework of the European Union's neighbourhood policy. Lebanon is currently plagued by serious internal unrest, particularly as a result of the massive influx of Syrian migrants in addition to Palestinian refugees. The country of Cedar is also suffering from the bloody incursions of the Islamic State. However, the European Union has demonstrated in the past that it has no legitimacy and credibility to interfere in internal affairs in a third country. On the one hand, the Union must respect the principle of non-interference; on the other hand, foreign policy remains an exclusive competence of the Member States. That is why I objected to this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The involvement of partner countries in the European Neighbourhood Policy is also transposed through various agreements—key. The Lebanese Republic's interest in participating in Union programmes and agencies open to partner states in the European Neighbourhood Policy has materialised through a protocol with standard provisions containing an agreement—framework on the general principles of Lebanon's participation. The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Lebanese Republic, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles of the Lebanese Republic's participation in Union programmes, aims to establish financial and technical rules, and at the same time , economic, financial and technical cooperation measures. I was in favour of the establishment of this agreement, because I believe it is a pillar for strengthening the European Neighbourhood Policy, making an important contribution to the extension of external relations and to facilitating the modernisation of neighbouring countries with the European Union.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2004, the EU has developed the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) to prevent the emergence of new lines of division between the new enlarged Union and its neighbours, as well as to strengthen their prosperity, stability and security. Since 2006, Lebanon has been one of 16 partner neighbours with whom the EU, within the Union for the Mediterranean, establishes a bilateral policy based on the values of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Lebanon aims to establish the financial and technical rules by which Lebanon may participate in certain Union programmes considered relevant to that Mediterranean State, such as economic cooperation and financial assistance. Lebanon is home to about 1.1 million Syrian refugees, which is an economic and administrative-technical burden for the state with a population of only four times the size. In the context of the deteriorating situation of Syrian refugees, this protocol comes to facilitate the technical procedure for the provision of financial assistance by the EU, also taking into account the fact that, for 2016, the European Commission is allocating EUR 87 million for humanitarian assistance in Lebanon.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I believe it is important to establish financial and technical rules that will enable the Lebanese Republic to participate in concretely in The European Union's programmes.  The horizontal framework established by the Protocol sets out principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Lebanese Republic to receive technical assistance, in particular financial assistance, from the European Union under EU programmes. This framework shall apply only to Union programmes whose relevant legal acts provide for the possibility of participation by the Lebanese Republic.  I would also point out that the standard conditions set out in the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, should apply to all partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy with which similar protocols are to be concluded. Under the Protocol in question, the representatives of Lebanon may participate, as observers and only in points concerning their country, in the management committees responsible for monitoring Union programmes to which the Lebanese Republic contributes financially.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote which was on a framework agreement between the EU and Lebanon through the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership (Euromed). This agreement promotes economic integration and democratic reform across 16 countries to the EU’s south. It seeks greater integration within the region and is linked to the European neighbourhood policy which is aimed at offering its neighbours a privileged relationship. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its Eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. As this agreement is foreseen to lead to future trade agreements, I was against it in principle. However, as the Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Lebanon. It contains principles and standards in financial and technical fields that apply to the Member States and other participating EU neighbourhood policy partners. This Agreement provides Lebanon with an easier access to take part in certain EU programmes and activities as well as receiving financial support. Both the EU and Lebanon will benefit from further cooperation and a strengthened partnership.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The procedure in question has parliament's consent to the conclusion of a protocol to the association agreement already in force between the EU and Lebanon aimed at allowing Lebanon's participation in European Union programmes. It is an instrument designed to help achieve the objectives of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to promote the development and stability of one of the Union's neighbours, which plays a key role in the neighbourhood policy. The measure is therefore entirely acceptable to our positions. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the agreement and consider the results of the negotiations between the Commission and the Republic of Lebanon to be satisfactory.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles governing the participation of that State in Union programmes. The effort to reach out and mutually link the two parties is positive. However, exclusive targeting of economic issues does not serve the interests of citizens and that is why I abstained from voting.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree that the European Union is providing financial aid to the Lebanese Republic: it is a country that is suffering greatly as a result of the continuous armed clashes that are taking place within the country and this phenomenon mainly affects many innocent citizens who live there and do not have the opportunity to move. I therefore believe that it is right for the European Union to allocate part of its funds to contribute to the security of the citizens living in Lebanon. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal, which lays the foundations for greater cooperation between Europe and the Lebanese Republic by concluding a well-defined cooperation programme.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Protocol, which contains a Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Lebanon in European Union programmes.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approved the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and the Member States and the Lebanese Republic, within the framework of a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the participation of the Lebanese Republic in Union programmes.  I voted in favour of the conclusion of this protocol, because I believe that it provides a fundamental framework in financial and technical matters to enable Lebanon to participate in Community programmes and, as such, to receive financial assistance from the Union. In fact, the protocol lays down clear rules on economic, financial and technical cooperation on EU programmes allowing Lebanon to participate.  This protocol strengthens cooperation between the EU and Lebanon, already trading partners and partners in the areas of human rights, democracy, political dialogue, cooperation in the fight against terrorism and money laundering.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Lebanese Republic is an important strategic partner of the European Union and the Member States, which has repeatedly demonstrated seriousness in meeting its commitments at international level, in particular within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP).  By its geographical and cultural proximity to Syria, the Lebanese Republic is the main destination for Syrian refugees. According to the statement of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, of 11 May 2016, there are more than 1.5 million refugees in the Lebanese Republic for an estimated population of 4.5 million. In this context, the Beirut Government had to take steps to ensure that asylum seekers could be received, accommodated, have access to education, the health care system and the labour market. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that it is necessary to establish the main measures of economic, financial and technical cooperation in order to provide technical assistance to this partner with whom we share a long-standing friendship.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Recommendation on a draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, concerning a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes. Bilateral trade between the EU and Lebanon continues to grow, with an average annual increase of 12.7% since 2008 and a total turnover of around €6.9 billion in 2014. The European Union is Lebanon's first trading partner and has an annual turnover of around one third of all Lebanese trade. In order to maintain this state of affairs, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the conclusion of the Protocol since this provides the right tools for the EU to reform, modernise and promote a seamless transition in the European Union’s neighbourhood and for Lebanon to participate in Community agencies and Community programmes. The aim of the European neighbourhood policy to achieve political and economic integration with the southern and eastern countries is crucially important. It is very important that Lebanon is given support through a strengthened relationship with the European Union.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Since Lebanon is a key partner of the Union in the Middle East, I support the idea that the European Union must engage more actively in promoting stability in that country.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report is a recommendation of the European Parliament on the Council's plan to conclude the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an association between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic. This protocol contains a framework agreement establishing the general principles, financial and technical rules allowing the Lebanese Republic to participate in the Union's programmes. The aim of this protocol is to define certain EU programmes. Considering that EU cooperation with Lebanon is essential, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of concluding the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon. As a partner country in the European Neighbourhood Policy since 2004, Lebanon will participate in EU programmes and receive EU assistance. The aim of this protocol is to promote reforms and modernization in Lebanon.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text on EU-Lebanon relations contributes to the updating of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements. These are the southern part of neighbourhood policy. Lebanon is destabilized by the arrival of about 1.5 million Syrian refugees in addition to Palestinian refugees. Added to this are the bloody incursions of the jihadists of the Islamic State group. Not only does the complexity of Lebanese issues and the political context of that country seem to escape the European oligarchy, but it should be remembered that the EU is not intended to play a role on the international stage. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles of the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes. Lebanon is part of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership, which promotes economic integration and democratic reform among 16 countries in North Africa and the Middle East. The European Neighbourhood Policy enables the EU to offer its neighbours a privileged relationship, building on a mutual commitment to common values such as democracy and human rights, the rule of law, good governance, market economy principles and sustainable development. Bilateral trade between the EU and Lebanon is increasing steadily, with gradual liberalisation of trade between the two sides of the agreement supporting Lebanon's economy and leading to the necessary security, stability and prosperity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are opposed to the aid of third countries through preferential trade agreements, when the peoples of many of the EU Member States (especially those of southern Europe) live in conditions of economic impoverishment by touching the limits of poverty.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: it should be remembered that the EU does not have to have an international role.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is intended to give its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement. Lebanon is of strategic importance to the EU in the Middle East on the issue of security and defence. The report notes that the EU wants to protect itself from new threats, such as terrorism. It also needs another country that will be a buffer for more refugees to arrive in Europe. The Agreement consists of a proposal for an association between the European Commission and the Republic of Lebanon to provide technical and financial support to the country, enabling it to participate in certain European programmes such as Horizon 2020, Cosme, Creative Europe. For the EU, there is little need for a collapsing Lebanon. The country has received thousands of refugees, there are problems with the Syrian border, with Israel, with the presence of the self-proclaimed Islamic State. The main objective of the euro-Mediterranean partnership is the economic integration and privileged relationship of these countries with the EU, and is inseparable from objectives of economic dominance and market colonization. The agreement opens the door to free trade agreements. It is part of the EU's political and economic agenda for the Middle East. These are reasons for our opposition.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the Euromed agreement on the participation of the Lebanese Republic in Union programmes. Our neighbourhood policy makes it possible to establish privileged relations with the Middle East, increasing bilateral trade that is beneficial to all EU Member States. The European Union is Lebanon's main trading partner, covering about a third of all Lebanese trade, which is why it is necessary to maintain and encourage this partnership, in order to pursue greater economic integration with reciprocal commitments and gains.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ Abstained. No opinion.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Protocol in question regulates the relationship and participation of the Republic of Lebanon in European Union programmes.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am opposed to supporting third countries through preferential trade agreements, when the peoples of many of the EU Member States (especially those in southern Europe) live in conditions of economic impoverishment by touching the limits of poverty. So my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Lebanon is a key partner for the EU in the Middle East. The country faces a fragile security environment, being at the forefront of the Syrian civil war, with over a million refugees out of four million of a total of the population. The EU must value strategic relations with Lebanon, and supports the country’s stability and security in a turbulent part of the world. To foster stability in Lebanon, developing capabilities and promoting people-to-people contacts and the transfer of the expertise is in our interest. The participation of Lebanon in the EU’s programmes is a way to tangibly support these strategic objectives. I support the Agreement as I believe we must engage with Lebanon more actively.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the Republic of Lebanon and the EU, and I therefore voted in favour of it. This gives countries that joined after 2004, including Hungary, the opportunity to accede to the Protocol.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Lebanese Republic, of the other part, concerning a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles of Lebanon's participation in Union programmes. The aim of the Protocol is, in fact, to define the financial and technical rules enabling the Lebanese Republic to participate in some of the Union's programmes and to consolidate financial, social and cultural cooperation and political dialogue between the two shores of the Mediterranean.  Relations between the EU and Lebanon are certainly one of the cornerstones of the foreign policy of the small country in the Middle East. Following a dramatic civil war lasting sixteen years, the country plays an important role in the complex framework of the Middle East and it is essential to ensure the political, economic and cultural proximity of the European Union as a whole in order to promote a full process of democratic transition and to resist the Islamist demands that would still cause unrest and tension in a country based on a fragile government balance.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the EU and Lebanon (Framework Agreement) because, as coordinator of my group for the ACP delegation, I believe that a good and close partnership policy on an equal footing in the Mediterranean is important and indispensable.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support Lebanon's participation in EU programmes. The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Lebanon now contains a framework agreement on the general principles for Lebanon's participation in the Union's programmes. In particular, it is intended to lay down the financial and technical rules.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am very much in favour of an agreement that includes and provides access to Lebanon for all EU programmes. Lebanon is an extraordinary country, a fundamental strategic partner, a country that is demonstrating much more strength and resilience than the European Union in managing the humanitarian emergency that involves and overwhelms it.  Lebanon is taking in 1.5 million refugees from Syria who are living in absolute poverty. The country is unable to provide economic assistance or ensure adequate reception conditions. Most refugee camps are spontaneous and there are no facilities.  Lebanon needs Europe and it is together, through effective cooperation, that solutions can be found to a situation of violence which forces thousands of people to flee. From Syria first to Lebanon, then to Turkey to Europe, all in order to escape Isis. It is precisely because we are all involved that cooperation and dialogue must be constant.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The framework agreements established an association between the EU and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in European Union programmes.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The 3 reports concern the EU-Lebanon cooperation framework and its participation in Union programmes.
