We have taken a position of abstention, because on the one hand it is the will of the Lebanese authorities, but on the other hand these agreements lead to free trade agreements with all the negative effects they have on the peoples and with which we naturally disagree.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this framework agreement between the EU and the Republic of Lebanon. This will now allow the Republic of Lebanon to participate in certain European Union programmes after the Commission determines the specific terms and conditions. Such actions are vital for economic, financial and technical cooperation, while it allows the Republic of Lebanon to receive assistance, in particular financial assistance, from the European Union pursuant to those programmes.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as I had no objections to its final terms.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Lebanon is a crucial partner for the EU in the Middle East. Having taken over a million refugees from the Syrian civil war, with a population of only four million, Lebanon is struggling. The EU needs to aid in stabilising the situation and engage more actively with Lebanon.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Lebanon, on the other hand, on the framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles of the Republic of Lebanon's participation in union programmes, as it strengthens cooperation between the EU and Lebanon and increases the Union's influence in the Middle East.  By participating in Union programmes, Lebanon is enabled to advance in certain areas and further promote union values and principles in the strategic part of South-West Asia. It is also important to stress that Lebanon must contribute financially to the EU budget for the specific programmes in which it participates. Therefore, I support the conclusion of this Protocol.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. These texts are the updating of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements, which are the southern part of the neighbourhood policy. They relate to EU-Lebanon relations for the first and the extension of these to the different incoming countries for the other two. Lebanon is now suffering further destabilization with the mass influx of Syrian refugees (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees, the bloody incursions of the Islamic State and the ongoing marginalization of the Sunni minority. This country does not need the interference of the European Union as an additional problem. I have taken issue with these three texts relating to the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the European Union and Lebanon.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this protocol, which will allow Lebanon to conclude participation agreements in the new Community programmes adopted in parallel with the EU's multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020.  Thanks to this protocol, Lebanon will be able to participate in certain Community programmes (research, innovation, support for SMEs, the environment) under the same conditions as EU Member States.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report of the colleague as I see that cooperation between the regions is of the utmost importance for the well-being of the people and it will only help in the procedure of modernisation and reform of the state.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 When approving the protocol to the EU-Lebanon Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, I abstained. Lebanon is a member of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership, which aims primarily at deeper economic cooperation with the 16 EU-neighbouring countries in North Africa and the Middle East. The purpose of the vote was to give parliament's consent or opposition to the PROTOCOL to the EU-Lebanon Agreement, while at the same time to make some formal changes to the agreement in relation to the accession of new states to the EU after its conclusion. Given that the agreement is generally aimed at gradually creating a free market between Lebanon and the EU, which could have some adverse economic consequences for Lebanon, I could not support the proposal. In my opinion, in general, when concluding economic cooperation agreements, it is necessary to take into account the negative effects that contracts may have on, for example, agriculture or industry in the country, and to try to limit them as much as possible. It is also necessary to lay down rules on respect for human rights in the treaties and to adjust sanctions for their violations. We will not find any such provisions in the agreement. On the other hand, I recognise that the will to conclude an agreement and gradually deepen economic cooperation between the EU and Lebanon has come directly from the Lebanese state authorities, which want to deepen cooperation.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur links the migration crisis with the call for countries to be strengthened in order to combat the causes of flight. This is to be welcomed, but this aid should be linked to clear and unambiguous commitments to readmission of migrants. As this report does not do so, I do not agree with the report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. Lebanon was once the Switzerland of the Middle East, where the population lived in a very wealthy and high degree of religious tolerance. However, this idyllic state did not correspond to certain forces, and the country descended into civil war and chaos between 1975 and 1990. The former place of life of ancient Christian cultures is slowly coming out of this difficult period, and I am confident that the Council decision on the Euro-Mediterranean Convention, cooperation between the EU and its member countries and Lebanon, and the country's participation in EU programmes can help.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the agreement between the European Union and Lebanon and the Protocol containing the framework agreement on the general principles of Lebanon's participation in EU programmes. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries, I believe that the agreement will have a positive impact on Lebanon and, through EU assistance, will contribute to greater stability, democratic institutions, political openness and economic development of the country. Due to the immediate challenges of the impact of the Syrian crisis, the foundations must be laid to help the country's long-term prosperity. The partnership with the EU will contribute to deepening democracy and respect for the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms. It will also contribute to the development of a sustainable and inclusive economy that reduces social and regional inequalities, creates jobs and improves the living standards of the population, increases productivity and provides protection of the natural environment. It should be noted that Lebanon, under peaceful conditions and stability, has very good prospects for economic development, as it has a good position in terms of water availability and fertile soil, and also has a high percentage of arable land as well as skilled labour.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Lebanon contains forecasts to be applied and enforced by all the partner countries of European policy with which these protocols are to be concluded. Its objective is to ensure the adequacy of the financial rules enabling the Republic of Lebanon to accede to certain European Union programmes.  The programme contained in the Protocol therefore defines the principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation, enabling the Republic of Lebanon to receive assistance, in particular financial assistance from the Union, under these programmes. However, I believe that Parliament's recommendation is to be welcomed and adopted, and I am therefore in favour of supporting it.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this protocol because I believe that the European Union does not have to have an international role.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon. The country of Cedar is now experiencing further destabilization with the mass arrival of Syrian refugees (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees, the bloody incursions of the Islamic State and the ongoing marginalization of the Sunni minority that does not bode well. It does not need the European Union as an additional problem to meddle in its affairs, as the subtlety of the Lebanese political game completely escapes the Community oligarchy, as evidenced by the last session of the Security and Defence Subcommittee. Moreover, it should be remembered that the European Union does not have to have an international role.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Lebanon, since the civil war (1975-1990), has been struggling to recover. New factors are complicating its recovery, including the massive influx of Syrian refugees (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees and bloody attacks by the Islamic State. Therefore, the European Union's updating of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements is of no help to it, as the subtle functioning of the Lebanese political balance is beyond the reach of the European elites. It is preferable to curb any intention of interference on the part of the EU, which does not have to replace Member States in international policy. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the protocol because the objective of the three Protocols to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Lebanon is to establish financial and technical standards enabling Lebanon to participate in certain European Union programmes. The specific terms and conditions for Lebanon's participation in each particular programme shall be determined by the negotiation of agreements between the Commission and the competent authorities in Lebanon.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that lays down a framework and rules for the Republic of Lebanon and its participation in certain EU programmes.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I am in support of free trade and cooperation agreements. However, I do not agree with the republic of Lebanon's integration into the European Union's programmes. The best way to make poorer countries richer is to loosen trade barriers, not send subsidies out of the pockets of European taxpayers.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption and entry into force of this Protocol will open the door to the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in the various European Union programmes under the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership. The Protocol as such defines the financial and technical rules for such future cooperation, with a primary step forward in the economic sphere, which is particularly important due to the current regional situation, as it has a clear and direct impact on all other areas. I am convinced that the closure of the Protocol will help to develop the links between the EU and Lebanon more actively and more productively, with all i welcome the positive results of the vote.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I vote against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes , because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against these three reports. Three reports are put to the vote of the European Parliament. These texts are a concrete translation of the European Union's Euro-Mediterranean policy. In this case, we oppose any interference in the affairs of the Lebanese state. In addition to the very principle of non-intervention in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, the country is currently experiencing a situation of great instability, due, on the one hand, to the mass immigration of Syrian and Palestinian refugees and, on the other hand, to the recurrent attacks of the Islamic State.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the recommendation supporting the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement setting up an Association between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the Lebanese Republic's participation in the Union's programmes.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This concerns the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Lebanon, on the other. The ENP provides for the gradual opening up of certain Union programmes and bodies to the ENP partner countries. To this end, the Council needs the assent of the European Parliament. On the other hand, this association agreement was not linked to an immigrant/asylum seeker readmission agreement. However, I believe that this would be essential. That is why I voted negatively here.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Lebanon is now experiencing serious domestic difficulties. In addition to the arrival of 1.5 million Syrian exiles, the number of Palestinian refugees already present is added. I believe that this country does not need in its affairs the European Union, which has no legitimacy in a foreign policy role. Moreover, the Union's very limited understanding of the phenomena occurring in that State lends itself to a justified reservation on this agreement. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Protocol is to establish the financial and technical rules enabling the Republic of Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol defines the principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Republic of Lebanon to receive technical assistance, in particular financial assistance, from the European Union in accordance with eu programmes. This framework applies only to programmes whose constitutive legal acts provide for the possibility of participation of the Republic of Lebanon. Therefore, the conclusion of the Protocol does not involve the exercise of powers under the various sectoral policies provided for in the programmes, which are exercised when the programmes are established. Hence my assent.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Protocol because of the inclusive practices that are established in this framework. Participation by the Republic of Lebanon in European Union programmes will have benefits in terms of economic development in both the EU and Lebanon.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the conclusion of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an association between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand and Lebanon on the other on a framework agreement on the general principles of that country's participation in the Union's programmes. This agreement falls within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) and the gradual opening up of certain European programmes to the countries that are part of the ENP. The protocol sets out, for example, rules for economic, financial and technical cooperation that will enable Lebanon to participate in important EU programmes as well as benefit from European technical and financial assistance. Lebanon is a country with which we must cooperate and which we must support in more ways than one. Let us remember that Lebanon hosts more than one million refugees for a population of approximately 6 million. I support this initiative enabling Lebanon to participate in the wide range of programmes open to ENP partner countries. This will strengthen and improve our international political relations with this country on issues such as economic stability or security.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because Lebanon is a key partner for the EU in the Middle East. The country faces a fragile security environment, being at the forefront of the Syrian civil war, with over a million refugees out of four million of a total of the population. The EU is interested in fostering stability in Lebanon, developing capabilities and promoting people-to-people contacts and the transfer of expertise.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted a draft decision on the conclusion of the Protocol on the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes annexed to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part. It must also obtain Parliament's consent in order to adopt the decision. In its report, the Committee on Foreign Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the Protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes deserves my favourable vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The EU has no international role to play. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which gives Parliament's approval for the conclusion of a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles of Lebanon's participation in certain EU programmes, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, which aims to promote relations between the EU and countries not intended to enter it on issues such as security , stability and the economy;

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the historical links and common values at the root of the closeness and interdependence between the European Union and Lebanon, In view of the fact that the Member States and Lebanon wish to consolidate these links and establish lasting relations based on reciprocity, solidarity, partnership and participation in development, I welcome the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States on the one hand , and the Lebanese Republic on the other.  Lebanon is a partner of strategic importance to the European Union in the Middle East. The country currently has precarious security conditions, being involved in the Syrian civil war, with over one million refugees out of a total population of four million. In this respect, I support the need to support the European Union's commitment to promoting stability, prosperity and security in Lebanon, in an ongoing dialogue between the parties that will seek to find new forms of cooperation for the achievement of common objectives.  Relations between the parties are based on respect for democratic principles and fundamental human rights set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which is an essential element of this Agreement.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon. The aim of the European Neighbourhood Policy is to promote economic and political development in the countries around Europe, thereby ensuring their stability. The importance of this is particularly felt now, at a time of migrant crisis. Thanks to the Neighbourhood Policy Convention, Lebanon can participate in EU programmes that make a major contribution to the success of reforms and modernisation in the country.  Last year, for example, a programme aimed primarily at increasing the capacity of Lebanese institutions in crisis situations was completed, with particular emphasis on basic and secondary schools hosting refugees. As always, in order for the programmes to function effectively, we must lay down the necessary financial and technical rules, for which this Protocol offers a great opportunity.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union aims to establish a common area of peace, stability and shared prosperity in the Euro-Mediterranean region. I voted for this recommendation that will update the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the EU and Lebanon by taking into account the enlargement of the EU.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I abstained on this vote which was on a framework agreement between the EU and Lebanon through the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership (Euromed). This agreement promotes economic integration and democratic reform across 16 countries to the EU’s south. It seeks greater integration within the region and is linked to the European neighbourhood policy which is aimed at offering its neighbours a privileged relationship. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its Eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. As this agreement is foreseen to lead to future trade agreements, I was against it in principle. However, as the Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Despite the fundamentally correct idea of solving the causes of flight on the ground, there is no clear commitment to readmission of migrants. Accordingly, I voted against the report.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On Mrs Mănescu's proposal, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour. Nowadays, a truly functioning EU neighbourhood policy requires the gradual opening of some EU programmes and agencies to partner countries affected by this policy. I therefore believe that the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement represents a significant step in this direction, as it regulates the financial and technical aspects that allow the Lebanese Republic to benefit from eu financial assistance in particular and to participate in Union programmes. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The Lebanese economy remains fragile. Regulatory inefficiency and uncertainty exacerbated by political instability and ongoing security threats by violent extremists continue to undermine private-sector activity and development. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol sets out principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Republic of Lebanon to receive assistance from the European Union pursuant to those programmes. EU development aid goes to 150 countries around the world and I believe Lebanon should be one of them. Hence, I supported the report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The European Neighbourhood Policy was created not only to help achieve close cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and its closest neighbours, but also to contribute to strengthening democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights in the countries where it is implemented, as well as their economic and social growth and development. Political, economic and social reforms are the basis on which this policy and good cooperation are based. Lebanon has recently undergone a turbulent period in which we have recently witnessed both terrorist attacks, which pose a threat to both Lebanon and the whole world. Therefore, I consider this Agreement and Lebanon's further rapprochement with the European Union and mutual cooperation as a good move on the road to further stabilisation of the country, the creation of reforms that are needed, but also the strengthening of the Lebanese Republic through the support of the European Union.  With this Protocol, we will establish rules that will allow Lebanon to participate in action plans created specifically for the needs of Lebanon and its inhabitants. The Protocol adopts standard rules applicable to all signatory countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy. It contributes to the betterment of the signatory countries, but also to the citizens of the European Union.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Lebanon is a key partner for the EU in the Middle East. The country faces a fragile security environment, particularly due to the Syrian war, from more than 1 million refugees to 4 million in total. The EU is interested in fostering stability in Lebanon, developing capabilities and promoting direct contacts and knowledge transfer. I join an already broad consensus at committee level on the need to further engage in efforts to help Lebanon. I also support this report.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 Lebanon is the EU's strategic partner in the Middle East. The country is particularly vulnerable to security threats in view of its war-sauling neighbourhood with Syria. Currently, Lebanon has granted asylum to some 1 million refugees whom the EU is trying to help through newly created trust funds. It is therefore in the EU's highest interest to strengthen stability in the country and develop capacities to cope with the difficult current situation. I am glad that there has been a broad consensus on the need to strengthen cooperation and support for Lebanon on the report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Among the many measures of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) aimed at promoting reforms and modernisation in the Eu ropean Union's neighbouring states, the gradual opening up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of the partner countries concerned. Protocols have so far been signed with Armenia, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Moldova, Morocco and Ukraine.  In December 2013, the Lebanese Republic said it was interested in participating in the wide variety of programmes open to european neighbourhood policy partner countries. The Protocol contains a framework agreement on the general principles of Lebanon's participation in Union programmes. In accordance with Article 218(6) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Council must obtain the assent of the European Parliament before concluding this Protocol.  I voted in favour of the European Parliament's approval so that cooperation between the EU and Lebanon can be strengthened.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for this protocol containing a framework agreement on the general principles (mainly technical and financial rules) of Lebanon's participation in various European Union programmes, particularly within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution by which the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement creating an Association between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the Lebanese Republic's participation in the Union's programmes. This agreement, and the two protocols that have been voted on in this plenary session, lay down economic, financial and technical rules to enable Lebanon to participate in certain European Union programmes. The specific terms and conditions for Lebanon's participation in each particular programme shall be determined by the negotiation of agreements between the Commission and the competent authorities in Lebanon.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This protocol contains a framework agreement on the general principles of Lebanon's participation in EU programmes. It includes standard conditions to be applied to all partner countries concerned by the European Neighbourhood Policy with which such protocols must be concluded. The aim of the protocol is to define the financial and technical rules allowing the Lebanese Republic to participate in certain EU programmes. The horizontal framework created by the protocol sets out the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Lebanese Republic to receive EU assistance, in particular financial assistance, under those programmes.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Lebanon is an important partner of the European Union, both in terms of trade and, more importantly, security. The fundamental principle of the European Union is to create security through inclusion. The adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon laying down the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes will therefore significantly facilitate the convergence, mutual understanding of the EU and Lebanon and, if not, the strengthening of security in the region, at least for the long-term prevention of crises.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Under the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the progressive opening of European Union (EU) programmes and agencies to partner countries integrated into it is one of many measures to promote reforms, modernisation and transition in those countries. On 18.06.2007 the Commission launched negotiations for the signing of framework agreements with partner countries under the ENP. To date, Protocols have been signed with Armenia, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Moldova, Morocco and Ukraine. In December 2013, Lebanon expressed its interest in participating in the wide range of programmes open to these partner countries. The Protocol in question includes a Framework Agreement on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in EU programmes, which also contain standardised provisions, equal to those applied to all other partner countries concerned. With the main objective of establishing financial and technical rules enabling Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes, the horizontal framework established by the Protocol defines principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation, allowing Lebanon to receive EU assistance, in particular in the financial field, in line with the programmes established. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives Parliament the approval of the Council's conclusion of a protocol to the EU-Lebanon Euro-Mediterranean agreement. This protocol contains a framework agreement on the general principles of Lebanon's participation in EU programmes. It includes standard conditions and sets out the financial and technical rules for Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. By this vote, Parliament allows Lebanon to have the conditions if it wishes to participate in EU programmes such as Horizon 2020, for example.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic. The agreement is part of the Neighbourhood Policy, one of the EU's pillars in its relations with third countries. Often described as a weak civil power at international level, Europe has over time demonstrated the goodness of its foreign policy, capable of establishing friendly and lasting relations with its neighbours.  They are eligible for financial assistance in the case of Lebanon from Europe, in accordance with the conditions laid down in the European programmes in question. Let us remember that Lebanon is currently facing a much more serious migration crisis than the European one, with migratory flows three times greater than those that have poured into Europe. Because of its geographical position, this country represents the destination of millions of Syrian refugees who, because of the war, seek shelter there.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the recommendation of rapporteur Ramona Mănescu, on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Lebanese Republic, of the other part, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus , the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, the Republic of Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic. This change was necessary and I am glad that it was made.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the participation of the Lebanese Republic in Union programmes', as it is important on the one hand. strengthen such partnerships and, at the same time, establish firm rules.  All third countries must follow rules on economic, financial and technical cooperation in order to receive support, including financial support, from the EU and its programmes.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I voted against this report because these types of agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the popular classes of the countries and States concerned.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Lebanon is a member of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership (Euromed) which promotes integration and democratic reforms in the 16 countries bordering North Africa and the Middle East with the European Union. As trade relations between Lebanon and the EU have been growing by an average of 12.7% since 2008 and given that the European Neighbourhood Policy provides for privileged relations with euromed members, I have decided to vote in favour of this recommendation allowing the Lebanese Republic to participate in European Union programmes.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. This Protocol seeks to define financial and technical rules enabling Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. The horizontal framework established by this Protocol lays down the principles for measures in the field of economic, financial and technical cooperation and enables Lebanon to receive technical assistance, and in particular financial assistance from the European Union, on the basis of European Union programmes.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EU-Lebanon Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, as it is mainly about clarifying the technical and financial rules relating to Lebanon's participation in Union programmes. The agreement is part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), which allows partner countries access to EU programmes and agencies. This is one of the instruments by which the EU supports reforms and modernisation in its neighbourhood. Similar agreements have been negotiated with several countries since 2007, and so far protocols have been signed with Armenia, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Moldova, Morocco and Ukraine. Lebanon expressed its interest in acceding to these programmes in 2013. Lebanon will thus have access to technical and financial assistance, which should enable the country to improve its public policies. As Lebanon is currently mired in instability in its region, an agreement with the EU could bring the support the country needs.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Lebanon Euro-Mediterranean Agreement is important for the EU as it will provide an appropriate framework for north-south political dialogue ensuring the gradual liberalisation of trade in the Mediterranean area.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The main objective of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Lebanon (framework agreement) is to lay down financial and technical rules enabling the Republic of Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol lists the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Republic of Lebanon to receive technical assistance, in particular financial assistance, to be provided by the Union in accordance with its programmes. This framework applies only to those EU programmes for which the possibility of participation of the Republic of Lebanon is foreseen in the relevant founding legal acts. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament has given its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, on the framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles of participation of the Republic of Lebanon in the Union programmes. The recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs was also taken into account when giving consent. I support the adoption of this protocol as I believe that this will improve relations between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the participation of the Lebanese Republic in Union programmes. I support Lebanon's participation in several Union programmes. The agreement should specify Lebanon's financial contribution, reporting and evaluation procedures, and participation as observers on points concerning Lebanon and in the programmes to which Lebanon contributes financially.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought that promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion approving the Additional Protocol in order to contribute to the swift application of the amendment to the legal framework of the previous agreement between Lebanon and the European Communities, which was essentially drawn up more than two years ago. I believe that the modernisation of the legal basis for cooperation between the European Union and Lebanon, including the possibility for the Lebanese side to participate in EU programmes, adapted to the present circumstances, is particularly important at a time when Lebanon is playing a major role in international efforts to address migration to Europe and the refugee crisis in the region.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union places particular emphasis on strengthening and developing relations with the countries of the Mediterranean basin. This direction became evident with the development of the revolutions in the so-called "Arab Spring" between 2011 and 2012. Relations with Lebanon date well before these events, with close cooperation between the two sides and constant ASSISTANCE provided by the EU in the context of efforts to rebuild the Lebanese state after decades of civil war. Naturally, the Lebanese State has been included, from the outset, among the partner countries under the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, but also among the countries within the European Neighbourhood Policy on the Southern Cooperation Dimension. With relations between the EU and Lebanon at a new historic stage, characterised by enhanced economic and political cooperation and cooperation in the field of combating Islamic terrorism and illegal migration, it is time to sign the Agreement on the Association of that State with the European Union. That document will further normalize the internal situation in Lebanon, including reconciliation between all ethnic and religious groups, as well as speeding up the reconstruction of the country and proper management of the Palestinian refugee issue. I believe that this is a necessary measure and I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I supported the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, concerning a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles of the Lebanese Republic's participation in EU programmes.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ In 2013, Lebanon expressed its interest in participating in the broad range of programmes open to partner countries of the European neighbourhood policy. The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, which is a response to this expression of interest, establishes an association between the EU, its Member States and Lebanon and aims to define the financial and technical rules permitting Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. I voted in favour of this Protocol, as I believe that Lebanon is a key partner of the European Union in the region. Promoting dialogue, cooperation and exchange with our Lebanese counterparts will hopefully improve diplomatic relations between our citizens, contribute to the development of Lebanon, and increase the chances for peace in this very fragile region.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I voted for a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles of participation of the Republic of Lebanon in the Union programmes. The objective of the Protocol is to lay down financial and technical rules allowing the Lebanese Republic to participate in certain Union programmes.  Since the Horizontal Framework established by the Protocol specifies the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Lebanese Republic to receive assistance, in particular financial assistance provided by the Union under those programmes, that framework applies only to those Union programmes for which the possibility of participation of the Lebanese Republic is foreseen in the relevant founding legal acts.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Recommendation on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes. The Protocol contains a framework agreement on the general principles for the participation of Lebanon in Union programmes. It contains the standard conditions to be applied to all ENP partner countries with which such protocols will be concluded. The objective of the Protocol is to lay down financial and technical regulations enabling the Republic of Lebanon to participate in certain Union programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol lays down the principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation enabling the Republic of Lebanon to receive assistance, in particular financial assistance from the Union under these programmes.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. I voted against this protocol because the European Union does not have to have an international role and because the intricacies of the Lebanese political game are completely beyond the reach of the Community oligarchy.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 This document concerns the draft Protocol to the Protocol on the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes annexed to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, the Republic of Lebanon. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon on the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Lebanon in Union programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol sets out principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Republic of Lebanon to receive assistance, in particular financial assistance, from the European Union pursuant to the programmes.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. – The main objective of this protocol is to establish the technical and financial rules enabling the Republic of Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. This framework agreement lays down the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation, allowing the Republic of Lebanon to receive EU assistance, especially in the financial field. It is vitally important to establish such agreements to aid economic development in the Mediterranean basin, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this protocol.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report on the framework agreement because I believe that the EU should work more closely with Lebanon to help deter further radicalisation and migration.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This recommendation deals thematically with the framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the participation of the Lebanese Republic in Union programmes.  It is also a question of combating the causes of flight on the ground, an effort which I certainly support. However, if, as here, concessions are made by the EU without being bound by obligations to take back illegal migrants, then I consider this to be irresponsible.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs approving the conclusion of a protocol on Euro-Mediterranean cooperation with Lebanon. The members of the committee responsible took note of the draft Council decision and supported this initiative by a large majority.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement of association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the participation of the Lebanese Republic in Union programmes. I believe that the EU-Lebanon Euro-Mediterranean agreement will bring positive results and strengthen cooperation between the EU and Lebanon.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Pursuant to art. 218 TFEU, for the conclusion of association agreements between the EU, Member States and third countries, Parliament must give its consent. The Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon is an indispensable instrument for the implementation of a coherent and innovative neighbourhood policy aimed at strengthening the prosperity, stability and security of neighbouring countries. This establishes a political dialogue aimed not only at economic issues, such as public procurement and state aid, but also at social issues, such as respect for human rights, access to services and labour regulations. Trusting in the value of such political and social cooperation, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. These texts deal with the updating of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements, which are the southern part of the neighbourhood policy. They concern relations between the EU and Lebanon for the first and enlargement to the different incoming countries for the other two. I voted against these texts, which constitute interference by the European Union in the affairs of a state already facing the massive influx of refugees, the bloody incursions of the Islamic State or the ongoing marginalization of the country's Sunni minority. The EU has no international role to play.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ Similar to the previous framework vote, this vote concerned greater economic integration between the EU and Lebanon in the framework of the European neighbourhood policy. The European neighbourhood policy is aimed at offering its neighbours a privileged relationship. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its Eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. This vote was on a legal text to add the names of those countries that joined the EU in the 2004 enlargement to the official documents. As this agreement is foreseen to lead to future trade agreements, I was against it in principle. However, as the Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation. The European Union has strategic relations with Lebanon. We support the stability of this country and its security in a region of the world in the midst of severe turbulence. Lebanon's participation in EU programmes is a way to concretely support these strategic objectives.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This Recommendation, which I voted in favour of, concerns the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, to take account of accession to the European Union of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania , the Republic of Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic. We await its notification to the relevant institutions and governments.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The proposed text is an update of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements. It concerns EU-Lebanon relations for the first and the extension of these to the different incoming countries for the other two. Lebanon is now experiencing further destabilization with the mass influx of Syrian refugees (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees. It does not need the European Union as an additional problem to meddle in its affairs. The subtlety of the Lebanese political game completely escaped the Community oligarchy, I voted against the protocol.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This agreement, updating the southern part of the neighbourhood policy, concerns the enlargement of EU-Lebanon relations to the various countries that have recently entered the agreement. I voted against him, believing that there is no reason for the Union to dictate their foreign policy to the Member States. Moreover, I cannot accept that an agreement whose harmful effects I denounce for both Lebanon and my country should be extended to other countries.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this protocol to include the 10 Member States of the 2004 enlargement to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon. As full members of the Union, it makes sense for the Czech Republic, Estonia, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Hungary, Malta, Poland, Slovenia and Slovakia to join this agreement.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Mănescu report approving a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community, with its Member States, and the Lebanese Republic. This is an important text that allows us to take into account the 2004 enlargement of the EU, which led to the entry into the Union of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, Hungary, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic.  The agreement strengthens the neighbourhood policy, responding to two requirements: on the one hand, the 2013 request of the Middle East state to have closer links with the Union will be met, and on the other hand the reform processes and stability of a country that, occupying a strategic position in an area extremely at risk, represents a fundamental ally in the fight against Daesh and Islamic terrorism.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon following the enlargement of 2004 and the 8 new countries entering at the time: Cyprus, Malta, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Slovenia.  As with the previous recommendation, the EU has no international role to play and foreign policy must be the responsibility of states. Lebanon does not need European interference in its national problems. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 There are some passages in this report that I do not support that have prompted me to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution by which the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Czech Republic , the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic. This agreement, and the two protocols that have been voted on in this plenary session, lay down economic, financial and technical rules to enable Lebanon to participate in certain European Union programmes. The specific terms and conditions for Lebanon's participation in each particular programme shall be determined by the negotiation of agreements between the Commission and the competent authorities in Lebanon.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it approves, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic to the European Union.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The enlargement of the European Union requires that the agreements in force reflect the real situation, so I voted in favour of the adoption of the amendment.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Lebanon does not need the EU to meddle in its affairs; it has enough problems related to the mass influx of Syrian refugees in addition to Palestinian refugees.   Added to this is that the EU does not have to have an international role. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – Similar to the previous framework vote, this vote concerned greater economic integration between the EU and Lebanon in the framework of the European neighbourhood policy. The European neighbourhood policy is aimed at offering its neighbours a privileged relationship. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its Eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. This vote was on a legal text to add the names of those countries that joined the EU in the 2004 enlargement to the official documents. As this agreement is foreseen to lead to future trade agreements, I was against it in principle. However, as the Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is correct that the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, Hungary, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic, now that they are fully part of the European Union, should also participate in the comprehensive partnership and/or cooperation agreements that the EU signs with foreign states. We consider this to be a due act.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to update the Euro-Mediterranean agreements, ratified within the framework of the European Union's neighbourhood policy. Lebanon is currently plagued by serious internal unrest, particularly as a result of the massive influx of Syrian migrants in addition to Palestinian refugees. The country of Cedar is also suffering from the bloody incursions of the Islamic State. However, the European Union has demonstrated in the past that it has no legitimacy and credibility to interfere in internal affairs in a third country. On the one hand, the Union must respect the principle of non-interference; on the other hand, foreign policy remains an exclusive competence of the Member States. That is why I objected to this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The involvement of partner countries in the European Neighbourhood Policy is also transposed through various agreements—key. The Lebanese Republic's interest in participating in Union programmes and agencies open to partner states through the European Neighbourhood Policy has been materialised through a protocol with standard provisions containing an agreement—framework on the general principles of Lebanon's participation. The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Lebanese Republic, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles of the Lebanese Republic's participation in Union programmes, aims to establish financial and technical rules, and at the same time , measures of economic, financial, technical cooperation. This report aims to take into account the accession to the Union of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, the Republic of Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic. I consider it essential to participate equally and to provide fair premises for involvement in the actions of the Union of all Member States, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I believe that we need an additional protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement that takes due account of the enlargement of the European Union in 2004. This Protocol is an adaptation to the Association Agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Lebanon on the other. The aim of this adjustment is to place the emphasis on the accession of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, Hungary, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic to the European Union. Respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights is an essential element of the Association Agreement in question and of the Protocol. Over and above the bilateral nature and peculiarities of each partner State, the Association Agreement and its Protocol reflect a similar pattern and thus aim to promote regular dialogue in political and security matters, in order to promote mutual understanding, cooperation, joint initiatives, economic, commercial and financial cooperation. The protocol aims, above all, to promote the progressive liberalisation of trade, sustainable development and investment.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ Similar to the previous framework vote, this vote concerned greater economic integration between the EU and Lebanon in the framework of the European neighbourhood policy. The European neighbourhood policy is aimed at offering its neighbours a privileged relationship. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its Eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. This vote was on a legal text to add the names of those countries that joined the EU in the 2004 enlargement to the official documents. As this agreement is foreseen to lead to future trade agreements, I was against it in principle. However, as the Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Lebanon on the principles and standards for the participation of Lebanon in certain EU programmes in order to take into account the 2004 enlargement of the EU. I welcome this Agreement which will be of benefit to both sides.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the EU and Lebanon aimed at sanctioning the accession of a whole series of states that are now EU Members, such as: the Czech Republic, Estonia, Cyprus, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland and the Slovak Republic. This agreement is a fundamental instrument of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the accession of which by all Member States is essential for the success of the objectives of cooperation with Lebanon.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the agreement and consider the results of the negotiations between the Commission and the Republic of Lebanon to be satisfactory.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision concerns the conclusion of an Association Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Lebanon to take account of the accession of States to the European Union after the 2004 enlargement. This debate is part of wider EU cooperation with the Lebanese State and, as it is primarily aimed at economic issues, I do not think it has the interests of citizens at the forefront. That is why I abstained.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this proposal, which simply represents the accession of ten Countries of the Union to the agreement concluded with the Lebanese Republic. In fact, negotiations began in 1998, and these countries had not yet joined the European Union. I therefore think it is right that, with accession to the European Union, they should also be included in the agreements concluded with third countries.  In my opinion, it is very important to safeguard the security of Lebanese citizens who face many threats and therefore countries that are not yet part of the agreement should be included. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Protocol, which contains a Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Lebanon in European Union programmes.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The accession of ten new States to the EU in 2004 also affected the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the European Community and the Member States and the Lebanese Republic. Taking note of this change, the European Parliament has adopted a resolution on the conclusion of this protocol, which I intended to approve by means of my vote in favour.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Lebanese Republic is an important partner of the European Union in the Mediterranean Area, representing a key link between European states and the Middle East. Friendly relations, long cultural, political and economic cooperation, together with commitments to strengthen democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights, make this partnership successful. As I consider it important for all Member States to benefit from this agreement, I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Lebanese Republic, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Czech Republic to the European Union of the Czech Republic , the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, the Republic of Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Recommendation on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic to the European Union. Lebanon is a Member State of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership (Euromed) that supports economic integration and democratic reforms in all sixteen countries neighbouring the EU from the south, i.e. North Africa and the Middle East. Partnership is an essential tool for building greater economic integration in the region. I personally support economic integration and partnership in all areas of the EU, which is why I voted yes.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to include the 10 new Member States (2004 enlargement) in the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the European Union and Lebanon, taking into account the changes outlined in the Treaty of Lisbon. The Protocol reflects the EU’s commitment to support Lebanon in sustainably addressing the consequences of regional instability, a refugee crisis and a presidential vacuum.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. Between 1998 and 2005, the European Union concluded Euro-Mediterranean association agreements with nine Mediterranean countries to replace the cooperation agreements of the 1970s. The provisions of these association agreements, which govern bilateral relations, vary from one Mediterranean partner to another.  These agreements give adequate discipline to the political dialogue between North and South and serve as a basis for the progressive liberalisation of trade in the Mediterranean area, establishing the conditions for economic, social and cultural cooperation between the European Union and the partner countries.  The aim of these agreements, and in particular in this recommendation with Lebanon (whose agreement entered into force on 1 April 2006), is to make the Mediterranean a common area of prosperity, peace and stability, thanks to economic, social, cultural and financial cooperation, and the strengthening of political and security dialogue.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report is a recommendation of the European Parliament on the Council's plan to conclude a Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic. This protocol aims to take into account the accession of the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Cyprus, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Republic of Slovenia and the Slovak Republic to the European Union. Considering the EU's cooperation with Lebanon is essential and that the enlargement of 2004 should be taken into account, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported the report on the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon to include the 10 Member States of the 2004 enlargement. The Czech Republic, Estonia, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Hungary, Malta, Poland, Slovenia and Slovakia must be included in the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text on EU-Lebanon relations contributes to the updating of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements. These are the southern part of neighbourhood policy. Lebanon is destabilized by the arrival of about 1.5 million Syrian refugees in addition to Palestinian refugees. Added to this are the bloody incursions of jihadists from the Islamic State group. Not only does the complexity of Lebanese issues and the political context of that country seem to escape the European oligarchy, but it should be remembered that the EU is not intended to play a role on the international stage. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
