Like the previous votes on the Framework Agreement between the EU and Lebanon, which I supported and which are vital for economic, financial and technical cooperation between the two regions, account needed to be taken of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this protocol as I had no concerns with its final format.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision regarding the stabilisation of Lebanon, having regarded the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement. This is a procedure of a technical nature arising from the membership of the abovementioned states in the European Union, which constitutes natural and consistent treatment, and I therefore support this Recommendation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. These texts are the updating of the Euro-Mediterranean agreements, which are the southern part of the neighbourhood policy. They relate to EU-Lebanon relations for the first and the extension of these to the different incoming countries for the other two. Lebanon is now suffering further destabilization with the mass influx of Syrian refugees (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees, the bloody incursions of the Islamic State and the ongoing marginalization of the Sunni minority. This country does not need the interference of the European Union as an additional problem. I have taken issue with these three texts relating to the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the European Union and Lebanon.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ensure that the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the Eurozone and Lebanon takes into account the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. – I have voted for the report of the colleague as I see that cooperation between the regions is of the utmost importance for the well-being of the people and it will only help in the procedure of modernisation and reform of the state.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report is purely technical and concerns an additional protocol between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Lebanon, on the other, on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and the Republic of Romania to the European Union. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. As with the two previous reports, the aim of this draft is to define the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EU and its Member States on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic on the other, so as to take into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. Parliament approved the conclusion of this protocol. The Latter defines all aspects aimed at ensuring financial, economic and technical cooperation, capable of dealing with the difficulties that will arise. I believe that Parliament's recommendation should be adopted, and I am therefore in favour of supporting it.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon. This component takes into account the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union in 2004. The country of Cedar is now experiencing further destabilization with the mass arrival of Syrian refugees (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees, the bloody incursions of the Islamic State and the ongoing marginalization of the Sunni minority that does not bode well. It does not need the European Union as an additional problem to meddle in its affairs, as the subtlety of the Lebanese political game completely escapes the Community oligarchy, as evidenced by the last session of the Security and Defence Subcommittee. Moreover, it should be remembered that the European Union does not have to have an international role.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to integrate Bulgaria and Romania into the Euro-Mediterranean agreements between the European Union and Lebanon. This is therefore the continuation of the process of integrating these new Member States into all European agreements and treaties. However, I believe that the EU does not have to take the place of the Member States in terms of international policy. The country of Cedar is undergoing major destabilization, such as the massive influx of Syrian migrants (1.5 million) in addition to Palestinian refugees, and the bloody and unannounced attacks of the Islamic State, and does not need further European interference. I voted against it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I am staying with the accession of the new Member States to the existing agreement.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Similar to a number of other agreements and protocols, the Protocol for the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Lebanon required it to be adapted to the fact of territorial enlargement of the Union so that cooperation could take place comprehensively and fully between all EU Member States and a third country. In particular, this vote concerned the enlargement of 2007, when Bulgaria and Romania joined the European Union. Given the specifics of the vote, I have unequivocally voted positively. At the same time, I would like to stress that it is necessary for the relevant vote to take place as soon as possible, also as regards Croatia's accession to the Union in 2013.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, to take account of accession to the European Union of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania, because it is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against these three reports. Three reports are put to the vote of the European Parliament. These texts are a concrete translation of the European Union's Euro-Mediterranean policy. In this case, we oppose any interference in the affairs of the Lebanese state. In addition to the very principle of non-intervention in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, the country is currently experiencing a situation of great instability, due, on the one hand, to the mass immigration of Syrian and Palestinian refugees and, on the other hand, to the recurrent attacks of the Islamic State.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – Regarding the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Lebanon(accession of Bulgaria and Romania), I voted in favour of it. The accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the Protocol will enhance the European Community’s cohesion and enlarge its impact, and more opportunities will be provided to these countries as well. The accession is a win-win strategy, and there is no controversy for this implementation.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This vote is purely formal in nature. It is due to the fact that Bulgaria and Romania must be included in the protocol after their accession to the EU. That is why I abstained.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Lebanon is now experiencing serious domestic difficulties. In addition to the arrival of 1.5 million Syrian exiles, the number of Palestinian refugees already present is added. I believe that this country does not need in its affairs the European Union, which has no legitimacy in a foreign policy role. Moreover, the Union's very limited understanding of the phenomena occurring in that State lends itself to a justified reservation on this agreement. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Protocol is to establish the financial and technical rules enabling the Republic of Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol defines the principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Republic of Lebanon to receive technical assistance, in particular financial assistance, from the European Union in accordance with eu programmes. This framework applies only to programmes whose constitutive legal acts provide for the possibility of participation of the Republic of Lebanon. Therefore, the conclusion of the Protocol does not involve the exercise of powers under the various sectoral policies provided for in the programmes, which are exercised when the programmes are established. It takes into account the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to the European Union.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because the inclusion of Bulgaria and Romania enhances the internal market and renews movement towards better trade relations between Member States and associated members.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I am in favour of the conclusion of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. For a coherent integration and a united and strong Union, it is important to facilitate the accession of new members to the European Union to the international treaties and agreements specific to Europe and which form the Community's achievements. This project does not change the substance of the Euro-Mediterranean agreement with Lebanon. I think it is essential to allow Romania and Bulgaria access to this agreement because that is the essence of the European Union. We have already taken this decision when we signed the agreement of these two countries to join the European Union, the rest is in line with this logic.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls on establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, which is important with regard of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the enlargement of the Union in 2014, the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, took into account the acceding of the Republic of Cyprus, the Czech Republic, the Republic of Estonia, the Republic of Latvia, the Republic of Lithuania, Hungary, the Republic of Malta, the Republic of Poland, the Slovak Republic and the Republic of Slovenia to the European Union. The Council adopted a draft decision on the conclusion of the protocol on this, but it must also obtain Parliament's consent to adopt the decision. In its report, the Committee on Foreign Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the Protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Lebanon, on the other hand, taking into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The EU has no international role to play. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which proposed the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an association between the European Community and the Lebanese Republic. As member countries of the European Union, the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania naturally join the agreement.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 After the conditions of accession were fulfilled, in 2007, Bulgaria and Romania became Member States of the European Union, which included participation in agreements with third countries. I also voted in favour of the addition of two new Member States to the Protocol to the EU-Lebanon Association.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union aims to establish a common area of peace, stability and shared prosperity in the Euro-Mediterranean region. I have voted for this recommendation that will update the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the EU and Lebanon by taking into account of the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This particular vote was on a legal text to add the names of Bulgaria and Romania, who joined the EU in 2009, to the official documents. I had concerns with this report as one of its aims is to increase economic integration between the EU and Lebanon in the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. In practice however, this policy has been criticised hugely for its eurocentricity, hypocritical attitude towards some of the conditionality requirements and damage that can be done to indigenous sectors. However, as Lebanese authorities have taken the decision themselves to enhance cooperation, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This is a purely technical vote, bulgaria and Romania are to be included in the Protocol after their accession to the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the draft Council decision and the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Given that the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union requires the conclusion of agreements between the EU and third countries to involve all the Member States of the Union, I felt it was right to vote in favour. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the Member States of the European Union, on the one hand, the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, signed in 2002, primarily creates a framework for political dialogue, sets the conditions for liberalisation of trade in the Mediterranean area in accordance with World Trade Organisation rules, encourages trade and the expansion of economic relations between signatory countries, and promotes economic, social, cultural, financial and monetary cooperation between the European Union and Mediterranean countries and contributes to ensuring peace stability, economic and social development and technological progress. This agreement is important for the development of regular political dialogue on bilateral and international issues and for the development of close relations on matters of common interest.  Since the Republics of Bulgaria and Romania have been members of the European Union and full stakeholders of its policy since 1 January 2007, I have supported this Protocol in order to better and more efficiently arrange relations between Bulgaria and Romania, as a Member State of the European Union, and the Republic of Lebanon, as one of the parties to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement. The adoption of this Protocol, will allow the Republics of Bulgaria, Romania and Lebanon to establish more efficient partnerships, expand harmonious economic and social relations, and co-operation will be of great importance for both imports of industrial products and trade in agricultural and fish products.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Lebanon is a key partner for the EU in the Middle East. The country faces a fragile security environment, particularly due to the Syrian war, from more than 1 million refugees to 4 million in total. The EU is interested in fostering stability in Lebanon, developing capabilities and promoting direct contacts and knowledge transfer. I join an already broad consensus at committee level on the need to further engage in efforts to help Lebanon. I also support this report as it is a technical update to the existing treaty which takes into account the 2007 EU enlargement.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical adjustment, which allows bulgaria and Romania to take into account the accession to the European Union in 2007, and thus enable them to be part of the cooperation framework of the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the Union and Lebanon.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution by which the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. This agreement, and the two protocols that have been voted on in this plenary session, lay down economic, financial and technical rules to enable Lebanon to participate in certain European Union programmes. The specific terms and conditions for Lebanon's participation in each particular programme shall be determined by the negotiation of agreements between the Commission and the competent authorities in Lebanon.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation. The Council's draft decision aims to ensure that the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, is approved on behalf of the European Community and its Member States, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 This issue does not require much discussion. Bulgaria's and Romania's EU membership has slightly changed our trade agreements with Lebanon. Today, we are simply legitimising the newly created situation. As far as I know, our trading partners are also satisfied with the proposal presented, so I am unequivocally voting in favour of the EU's trade with our important partner, Lebanon, to continue to develop freely, thereby contributing to the creation of a zone of prosperity and stability in the European neighbourhood.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union in 2007, this draft Council decision concerns the updating of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement with Lebanon (which had been signed in 2002), given the accession of those Member States to the European Union. This Agreement creates an association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Lebanon on the other. Like the recommendation taken in this regard with regard to the adoption in 2004 by 10 other Member States, and having no reason to object to the Council's decision, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows the enlargement of the European Union of 2007 to take into account in the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon. With this vote, the European Parliament approves the Council's decision to include Bulgaria and Romania in the European Union's relations with Lebanon.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the third recommendation to conclude a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EU and Lebanon. In this particular case, the text refers in particular to the extension of the agreement to Bulgaria and Romania, two countries that joined the EU in 2007. I voted in favour of the recommendation, aware of the importance and value of the association agreements that the European Union enters into in the Mediterranean region.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for Mrs Mănescu's draft report on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Lebanese Republic, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. Romania has always had good relations with Lebanon and this amendment to the protocol, to include Romania and Bulgaria, was necessary.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union", as it is important to document our progress in order to continue to work for a better partnership between the EU and the Lebanese Republic in the future.  Here we look at our cooperation with our new Member States and Lebanon in order to be able to make improvements when they are needed.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I voted against this report because these types of agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the popular classes of the countries and States concerned.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Protocol on the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement takes into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. I think it is important for all the current Members to sign this protocol, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. This Protocol seeks to define financial and technical rules enabling Lebanon to participate in certain EU programmes. This resolution concerning the Protocol is about taking account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EU-Lebanon Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, as it is mainly about clarifying the technical and financial rules relating to Lebanon's participation in Union programmes. The agreement is part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), which allows partner countries access to EU programmes and agencies. This is one of the instruments by which the EU supports reforms and modernisation in its neighbourhood. Similar agreements have been negotiated with several countries since 2007, and so far protocols have been signed with Armenia, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Moldova, Morocco and Ukraine. Lebanon expressed its interest in acceding to these programmes in 2013. Lebanon will thus have access to technical and financial assistance, which should enable the country to improve its public policies. As Lebanon is currently mired in instability in its region, an agreement with the EU could bring the support the country needs. I also agreed to extend this Protocol to Bulgaria and Romania, which joined the EU in 2007.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union must also be ratified in the light of international agreements, such as the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I agree to the conclusion of the Agreement taking into account the draft Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. Furthermore, I supported this decision in view of the position of the Committee on Foreign Trade, bearing in mind that Bulgaria and Romania became members of the Union in 2007.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The European Parliament has given its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement taking into account the draft Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. Consent was also given on the basis of a recommendation from the Foreign Trade Committee.  I support the conclusion of this Agreement because I consider that such a thing naturally stems from the fact that those countries are members of the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement concerning the association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. This approval of the Protocol, which is of a purely technical nature, also brings with the inclusion of Bulgaria and Romania, which were the last to join the European Union and were thus not parties to the original agreement.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought that promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion approving the Additional Protocol in order to contribute to the amendment of the legal framework of the previous agreement between Lebanon and the European Communities in accordance with the legal environment following the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU. In my view, the modernisation of the legal basis for cooperation between the European Union and Lebanon, adapted to the present circumstances, is particularly justified in the current period, when Lebanon has become an important partner of the EU in the Middle East region by placing a particular burden on international efforts to manage migration to Europe and the refugee crisis.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Cooperation with partner countries in the European Neighbourhood can only be successful if all the European Member States are involved. This is why I voted in favour of the recognition of the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU by the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement. This agreement establishes an association between the EU, its Member States and Lebanon, in view of increasing cooperation projects between the EU and Lebanon to foster stronger ties between Europeans and Lebanese and contributing to the continued development of Lebanon.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Lebanese Republic, on the other hand, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union.  Given the increasing situation in neighbouring Syria, the European Union supports the unity, stability, independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Lebanon. Around 1.1 million registered Syrian refugees currently reside in Lebanon, which has a population of 4.4 million, and therefore the Commission has provided over €550 million in humanitarian aid and support for lebanon's development and stabilisation, with regular envisaged cooperation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The purpose of the Council Decision is to establish a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, approved on behalf of the Union and its Member States, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. I therefore supported the recommendation on the Council decision on the conclusion of the said Protocol.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 This document concerns the draft Protocol annexed to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, with a view to taking into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We abstain in this vote by considering that, while such agreements seek to advance eminently economic-commercial integration that excludes fundamental dimensions of integration (such as respect for human rights in general and labour and women's rights in particular, free human mobility, recognition of academic qualifications, the treatment of environmental issues of common interest , and others), it is the citizens of the States that must choose the type and degree of partnership they wish to maintain with the EU.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. " I support this idea.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol sets out principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows the Republic of Lebanon to receive assistance, in particular financial assistance, from the European Union pursuant to the programmes. I believe that the participation of Bulgaria and Romania in this agreement is a natural consequence of their EU accession.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This protocol incorporates The Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Lebanon Bulgaria and Romania by the EU. That is why I believe it is necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement (Euromed) promotes the economic integration and reform of 16 neighbouring EU countries in North Africa and the Middle East. This partnership aims at greater economic integration in the region and states that the EU can offer its neighbours a privileged relationship that benefits both sides. Parliament was requested to adopt three mainly technical protocols in order to give its consent for the adoption of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and to add to the official documents the name of the countries of the 2004 enlargement and Bulgaria and Romania since its integration. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because such agreements lead to the establishment of free trade agreements which we oppose because of all their disastrous consequences for the majority of the population, but on the other hand I recognise the will of the Lebanese authorities, and respect for the decision of a sovereign country. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 The same protocol with Lebanon was to mention the last wave of EU enlargement (Romania and Bulgaria) and this was able to carry my approval.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. A recommendation on the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Lebanese Republic on the general principles for the participation of the Lebanese Republic in Union programmes. In particular, it concerns enlargement with regard to the Member States of Romania and Bulgaria.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for the conclusion of a protocol on relations between Lebanon, Bulgaria and Romania, within the framework of Euro-Mediterranean cooperation. The text tabled has been supported by most political forces.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement concerning the association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Lebanon, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. The approval of the Protocol allows the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU-Lebanon Euro-Mediterranean Agreement.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Principality of Monaco and the European Union signed, in 2005, an agreement on taxation that puts an end to banking secrecy, providing for an automatic exchange of financial information. The agreement, referring to the residents' financial accounts, will begin to take effect from 1 January 2017. While efforts and progress can be appreciated, it is also true that the text still has gaps and gaps in legislation, which can be easily circumvented, especially as far as transparency is concerned. In view of the importance of the fight against evasion, fraud and circumvention in European policies, I have chosen to abstain, hoping for stronger action in this area.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an indispensable step forward in the exchange of tax information with the Principality of Monaco. While the exchange of information has proved not sufficient for member states to take action against the continent's main tax evasors and elusors, it is an important step for states to identify such capitals and their owners. This is why the provisions of this agreement represent an objective improvement in the functioning of information exchanges with Monaco. Although such measures do not pursue a ban on the use of tax havens by European capital, it is an important step forward in being able to carry out more radical measures to make capital taxes where wealth is generated. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement between the EU and Monaco to increase cooperation against tax evasion and evasion. As with those with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino, I support this type of agreement providing for the automatic exchange of information on account income but also on their balance and asset disposal proceeds with the aim of eradicating tax evasion and evasion on Europe's doorstep.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which has the overall aim of reducing tax avoidance and evasion. Sinn Féin have been very active in Europe on the issue of tax avoidance and closing the loopholes which permit multinationals to engage in widespread tax avoidance and evasion. From playing an active role on TAXE and now on the Panama Papers, Sinn Féin will continue to ensure that multinationals are obliged to pay the taxes which they owe. This particular report approves the agreement that has been negotiated by the EU and Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial account information between EU Member States and Monaco relating to accounts of each other’s residents. Automatic exchange of information will take place from 2018 on information collected since the start of next year. Under the agreement, Monaco will apply measures equivalent to the EU’s on reporting the taxation of savings income, and come into line with the OECD’s 2014 standards. (There was a previous agreement on this in 2004 which Monaco is updating to current standards adopted in the EU in December 2014).

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC. This Agreement concerns the automatic exchange of financial account information and aims to improve cooperation and compliance in the international tax field.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The EU and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in order to improve international cooperation in tax matters and tax honesty in international situations.  The agreement is an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and is therefore desirable. I voted in favour of the agreement. It is expected to be in place from 1 January 2017.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. On 22 February 2016, the European Union and the Principality of Monaco signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information as part of a series of agreements between the EU and neighbouring states to increase cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. These agreements were one of the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy two years ago. Tax havens had to be avoided at the gates of the EU, where fraudsters could take refuge. The automatic exchange of information will always focus on the income of the accounts but also on their balance and the proceeds of asset disposal. I voted in favour of this report

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This protocol relates to the agreement on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts signed on 22 February between the EU and the Principality of Monaco; It is part of a series of agreements between the EU and neighbouring states aimed at increasing cooperation against tax evasion and evasion. For the record, these agreements were one of the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy two years ago. Tax havens should not be allowed to remain at the eu's doorstep, or within it, where fraudsters could take refuge. I had supported the previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted for this European agreement with Monaco, aimed at making it more difficult for European citizens to evade tax by hiding cash in bank accounts. As part of the agreement, the European Union and Monaco will automatically exchange information on their residents' bank accounts from 2017.  The European Union and Monaco signed an agreement on 22 February 2016 to combat tax evasion and evasion. The information that will be exchanged relates to income, such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and profits from the sale of financial assets.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Cooperation in the field of taxation is one of the priorities of the European agenda, a need that has led the Commission and the Government of the Principality of Monaco to conclude a new agreement on this subject in February this year. The signed text represents a considerable step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and represents a clear improvement on the previous agreement of 2004, which already ensured that Measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income were applied by Monaco.  I voted in favour of the Schwab report because I agree with the content of the agreement and believe that it can be a useful tool for strengthening the Union's action against tax crimes. The provisions on the exchange of information with Munich will be adapted to the new EU regulations and will comply with the procedures for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standard. Tax evasion will be more easily identified and unnecessary investigations will be avoided.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, where by which the EU and Monaco agree to exchange information on financial accounts in the respective territories, in order to improve the ability of the tax authority to identify taxpayers, apply tax law in cross-border situations, and identify possible cases of tax evasion.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I think this is an agreement in the right direction to combat tax evasion and evasion and money laundering. The geographical situation of Monaco, a state of its characteristics embedded in the union, made it incomprehensible that any form of banking secrecy should be maintained for the members of the Union. It is important that the information to be exchanged automatically affects all banking concepts of the asset holder in monegasque banks such as account balances or income from the sale of financial assets.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns an agreement between the European Union and Monaco to automatically exchange information relating to financial accounts. The agreement, signed last February, aims to increase cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. This agreement was one of the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy two years ago to prevent tax havens from remaining at the EU's doorstep, even though many paradises still exist within the EU itself, and the various media scandals regularly prove this.  The automatic exchange of information will always focus on the income of the accounts but also on their balance and the proceeds of asset disposal. We have previously supported the agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino, so it is obvious to symbolically support the agreement which will come into force on 1 January 2017. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text analysing the amendments to the agreement between the EU and monaco on the automatic exchange of financial information is well structured and acceptable, so I supported it with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the negotiations between the European Union and Monaco on an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information with a view to improving international cooperation and tax compliance.  This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. Under the new agreement, from 2018, EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on financial accounts collected in their territories by residents of EU Member States and Monaco. The aim is to respond to cases where a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. The agreement aims to ensure that Monaco applies stricter measures that are equivalent to eu legal order and that they comply with the automatic procedures for the exchange of financial accounts information recommended by the OECD World Standard 2014. Also, to exchange not only information on income such as interest and dividends, but also on account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The EU and the Principality of Monaco signed an agreement on 22 February 2016 on the automatic exchange of financial account information to increase cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. Just as we have done for Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and Sain-Marin, this symbolic agreement must be supported. Therefore, I vote for this agreement with Monaco.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which has the overall aim of reducing tax avoidance and evasion. Sinn Féin have been very active in Europe on the issue of tax avoidance and closing the loopholes which permit multinationals to engage in widespread tax avoidance and evasion. From playing an active role on TAXE and now on the Panama Papers, Sinn Féin will continue to ensure that multinationals are obliged to pay the taxes which they owe. This particular report, approves the agreement that has been negotiated by the EU and Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial account information between EU Member States and Monaco relating to accounts of each other’s residents. Automatic exchange of information will take place from 2018 on information collected since the start of next year. Under the agreement, Monaco will apply measures equivalent to the EU’s on reporting the taxation of savings income, and come into line with the OECD’s 2014 standards. (There was a previous agreement on this in 2004 which Monaco is updating to current standards adopted in the EU in December 2014).

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The exchange of financial information between different political entities is one of the basic prerequisites for effectively combating transnational phenomena such as fraud and tax evasion. From this point of view, the new agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco is an important mechanism capable of speeding up the detection and facilitate the fight against possible cases of tax fraud. More specifically, the agreement in question, by strengthening the pact already concluded in 2004, establishes the automatic exchange of information on interest, dividends, current account balances and products derived from the sale of financial assets of citizens and businesses in the two respective areas, favouring the application, including within the Principality of Monaco, of reinforced measures equivalent to those currently existing in the European Union.  For all these reasons, I hope that the agreement will be concluded, ratified and entered into force as soon as possible.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. On 22 February 2016, the European Union and the Principality of Monaco signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, as part of a series of agreements between the EU and neighbouring states to strengthen the fight against tax evasion. This agreement was also a condition of Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy. This automatic exchange of information covers financial income as well as asset disposal proceeds. We believe that these agreements are moving in the right direction. Not only do they contribute effectively to the fight against tax evasion, but they also respect the sovereignty of the Member States. That is why I approved this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The automatic exchange of information on financial accounts is an important method of combating cross-border tax fraud and evasion, based on cooperation and strengthening relations between tax administrations worldwide, while ensuring tax transparency. The Protocol amending the Agreement between the EU and Monaco on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts is intended to align the measures provided for with similar measures in Council Directive 2003/48/EC, based on the latest developments at international level with regard to the automatic exchange of information, namely the global standard for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in tax matters drawn up by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. This amending protocol therefore transposes global standards between the Member States and Monaco with a view to strengthening the fight against tax fraud and evasion. I believe that transparency in the exchange of tax information is a mandatory condition for combating forms of tax evasion, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations between the European Union and Monaco, with the aim of improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax rules at international level, ended with the signing of a new agreement ensuring that Monaco applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for by the EU legal framework, updated in December 2014. The Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco implements the global standard for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in tax matters drawn up by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), in agreement with Union legislation. I support the EP report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco establishing measures similar to those provided for in Council Directive 2003/48/EC, as I believe that this arrangement is an important step towards strengthening the fight against tax fraud and evasion. The EU must adopt a clear and coherent policy towards third countries in order to be able to promote its standards at international level and ensure a level playing field.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I approved the protocol to the agreement between the European Union and Monaco providing for the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. This agreement is a new success in terms of tax transparency. It should enable the tax administrations of the Member States and Monaco to strengthen their cooperation. This will make them more effective in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. Following the conclusion of the new agreement, tax administrations will have the ability to identify affected taxpayers, enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, and assess the likelihood of tax evasion.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the vote on this report, I gave my favourable opinion on the signing of the agreement reached between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. This agreement represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and improves the 2004 agreement guaranteeing monaco's application of measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. The purpose of the understanding is to ensure that Monaco applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework as updated in December 2014, and complies with the procedures for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standard.  The EU and Monaco agreed that the agreement should enter into force on 1 January 2017, where necessary in the form of provisional application, after completion of their internal procedures for conclusion and ratification.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which approves the agreement that has been negotiated by the EU and Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial account information between EU Member States and Monaco relating to accounts of each other’s residents. The purpose is to reduce tax avoidance and evasion. Automatic exchange of information will take place from 2018 on information collected since the start of next year. Under the agreement, Monaco will apply measures equivalent to the EU’s on reporting the taxation of savings income, and come into line with the OECD’s 2014 standards. There was a previous agreement on this in 2004 which Monaco is updating to current standards adopted in the EU in December 2014. As the general aim is to reduce tax avoidance and evasion I was happy to vote in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that approves the conclusion of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the EU and Monaco. This Protocol will enable automatic information exchange of financial accounts between the two parties in order to fight tax fraud and tax evasion through transparent policies and in line with EU legislation. I welcome this development, which will surely enhance and develop our cooperation in this area.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes aims to increase efforts to combat fraud, avoidance and tax evasion by EU citizens. Although the EU-Munich agreement is more advanced than the agreements of the same kind already concluded by the EU with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino and Andorra, there are unfortunately many regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain during the vote in plenary.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the current economic system based on absolute capital mobility, the exchange of information between national authorities is the most effective tool for combating cross-border tax fraud and evasion. Following the adoption of the So-called 'Directive on the taxation of savings income' and in order to maintain conditions of fair competition between economic operators, the European Union signed on 22 February 2016 an agreement with the Principality of Monaco providing for the introduction of measures equivalent to those laid down in the Directive and will enter into force on 1 January 2017. Among the information that will be exchanged between the competent authorities, those relating to current accounts in the name of non-residents that will serve to identify those who try to conceal capital on which no taxes have been paid. I supported the vote of the House which gave its approval to the Council for the conclusion of the Protocol with the Principality of Monaco, which I hope will be ratified as soon as possible.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we consider this agreement to be an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of an amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco and provides for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC. I believe that any attempt to strengthen and improve the procedures for exchanging information on economic data helps to prevent illegal or behind-the-scenes activities and therefore protects the interests of European citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against tax evasion is a very sensitive issue. The European institutions have been fighting this phenomenon for years now, which enriches some societies every year to the detriment of thousands of citizens. Through agreements on the exchange of financial information with other countries, it is possible, being able to correctly identify the taxpayers concerned, to limit this phenomenon in part. I am therefore pleased with this agreement, which establishes the good relationship between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco and widens the pool of information available to the Union to combat tax fraud. In my view, this cooperation represents a great step forward in the fight against this phenomenon, and I could therefore only vote in favour of it.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an indispensable step forward in the exchange of tax information with the Principality of Monaco. While the exchange of information has proved not sufficient for member states to take action against the continent's main tax evasors and elusors, it is an important step for states to identify such capitals and their owners. This is why the provisions of this agreement represent an objective improvement in the functioning of information exchanges with Monaco. Although such measures do not pursue a ban on the use of tax havens by European capital, it is an important step forward in being able to carry out more radical measures to make capital taxes where wealth is generated. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution approves the ratification of the agreement reached between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco on the automatic exchange of information on tax and financial matters. With my vote in favour of the Resolution, I wanted to support the EU-Principality of Monaco agreement because it represents an important step forward in the fight against fraud and tax evasion and at the same time represents a major improvement on the pre-existing agreement that dates back to 2004. With the new agreement, the European Union and the Principality of Monaco will facilitate the automatic exchange of information related to citizens' accounts from 2018. In this way, the Principality of Monaco will have tax rules equivalent to those applied in the EU and will limit situations in which a taxpayer tries to hide capital on which no taxes have been paid.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 In February 2016, representatives of the European Commission and the Principality of Monaco initialled the Agreement establishing measures for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, with the aim of improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax rules at international level. Thus, from 1 January 2017, it will be possible to combat tax fraud and evasion by developing a common instrument that will enable tax authorities to identify, assess and investigate potential risks, and in the event of criminal offences the administration and implementation of tax legislation in cross-border situations is authorised. Wanting to reaffirm the need for transparency on the issue of taxes, both at European Union level and in relations with third countries, I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco establishing measures similar to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU and Monaco will automatically exchange financial information on residents of the other party, in line with the updated requirements of the Administrative Cooperation Directive (DAC2) and the OECD Global Standards. The EU and Monaco will exchange information from 2018 and will start collecting information from 1 January 2017. The aim is to remedy situations in which the taxpayer attempts to hide capital constituting income or assets from which no taxes are paid. Similar updates apply to agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino and Andorra.  I welcome this update because the agreement is in line with existing EU legislation and global OECD standards. This will avoid the use of double standards in the future. As a result, Member States and Monaco will correctly identify taxpayers, manage tax rules in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and avoid unnecessary proceedings. The information exchanged will relate not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. In view of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the agreement between EU and Monaco to provide the automatic exchange of financial account information. I believe that this is an important step forward when taking into account the importance of automatic exchange of information as a means of combating cross-border tax fraud and tax evasion, an issue that has also been recognised at the international level.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's positive vote, the European Parliament confirms the agreement established on 22 February 2016 between the European Commission and the Government of the Principality of Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes.  An important legislative step that updates the previous agreement of 2004 and ensures the application by the Principality of Monaco of measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework – updated in December 2014 with the amendment of the Directive on administrative cooperation.  The agreement I have supported today improves cooperation and compliance with tax obligations, through the automatic exchange of information between administrative and financial authorities: a necessary measure to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, to assess more precisely the likelihood of tax evasion and to avoid unnecessary investigations. I am convinced that the agreement agreed with monaco, part of a broader EU approach with third countries, is a step forward in increasing transparency in the area of administrative cooperation and confirming the EU's concrete commitment to the fight against tax fraud.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report is a recommendation on the Council's plan to conclude the agreement between the EU and the principality of Monaco, providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the European directives. The aim is to ensure that the principality continues to apply measures equivalent to those of the European Union. As part of the agreement, the European Union and Monaco will automatically exchange information on their residents' bank accounts from 2017. The information that will be exchanged relates to income, such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and profits from the sale of financial assets. Considering that the European Union must tighten its rules on combating tax fraud and evasion and that cooperation with our closest neighbours is essential to make this fight more effective, I supported this report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. On 22 February 2016, the European Union and the Principality of Monaco signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. The aim is to increase cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. For the record, this type of agreement was one of the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy two years ago. The automatic exchange of information will always focus on the income of the accounts but also on their balance and on the proceeds of asset disposal. Having supported the previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino, I have logically supported this agreement which will come into force on 1 January 2017.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the draft report on the agreement with Monaco, because thus another loophole for concealing taxes, in large amounts, will be closed. This shows clear steps towards the Union's desire to limit these criminal actions towards the Community. But I must say that we began to work on such agreements only after the facts on the so-called Luxembourg Leakes became known.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The European Union and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information to improve tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations and represents important progress in the context of efforts being made to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. Under the new Agreement, the tax administrations of the Member States and Monaco will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, enforce and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and avoid further unnecessary investigations.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I vote for: we have already supported the previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The agreement signed this year on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, which aims to improve international tax cooperation, represents a step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. With the new agreement, Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on financial accounts held in their territories by residents of each country, starting in 2018 for information collected from January 2017.  The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide income or capital goods for which no tax has been paid. The agreement aims to ensure that Monaco applies measures equivalent to the EU legal framework, as updated in December 2014 (with the amendment to the Administrative Cooperation Directive, "DAC2"), and complies with procedures for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts promoted by the OECD globally. As a result of the new agreement, the tax administrations of the Member States and Monaco are expected to be able to: - Correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned; - Administer and enforce your tax laws in cross-border situations; - Assess the probability of tax evasion; - Avoid unnecessary further investigations. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Principality of Monaco negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. The agreement represents an important step forward in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and is intended to ensure that Monaco applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework, thereby complying with the procedures for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standard. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of the protocol to the AGREEMENT between the EU and Munich on the automatic exchange of financial information.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because as a result of the new agreement, tax administrations in the Member States and in Monaco will be able to: - identify correctly and unequivocally the taxpayers concerned.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has long sought to actively combat tax fraud and tax evasion through the legislation adopted. The aim of this agreement between the European Union and Monaco is to improve international cooperation in the area in question and to ensure that Monaco applies measures equivalent to those laid down in the European Union Directive on taxation of savings income. The new provisions of the agreement in question are intended to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to the state of the accounts and the proceeds from the sale of financial assets.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report for greater transparency with regard to the automatic exchange of information in order to avoid fraud and tax avoidance.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this agreement, as it is an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. The Principality of Monaco is a well-known tax haven and therefore the exchange of tax information serves international tax cooperation and compliance with the relevant provisions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in on-going efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that Monaco applied measures equivalent to those in an EU directive on the taxation of savings income. I believe that this agreement is in line with the need for more transparency on tax issues in the EU and in its relations with third countries. The EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts held on their territories by each other’s residents, starting in 2018 for information collected since 1 January 2017. I support its aim to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. Furthermore, in line with that OECD standard, I welcome the further provisions in the agreement which aim at securing that exchanged information concerns not only income such as interest and dividends, but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Negotiations between the European Union and Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial account information aim at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement could be an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and update the past agreement to ensure that Monaco applies measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings interest income. The aim is to address situations where taxable persons seek to conceal capital conbodied in the sense of income or property for which the tax has not yet been paid.  In accordance with OECD standards, the further provisions of the Agreement aim to ensure that the information shared relates not only to revenues such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and income from the sale of financial instruments. The unconditional exchange of information should be ensured on request under the new Agreement in line with the latest developments in the work of the OECD and the Union in this regard.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax and international obligations, as the agreement represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion.  The agreement, which will enter into force in 2017, represents a significant step forward compared to the 2004 agreement, currently in force, as the latter merely ensures the application of equivalent measures by Monaco in relation to the fight against fraud and tax evasion. The new agreement improves the 2004 agreement and, above all, is in line with the OECD standard. In fact, under the agreement, the EU Member States and Munich will automatically and unconditionally exchange information on the accounts held in the territories by their residents. Under the new agreement, the tax administrations of the Member States and Munich will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, apply and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border situations and assess the likelihood of tax evasion and avoid further unnecessary investigations.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Monaco agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. Justice and transparency in the financial market is a point that my family party has long stood for – in the interests of citizens, families and small and medium-sized enterprises. That is what I am fighting for as an MEP.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the agreement between the EU and the Principality of Monaco, as the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts ensures a more secure level of competition.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. On 22 February 2016, the European Union signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information with the Principality of Monaco. This is one of the mechanisms put in place by the European Union and neighbouring states to cooperate in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. These agreements will allow these states to share data on account income, balances, and asset disposal income. Following on from my votes in favour of the fight against tax evasion and evasion, I voted for this cooperation with the Principality of Monaco.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, where by which the EU and Monaco agree to exchange information on financial accounts in the respective territories, in order to improve the ability of the tax authority to identify taxpayers, apply tax law in cross-border situations, and identify possible cases of tax evasion.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of a protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco laying down measures equivalent to those provided for in Council Directive 2003/48/EC. I support the agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial data. This agreement is of great importance for the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and updates the 2004 agreement providing for monaco to apply measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU Savings Tax Directive. Under the new agreement, EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange financial information on other party's residents in their territories from 2018 on, including information collected as of 1 January 2017. The purpose of that agreement is to remedy situations in which the taxable person attempts to conceal capital constituting income or assets from which no taxes have been paid.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. This is an important partnership agreement which allows to exchange financial account information with an important financial partner of EU – Monaco. The agreement ensures the efficiency of the information flow between two parties as well as transparency of financial account.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. Our firm position is that any agreement aimed at tackling tax evasion and avoidance is in the positive direction and that is why we voted in favour of the protocol of agreement between the EU and Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial transaction information.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the EU- Monaco agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information because I believe that it will be an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion. In the wake of the Panama Papers scandal this agreement will allow the EU Member States and Monaco to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts held on their territories by each other’s residents.
