I was happy to note that the agreement will be in line with the 2014 OECD Global standard and provides for further provisions which aim at securing exchanged information concerns such as interest and dividends, and also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. I also believe that this agreement will improve international tax cooperation and compliance.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections to its final arrangement.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Council Decision on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco on measures equivalent to those set out in Council Directive 2003/48/EC (COM(2016)0201 - C8-01 57/2016 - 2016/0109(NLE)), as this agreement is an important step in ongoing efforts to fight tax fraud and tax evasion and is an upgrade of the previous 2004 agreement.  Hereby, EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of citizens of the country representing the other party to the Agreement, starting in 2018 for information collected from 1 January 2017.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. On 22 February 2016, the European Union and the Principality of Monaco signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information as part of a series of agreements between the EU and neighbouring states. This series aimed to increase cooperation in the fight against evasion and tax evasion. For the record, these agreements were one of the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy two years ago. Tax havens had to be avoided at the gates of the EU, where fraudsters could take refuge. The automatic exchange of information will always cover the income of the accounts but also their balance and the proceeds of asset disposal. The ENL Group supported previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino.  The one with Monaco is obviously symbolic, and it was appropriate to support it as well, hence my vote in favour of it.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this protocol, which aims to implement, between the EU and Monaco, the OECD's global standards, specifically those on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments and the automatic exchange of tax information between the EU and Monaco. This will strengthen the fight against tax evasion in the EU.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. – In the line of previous similar agreements we welcome the regime established between EU and the Principality of Monaco regarding the automatic exchange of information on issues related to taxation, money flows and bank savings reporting.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This agreement represents a significant step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and is an update of the 2004 agreement, which ensured that Monaco applies rules equivalent to those in the relevant EU directive on the taxation of savings. The agreement is to be welcomed and supported, as it promotes transparency in tax matters and tax honesty. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Monaco is considered one of several tax havens in the world. The tax system in Monaco almost lacks FO income taxes, property taxes, property taxes, land taxes or capital gains taxes. The only direct tax is the income tax of the PO, 33.33% of profits, but it is also quite benevolent to taxpayers. Tax havens and tax fraud must be combated, which is why I supported the EU-Monaco agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. This agreement will help prevent taxpayers from hiding their capital abroad, but will also improve international cooperation on taxation and compliance. Under the new agreement, EU countries and Monaco will be able to automatically exchange information about financial accounts that citizens of the opposite party have on their territory. The exchange of financial account information between EU countries and Monaco will also be intensifying and it will be easier to identify financial support.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – I will continue to support all initiatives to combat tax fraud and evasion. Monaco is also one of the tax havens, so the agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information is also effective for these purposes. The report rightly states that this will also update the previous agreement of 2004 on the taxation of interest income from savings.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the agreement on automatic exchange of financial account information as it represents another step towards improving international cooperation in the field of taxation and tax compliance. This Agreement ensures that Monaco will apply equivalent to those of the EU Savings Taxation Directive and limit tax fraud and tax evasion. Its main objective is to take action against situations in which a taxable person tries to hide capital representing income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. The exchange of information will affect not only income, such as interest and dividends, but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. In line with the latest developments in the work of the OECD, the EU's unconditional exchange of information on request is ensured. Thanks to the agreed agreement, tax administrations in the Member States and Monaco will be able to correctly and unambiguously identify the taxpayers concerned, administer and enforce their cross-border taxation laws and assess the likelihood of tax evasion.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This report analyses the agreement negotiated between the EU and the Principality of Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes and the anticipation of an improvement in tax obligations at international level. It is making progress because it is capable of combating tax evasion and fraud mechanisms, already provided for in the previous agreement of 2004, which provided for the application by the State of Munich of measures equivalent to those already contained in the EU directive corresponding to the taxation of savings income. The aim of this report is to address situations in which the taxpayer tries to conceal capital from income or tax evasion. For these reasons, it is called for the State of Munich to apply enhanced measures to prevent such omissions. For these reasons, I support Mr Schwab's report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement with Monaco because it aims to increase cooperation in the fight against tax evasion.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Monaco for the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. On 22 February 2016, the European Union and the Principality of Monaco signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, as part of a series of agreements between the EU and neighbouring states to increase cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. For the record, these agreements were one of the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy two years ago. Tax havens had to be avoided at the gates of the EU, where fraudsters could take refuge. The automatic exchange of information will always cover the income of the accounts but also their balance and the proceeds of asset disposal. The National Front supported previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino.  The one with Monaco is obviously symbolic, and it should be supported as well.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. In 2014, agreements were reached with member countries to end bank secrecy as part of the fight against tax evasion and evasion. The texts provided for the establishment of other agreements with neighbouring states, in order to establish links of cooperation and automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, in accordance with the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria. After Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino, the EU concludes an agreement with Monaco, which is subject to the approval of the European Parliament by this report. I support this policy of transparency by voting FOR.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an indispensable step forward in the exchange of tax information with the Principality of Monaco. While the exchange of information has proved not sufficient for member states to take action against the continent's main tax evasors and elusors, it is an important step for states to identify such capitals and their owners. This is why the provisions of this agreement represent an objective improvement in the functioning of information exchanges with Monaco. Although such measures do not pursue a ban on the use of tax havens by European capital, it is an important step forward in being able to carry out more radical measures to make capital taxes where wealth is generated. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This agreement represents an important step in the fight against tax evasion and evasion.  Under it we will be able to get the Member States of the Union and Monaco to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of the respective countries, so as to prevent the taxpayer from being able to hide a wealth representing income or assets on which no taxes have been paid.  This report aims to ensure that Monaco implements enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the legal framework of the European Union and that these measures are in place in the automatic exchange of information procedures. And here, we are no longer just talking about income such as interest or dividends, but also account balances and income from the sale of financial assets.  From the above and because I believe that we must enforce tax legislation in cross-border situations, I vote favorably for the adoption of this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report that updates the EU’s agreements with Monaco.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Automatic exchange of financial account information is one of the best ways to guarantee the most effective international cooperation in the field of taxation and thus minimise the possibilities of avoiding payment. It is necessary to note that such automatic exchange will start from the beginning of 2018 and will refer to data collected from 1 January 2017. As is known, not including Monaco similar agreements were also signed with Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein and San Marino. Over the last few years, the agreements have been renewed with the aim of adapting them to international innovation in this area. Given the fundamental importance of taxation and the need for further as effective a fight against tax evasion as possible, I voted positively.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the conclusion of this agreement, which will make it possible to detect tax fraud and evasion more effectively from 2018 through the exchange of account information. The Agreement will apply to information collected as of 1 January 2017 and will enable the Parties to enforce and control compliance with the law in cross-border situations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC, because it is well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. These agreements are in line with similar agreements signed with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino. The signing of an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information by Monaco was a condition for lifting the banking secrecy imposed by Luxembourg and Austria two years ago. In its absence, the Principality of Monaco would have established itself as the leading destination for tax evasion in Europe. We can only support the purpose of this report, which seeks greater financial transparency. Moreover, our vote is consistent with our vote on the previous reports.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – Regarding the EU-Monaco agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, I voted in favour of it. This agreement is an imperative and indispensable step for abrogating tax fraud and tax evasion, and will guarantee that Monaco’s procedures are identical to the EU framework. The implementation of this will also forestall additional investigations and strengthen cross-border tax laws.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the recommendation in favour of the EU-Monaco agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations.  This agreement represents an important step in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion and updates the 2004 Agreement, which ensured the implementation by Monaco of measures equivalent to those provided for in the UNION Directive on the taxation of savings yields.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The European Union and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts aimed at improving international cooperation in tax matters and tax honesty in international situations. The agreement represents a significant step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and is an update of the 2004 agreement, which ensured that Monaco applies rules equivalent to those in the relevant EU directive on the taxation of savings income. I can only agree with this.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. At the end of February, Monaco and the European Union signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, in order to increase their cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. This is in line with what has been done before for San Marino, Andorra, Switzerland and Lichtenstein. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco, which provides for measures equivalent to those laid down by Council Directive 2003/48/EC.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this agreement as it aims to bolster international tax cooperation and combat tax evasion. This agreement seeks an efficient upholding of the current international tax system, and therefore does not damage SMEs.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Tax evasion, tax havens must be a thing of the past. We need to combat the erosion of the tax base and the transfer of profits. This must be a priority to ensure the sustainability of our social model. To this end, a key measure is to end bank secrecy in third countries. The EU's priority is to tackle the opaque systems of other European countries. After Switzerland, it's Monaco's turn. I therefore congratulate the European Commission on its efforts to enable the signing of this agreement on the automatic exchange of information on declarable accounts. This is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts agreed between the Member States of the European Union and Monaco aims to improve international cooperation and compliance with tax rules. The agreement is an important step in the ongoing efforts to reduce tax fraud and tax evasion and complements the 2004 Agreement, which ensured that Monaco applies measures equivalent to those laid down in the European Union Directive on taxation of savings income. Monaco should apply stricter measures equivalent to the Union legal framework. Other provisions of the Agreement are intended to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to the status of accounts and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. The new agreement must also provide for the unconditional exchange of information upon request. In view of the above, I support the proposal on the table.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the EU-Monaco agreement because this agreement is in line with the need for more transparency on tax issues in the EU and in its relations with third countries.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted a draft decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of a Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco laying down provisions equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC. However, in order for the decision to take effect, it must obtain Parliament's approval. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the conclusion of the Protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This agreement, which seals the automatic exchange of information between EU countries and the Principality of Monaco on tax matters, is the continuation of efforts to end bank secrecy.  Monaco is a particularly complacent place for capital of dubious origin, so it is all the more necessary to support the rapid implementation of this agreement. The ENL Group supported previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino and Andorra.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations, the European Union and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The Agreement shows significant progress in anti-tax fraud and tax evasion and updates the 2004 Agreement, which ensured that Monaco would implement measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. Under the new Agreement, from 2018, EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange the information collected from 1 January 2017 onwards on the financial accounts held in their territories by residents of the other Party. The purpose of this exchange is to prevent situations where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid.  For the foregoing, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text is useful in the fight against tax evasion, and is therefore beneficial to Member States' budgets. I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU-Monaco agreement providing for the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, in order to avoid financial cover-up as much as possible. At a time when, according to the Commission's estimates, tax evasion and tax avoidance are causing up to EUR 1000 billion to be lost each year to the detriment of European taxpayers, we must do everything possible to combat this phenomenon.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to improve more transparent international tax cooperation and compliance, the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco is essential. I think it is very important that the automatic exchange of financial account information is started as soon as possible. Under the agreement, we will have more accurate information and tax evasion will be easier to prevent. I wished to contribute to this by voting.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. I have voted for this report that will start in 2018 an automatic exchange of financial account information held on each other’s territories.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote because I believe that, in the current economic context, we need to become increasingly active in combating tax fraud and evasion. In this respect, the report voted on today encourages the exchange of information on financial accounts between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco, which will give more transparency to the Monegasque banking activity and make it easier to combat fraud on European territory. At the same time, the message we are sending to the world is that the EU is no longer tolerant of tax havens, and I hope that this will follow in the future, imposing more and more restrictions on companies and citizens using these spaces to avoid paying taxes.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which has the overall aim of reducing tax avoidance and evasion. Sinn Féin have been very active in Europe on the issue of tax avoidance and closing the loopholes which permit multinationals to engage in widespread tax avoidance and evasion. From playing an active role on TAXE and now on the Panama Papers, Sinn Féin will continue to ensure that multinationals are obliged to pay the taxes which they owe. This particular report, approves the agreement that has been negotiated by the EU and Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial account information between EU Member States and Monaco relating to accounts of each other’s residents. Automatic exchange of information will take place from 2018 on information collected since the start of next year. Under the agreement, Monaco will apply measures equivalent to the EU’s on reporting the taxation of savings income, and come into line with the OECD’s 2014 standards. (There was a previous agreement on this in 2004 which Monaco is updating to current standards adopted in the EU in December 2014).

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The automatic exchange of information on financial information is to be welcomed.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the agreement between the European Union and Monaco on the exchange of financial account information. In particular, it will allow for improved international cooperation and tax compliance. It should be noted that the agreement contributes to the development of the prevention of tax fraud. One of the most important aspects of the agreement is that tax authorities will henceforth be able to administer their tax laws and ensure compliance with them in cross-border cases. The agreement is also significant in the fact that the Principality of Monaco will apply more stringent measures that are equivalent to the EU legal order.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the new agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial information provides for enhanced measures to combat tax fraud and evasion; whereas the agreement, once it enters into force, would allow national authorities to access the necessary financial information of taxpayers and to ensure that tax legislation is properly complyed in their territories; Finally, given that the exchange of information promoted by the text complies with the OECD standard procedures of 2014, I felt it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Automatic exchange of financial information is essential for combating money laundering and tax evasion. Moving towards greater tax transparency is essential for the sustainability of European economy and I take the chance to vote in favour and support the report as it stands.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The importance of automatically exchanging information on financial accounts as a means to combat cross-border tax fraud and cross-border tax evasion internationally is great. That is why a single global standard for automatic exchange of information was developed in July 2014.  In my view, the dissemination of mandatory automatic exchange of information between the competent Tax Administrations of the Union, and in accordance with the global standard, is necessary and desirable. Given that the 'Austerity Taxation Directive' has been repealed and directive 2014/107/EU on amending Directive 2011/16/EU regarding the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, existing savings taxation agreements with Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco and San Marino need to be amended.  In this context, I supported this report and the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco. The Amending Protocol will implement a global standard between Member States and Monaco, and this will certainly contribute to the transparency of the Union tax and financial system.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The EU and Monaco have reached an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, aimed at improving tax cooperation and implementing tax obligations internationally. This agreement is an important step in the ongoing efforts to fight tax fraud and tax evasion and is an upgrade of the 2004 agreement, which guarantees that Monaco applies measures equivalent to those of the EU Savings Taxation Directive. Under the new agreement, the Member States of the European Union and Monaco will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts held on their territory by citizens of the state representing the other party to the agreement, starting in 2018 for information collected from 1 January 2017. The aim is to tackle situations where taxpayers want to conceal capital representing income or assets for which no tax has been paid. In accordance with this OECD standard, the additional provisions of the agreement aim to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and revenues from the sale of financial assets. I fully welcome and support the agreement.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and monaco signed an agreement on 22 February 2016 that will make it more difficult for EU citizens to evade tax and hide money in Monegasque bank accounts. The information to be exchanged relates not only to income, such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and proceeds from sales of financial assets. Under this agreement, the EU and Monaco will automatically exchange information on their residents' bank accounts, starting in 2018 and for information collected from 1 January 2017. The tax administrations of the Member States and Munich will thus be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, apply and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and avoid further unnecessary investigations. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of approving this agreement.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU and Monaco will automatically exchange financial information on residents of the other party in accordance with the updated requirements of the Administrative Cooperation Directive (DAC2) and the OECD Global Standards. The EU and Monaco will exchange information from 2018 and will start collecting information from 1 January 2017. The aim is to remedy situations in which the taxpayer attempts to hide capital constituting income or assets from which no taxes are paid. Similar updates apply to agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino and Andorra. The ECON Commission has drawn up a report under the simplified procedure. The agreement is in line with existing EU legislation and oecd global standards. This will avoid the use of double standards in the future. As a result, Member States and Monaco will correctly identify taxpayers, manage tax rules in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and avoid unnecessary proceedings. The information exchanged will relate not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. I hereby supported the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement with Monaco on the exchange of tax information has my support, because I consider it to be the next step towards fair tax collection. Of particular importance is the fact that this is an agreement with a state that is as closely linked to the EU as the Principality of Monaco.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical text which amends the protocol of the agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco related to the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. This agreement essentially allows the same level of measures relating to financial accounts to apply outside THE EU's borders and here in Monaco.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The European Parliament once again supports tax transparency and compliance with international tax obligations with its vote to sign this protocol with the Monegasque principality.  In line with those signed with Liechtenstein, San Marino or Andorra, this agreement provides for the automatic exchange between Monaco and the Member States of the Union of information relating to financial accounts. This information will be collected from January 1, 2017. The act is primarily aimed at preventing tax evasion by European taxpayers and concealing capital in the form of income or assets over which the tax has not been paid.  In line with the global standard adopted by the OECD in 2014, Monaco will need to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. As a reminder, according to the Commission, tax evasion and avoidance would represent up to 1000 billion euros of loss per year in the European Union.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, in which this House endorses an agreement reached in February this year between the European Union and Monaco on the automatic exchange of information relating to the bank accounts of the residents of the two signatory parties, an exchange that will begin in 2018 for information gathered since 1 January 2017. Formal signing of the agreement is expected this summer.  In addition, the agreement provides that Monaco will implement enhanced measures, equivalent to those in place within the EU since March 2014. Finally, it remains in line with 2014 OECD standards on the automatic exchange of financial account information.  This agreement is a necessary new step in the fight against tax evasion and evasion as it will be more difficult for a person to hide money on which the tax must apply. Tax authorities will be able to identify the taxpayers involved, administer and strengthen their tax laws in cross-border cases, or assess the likelihood of tax evasion at issue. This agreement is similar to the agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein and San Marino, to which I had also supported it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament approved, by 549 votes in in each vote, 16 against and 23 abstentions, the agreement signed last February between the European Union and Monaco on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. The agreement provides for Monaco and EU Member States to automatically exchange information on their residents' financial accounts from 2018, which will be collected from 1 January 2017. Under the new agreement, Member States will receive the names, addresses, tax identification numbers and dates of birth of their residents with accounts in Monaco, as well as certain other financial information, including the balance of these accounts. The formal signing of the agreement is expected to take place before the summer holidays (note that similar agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino and Andorra have already been approved by the European Parliament).

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. Monaco is sometimes classified as a tax haven and is not always accused of aiding tax evasion. I am therefore convinced that this protocol on the exchange of information on financial accounts will at least help Monaco get rid of the disgraceful 'tax haven' label and help the European Union in the fight against tax evasion.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The European Union and the Principality of Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, which is an important milestone in efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. This Agreement also updated the previous 2004 agreement, which ensured that Monaco adopted measures equivalent to those stipulated in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. With this agreement, EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on financial accounts held in their territories by residents of the other. The primary purpose of this agreement is to detect situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide income or capital goods on which no tax has been paid. Thus, the tax administrations of the Member States and Monaco will now be able to accurately identify the situations concerned, administer and apply their tax laws in cross-border situations and also assess the possible likelihood of tax evasion. I agree with the rapporteur's position on the acceptance of this agreement as a viable and important measure to ensure the smooth, transparent and more effective functioning of our tax administrations, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the protocol to the agreement between the European Union and Monaco providing for the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. This agreement complements those reached with Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein and San Marino, providing for equivalent measures.  The importance of automatic exchange of information has been recognized internationally as a means of combating cross-border tax evasion and evasion. In this context, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has been tasked by the G20 to develop a single global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information.  It is through effective bilateral cooperation that we will be able to combat and end tax evasion. This type of agreement responds not only to an economic need but also to an expectation of the citizens of the Union.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the agreement between the European Union and monaco on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes. The agreement in question extends to the Principality of Monaco European measures on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments contained in Directive 2003/48/EC. This directive plays an important role in financial matters. In fact, regulation at Community level makes it possible to fill the gaps in coordination between Member States in the exchange of information, thus responding to the principle of subsidiarity. However, in order for the measures to be effective, other states in Europe, such as the Principality of Monaco, must participate in the effective exchange of information on request on interest payments. Without real financial coordination not only between Member States but also with other European countries, the EU will continue to suffer from the flight of capital to third countries, with serious consequences for its economy.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, where by which the EU and Monaco agree to exchange information on financial accounts in the respective territories, in order to improve the ability of the tax authority to identify taxpayers, apply tax law in cross-border situations, and identify possible cases of tax evasion

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol of Amendment to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco on rules equivalent to those of Council Directive 2003/48/EC'. The EU is thereby adapting its relations with Monaco to the current political situation. At the moment, this is about data protection and also tax laws. In particular, the innovations against tax avoidance and tax fraud will also be extended to Monaco in this Treaty.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an indispensable step forward in the exchange of tax information with the Principality of Monaco. While the exchange of information has proved not sufficient for member states to take action against the continent's main tax evasors and elusors, it is an important step for states to identify such capitals and their owners. This is why the provisions of this agreement represent an objective improvement in the functioning of information exchanges with Monaco. Although such measures do not pursue a ban on the use of tax havens by European capital, it is an important step forward in being able to carry out more radical measures to make capital taxes where wealth is generated. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Principality of Monaco signed, on 22 February 2016, an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on tax matters, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. I have decided to support the conclusion of the agreement as it represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. From 2018, the EU and the Principality of Monaco will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, with the aim of addressing situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax fraud.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the EU has negotiated an agreement with Monaco on the automatic exchange of financial account information. I supported the agreement because I believe that hiding cash in Monaco accounts in order to avoid paying taxes should not be given space in Europe. The approval of this agreement will introduce automatic exchange of information between the EU and the Principality of Monaco on bank accounts from 2018. The exchange will be subject to account-by-account data recorded from January 2017. The aim of this agreement is to combat tax evasion, which should be achieved by applying stricter measures on the part of the Principality of Monaco. From now on, Monaco will also be subject to the same data exchange rules agreed by EU Member States in 2014, which are in line with OECD global standards. The information exchanged between the tax authorities of the EU Member States and Monaco concerns not only citizens' income, for example in the form of interest and dividends, but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. These measures should also contribute to making high-earning citizens pay their taxes in the countries where they make their profits.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Union has agreed with Monaco an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information in order to improve international cooperation in the tax area and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. The agreement builds on the previous agreement of 2004, which made Monaco implement measures equivalent to those laid down in the EU Directive on taxation of savings income. As a result of the new agreement, the tax authorities in the Member States and Monaco will be able to correctly and unambiguously identify those taxpayers, manage and enforce national tax legislation in cross-border cases, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and also avoid unnecessary further investigations. For the reasons mentioned above, I believe that the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco on measures is good and I also voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Hiding assets and not paying taxes needs to be addressed, including in the way of an agreement that gives the EU access to information in other countries. This agreement will make it easier to identify taxpayers and prevent tax evasion.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and Monaco negotiated an agreement envisioning the automatic exchange of information on more financial accounts, with the aim of improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement is an important step in combating tax evasion and tax fraud and builds on a 2004 agreement that began applying Monaco measures equivalent to those required by the EU Savings Tax Directive.  Under the new agreement, Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange financial account information, with the main objective being to adequately respond to situations where taxpayers are trying to avoid paying taxes.  I support this report because I believe that Monaco should apply measures equivalent to the legislative framework of the European Union that are in line with the procedures for automatic exchange of information on financial accounts.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and Monaco have agreed an Agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information with a view to improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement is an important step in the process of combating tax fraud and tax evasion. Under the Agreement, Member States of the Union will automatically exchange financial account information on their territory with Monaco starting in 2018 for information collected from 1 January 2017. As a result of this Agreement, the tax administrations of the Member States and Monaco will be able to accurately and unequivocally identify which taxpayers are concerned, enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations and avoid unnecessary further investigations. I support the adoption of this Agreement as I believe that this will address situations where the taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which they have not paid tax.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco on measures equivalent to those laid down in a Council Directive. The agreement will strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Monaco in the area of exchange of information on financial accounts and in the tax area. I believe that the agreement will strengthen the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, to which we must have zero tolerance. However, it is an upgrade of the 2004 agreement.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This agreement is an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. The Principality of Monaco is a well-known tax haven and therefore the exchange of tax information serves international tax cooperation and compliance with the relevant provisions.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report, which endorsed the Protocol to the EU-Monaco Agreement on the automatic exchange of financial settlement information. Under the 2004 AGREEMENT between the EU and Monaco, Monaco introduced measures equivalent to EU rules on the taxation of savings interest income. The aim of the new agreement is for the Principality to use the strengthened oecd recommendations following the revised EU legal framework in December 2014.  This has taken EU-Monaco cooperation to the next level in preventing and suppressing tax fraud and tax evasion, which is certainly to be welcomed, as this will make it easier to detect cases where taxable persons are trying to hide property or income from the authorities for which no tax has been paid.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the European Union's fight against tax evasion in the Member States, the European institutions have taken steps to adopt automatic information exchange agreements with a number of third countries with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax rules at international level. These agreements are intended to combat tax evasion and evasion on the taxation of savings income, including through so-called 'tax havens'. The Principality of Monaco is one of the small European states considered a "tax haven", where some European citizens tend to hide their income. In this context, since 2004, the EU has concluded an agreement with Monaco to implement equivalent tax measures. The new agreement, signed by the European Commission in February 2016 and which will enter into force from 2018, will facilitate the automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts held by residents of the two parties in their territory. This agreement will improve administrative cooperation procedures between the two parties in line with the OECD global standard of 2014. I believe that this is a welcome measure and I support the adoption of this report in its current form.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Union and the Principality of Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. The text of this agreement was signed by a representative of the European Commission and a representative of the Government of the Principality of Monaco on 22 February 2016, and the official signature is expected before the summer holidays, as soon as the Council has given its approval.  This agreement marks an important step in the current efforts to combat tax evasion and evasion and reinforces the 2004 agreement which ensured that Monaco applied measures equivalent to those set out in the EU directive on the taxation of savings income. The new agreement provides that EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents, starting in 2018 for information collected since 1 January 2017. The objective is to deal with situations in which a taxpayer seeks to conceal capital that corresponds to income or assets over which the tax has not been paid.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Cross-border tax fraud and tax evasion are harmful for our economy, as well as for our financial credibility and long-term sustainability. This is why I voted in favour of amending the Protocol to the Agreement concluded between the EU and Monaco, which aims at improving international tax cooperation and compliance through the automatic exchange of financial account information. This agreement will increase tax transparency in Europe by ensuring that Monaco applies the same measures on the taxation of savings income as those currently applied in the EU. It will also incorporate a new set of provisions to reflect the global standard for automatic exchange of financial account information developed by the OECD in 2014.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Monaco, which provides for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. The automatic exchange of information as a means to combat cross-border tax fraud and cross-border tax evasion by ensuring full tax transparency and systematic cooperation between tax administrations around the world is very significant.  The G20 entrusted the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) with the task of developing a single global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information and the OECD Council published this global standard in July 2014. Both Contracting Parties undertake to implement and comply with specific data protection measures, and the information shall be disclosed exclusively to persons or authorities responsible for assessing, collecting and collecting taxes, carrying out or prosecuting tax, handling tax complaints and jurisdiction or supervision there so.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the adoption of the Savings Directive and with a view to maintaining a level playing field for economic operators, the European Union has signed an agreement with the Principality of Monaco on measures equivalent to those laid down in the Directive. On 17 June 2011, the Commission presented recommendations for a mandate to open negotiations with the Principality of Monaco with a view to upgrading the European Union's agreements with these countries in line with international developments and to ensure that these countries continue to apply measures equivalent to those in the European Union. On the basis of this proposal, the Council was invited to approve, on behalf of the European Union, an amendment protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco on measures equivalent to those laid down in the Directive on the taxation of income derived from savings in the form of interest payments. The report agrees to conclude a protocol amending the agreement, which is why I supported it.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, where by which the EU and Monaco agree to exchange information on financial accounts in the respective territories, in order to improve the ability of the tax authority to identify taxpayers, apply tax law in cross-border situations, and identify possible cases of tax evasion.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. On 22 February 2016, the European Union and the Principality of Monaco signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information as part of the round of agreement between the EU and neighbouring states to increase cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. For the record, these agreements were one of the conditions laid down by Luxembourg and Austria to end their banking secrecy two years ago. Tax havens had to be avoided at the gates of the EU, where fraudsters could take refuge. The automatic exchange of information will always focus on the income of the accounts but also on their balance and on the proceeds of asset disposal. We have supported previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra and San Marino. The one with Monaco is obviously symbolic, and it should be supported as well. I voted FOR.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of automatic exchange of information has been recognised internationally as a means of combating cross-border tax fraud and evasion. In this context, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development has established a single global rule on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, in force since July 2014. This Protocol proposes that the oecd rule should apply between EU Member States and Monaco. Thus, under the new agreement, the Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on existing financial accounts in their territories from 2018. This is the information that has been collected since 1 January 2017. The aim is to avoid situations where a tax payer seeks to hide his capital representing income or goods for which no taxes have been paid. The purpose of the cartel is also to ensure that Monaco applies strengthened measures which are equivalent to the legal framework of the European Union and that it complies with the procedures for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. I therefore voted in favour of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Union and Monaco.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The current agreement is an update of the agreement concluded between the European Union and Monaco in 2004. It will m.in improve international tax cooperation. In addition, it will enable a more effective fight against tax fraudsters and those who avoid paying taxes. I therefore voted in favour of the agreement.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union and Monaco negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The text of this Agreement was corked on 22 February 2016 by a representative of the European Commission and a representative of the Government of Monaco, which would be officially signed before the summer break, as authorised by the Council. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this report, where by which the EU and Monaco agree to exchange information on financial accounts in the respective territories, in order to improve the ability of the tax authority to identify taxpayers, apply tax law in cross-border situations, and identify possible cases of tax evasion.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and improves the 2004 agreement, which ensured that Monaco applied measures equivalent to those of the EU Savings Tax Directive.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC. The European Union and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. I voted in favour because I find that this agreement represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that Monaco applied measures equivalent to those in an EU directive on the taxation of savings income. Under the new agreement, the EU Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts held on their territories by each other’s residents. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This protocol will automatically exchange information about its residents' bank accounts, including not only income, but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. We are talking about good news in the fight against tax evasion, so I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this protocol.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an indispensable step forward in the exchange of tax information with the Principality of Monaco. While the exchange of information has proved not sufficient for member states to take action against the continent's main tax evasors and elusors, it is an important step for states to identify such capitals and their owners. This is why the provisions of this agreement represent an objective improvement in the functioning of information exchanges with Monaco. Although such measures do not pursue a ban on the use of tax havens by European capital, it is an important step forward in being able to carry out more radical measures to make capital taxes where wealth is generated. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 The European Union and Monaco have negotiated an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account data designed to improve international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement is an important step in ongoing efforts to tackle tax fraud and tax evasion. That is why I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report deals with the agreement between the EU and the Principality of Monaco. The aim is to cooperate on the exchange of information on financial accounts, with the aim of improving international cooperation in tax matters and tax honesty in international situations. A sensible step that will give me support.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union and Monaco have concluded an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information. This agreement was concluded with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international rules. This agreement will make it possible to prevent tax fraud more effectively and, moreover, to increase the effectiveness of law enforcement in the area of tax evasion. Under this agreement, which will be formally signed in 2016, Member States and Monaco will automatically exchange financial information regarding the residents of individual parties in their territories. I believe that the objective of signing this agreement is very important for the European Union and for Monaco, because with this agreement the tax administrations of the Member States and Monaco will be able to clearly identify taxpayers and, moreover, they will be able to enforce tax rules and assess the likelihood of the taxpayer evading tax. I believe it is right to finalise the agreement as soon as possible, as this will speed up the introduction of the instruments agreed in the agreement that will help to combat the action of rogue actors.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the Protocol amending the Agreement between the EU and Monaco on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. The EU and the Principality of Monaco have concluded an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, with the aim of improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax rules at international level. As a result of the new agreement, the tax authorities of the Member States and Monaco will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned; manage and ensure the implementation of their tax legislation in cross-border situations; assess the likelihood of tax evasion; avoid unnecessary further investigations.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Schwab's report on the exchange of information on financial accounts and it is expected to be adopted by the Council in the next period. This initiative strengthens the mechanisms for combating tax evasion and will enter into force from the start of next year.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. This agreement represents another step in the fight against tax evasion and evasion in the European Union. It will be more difficult to find, from now on, cases in which European citizens hide in banks of the Principality alleged funds initially earmarked for taxes.  The great progress I believe has been made with this resolution has been to expand the information exchanged between Monaco and the European Union, as the data transferred from 2018 on the basis of 2018 will include the balance sheets of bank accounts, as well as revenue and transfers. Greater cooperation, such as that sought by such measures, will strengthen the effectiveness of laws imposed by both member states and the Union, build more trust among taxpayers who rightly pay their taxes, and shield the authorities from future strategies to evade their responsibilities.  Finally, reaching such a positive agreement is a sign of clear institutional competence, and it is evidence of a constructive reaction to some tax scandals that have recently emerged in the press.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Principality of Monaco have signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. On the basis of this agreement, the EU and the Principality of Monaco will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, in order to increase efforts to combat fraud, avoidance and tax evasion from 1 January 2017. The agreement (the latest in a package of five agreements, covering Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Andorra and Monaco) is better than the status quo but is still unsatisfactory. I think we could and should have looked for a more complete and in-depth agreement. There are still, in fact, a number of easily circumvented regulatory gaps and not insignificant gaps in the area of transparency. In general, all the agreements signed are still a long way from solving most of the existing problems with all these countries in practice. That is why I preferred to abstain during the vote in this House.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report as it deepens international cooperation in the field of taxation and commits to compliance with the relevant regulations. I believe that this agreement is an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax avoidance. The aim of the agreement is to ensure that Monaco implements more stringent measures equivalent to the EU legal framework. In particular, in this measure, I appreciate the possibility of correctly and unequivocally identifying the taxpayers concerned and assessing the likelihood of tax avoidance.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Schwab report for agreeing to the EU-Monaco agreement, which represents an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and updates the 2004 agreement ensuring that Monaco adopts measures equivalent to those of the EU on the taxation of income from savings applied. Under the new agreement, EU Member States and Monaco will be able to automatically exchange information about existing financial accounts in their territories by residents of other territories, starting in 2018 for information collected from 1 January 2017.  The purpose of the agreement is to ensure that Monaco implements enhanced measures, equivalent to those of the European Union legal framework and that they comply with the procedures for the automatic exchange of financial account information in accordance with the rules laid down by the OECD.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Monaco. I support the purpose of the agreement, which is to ensure that Monaco implements enhanced measures to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and respects procedures for the automatic exchange of financial account information, as promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standards.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund offers forms of support to those who, due to structural changes in global trade, have lost their jobs. The request was made in this case for the Belgian region of Hainaut, where, as a result of a collective redundancy procedure, some 488 workers from a local company were made redundant. In view of the aims of the Fund and the fact that this area has one of the highest unemployment rates in the country, I voted in favour, believing that it is necessary to support young people and families in such a time of crisis.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 824 041 following 488 dismissed workers from Hainaut Machinery, as well as 300 young people from the Hainaut region who do not work or follow studies or training (ninis) and are under 25 years old. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in Belgium, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim of this report is to mobilise the sum of 1.824 million euros in order to reintegrate 488 workers laid off by 3 companies in the machine manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as support to 300 young people without employment, training or diploma ("NEET"). Even if this type of disaster is only the consequence of the FREE trade policies of the EU, I stand in defence of these workers and therefore support the granting of this aid.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Sinn Féin have called for reform of this European fund which is designed to support workers who lose their jobs as a consequence of globalisation. However, my Sinn Féin colleague Eoin Ó Broin requested documents to be released under the Freedom of Information Act which showed that millions of euro in such supports, provided through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, had already been returned to the European Commission. Sinn Féin has called on the Minister for Education Jan O’Sullivan and Minister of State for Skills Damien English to ensure €4.15 million in funding for 424 redundant Lufthansa Technik workers in Rathcoole, Dublin, to be spent by next September’s deadline as, as it stands, it appears that 63% of this fund will remain unspent.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of globalisation. It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and training to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving the application EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery, for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, or EGF for short, was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.  Trade has fallen sharply due to declining public and private infrastructure investment in the EU and the sharp rise in steel prices in Europe. In addition, the competitiveness of European construction machinery has decreased.  As a result, 488 workers in this sector were made redundant in the Belgian region of Hainaut. It also affects 300 young people under the age of 25.  In order to help those affected to reintegrate into the labour market, the mobilisation of the EGF would be extremely helpful. That is why I fully support Belgium's request.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.824 million euros for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by 3 companies in the machinery manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as support for 300 unemployed, training or diploma ("NEET" young people.  Belgium argues globalization as a key reason for the crisis in this sector, but also the decline in public and private investment that has squeezed the demand for machinery.  I voted in favour of this text in order to support laid-off workers who must not suffer the consequences of the actions decided by the EU (free trade at all costs, austerity...), even if these aids must not relieve governments of their responsibility.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to help financially reintegrate 488 laid-off workers in the machinery manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as to support 300 young people without jobs, training or diplomas. According to the Belgian authorities, globalisation is the main reason for the crisis in this sector, but we must also take into account the decline in public and private investment. If we are to support laid-off workers, who must not suffer the consequences of the free trade acts decided by the EU, it must not be riddated by governments of their responsibility.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have obviously supported this intervention of EUR 1,824,041 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which has not only helped to help the reintegration of workers made redundant at Caterpillar and Doosan, but which will also support 300 young NEET from Hainaut in their training and access to employment.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument designed to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The outbreak of the international economic crisis has led to a decline in public and private investment in infrastructure within the EU and a considerable increase in steel prices in Europe. These events have led to serious disruptions to trade and a loss of competitiveness of European construction machinery plants. Among the plants affected are those of Hainaut Machinery, in the Belgian region of Hainaut. I voted in favour of the Negrescu report because I agree with the need to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide assistance to the 488 redundant workers and the 300 young NEETs in the Hainaut region. Thanks to the EGF, they will be able to provide them with a coordinated package of instruments including training and mobility allowances as well as contributions for business start-ups and training, retraining and vocational training programmes.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in the one already punishable by unemployment, Hainaut region (Belgium), in the sector of the manufacture of machinery and industrial equipment, which come from an earlier process of redundancies. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report to mobilise resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because the redundancies produced at the Hainaut Machinery in Gosselies public works machinery factory meet the requirements required to make such aid. Layoffs are caused by the decline in public and private investment in infrastructure works and the steel crisis that have led to a loss of competitiveness of European construction plants in this type of machinery. The guarantees to be provided by Member States in the equitable implementation of support measures are also fulfilled and are also in line with the objectives of the fund the type of active employment programmes organized to reintegrate the dismissed into the world of work.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report proposes a mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.824 million euros for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by 3 companies in the machinery manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as support for 300 unemployed, training or diploma ("NEET" young people.  The explanations given by Belgium and the company for this dismissal are multiple: production of construction equipment in free fall, increase in the price of steel, increase in unit costs (hence the justification for relocations ...).  I voted for this report in order to support the employees, but I still consider that the EU is playing arsonist fireman with this report by now supporting what it has helped to achieve through the rejection of protectionism and its ultraliberalism.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I wanted to support the Negrescu report calling for the mobilisation of the EGF worth € 1,824,041 in favour of 488 workers made redundant in the machinery and equipment manufacturing sector of the Hainaut Region (BELGIUM). The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a key instrument for supporting citizens in this time of crisis, but I believe that the EU should do even more to improve its efficiency.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to allocate EUR 1 824 041 to reintegrate 488 workers dismissed by three machinery companies in Belgium's Hainaut region into the labour market and to support 300 young people who do not work or follow studies or training. With these funds, support, guidance and integration measures will be developed for dismissed workers covered by this application; job-seeking aid; integrated training; support for business creation; support for collective projects, job search and training assignments.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the commission's proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help Belgium support the return of 3 companies to the labour market.  A total of EUR 1 824 041 is intended to be allocated from the EGF for Belgium. The personalised services to be provided to redundant workers consist of six types of measures: support, advice and inclusion, (ii) facilitating job search, (iii) integrated training, (iv) support for setting up enterprises, (v) support for collective projects and (vi) job search and training allowances. Tailor-made services to NEETs include:(i) inclusion and counselling by directing to training or by offering specific introductory courses, (ii) training, (iii) personalised upskilling and (iv) job search, training and mobility allowances. As the Commission points out, the proposed actions described are active labour market measures classified as eligible actions. These actions do not replace passive social protection measures.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery'. The request complies with the requirements of the relevant Regulation, according to the Commission's investigation, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report proposes a mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.824 million euros for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by 3 companies as well as support for 300 young people without employment, training or diploma. We must support these laid-off workers, who must not be dependent on the actions decided by the EU (austerity, free trade), without absolving governments of their responsibility. Therefore, I voted for this report.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Sinn Féin have called for reform of this European fund which is designed to support workers who lose their jobs as a consequence of globalisation. However, my Sinn Féin colleague Eoin Ó Broin requested documents to be released under the Freedom of Information Act which showed that millions of euro in such supports, provided through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, had already been returned to the European Commission. Sinn Féin has called on the Minister for Education Jan O’Sullivan and Minister of State for Skills Damien English to ensure €4.15 million in funding for 424 redundant Lufthansa Technik workers in Rathcoole, Dublin, to be spent by next September’s deadline as, as it stands, it appears that 63% of this fund will remain unspent.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is useful for providing support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, either because of the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis or because of a new economic and financial crisis of a supra-regional nature. The Fund must be used to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market, updating their training and giving it financial support at the same time. It is therefore appropriate to mobilise the EGF in order to make a financial contribution to workers in the Belgian region of Hainaut who have suffered serious damage as a result of these phenomena.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing.
