This report aims to mobilise EUR 1.824 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 488 workers laid off by three machine-making companies in the Hainaut, Belgium. This sum should help to reintegrate these employees into the labour market, as well as to support 300 young unskilled job seekers.  Belgium, like all Western states, is subject to unfair international competition, exacerbated by social and environmental dumping by emerging countries. In these circumstances, the widespread free trade and austerity policies imposed on member states must be put to an end; the latter have weighed sharply downwards on the level of public investment in Europe.  I have therefore spoken in favour of the mobilization of this Fund, which nevertheless provides no lasting solution to stop the disastrous consequences of savage globalization.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund plays a key role in supporting workers affected by structural changes in global trade practices. In the given situation, the European Adjustment Fund was requested by Belgium in order to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from three undertakings. The issues that triggered these redundancies are both the decrease in public and private investment in infrastructure within the EU and the significant increase in steel prices in Europe, which have had a negative impact on trade, resulting in a loss of competitiveness for European construction machinery factories. By mobilising this fund, workers will benefit from various active labour market measures such as: vocational advice services, job-seeking facilitation, integrated training, job search and training allowances. I have expressed myself in favour of this request because I consider it necessary to support workers who have been made redundant for external reasons, through various forms that facilitate reintegration into the labour market.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. In an era of globalization, workers are the first victims of structural changes in international trade. They must therefore be protected and supported in the face of layoffs caused by heightened global competition.  Recently, the decrease in investment in infrastructure and the increase in the price of steel in Europe have led to a loss of competitiveness for European construction machinery plants.  Belgium has made a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This request has been validated by the European Commission. 488 laid-off employees of Hainaut Machinery will be able to benefit from financial assistance that will facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. Community aid will also benefit 300 unemployed and trained young people.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. The application in question was submitted by Belgium in connection with 488 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. in the Hainaut region, a company operating in the manufacture of machinery and equipment. I note that the Hainaut region is facing a difficult labour market situation, with an unemployment rate of 14.5 % (5.9 % higher than the national average), the loss of 1 236 jobs in 2013 and 1 878 jobs in 2014 in manufacturing, a 13 % drop in job vacancies since 2012 and a high percentage of underqualified workers , as more than half of job seekers do not have upper secondary education, as well as high levels of long-term unemployment. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from this fund because of the lack of support from local and national institutions.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was an approval of an application by Belgium to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The report approved aid of €1.8 million for 488 redundant workers from Caterpillar Belgium SA. The EGF funds are used to provide re-training and personalised job search supports to workers made redundant as a result of globalisation and major changes in global trade patterns. In recent years changes to the rules of the EGF has meant that workers made redundant as a result of the financial crisis can also be covered by the EGF programmes. Caterpillar Group in the EU was largely dependent on public/private partnerships. Since these have been considerably reduced since the financial crash, large scale liquidations ensued. Naturally I support the proposal to provide assistance to workers made redundant as a result of the crisis to find new employment.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the three manufacturing enterprises in the Hainaut region of Belgium in order to aid the workers who lost their jobs because of the major structural changes in world trade patterns. The decrease in investment and the rise in steel prices have hit the European the manufacturing of construction machinery hard, leading to redundant workers who are at risk of long-term unemployment and social exclusion. I am confident that the activation of the fund can effectively help these individuals find new jobs through professional training and guidance.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for workers made redundant from 3 companies operating in the Hainaut region of Belgium. This region is one of belgium's highest unemployment areas and the contribution is to promote the reintegration of as many as 488 workers and support up to 300 young people who are not in work and do not participate in any training.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report as the redundancies were indeed caused by a reduction in public and private investment in infrastructure in the EU and a significant increase in steel prices in Europe, which caused serious disruptions to trade and a loss of competitiveness of European plant construction machinery.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It is a given that this fund has been set up precisely to support workers from small and medium-sized companies who are experiencing problems of survival as a result of economic turbulence due to adaptation to a global environment. As I welcome the effort to support such companies for the benefit of employees, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Many workers and young people living in Belgium are currently made redundant in three companies and therefore have neither a job nor participate in any education or training cycle. In my opinion, the Belgian State's request should be taken into account. I believe that it is right to mobilise part of the Union's funds to ensure that those who are currently made redundant have support in finding suitable employment and academic and professional training. On the other hand, it is necessary that this fund should not be used for the sole purposes of social assistance, because then there would be quite another reality that would need it, but as long as its use is detailed and justified, I am also well aware that it should be used in moderation.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Support the Negrescu Report which allows the use of EUR 1 824 041 of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to reintegrate into the labour market of 488 workers made redundant from Hainaut Machinery and 300 young people who do not work, study or train. The redundancies were caused by the decline in public and private investment in EU infrastructure and the considerable increase in steel prices in Europe, which caused serious disruption to trade and the loss of competitiveness of European construction machinery factories. Through the use of this Fund, created to provide additional support to workers for major structural changes in world trade, it will be possible to support these workers through measures ranging from guidance/interpretation and facilitating job search to support for business creation or personalised professional requalification.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 824 041 following 488 dismissed workers from Hainaut Machinery, as well as 300 young people from the Hainaut region who do not work or follow studies or training (ninis) and are under 25 years old. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in Belgium, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, due to a global economic and financial crisis or because of and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. The European Parliament resolution, which I voted in favour of, authorises belgium's application at the end of 2015 for a financial contribution from the EGF for 488 redundant workers and 300 young people under the age of 25 who do not work and do not participate in any education or training (NEET) cycle in the Hainaut region. The resolution notes the admissibility of Belgium's application, as redundancies have a serious impact on employment and the local, regional and national economy, and authorises the mobilisation of the EGF for a financial contribution of EUR 1 824 041.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis, recession and austerity measures imposed in certain Member States for economic recovery have often had a strong impact on the well-being of citizens. Along with falling wages, massive redundancies and a drastic increase in unemployment, especially among young people, have caused a reduction in domestic incomes and, by implication, in the purchasing power of citizens. Since 2012, as a result of major disruptions caused by rising raw material prices and the relocation of various industries to Asian countries, Hainaut Province (Belgium) has seen a rapid increase in the unemployment rate. As I believe that a global perspective requires, first of all, local action, I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Adjustment and Globalisation Fund, in which 488 workers made redundant, as well as 300 young people under the age of 25 from the Hainaut region, who are not in employment, will receive support for employment , training, retraining and vocational training, contribution to the establishment of enterprises and social or mobility allowances.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills when they lose their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. in the event of the closure of a large company, the relocation of a factory outside the EU or the global financial and economic crisis. This is the sixth proposal examined under the 2016 budget and the 14th proposal for the machinery and equipment sector and concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1.8 million from the EGF to Belgium. Applies to 488 redundant workers and up to 300 assisted young people not in education, education or training (NEETs). Personally, I fully support the actions carried out in the framework of the New Jobs Strategy. I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for implementing these strategies. In view of the above-mentioned position, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ As a general rule, the EGF can be used only where over 500 workers are made redundant by a single company, or if a large number of workers are laid off in a particular sector. I voted in favour of this report as the eligibility for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment fund is met and as I believe in helping redundant workers integrate back in the labour market.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Hainaut Machinery Belgium has applied for the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). This company specializes in the manufacture of automotive machinery and equipment in the Hainaut region. Hainaut Machinery is calling for a mobilization of 1,824,041 euros, for 488 workers who have been laid off.  According to the European Commission, the impact of these layoffs on the local and regional economy and on employment is significant. The entire manufacturing sector reduced production in Wallonia, with 1,236 job cuts in 2013 and 1,878 in 2014.  Considering that the European Union must promote the transition of sectors in decline to a competitive economic model and the retraining of workers, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to enable Belgium to receive financial contributions from the EGF to support the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers. Since Belgium has complied with the conditions for granting the WEF's financial contributions and the redundancies are due to the reduction in public and private investment in infrastructure within the Union and the significant increase in the price of steel in Europe, so I voted in favour of this text.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. \u2012 On 4 May 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from two companies in the Hainaut region. This is the sixth request to be examined in the framework of the 2016 budget and a total of EUR 1 824 041 from the EGF for Belgium. The application concerns 488 redundant workers and approximately 300 non-employed young people (NEETs) who are not in education or training. The request was submitted to the Commission on 17 December 2015 and further information was added by 31 December 2015. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application.  Personalised services for redundant workers include the following six measures: assistance/advice/integration; facilitating the search for work; integrated training; aid for the creation of an undertaking; support for collective projects; job search and training support. According to the Commission, the measures described above constitute active labour market measures which are eligible activities under Article 7 of the EGF Regulation. These activities are not a substitute for passive social protection measures. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report proposes a mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.82 million euros for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by three companies, in the machine manufacturing sector, in Hainaut, Belgium. It also offers support to 300 unemployed young people, training or diplomas (so-called "NEET").  Belgium argues globalization as a key reason for the crisis in this sector, but also the decline in public and private investment that has squeezed demand in the machinery sector.  If it is necessary to support laid-off workers, who must not suffer the consequences of the actions decided by the EU (widespread free trade, austerity, etc.), these aids must not relieve governments of their responsibility. However, I voted in favour of this measure.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again I am voting against because I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not the right instrument for the implementation of such policies, nor do I believe that it is an efficient instrument that offers a return on investment in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market. But I would like to stress that both I and my Group of European Conservatives and Reformists support measures that create growth and jobs. However, this fund is not the right measure. In this case, it is proposed to allocate EUR 1.8 million for the redundancy of 488 workers in Belgium.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns and cannot exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million. Belgium has submitted an application following redundancies in the machinery and equipment manufacturing sector and has also decided to provide personalised services co-financed by the EGF to 300 young people who do not work, study or train.  I therefore agree that a financial contribution of EUR 1 824 041 should be mobilised to satisfy belgium's request.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: support for laid-off workers, who must not suffer the consequences of the actions decided by the EU.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Applications submitted under the intervention criteria are followed due to the high number of workers made redundant. This is one more of these cases, although the application does not meet the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulation and therefore falls within an application under exceptional circumstances and may have a serious impact on employment and the regional or national local economy. The application refers to 488 workers made redundant in 3 companies - SA Carwall, Caterpillar Belgium SA, Doosan SA - in the area of machinery and equipment manufacturing, arising following previous orders already related to the same companies. The conversation is always the same: as a result of the fall in demand for products in Europe, they close a production unit in Europe (Frameries, in this case) and supply the European market with factories located elsewhere (in South Korea, in this case). Each new approval of this Fund is a living libel accuser against capitalism, against the EU and its neoliberal policies. The Hainaut region is facing a difficult labour market situation, with an unemployment rate of 14.5 % (5.9 % higher than the national average), and support is therefore required for affected workers. But, more than palliative, a change of policies is required to make these palliatives unnecessary.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it reiterates its call on the Commission to assure public access to all the documents related to EGF cases.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund serves to assist specific companies in the Member States of the European Union in combating the effects of the financial and economic crisis and relocating employees from disappearing companies and placing them on the labour market. This particular application is a release of a total amount of EUR 1 824 041 in favour of Belgium. This amount affects 488 redundancies, of which more than 300 are young people who are not in employment.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which seeks to help European citizens in difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a report giving the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium, mainly Hainaut. The application relates to 488 redundancies of the enterprise Hainaut Machinery in Belgium operating in the economic sector, classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 28 (Manufacture of machinery and equipment) during the reference period 25 December 2014 to 25 September 2015. The EGAF funding of EUR 1,824,041 shall contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for 488 targeted beneficiaries following redundancies in three enterprises operating in the Hainaut region in the construction machinery sector, as well, as for 300 targeted young persons not in employment, education or training (NEETs) under the age of 25, with the aim of providing assistance for integrating the affected persons into the labour market. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 824 041 requested by Belgium in relation to the redundancies of hainaut machinery, because I believe that these measures are a glaring example of the added value that the EU brings to individual Member States. The Belgian region of Hainaut is experiencing a serious crisis, with an unemployment rate almost 6 points above the national average, almost 4 000 jobs lost in manufacturing in recent years and a worrying proportion of underskilled workers and longterm unemployed. The financing through the EGF of personalized services to assist in job search, support and integration into the labour market, support for start-ups and newly established collective enterprises and actions for retraining will therefore make it possible to implement individual and collective actions to protect redundant workers, with particular attention to workers over 55 years of age , which account for 36 % of the beneficiaries of the assistance. An expected intervention that gives direct benefits to the territories, show the added value of the EU.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained from the vote on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Belgium's application – EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery). In my opinion, the EGF in its current form is not really suitable for helping regions and people in such social upheavals.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was introduced to provide additional support for workers suffering from the changing structural circumstances of world trade. In this context, I support Belgium's request.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Globalization is a key reason for repeated sectoral crises. The Globalization Adjustment Fund is precisely the way to right the mistakes made by our institutions, following the opening of borders with countries that impose unfair competition on us. I voted for this report, which follows Belgium's request. The Fund will be mobilized to enable 488 workers to return to work. Almost 36% of the workers targeted are between the ages of 55 and 64 and have a high risk of social exclusion, especially as they have specific needs. In addition, it will help 300 unemployed, trained or graduated youth.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in the one already punishable by unemployment, Hainaut region (Belgium), in the sector of the manufacture of machinery and industrial equipment, which come from an earlier process of redundancies. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery). I support the proposal for a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of significant changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. On 4 May 2016 the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in three enterprises operating under the NACE Revision 2 Division 28 (Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c.) in the NUTS level 2 region of Hainaut (BE32) in Belgium.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the outflow of funds from the EU Globalisation Fund to give the 488 redundant workers and 300 young people out of education from Belgium with the aim of supporting and retraining them.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application to mobilise €1,824,041 of the EGF for 488 workers in Belgium made redundant in three enterprises under Hainaut Machinery that specialised in production of machines in the construction sector (Carwall SA; Caterpillar Belgium SA; Doosan SA) in the economic sector classified under the NCE Revision 2 division 28 (Manufacture of machinery and equipment). Hainaut Machinery is a Belgian Machine construction company that due to structural changes in world trade patterns has undergone serious disruptions in union trade, resulting in a negative impact on the profitability in the three EU enterprises that specialised in production of machines in the construction sector. Hainaut is facing a difficult labour market situation with an unemployment rate of 14.5% (5.9% higher than the national average), 1 236 job losses in 2013 and 1 878 in 2014 in the manufacturing sector. There has been a drop in job offers of 13% since 2012 and high proportion of underqualified labour, as over half of the job seekers lack upper secondary qualifications, as well as high levels of long-term unemployment, which stands at 39.0% of overall unemployment in Hainaut Region.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, as I had no objections to the proposed outcome.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide real support to redundant workers who have suffered as a result of the global financial crisis. This fund may not exceed the maximum ceiling of EUR 150 million per year. The application submitted by Hainaut Machinery for access to EUR 1 824 041 for Belgium from the EGF for the reintegration into the labour market of dismissed workers from three undertakings was adopted by the European Commission. I voted in favour of this report which provides concrete and effective measures for support, guidance and integration in the labour market, training and courses in this regard, job seekers and labour mobility.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application submitted by Belgium - EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery) as I think the Union's financial assistance to redundant workers should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible.  This Report agrees with the Commission that the intervention criteria referred to in Article 4(2) of the the EGF Regulation has also been fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 824 041 under that Regulation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report proposes a mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.824 million euros for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by 3 companies in the machinery manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as support for 300 unemployed, training or diploma ("NEET" young people.  Belgium argues globalization as a key reason for the crisis in this sector, but also the decline in public and private investment that has squeezed the demand for machinery.  If we are to support laid-off workers, who must not suffer the consequences of the actions decided by the EU (unlimited free trade, austerity, etc.), these aids must not relieve governments of their responsibility. This reason led me to vote in favour of the text.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the mobilisation in favour of the Belgian company Hainaut Machinery. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides assistance to workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in global trade related to globalisation. The grants from the Fund are intended to provide workers with professional advice, training, retraining and training, as well as mobility allowances. Since the Belgian authorities have provided the necessary information and this case fulfils the conditions for granting subsidies, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to mobilise, at the request of Belgium, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 1,824,041 to help sacked employees in the machinery and equipment manufacturing sector in Hainaut province. This amount should help finance support, counselling, integration or training for laid-off workers.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. – It is of paramount importance to identify the spots that cause inefficiencies and worsening of the standards of labour for the workers who experience the pressures from the structural changes in the patterns of trade. The European Globalisation Adjustment fund must necessarily play its role in dealing with these problems and assist workers in their transition to other optimal labour and income allocations due to the necessary structural adjustments.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This application concerns the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to redundancies at Carwall S.A., Caterpillar Belgium S.A. and Doosan S.A. of 488 workers and a further 300 young people under the age of 25 from the Hainaut region who have neither any other work nor education or training (NEET youth). I therefore agree with this report.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ As you know, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis. In this regard, the main aim of the fund is to help people who lost their jobs to reintegrate into the labour market. I supported the resolution because we should mobilise the fund to support Belgium’s submitted application EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery for a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies in the economic sector classified under the NACE Revision 2 Division 28 (Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c.) in the region of Hainaut (BE32). In this case, 488 redundant workers, as well as 300 young people from the Hainaut Region are not in employment, education or training and the EGF is expected to support them and give them new opportunities to reintegrate into the labour market. Another reason why we should support the mobilisation of the fund is that Belgian authorities have implemented all necessary measures to activate and receive the EGF fund.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide support for workers suffering the consequences of the continuous changes in world trade. There are many workers made redundant in the reference period 2014-2015. In the present case, the funds go to the Belgian company Hainaut Machinery and will be used to help redundant or redundant workers to be retrained and to find a new job. That is why I support the report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims in particular to grant 1.824 million euros for the reintegration into the labour market of 488 workers laid off in the machine manufacturing sector in Hainaut (Belgium).

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the request for Hainaut Machinery. This report proposes a mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.824 million euros in aid for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by 3 companies in the machinery manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as support for 300 young people without employment, training or diploma.  Belgium argues globalization as a key reason for the crisis in this sector, but also the decline in public and private investment that has squeezed the demand for machinery.  If we are to support the laid-off workers, who must not suffer the consequences of the actions decided by the EU (free trade at all costs, austerity...), it must not be riddated by governments of their responsibility.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Mobilisation Adjustment Fund is a European aid for laid-off workers who have been affected by globalisation to enable them to re-enter the labour market. This is currently the case for 488 employees of 3 companies in the machine manufacturing sector in Hainaut. The rapporteur proposes to provide them and 300 young people without jobs and diplomas with assistance of 1.824 million euros.  I support this proposal, because I believe that European citizens do not have to suffer the consequences of the DISASTROUS policies of the EU (free trade agreements, austerity...). On the other hand, it is necessary for governments to take responsibility and not to clear themselves with this aid.  I vote FOR its application.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 824 041 following 488 dismissed workers from Hainaut Machinery, as well as 300 young people from the Hainaut region who do not work or follow studies or training (ninis) and are under 25 years old. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in Belgium, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. As we have done on other occasions, I support this proposal to allocate part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to support the return to the labour market of dismissed Belgian workers in three companies operating in division 28 of NACE Revision 2, for the manufacture of machinery and equipment, in the Hainaut region of Belgium. The Belgian authorities indicate that the events that gave rise to redundancies are the decline in public and private investment in infrastructure and a significant increase in the price of steel in Europe, which have caused serious disruptions in trade and a loss of competitiveness. Since the Commission has ensured that the measures described constitute active labour market measures capable of receiving subsidies referred to in Article 7 of the EAGF Regulation, I support this report so that some of those funds are earmarked for that purpose.  For the reasons described above, I vote favorably for approval.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the mobilisation of funds to assist those facing long-term unemployment.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I am opposed to taxpayers' money and competing firms subsidised by firms that are failing in the market. The best thing we can do for businesses is to free up red tape, cut taxes and improve the business environment.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 This financial allocation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerns a total amount of EUR 1,824,041 to be used for the reintegration of 488 Belgian workers into the national labour market, as well as a further 300 young people for training and relevant integration into the national labour market. Hainaut Machinery is a heavy industrial company from the Wallonian region of Belgium, once one of the most industrialised regions of Europe. Miserably, but its economy lost another half a thousand jobs. It is hoped that providing financial support will help these people overcome existing difficulties and return to the labour market as soon as possible. Given the high importance of what has been written above and the importance of the issue as such, I voted positively.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 By mobilising, we are allocating a total of EUR 1 824 041 from the EGF in favour of Belgium, where mass redundancies at the Gosselies plant have occurred in the area of machinery and equipment production as a result of the reduction in infrastructure investment in the EU and the increase in steel prices. The aid is intended for 488 redundant workers and up to 300 young people who are not in employment, education or training. The application qualifies as an EFG, which is why I support it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. We have the same customary reservations about the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), which should not be used to clear governments and the European Union of their economic and employment responsibilities. However, we cannot oppose this financial aid amounting to EUR 1.824 million for the 488 laid-off workers in the machinery sector in Hainaut and 300 young people without employment or training.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund , EGF /2015/012 BE/ - for a total amount of EUR 1 824 041 for 488 workers made redundant by Carwall S.A. , Belgium Caterpillar S.A and Doosan S.A., companies operating in Belgium.  These appropriations relate in particular to measures to support collective projects and business creation. It is of the utmost importance to implement measures in favour of redundant workers in the field of: placement, training and safeguarding jobs.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the proposal to mobilize the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Belgium to support the return to the labour market of laid-off workers in three companies, which had to lay off staff in the face of declining public and private investment in infrastructure and the considerable increase in the price of steel in Europe, which have caused serious disruptions in trade and a loss of competitiveness of European construction machinery plants. The beneficiaries would be 488 laid-off workers and a maximum of 300 young people who do not work or follow studies or training.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. On 17 December 2015, Belgium submitted an application eGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of redundancies. About 300 young people under the age of 25 and 488 workers who are considered NEET youths (Not in Education, Employment or Training) have been made redundant. The report shares the Commission's view that the intervention criteria set out in Article 4(2) of the EGF Regulation are met and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 824 041 under this Regulation. This amount corresponds to 60% of the total cost of EUR 3 040 069.  This financial contribution will support: facilitating job search, integrated training, support for business start-ups, support for collective projects, job-search subsidies and training and training grants. I therefore support this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is proposed that the Globalization Adjustment Fund should help the layoffs of 488 workers and 300 young people without a degree.  In principle, I disapprove of the existence of this Fund, because it makes companies irresponsible for their relocations. I am aware of this phenomenon that raises questions about the usefulness of this Fund. It also prevents states from being concerned about the unfair competition that free trade allows. However, it is right to help these workers to allow their reintegration. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights.  The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. In the past, the EGF has been used by other EU countries and it is now up to Belgium, which submitted the EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery application, with the eGF applying for this aid, following redundancies in the economic sector classified in division 28 (Manufacture of machinery and equipment, n.e.) of NACE Rev. 2, in the level 2 region of nuts hainaut (BE32), and which estimates point to 488 workers made redundant, as well as 300 young people, from hainaut province, who do not work, study or follow any training (NEET).

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the tools at the Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to grant EUR 1,824,041 under the European Globalisation Fund (WEF), out of a total amount of EUR 3,000,000, to help 488 laid-off workers at Carwall SA, Caterpillar Belgium SA and Doosan SA in Hainaut province and to help 300 other unemployed young people under the age of 25 in hainaut who are not working , do not attend education or training (NEET).  The Hainaut, already facing a difficult labour market situation with an employment rate below the national average, suffers particularly from the decline in public and private investment in infrastructure in the European Union and the significant increase in steel prices in Europe, which inevitably leads to relocations.  These 788 unemployed and young workers had to be helped to integrate or reintegrate into the labour market by providing them with active career guidance, job search assistance, vocational training or retraining, help in setting up a business and contributing to collective projects.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. This fund may not exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million. The amounts concerned shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a reserve. The European Commission has adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the Fund in favour of Belgium to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in three enterprises in Belgium. A total of EUR 1 824 041 for Belgium concerns 488 redundancies and up to 300 young people who are neither in employment nor in education or training. The Commission has assessed that the Belgian application in question fulfils the conditions for a financial contribution. The personalised services to be provided to redundant workers are six types of measures. These include, in particular, integration, job search support, integrated education, support for business start-ups, support for joint projects and job search allowances. Personalised services provided to young people include mobilisation and guidance for the purpose of either further education or training, training, individual upskilling and job search, training and mobility allowances. I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because it is essential to provide additional support to workers who are suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or of the global financial and economic crisis and to assist their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Belgium has applied for the Fund: it intends to provide personalised services to 488 workers made redundant at Carwall SA, Caterpillar Belgium SA and Doosan SA in the Hainaut region, as well as to 300 unemployed young people under the age of 25 who are unemployed, not trained or trained in the Hainaut region.  Measures planned for the 488 made redundant: assistance/advice/integration; facilitating job search; integrated training; aid for the creation of an undertaking; support for collective projects and job search and training allowances, while mobilisation and guidance for 300 young people for further education/further training and introduction; targeted training, personalised training, job search, training and mobility allowances. The cost of the measures is EUR 3 040 069. The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council the granting of a financial contribution of EUR 1 824 041 to the measures under the EGF Regulation.  In its report, the Committee on Budgets recommends that Parliament agree with the Commission that the intervention criteria set out in the EGF Regulation are met and that Belgium is therefore eligible for that aid. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This report proposes a mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.824 million euros for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by 3 companies in the machinery manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as support for 300 young people without employment, training or diploma.  Belgium argues globalization as a key reason for the crisis in this sector, but also the decline in public and private investment that has squeezed the demand for machinery. This action should be supported, even if it is only a modest compensation on the part of the EU for workers, which it plunges into precariousness through its ultra-liberal policies.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium has applied for a contribution from the EGF following redundancies of Carwall SA, Caterpillar Belgium SA and Doosan SA, and estimates indicate that 488 redundant workers, as well as 300 young people from hainaut province who do not work, study or train (NEETs), under 25, participate in the measures. The application complies with Article 4(2) of the EGF Regulation, which allows a derogation from the number of workers made redundant, and Belgium is so entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 824 041 under that Regulation, representing 60 % of the total cost of EUR 3 040 069. I stress the importance of improving the employability of all workers made redundant through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, and it is vital that the proposed training is adapted not only to the needs of redundant workers but also to the real environment of enterprises. I believe that measures aimed at the reintegration of workers made redundant into the labour market, avoiding the consequences of a significant impact on the Hainaut economy, should be adopted.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I vote for this aid to workers who are victims of globalization.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of three Belgian companies specialising in the production of parts and the assembly of machinery used in the construction sector to finance support, guidance, integration, training, business start-up assistance and the job search allowance of 488 laid-off people.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund intervenes to support sacked employees due to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalisation, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis, or due to a new global financial and economic crisis.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 As the process of globalization of trade in Europe's productive sectors progresses, in conjunction with socio-economic phenomena as relevant as persistent economic and financial crises, we can only vote in favour of a proposal aimed at rebalancing commercial forces and providing support to workers made redundant or whose self-employment has ceased. It mainly includes the use of an annual fund of EUR 150 million together, combined with legislative and budgetary instruments. In this way, the European Union is able to assist all those workers who, as a result of structural changes in world trade, find themselves having to re-enter the labour market. In this context, for example, intervention in belgium's industrial sector can be taken as an example, which has seen its competitiveness in the production of construction machinery steadily diminished by relocating production facilities to Asia. In addition to the actions financed by the Structural Funds, the Commission has therefore not only allocated EUR 1.8 million to some 500 workers, but has promoted state intervention in projects aimed at facilitating job search, providing integrated training and supporting the creation of new businesses.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic problems within the European Union, such as the decline in infrastructure investment and the rise in steel prices, have severely affected the competitiveness of construction machinery companies. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is intended, inter alia, to help and support employers affected by the consequences of such structural changes. Against this background, I supported the application of Hainaut-Namur Glass in Belgium, and I hope that the subsidies for redundant workers will be a real help in their rapid employment in the labour market.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission has proposed to provide Belgium with €1.8 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help 488 workers made redundant by several manufacturers of construction machinery in the province of Hainaut (Wallonia, Belgium). The aim of the funding is to help these former workers to find new jobs. 300 young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs) will also be included in the actions planned. The proposal now goes to the European Parliament and the EU’s Council of Ministers for approval. As rapporteur I have voted for this report that would help the workers and the NEETs find new jobs by providing them with active career guidance, job-search support, vocational training and retraining, promotion of entrepreneurship and contributions to collective projects. Job-search and training allowances will also be made available.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Sinn Féin have called for reform of this European fund which is designed to support workers who lose their jobs as a consequence of globalisation. However, my Sinn Féin colleague Eoin Ó Broin requested documents to be released under the Freedom of Information Act which showed that millions of euro in such supports, provided through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, had already been returned to the European Commission. Sinn Féin has called on the Minister for Education Jan O’Sullivan and Minister of State for Skills Damien English to ensure €4.15 million in funding for 424 redundant Lufthansa Technik workers in Rathcoole, Dublin, to be spent by next September’s deadline as, as it stands, it appears that 63% of this fund will remain unspent.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support to redundant workers and self-employed persons whose activities have ceased as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns as a result of globalisation as a result of the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis or as a result of a new global financial and economic crisis, and to support their reintegration into the labour market. The report notes that following caterpillar Belgium's announcement on 23 February 2013 of a collective redundancy procedure at its production site located in Gosley, most of its 1399 workers were the subject of application EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar, and stresses that the Esno region faces a difficult labour market situation with an unemployment rate of 14.5% (5.9% higher than the national average), 1236 jobs closed in 2013 and 1878 in 2014, as well as a high level of long-term joblessness. In turn, the EGF report must not replace measures which are the responsibility of undertakings under national law.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Hainaut Machinery in Belgium is facing the dismissal of 480 employees. These employees are in a socio-economically tense area that needs this support. Accordingly, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for financial assistance submitted under the Belgian application submitted.  In particular, this support is necessary in order to mitigate the existing negative consequences. In addition, measures will be appropriate to help workers integrate into the labour market by increasing employability, and provide access to refresher courses or other measures tailored to their needs, and individual measures are provided for only for young people.  However, it is essential to ensure that all the measures envisaged respect the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination, as well as the avoidance of any double funding.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to support European workers affected by the global economic crisis or changes in the structure of world trade in order to assist them in their reintegration into work; whereas Belgium applied in 2015 for financial assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; whereas, moreover, as the Commission found, the application, while not complying with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, was submitted in accordance with the criteria set out in Article 4(2); Finally, given that, due to the critical economic and employment situation in the region concerned, the involvement of NEETs in access to the fund even after 2017 cannot but be welcomed and that the guarantees provided by Belgium are satisfactory, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Due to production cuts across one manufacturing sector in Belgium, the production of machinery and appliances, resulting in the redundancies of as many as 488 hainaut workers made redundant, and as the EU has instruments but also obligations to assist workers affected by major structural changes, I supported the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on the basis of a request submitted by Belgium. I am pleased that, with the help of collectively laid-off workers, financial assistance received from the Fund will also be invested in measures to create new opportunities and jobs for unemployed young people of which there are extremely many in this region.  Belgium's Hainaut region faces a difficult labour market situation, with an employment rate of 52.7%. This situation is made even more difficult by the fact that production is decreasing across the manufacturing sector in Wallonia, which is why 3,114 jobs were lost in 2013 and 2014, and the regional employment service reports that since 2012 the supply of vacancies has significantly decreased. On the other hand, the Hainaut labour market is characterised by a high proportion of underqualified labour (just over half of jobseekers do not have completed secondary school), so it is important to invest in guidance and training measures and to improve needs-friendly skills.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The EU has set up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in global trade flows and the global financial and economic crisis and to help them re-enter the labour market. Belgium applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) following the redundancies of workers in the economic machinery and device manufacturing sector, and as the measures are projected to cover 488 displaced workers, as well as 300 young people from the Hainaut region who are not in employment, education or training and are under 25. Although the application does not meet the eligibility criteria referred to in Article 4, paragraph 1 of the The EGF Regulation, submitted on the basis of the intervention criteria set out in Article 4(2) allowing a derogation from the eligibility criteria in accordance with the number of workers made redundant, I agree with the Commission that the intervention criteria referred to in Article 4(2) of directive 2013/2013 have been referred to as a derogation. The EGF Regulation has also been met and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 824 041 under that Regulation, amounting to 60% of the total cost of EUR 3 040 069.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. This application relates to the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 1 824 041 in favour of Belgium. It covers 488 workers made redundant and up to 300 young people who are not in work and who do not participate in any education or training (NEET). According to the Belgian authorities, the events that caused the redundancies were the decline in public and private investment in infrastructure in the EU and the considerable increase in steel prices in Europe, which caused serious disruptions to trade and the loss of competitiveness of European construction machinery plants. I hope that the mobilisation of the EGF will prove to be a decisive instrument for supporting these workers and a valuable aid to the communities affected by the crisis in the construction machinery production sector.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills when they lose their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. in the event of the closure of a large company, the relocation of a factory outside the EU or the global financial and economic crisis. This is the sixth proposal examined under the 2016 budget and the 14th proposal for the machinery and equipment sector and concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1.8 million from the EGF to Belgium. Applies to 488 redundant workers and up to 300 assisted young people not in education, education or training (NEETs). This conclusion follows on from BE/Caterpillar's APPLICATION EGF/2014/011 concerning redundancies at the Gosselies plant. Actions implementing strategies for growth and jobs are worthy of support. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of structural changes in international trade, such as relocations or business closures. Here, 488 former employees of the Belgian company Hainaut Machinery will receive a total of 1.8 million euros in aid to finance measures such as support, guidance, help with the creation of businesses or job search allowances.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Good news in a difficult social climate: the European Parliament has granted Belgium EUR 1,824,041 to support the reintegration into the labour market of 488 workers laid off by several manufacturers of construction machinery in the province of Hainaut in Wallonia.  Eventually, about 300 other unemployed young people are also expected to benefit from the aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). This aid is the European participation, up to 60%, aimed at accompanying the former employees of the Carwall, Caterpillar Belgium and Doosan factories in their job search and more broadly in their career reorientation.  Like many economic layoffs, people working in a sector that is facing the brunt of global competition are affected. In this case, the decline in public and private investment in infrastructure and the significant increase in steel prices in Europe have caused serious disruptions in trade, undermining the competitiveness of European construction machinery plants. This financial assistance is therefore welcome for the families of these workers. The major challenge for the Juncker Commission is now to establish a European industrial policy that can optimise European know-how in the cutting-edge sectors.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I have, of course, voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. As a reminder, Belgium had applied for a financial contribution from this European Fund following layoffs in the economic sector related to the manufacture of machinery and equipment, in Hainaut province. Layoffs had occurred at Carwall, Caterpillar Belgium and Doosan following the disruptions in the construction machinery trade in the European and global markets in recent years (demand for products from all three companies had declined accordingly).  It should be noted that in addition to the 488 workers made redundant, 300 young people under the age of 25 from the same region who are not working should be affected by the measures and benefit from personalised services co-financed by the Fund, including: mobilization and guidance to undertake new specific studies or training, a personalised upgrade of skills, etc.  However, the Fund's current regulations provide that such access can only be granted until December 31, 2017. I would therefore like to take this opportunity to request a review of the regulation as part of the revision of the multi-year financial framework so that these people can continue to benefit from this access after 2017.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. Hainaut Machinery's application to benefit from the European Globalisation Fund is a sad outcome of globalisation and an escalating global competitive struggle. However, in order not to find people on the street when big businesses are closed, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up. The case we are discussing is quite sad: 1 399 workers were made redundant in 2014. More support is now being sought. And all this is happening in a region where the labour market is already in a difficult situation, with the unemployment rate reaching 14.5%, or 5.9% higher than the national average. Since 2012, job offers in the Hainaut (Hen) region have fallen by 13%, with the market itself characterised by a large number of unskilled workers: almost half of jobseekers do not have secondary education.  I therefore support this proposal unequivocally, and at the same time I call on the Member States to take measures to avoid such large redundancies.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EF) in the amount of € 1 824 041 for Belgium in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 488 workers made redundant by three companies operating in the economic sector of machinery and equipment manufacturing , a sector that has suffered as a result of the decline in public and private infrastructure investment in the EU and which has been greatly affected by the considerable increase in steel prices in Europe. From the analysis carried out, it was possible to conclude that the application meets the assumptions of allocation of the fund provided for in the EFRegulation, and I voted in favour of the allocation of this financial contribution, which will be channelled to support, guidance and integration of redundant workers, seeking to facilitate the search for employment, support for the creation of companies, collective projects and also training subsidies.  The 300 young people who do not work, study or train will also be included with mobilisation and guidance measures to initiate complementary education and training actions within the framework of the eligible actions provided for by Article 7 of the EGF Regulation.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument available to the European Union to provide additional support and help the reintegration into the labour market of those workers affected by the consequences of the process of economic globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis. In this particular case, belgium has requested the mobilisation of the Fund in order to reallocate some 500 workers in the manufacturing sector. In a Europe that is constantly criticised for the austerity policies imposed on its Member States, the Adjustment Fund is a positive note, which is why I voted in favour of the report. This is an opportunity to reflect on the challenges posed by globalisation to which the EU can no longer wait to respond. Partial solutions only buffer the problem, but it is necessary to reflect on forward-looking solutions, which can relaunch long-term, and effective growth and employment, that is, equal to the challenges posed by global trade.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in the one already punishable by unemployment, Hainaut region (Belgium), in the sector of the manufacture of machinery and industrial equipment, which come from an earlier process of redundancies. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Negrescu report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I am pleased that, as a result of this decision, 488 laid-off workers, as well as 300 young people under the age of 25 in the Hainaut region, who are not in employment, will receive support for employment, training, retraining and vocational training, a contribution to the establishment of enterprises and social or mobility allowances.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Belgium's application – EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery)', as we should also help our citizens in times of rapid economic change. The package that has now been adopted represents money for counselling, training and help with business start-ups for around 800 people, 300 of whom are younger people who either lack training or have never had a job. A similar package has already been adopted for German companies in difficulty.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 824 041 following 488 workers dismissed from Hainaut Machinery, as well as 300 young people from the Hainaut region who do not work or follow studies or training (ninis) and are under 25 years of age. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in Belgium, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the measures that are implementing policies to create growth and jobs. Nevertheless, I voted against this resolution. In fact, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right instrument for implementing such policies, nor do I think it is an effective instrument that offers the right value (by reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market) for money.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in the structure of world trade in order to provide support to workers made redundant as a result of globalisation or the financial and economic crisis. Following a request from Belgium, we approved EUR 1 824 000 for 488 redundancies in three machinery and equipment companies. This project will also support 300 young people under the age of 25. Personalised services will be provided for redundant workers and young people, including: mobilisation and guidance, either for the purpose of further education and training or for the purpose of initial training to identify interests, specific training courses, individual upskilling, job search allowances and training and mobility.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is trying to support unemployed people who have suddenly been made redundant. The EU has created personalised services for them, providing support, guidance and integration to the unemployed.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Caterpillar Belgium SA laid off 1,399 workers in the Hainaut region due to a significant rise in steel prices in Europe, where the current unemployment rate is a high of 14.5% (5.9% higher than the national average). The report notes that the fund will finance integrated worker training, start-up support and group projects, as well as the cost of job search and training allowances.  Taking into account that the Union undertakes to provide financial assistance to workers made redundant as a result of the economic crisis as soon as possible, it is very important that this proposal is adopted as soon as possible. I support the Budget Committee's report, as the launch of the Hainaut Region Globalisation Adjustment Fund (BE32) will provide additional support to workers and unemployed young people affected by the decline in competitiveness of European producers.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFG) was created to provide additional assistance to workers directly affected by major structural changes in global sample trade. On 4 May 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers who have become redundant in 3 companies operating under NACE Audit 2 Division 28 (Machinery and Equipment Manufacturing) in nuts level 2 of the Hainaut region (BE32) in Belgium. The Belgian authorities say that the events leading up to the redundancies, the decline in public and private investment in infrastructure in the EU and the significant increase in steel prices in Europe are causing serious disruption to trade. I support the proposal for this Resolution because I believe that its aim is to support redundant and self-employed workers, whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in globalisation pattern trade, as a result of the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration in the labour market.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds – the application from Belgium's Hainaut Machinery. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is implemented as an expression of the Solidarity of the European Union, which is one of the foundations on which the community was built. With today's confirmation in plenary, with EUR 1,824,041, we will help 488 redundancies from three companies in the manufacturing sector of other machinery and equipment in the Belgian region of Hainaut, and 300 young people who are not in employment, education or training and are under 25. It is very important to ensure that training is consistent with the needs of the region and neighbouring regions and attention to the needs of older workers. Older workers are at higher risk of becoming unemployed and socially excluded in the long term, so they have specific needs to take into account when supporting them.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising globalisation funds because the regions facing tough structural changes must be helped and Belgium's application was properly fulfilled. In Finland, too, there is a need for these funds, for example in the cities of Oulu and Salo.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has set up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers who are suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or of the global financial and economic crisis and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. I welcome the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium, which will cover the 488 redundancies of the enterprise Hainaut Machinery operating in the economic sector during the reference period 25 December 2014 to 25 September 2015. The EGAF funding of EUR 1 824 041 shall contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for 488 targeted beneficiaries following redundancies in three enterprises operating in the Hainaut region in the construction machinery sector, as well, as for 300 targeted young persons not in employment, education or training (NEETs) under the age of 25 , with the aim of providing assistance for integrating the affected persons into the labour market. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. This is the sixth mobilisation of the EGAF in 2016.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade.  Under the provisions of Article 12 of the Regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 1311/2013 setting the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020 and Article 15 of the Regulation (EU) No. 1309/2013, the annual endowment of the WEF may not exceed EUR 150,000,000 (at 2011 prices). The necessary amounts are included in the general budget of the European Union as a provision. With regard to the procedure, in accordance with point 13 of the 2 December 2013 inter-institutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and good financial management, the Commission, to activate the EGF when the request has been favourably assessed, presents the budgetary authority with a proposal to mobilise the WEF and, at the same time, the corresponding transfer request. In case of disagreement, a trilogue procedure is initiated.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers in Belgium who lost their jobs at Hainaut Machinery, a company producing construction equipment. In recent years, trade in the sector of machinery and equipment manufacture has suffered significantly because of the declining public and private investments in infrastructure, the increasing cost of steel, and the delocalisation of production to other countries.
