Furthermore, the situation of Hainaut Machinery also has a negative effect on the suppliers as well as on the local and regional economy of the region Hainaut, which has been facing an unemployment rate of 14.5%. The fund will thus provide the former employees with much needed advice, guidance and training to improve their future employability, will offer training allowances and facilitate their job-search.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund supports people who have lost their jobs as a result of significant structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation, the closure of large enterprises or the relocation of production outside the European Union, or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. Belgium has applied under this programme for egf/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following redundancies in the economic sector.  As an MEP, I support all measures to create jobs and growth, but I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not an effective tool for reintegration of redundancy and in principle I do not support its work and voted against this Report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. I supported the proposal to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In the case of Belgium, there are 488 workers who were made redundant during the reference period from 25 December 2014 to 25 September 2015 and 300 unemployed young people. In recent years, intra-Union trade in construction machinery has experienced serious disruption due to the decline in public and private infrastructure investment. This has led to a dramatic loss of market share for European producers, together with a significant increase in steel prices in Europe. Workers aged between 55 and 64 account for 35.9% of the total target beneficiaries of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as they are at higher risk of long-term unemployment and social exclusion.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in the one already punishable by unemployment, Hainaut region (Belgium), in the sector of the manufacture of machinery and industrial equipment, which come from an earlier process of redundancies. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ For several reasons that may change in every country, companies strategies affect their workers’ jobs and lives. That is why I support this resolution, to help in an effective and fast way those who are suffering from the consequences of structural changes in world trade patterns or of the global financial and economic crisis and to assist their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report proposes a mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide 1.824 million euros for the reintegration into the market of 488 workers laid off by 3 companies in the machinery manufacturing sector in Hainaut, as well as support for 300 unemployed, training or diploma ("NEET" young people.  Belgium argues globalization as a key reason for the crisis in this sector, but also the decline in public and private investment that has squeezed the demand for machinery.  If we are to support laid-off workers who are suffering the consequences of EU decisions, these aids must not relieve governments of their responsibility.  I voted FOR this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to help workers who have been affected by changes in international trade. The tools provided to help redundant workers are m.in training, career guidance or support for business creation. I decided to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The objective of the Fund is to support workers who have been made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade or as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and to support their reintegration into the labour market. I voted in favour of the Belgian request.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in the one already punishable by unemployment, Hainaut region (Belgium), in the sector of the manufacture of machinery and industrial equipment, which come from an earlier process of redundancies. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – In particular, I welcome the position of the Belgian authorities and their cooperation with the social partners in supporting joint projects for workers considering setting up a so-called social enterprise together as a group, as this measure can have extremely high added value; I welcome the fact that, in addition to the 488 redundancies, 300 young people under the age of 25 (NEETs) living in the same region are expected to participate in measures and receive personalised services co-financed by the EGF, which include: inclusion and counselling by directing training or offering introductory courses to identify interests; specific training courses; personalised upskilling; job search, training and mobility benefits.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application from Belgium - EGF/2015/012 BE/Hainaut Machinery). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The report highlights the need to improve employability of all workers by adapted training and expects that the training offered in the coordinated package will meet both needs of the workers and the business environment in the region and in the neighbouring regions. In addition, the report calls on Member States to prepare, together with the social partners, strategies to anticipate the projected labour market changes and to protect Union jobs and skills, especially when negotiating trade agreements in order to ensure fair competition rules and common measures against economic, social and environmental dumping. The report equally highlights the need of improving employability of all workers by adapted training and expects that the training offered in the coordinated package will meet both needs of the workers and the business environment in the region and in the neighbouring regions.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay compensation for maximum redundancies for the cessation of different business activities of the Member States. In this case we are talking about a transfer that comes to reintegrate 488 manufacturing workers into the Belgian Hainaut region and for the support of 300 unemployed young people through education and training. It is therefore appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 824 following 488 dismissed workers from Hainaut Machinery, as well as 300 young people from the Hainaut region who do not work or follow studies or training (ninis) and are under 25 years of age. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in Belgium, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering from the effects of major structural changes due to globalisation. On 4 May 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of funds from the EGF to Belgium to support the return to the labour market of workers who have been forcibly made redundant at three companies in Hainaut. I supported this Belgian question.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund follows the line I have maintained. I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be abolished and linked to the European Social Fund. However, while this programme is still in place and has supported, among other things, the Oulu and Salo regions in the sudden structural changes that have affected them, I also support this report. The employment situation in Hainaut, Belgium, is unsustainable due to the mass reduction procedure of the belgian company Caterpillar, which operated in the region, and therefore EU support measures are justified.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Belgian company Hainaut Machinery is forced to lay off 480 employees to help reintegrate into the labour market. This amounts to EUR 1.8 million. The Belgian authorities argue that the redundancies were caused by the decline in public and private infrastructure investment in the EU and the significant rise in steel prices in Europe. I believe that it is right to offer a perspective to these people who have fallen victim to a misguided economic policy.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This request is the sixth in 2016 and concerns the manufacturing of machinery and equipment. According to the report, around 800 people have been affected in Wallonia, Belgium, in this case. The total amount is EUR 1 824 041 from the EGF for Belgium. I supported the report.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted on the call for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium to facilitate the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant by 3 companies operating in the manufacture of machinery and equipment, concentrated in the Hainaut region. It should be pointed out that this request is to be considered complementary to an initial application submitted by Belgium in 2014, since the original cause is the announcement made by Caterpillar Belgium S.A., on 23 February 2013, concerning the initiation of collective redundancy proceedings at its production plant in Gosselies. Most of the nearly 1 400 workers made redundant by the company were considered by the EGF in 2014, while today a contribution of EUR 1 824 041 (out of a total cost of around EUR 3 million) is being asked to help reintegrate 488 workers who have been made redundant and to support up to 300 young people who are not working and who do not participate in any education or training cycle. I am in favour of mobilising this fund as a general rule, although I am aware that this is probably not the instrument that best can help workers affected by company crises, but in the absence of viable alternatives I believe that it should be supported nonetheless.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds – the application from Belgium's Hainaut Machinery. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support to workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade flows as a result of globalisation and the global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, today is a great day for bluefin tuna fishermen and especially for those in the Canary Islands. The European Parliament has said, by a crushing majority, that the allocation of quotas for bluefin tuna fishing has to be fairer and that Member States have to take into account traditional boats that do artisanal and more sustainable fishing. And that's our case. The recovery plan is clearly working. There is therefore a possibility of increasing quotas significantly, and this increase should be aimed primarily at these fleets. It cannot be repeated that a craft fleet, such as the Canarian fleet, with a miserable quota, sees this fisheries close in 24 hours, having consumed that quota. I thank Parliament for the majority support for my proposal, and my vote is a resounding yes to sustainable fishing and a much fairer allocation of bluefin tuna quotas.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, I would like to support this Regulation, which makes ICCAT's recommendations into European legislation and bet on a methodology which, according to scientific estimates, is managing to recover stocks of bluefin tuna at sea. This species is crucial, especially for the delicate Mediterranean ecosystem, and one of the most valued in the world. Therefore, recovery and maintenance of fishing activity must go hand in hand. In this regard, I stress my special support for three fundamental issues. The first, my total agreement to offer special recognition to the traditional arts with which this species is fished: either longline, or live bait fishing or almadraba. We are talking about arts that have a low impact on marine ecosystems, a high degree of selectivity of catches and, in addition, an appreciable ability to create jobs. The second is to bet on a more equitable distribution of fishing quotas between the different fleets, with particular consideration for small-scale and artisanal fishing. Finally, to strengthen Parliament's powers in transposing the recommendations of regional fisheries organisations, which are the responsibility of this House and the Council and should not be controlled by delegated acts of the Commission.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, I would like to use this opportunity to explain why I abstained in this report. It is because in the passage of this Regulation from Parliament to the Council we have lost something: the explicit defence of additional and specific quotas for almadraba tuna. A reference to almadrabas is not enough, as is done in this document. They must be defended and supported, because almadraba tuna represents fishing with rights, fishing linked to a territory and a nearby economy. It represents environmentally sustainable fishing, even if the PP Government has been forgotten in its unfair allocation of quotas. I do not want to extend myself, because this is all something that this House already knows and which it will have to defend more firmly against the Governments of the Council in the future. We don't abandon our commitment. We have presented in the Committee on Fisheries two pilot projects with which we seek to protect and defend the production of almadraba tuna through specific quotas and a special label for this product, an initiative which I trust will receive a favourable vote.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because it is a good thing that the ICCAT plan has been a real success and that today our seas, the Mediterranean Sea in particular, are abounding in bluefin tuna. However, I would like to stress that it was the fishermen who made great efforts to comply with the limits imposed, and today it is the fishermen themselves who are returning to fishing. Unfortunately, however, this is not the case. The increase in quotas as a result of the restocking of bluefin tuna has not involved small-scale fishing at all. It is always only the large shipowners who benefit and thus be able to exploit a sea that has returned to being rich and which could therefore once again be the economic turning point for thousands of small fishermen and small family farms living at sea. European fisheries policy must therefore take the right direction, and I suggest support for small-scale and traditional fishing, I choose small-scale fishing, operators who have counted on the sea for centuries and who today are crushed by rules and economic interests that have little to do with environmental sustainability.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Commission for the Conservation of Tunas in the Atlantic (ICCAT) has the power to adopt binding recommendations for the conservation and management of fisheries. Of the fish species protected by ICCAT, bluefin tuna is undoubtedly of central importance, given the many decisions taken since 2006 to limit their catches, for example, to a maximum percentage granted. I therefore voted in favour because I believe that such strategies will not only be in favour of the environment and biodiversity, but will also ensure sustainable economic development.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014, ensuring uniform and effective application of them throughout the European Union. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete, which addresses some poor technical aspects and which was dealt with with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries. However, I would like to stress that the text resulting from interinstitutional negotiation is much less ambitious than the text left Parliament itself. Since, although the importance of artisanal fishing is important, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba, which I understand, deserves a specific mention in this regulation have been removed.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this report because it was a serious step backwards in favour of industrial tuna fishing and a fair allocation of fishing quotas. This report represents the outcome of the trilogs with commission and council on the recovery plan for bluefin tuna. The parliament's initial position, which we supported, contained provisions for traditional, sustainable and small-scale arts, specific to the almadraba. Parliament's proposal would have allowed an improvement in the situation of almadrabas with an increase in quotas for them which represent an increase in the sustainable exploitation of tuna. However, all these references have been erased in the process of trilogs relegating the almadraba to a mere reference without any binding power. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this project, which, despite some problems (request on the part of the Commission to carry out delegated acts, only a few tuna boats take advantage of the reconstituted stocks), allows to respect the codecision procedure established between the European Commission and Parliament. It also defends artisanal fishing methods (madrague) and does not go beyond the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), as the Commission wanted.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, which was concerned with technical measures concerning caging operations in the Mediterranean.  The report which was a multi annual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean put in place by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) in 2006 to address the alarming depletion in stock levels. However, it should be noted that the provisions contained within the recovery plan do not apply to Ireland

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. The introduction of quotas and rules in fisheries for the protection of bluefin tuna stocks is a particularly important issue. I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because, in order to have uniform and effective legislation throughout the European Union, the measures included in the recovery plan adopted in 2012 and 2014 should be incorporated into a Union regulation and implemented by all Member States.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Tuna stocks have been restored. The debate is about a simple transposition of the Convention of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.  The European Commission wants to act very quickly, and it is asking for delegated acts. But the rapporteur defended the codecision procedure, in order to defend the prerogatives of the European Parliament.  Only a few tuna fishers take advantage of the stocks; artisanal fishing is largely excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it. However, the European Commission and MEPs stress the protection that must be afforded to traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly. The Commission specifies that it will provide these traditional fishing methods with a specific advantageous regime. The Commission wanted to go beyond the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. Members opposed it by amendment. Thus, on the whole, the amended project allows us to respect the codecision procedure, to defend artisanal fishing methods (madrague) and not to go beyond iccAT's recommendations. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The debate is about a simple transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). In addition, this report defends the codecision procedure and the prerogatives of the European Parliament, while the Commission calls for delegated acts to be taken on the pretext of being able to act more quickly. Finally, against the Commission's desire to go beyond ICCAT's recommendations, this report aims instead at better compliance with the current guidelines; So I voted for it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In the context of the new Common Fisheries Policy, I approved the transposition into EU law of measures of the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and Mediterranean that were adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCTA) between 2012 and 2014.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2006, ICCAT, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, consisting of a series of measures to be followed up to 2022. The European Union, which is part of this regional fisheries management organisation, is called upon to adopt a set of regulatory instruments to transpose the binding decisions established there, in particular with regard to the period 2012-2014. The Mato report, which I supported with my vote, makes some changes to the Commission's proposal, the aim of which is to incorporate the ICCAT recommendations. In particular, the text adopted stresses the key role played by artisanal tuna stocks in the conservation of fish stocks. The recovery plan should promote precisely greater use of these traditional means, which guarantee not only higher selectivity but also have a very limited impact on marine ecosystems.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted ABSTENTION because while the report underlines the role of artisanal fishing gear, such as traditional almadrabas, we believe that when implementing the recovery plan, the EU should emphasize even more the use of traditional traps that contribute to the restoration of tuna stocks and have very little impact on marine ecosystems thanks to the low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. We also believe it is necessary to denounce that in practice the distribution of quotas in Member States does not apply Article 17 of the CFP urging distribution on the basis of "transparent and objective criteria, including those of an environmental, social and economic nature".

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report relates to the multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks. However, there are several problems in this text. Only a few tuna fishers take advantage of the stocks; artisanal fishing is largely excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it.  Nevertheless, it is necessary to protect traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as madrague, because they are environmentally friendly. The Commission wants to make these traditional fishing methods benefit from a specific advantageous regime. Finally, MEPs objected to going beyond ICCAT's recommendations, which seems to be a good move. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I support the objective of this proposal to include in a regulation all the measures of the bluefin tuna recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014, so as to ensure more uniform implementation throughout the EU, I must point out that some of the provisions applied have caused an excessive increase in bureaucracy with negative effects on fleet activities. That is why I have chosen to abstain and not fully support this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014, ensuring uniform and effective application of them throughout the European Union. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete, which addresses some poor technical aspects and which was dealt with with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries. However, I would like to stress that the text resulting from the interinstitutional negotiation is much less ambitious than that which came out of Parliament itself. Since, although the importance of artisanal fishing is important, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba, which I understand, deserves a specific mention in this regulation have been removed.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to ensure the uniform and effective application of all measures of the Recovery Plan adopted in 2012-2014 throughout the European Union. The technical measures included in the proposal concern the relocation and caging operations of live bluefin tuna (including measures relating to the use of stereoscopic cameras for the calculation of bluefin tuna quantities and quantities released), catch reporting requirements and the implementation of the ICCAT Regional Observer Programme. The new basic CFP Regulation imposes an obligation to land all catches, which also applies to bluefin tuna. However, the landing obligation shall apply without prejudice to the Union's international obligations. The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in order to implement such international obligations under Union law, including in particular provisions allowing derogations from the landing obligation. Therefore, discards of bluefin tuna will be allowed in certain cases to be determined by the Commission.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This draft regulation on the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and Mediterranean had three problems. The first problem arises from the European Commission, which, wanting to act as soon as possible, asks to be able to do delegated acts. There is also the problem that is due to the largely exclusion of small-scale fishing, with only a minority of tuna fishers taking advantage of the stocks. The last issue raised is again the Commission's desire to go beyond the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). This amended project puts an end to these problems by allowing the codecision procedure to be respected, to defend artisanal fishing methods, such as madrague, and not to go beyond ICCAT's recommendations. It is for these different solutions that I voted for this report.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report, which was concerned with technical measures concerning caging operations in the Mediterranean.  The report which was a multi annual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean put in place by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) in 2006 to address the alarming depletion in stock levels. However, it should be noted that the provisions contained within the recovery plan do not apply to Ireland.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 As we know, the European Union, together with the Member States, is a contracting party to ICCAT and in 2014, at the Annual Assembly of ICCAT, we welcomed the news of the positive data on the state of good health of bluefin tuna and a 20 % increase in the quotas allocated to the Contracting States. The quotas for bluefin tuna are laid down in the ICAT, but the distribution criteria are decided at the discretion of the individual Member States. Unfortunately, in very many cases only a few shipowners benefit from these quotas, while small-scale fishermen are substantially excluded. Not forgetting that, if a bluefin tuna is accidentally caught, the small fisherman is in danger of being severely penalised. With the agreement reached with the Council, we are making a clear appeal for the protection of small-scale and traditional fishing in the distribution of bluefin tuna quotas.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Responsible exploitation of aquatic resources is required, taking into account sustainable economic, environmental and social conditions. This proposal is intended to transpose into Union law the measures provided for in the multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean so that the latest measures are applied uniformly and immediately throughout the Union. In order to restore bluefin tuna stocks, a number of new provisions are needed, including the gradual reduction of the total catch, certain fishing restrictions by area and period, a new minimum size for bluefin tuna, and measures on rearing and fishing capacity. Therefore, this initiative is intended to reconstitute bluefin tuna stocks, setting out a number of provisions on reducing total allowable catch and fishing capacity and strengthening control measures. I consider it necessary that the exploitation of aquatic resources, and not only, should always be based on principles such as sustainable, sustainable development and should consider the protection of natural resources, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this initiative.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014, ensuring uniform and effective application of them throughout the European Union. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete, which addresses some poor technical aspects and which was dealt with with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries. However, I would like to stress that the text resulting from interinstitutional negotiation is much less ambitious than the text left Parliament itself. Since, although the importance of artisanal fishing is important, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba, which I understand, deserves a specific mention in this regulation have been removed.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is intended to transpose into EU law recommendations from the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA) with regard to bluefin tuna. In 2006, CICTA adopted a multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks that will end in 2022. The totals of eligible catches (TAC) of bluefin tuna were gradually reduced from 2006, to their lowest level in 2012. As bluefin tuna biomass then showed a significant positive development, CICTA decided to increase the TAC by 20% for the years 2015 to 2017. The measures taken a few years ago have therefore paid off. The significant improvement in bluefin tuna stocks is a direct result. I welcome this and call on the Commission to continue to work closely with CICTA to ensure sustainable bluefin tuna exploitation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report, which aims to include in a single regulation all the measures of the tuna recovery plan adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) between 2012 and 2014, in order to ensure their uniform and effective implementation throughout the EU. Uniform application should ensure a level playing field for all tuna operators, including, in particular, operators from third countries.  I would stress that all the efforts made by EU fishermen and the restrictions applied to them would be in vain if different rules were applied to foreign fleets. EU operators should not be penalised by the imposition of stricter measures than agreed, because the European Commission failed to impose such measures in the ICCAT negotiations.  Finally, the question of the absence of the European Parliament in these international negotiations must be raised. I insist that the transposition of the recommendations of regional fisheries management organisations (GPOs), such as ICCAT, must remain a joint competence of the European Parliament and the Council in the ordinary procedure.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, which was a multi annual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean put in place by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) in 2006 to address the alarming depletion in stock levels. This proposal aims at implementing into Union law recovery measures adopted by the ICCAT at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014 with a view to ensuring uniform application of the recovery plan throughout the EU. These are mainly technical measures concerning caging operations in the Mediterranean. These measures do not concern Ireland.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report in support for a detailed and integrated multiannual recovery plan that aims to rebuild the stocks for Bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Under scrupulous fishing restrictions, our fishermen have made considerable efforts in reducing catches in order for the market to return to a healthy level. The efforts have paid back and the rapporteur proposes to incorporate all related recovery plans into a Regulation in order to ensure that there is uniformity in EU legislation. Moreover, I agree that the Regulation should also apply to foreign fleets, otherwise their efforts will be less effective and discriminatory against our fishermen. I therefore encourage holding international negotiations for the purpose of protecting the European environment, our market and citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, as this is a measure aimed at implementing the recent recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas within the European regulatory framework.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfair and illegal fishing practices are a threat to marine ecosystems, which have put the survival of fish species, in particular bluefin tuna, at risk.  The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) has made recommendations and measures which, in order to become operational within the EU, must be transposed into EU law in order to ensure uniform and effective implementation throughout the European Union. Hence the need for the regulation that we voted on in plenary, which includes all the measures of the ICATT recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014. Various technical measures are envisaged: from the transfer and clogging of live red tuna, to the use of stereoscopic cameras for estimating the quantities of bluefin tuna.  The measures implemented in previous years are yielding initial results and we are witnessing a gradual reconstruction of fish stocks. Since this year, European fleets have benefited from a 20% increase in the quota compared to the previous year, i.e. 9 372 tonnes of catches eligible for the EU in 2015. All legislative instruments must be supported to protect fishery resources in order to allow the restocking of our seas. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and agree with the position of the rapporteur, Gabriel Cato, that the aim of transferring the ICTAT recommendations is to apply them uniformly throughout the EU and not to reopen the debate on issues that have already been decided, often after lengthy negotiations, where every word and punctuation is relevant.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. This project is about supporting a species threatened by overfishing but also by environmental risks and we must support it. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this proposal as it simply represents the evolution of a regulation already implemented in 2006. The regulation provided for a reduction in bluefin tuna fishing, which was thought to be in danger due to overfishing. In view of this, I am pleased to note that the amount of tuna caught has fallen considerably since 2006, more than halved. However, such a drastic reduction means fewer jobs, less food availability for many countries that would really need it. Therefore, since the quantity of red tuna has evolved very positively in recent years, I agree to moderately increase their catch so that there is a good balance between the safety of the animal species and the possibility of small businessmen trading it.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote on the report on a multiannual recovery plan for Bluefin tuna.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that we need to draw up long-term plans to protect bluefin tuna from extinction. Sustainability in fisheries is an important issue for which we need strong answers. Common European solutions must be found here.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this report because it was a serious step backwards in favour of industrial tuna fishing and a fair allocation of fishing quotas. This report represents the outcome of the trilogs with commission and council on the recovery plan for bluefin tuna. The parliament's initial position, which we supported, contained provisions for traditional, sustainable and small-scale arts, specific to the almadraba. Parliament's proposal would have allowed an improvement in the situation of almadrabas with an increase in quotas for them which represent an increase in the sustainable exploitation of tuna. However, all these references have been erased in the process of trilogs relegating the almadraba to a mere reference without any binding power. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a positive report to ensure the reconstruction and preservation of bluefin tuna stocks. Mediterranean fishermen, especially small ones, have suffered in recent years as a result of the restrictions imposed and because of the imbalance in the provision of quotas, which have benefited large companies and large shipowners, putting so many small companies in difficulty and often forcing them to divest. This policy must be subverted: many small farms, operating under traditional fishing regimes, which are very often largely sustainable, must not only not be penalised, but must be valued and supported. It is true that the distribution criteria are decided by the Member States, but the Commission and the institutions can do a great deal, especially by introducing criteria and mechanisms for defending and safeguarding quotas for bluefin tuna in favour of small-scale fishing. I believe that we owe it to the many families and small fishermen who, day after day, contribute to the protection of our seas.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union, in its capacity as a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCA) - the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP) - is responsible for the management of bluefin tuna stocks and similar species in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The proposal drawn up by the European Commission contains a number of technical measures relating to industrial and non-industrial fishing efforts, highlighting the reduced impact on marine ecosystems of artisanal capture techniques and their importance in restoring tuna stocks and economic support for SMEs. I voted in favour of this report, wishing, on the one hand, to draw attention to the importance of using transparent, objective, social and environmental criteria in addressing the subject of fishing in European waters, and, on the other hand, to affirm the importance of maintaining the codecision procedure in transposing the ORGP recommendations.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proposal aims to transpose into EU law the measures contained in the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings in 2012 and 2014. A multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna stocks was established in 2006 and entered into force in 2007. In order to ensure uniform and effective application across the EU of all the measures contained in the recovery plan adopted in 2012-2014, the current proposal will include them in the Regulation on the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The proposal includes technical measures such as rules governing the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the number of bluefin tuna specimens and the number of specimens released, provisions on live bluefin tuna transfer operations and their placing in ponds, as well as requirements for the implementation of the ICCAT regional observer programme and catch reports. I support this resolution. I voted yes.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this report of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for Bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean as the amendments proposed are in line with the recovery plan adopted by ICCAT. Since the recovery plan has been adopted, bluefin tuna biomass has shown a positive trend.  The regional organisation decided to increase the TAC by 20% for the following 3 years, based on solid scientific data stating that stocks are at healthy levels.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report focuses on the proposed regulation to transpose into EU law the measures of the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and The Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCTA). The rapporteur considers that the Commission is properly transposing the relevant recommendations of THE CICTA, but would like to point out that the aim of transposing the recommendations is to have uniform application throughout the Union. Considering that this multi-year plan will establish an economically viable model for the bluefin tuna fishery while ensuring the sustainability and reasonable management of fishing activities, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported the report on the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The acts adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCTA) are binding and it is important that they be transposed into EU law in order to restore bluefin tuna stocks. The strict fishing conditions under this plan must be met.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. To the extent that some tuna fishers benefit from bluefin tuna stocks, small-scale fishing is largely excluded. However, the European Commission and MEPs on the Committee on Fisheries have stressed the protection that must be afforded to traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly. The Commission states that it wishes to provide them with a specific advantageous scheme. The amended text also allows for compliance with the codecision procedure and does not go beyond the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). Also, I voted for this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Red tuna is a delicacy that we, the inhabitants of this planet, had led to almost extinction. I am glad that with the actions we are taking, all the inhabitants of planet Earth have somewhat corrected this mistake of ours. Unfortunately, this improvement of the picture is not mainly due to our activities, but to other countries around the world. That our fishing policy is, if not a disaster, it is at least a failure and perhaps that is one of the reasons why Iceland does not want to be part of the Community. I hope we too will start helping the rest of the world save the bluefin tuna.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of fish stocks and the adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets must take into account the specificities of the marine areas concerned and the States concerned.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to ensuring uniform and effective application throughout the European Union of all measures in the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014, this proposal aims to incorporate them into a Regulation. The proposal contains technical measures, such as those relating to the transfer and cageoperations of live bluefin tuna, including also measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and releases, the requirements for the declaration of catches and the implementation of the ICCAT regional observation programme.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: overall, the amended draft allows the codecision procedure to be respected, to defend artisanal fishing methods (madrague) and not to go beyond ICCAT's recommendations.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the legislative proposal published by the Commission with a view to updating the previous Directive on the conservation of bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean regions, which had been in force since 2009. This multiannual plan comes under the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The figure of the multiannual plans has potential, but suffers from some of the limitations and constraints inherent in the CFP itself. There are positive aspects, which we highlight: - the definition of quotas takes into account the guidelines of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna - ICCAT; - the Regulation becomes more comprehensive, with several amendments valuing traditional fishing techniques and coastal fishing, regarded as sustainable techniques, in particular through the use of objective criteria for the allocation of quotas at national level; - valuing the role of ICCAT observers. The growth trend in bluefin tuna stocks has led ICCAT to increase its share by 20 %. We advocate a management of fisheries resources based on scientific knowledge, so that the measures adopted under this plan seem appropriate. We voted in favour. We again stressed the need to increase the Portuguese quota of tuna—bluefin, a fair aspiration of azorean fishermen.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it appropriate to transpose the ICCAT recommendations with regard to bluefin tuna by the Commission. In addition, it is important to highlight the importance of traditional and artisanal techniques when conserving bluefin tuna, since these are very selective techniques, which contribute to the recovery of the species.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation as I consider it essential to safeguard and replenish bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. To do this, all measures taken by the International Commission for the Atlantic Tuna Conversation (ICCAT), to which the EU is a contracting party, must be applied uniformly and effectively across the EU through a dedicated regulation. In particular, I welcome the presence of important technical measures, such as the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and the quantities released at sea, and the obligations regarding the declaration of catches.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as I do not believe the common fisheries policy is Ireland’s interests.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain from the report as it generates excessive obligations and bureaucracy that could have been avoided.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the multiannual tuna recovery plan, as the protection of fish stocks and the adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets must take into account the specificities of the marine areas concerned and the States concerned.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ When dealing with this fishing sustainability, we must safeguard long-term productivity, promote local employment opportunities, encourage the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and a responsible exploitation of fisheries resources. Unfortunately, the current Bluefin tuna fishing quota system penalises small-scale fishermen, and needs to be reviewed. Owners of large vessels are too dominant and might harm fishing sustainability. I therefore support transposal into Union law of the measures of the multiannual Bluefin Tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014. I believe that the technical measures included in the multiannual recovery plan will lead to positive developments for environment, nature and local employment.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the report of the recovery plan for the bluefin tuna stock. The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), the regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of tuna and tuna-like species in the Atlantic Ocean and its bordering seas. The transposition of the ICCAT recommendations aims to ensure uniform application throughout the EU. Uniform application should aim at ensuring a level playing field for all operators engaged in tuna fishing, especially non-EU fishermen. Otherwise, if other rules apply to foreign fleets, the efforts of EU fishermen and the restrictions imposed on them will be futile.  EU actors should not be penalised for applying tougher measures than those adopted because the Commission was unable to implement these measures during the ICCAT negotiations. It is important that the European Parliament does not lose its powers on this issue. The lack of MEPs' participation in international negotiations would mean that it would have no say in the negotiations in ICCAT and in other international for a. Transposing the recommendations of regional fisheries management organisations should remain a joint responsibility of the European Parliament and the Council under the ordinary legislative procedure.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014. In this regard, uniform and effective implementation of these measures across the EU is ensured. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete and negotiated with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries. However, I would like to stress that the text resulting from interinstitutional negotiation is less ambitious than that which came out of Parliament itself. While the importance of artisanal fishing is relevant, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba have been removed.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for the variety of fish fauna and the protection of the sustainability of our seas are undisputed priorities in European fisheries, environment and sea policies. These objectives are even more sensitive when they concern species that are at risk and of particular importance for the wildlife, gastronomic and cultural heritage of the Mediterranean basin, the heart of European civilisation. I therefore voted strongly in favour of Parliament's position on this regulation, in which we support the proposal to rationalise and standardise all the measures of the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014 in order to ensure their uniform and effective implementation throughout the EU.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna. The biodiversity of our seas is an honest concern to me. It is the basis of a good future for future generations. And that is what I am fighting for as an MEP for the Family Party.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. In order to ensure the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean, it provides, inter alia, for a gradual reduction in total allowable catches and the strengthening of the ICCAT Joint International Inspection Regime. In the negotiations with the Council, we have succeeded in persething preferential treatment for artisanal and traditional fishermen. This was an important basis for supporting the recovery plan.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Thanks to the efforts of fishermen, bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean have been restored. The report present takes this into account and simply proposes to transpose the CICTA Convention, the convention of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. The European Commission, in order to act quickly, has of course tried to introduce acts of execution and delegated acts into the proposed regulation, in order to increase its power to the detriment of the European Parliament. But MEPs voted on amendments removing these provisions, in order to defend Parliament's prerogatives. It should also be noted that increased protection is afforded by the new regulation to artisanal fishermen, who use traditional fishing methods such as madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly.  In conclusion, the amended draft preserves Parliament's control, defends artisanal fishing methods and does not go beyond the recommendations of THE CICTA, i.e. not to impose unnecessary constraints on fishermen. So I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted abstention because while the report underlines the role of artisanal fishing gear, such as traditional almadrabas, we believe that when implementing the recovery plan, the EU should emphasize further the use of traditional traps that contribute to the restoration of tuna stocks and have very little impact on marine ecosystems thanks to the low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. We also believe it is necessary to denounce that in practice the distribution of quotas in Member States does not apply Article 17 of the CFP urging distribution on the basis of "transparent and objective criteria, including those of an environmental, social and economic nature".

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009. I strongly support the plan to restore bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The application throughout the European Union of all the measures contained in the bluefin tuna recovery plan is essential for uniform and effective action in this field. The current proposal aims to transpose into EU law the technical measures contained in the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The agreement was reached in principle on a proposal aimed at implementing measures of the recovery plan for Bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014, ensuring uniform and effective application of them throughout the European Union. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I would like to stress that the text resulting from interinstitutional negotiation is much less ambitious than the text left Parliament itself. Since, although the importance of artisanal fishing is important, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba, which I understand, deserves a specific mention in this regulation have been removed. However, I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete, which addresses some poor technical aspects and which was dealt with with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report, since it favours a further increase in total annual tuna catches and therefore an increase in quotas, which reduces the species (which is on the red list of endangered species and has suffered a significant decrease in its numbers in the recent past).

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report. This plan was set up to rebuild Bluefin tuna stock and came after the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas also adopted a multiannual recovery plan. I was happy that the report acknowledged that the Commission’s proposal went further than the ICCAT and even what EU legislation allows for. The aim of the transposition of the ICCAT Recommendations is to have uniform application throughout the EU; it is not to reopen the discussion about what has already been decided. Uniform application should aim at ensuring a level playing field for all operators, including non-EU operators. Otherwise, all the restrictions applied to EU fishermen will have no result, if different rules apply to foreign fleets.  Finally, I was pleased that the rapporteur addressed the issue of delegated acts by the Commission. Considering the European Parliament are not negotiating the ICCAT agreement, the co-decision procedure is the only possible way we can influence the transposition of the agreement into Union law. If, in the future, delegated acts were used then it would mean that the Parliament has no say at all in ICCAT negotiations.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, as I had no objections to the recovery plan.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) is the authority that has been adopting decisions since 2006 on the conservation and management of fishing activities, the most important regulated species being bluefin tuna. I voted in favour of this report for the effective implementation of the bluefin tuna recovery plan with a significant impact on the maritime ecosystem.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas and on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 302/2009 (COM(2015)0180-C8-0118/2015-2015-2015/0096(COD)), as this Regulation aims to ensure a single and effective application in the European Union of all recovery plan measures adopted between 2012 and 2014. and 2014, which, in addition to previous measures since 2008, has contributed to outstanding results in terms of preserving the number of bluefin tuna, and it is possible to gradually increase the total catch possible without ingesting the results achieved. This proposal also includes the technical measures and procedures used in the assessment, monitoring and reporting of catches.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The debate is about a simple transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). Overall, the amended project allows the codecision procedure to be respected, to defend artisanal fishing methods (madrague) and not to go beyond ICCAT's recommendations. It was only natural that I supported the text.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the report, which deals with the multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks. The plan presents several necessary steps to achieve the goal. It is necessary to reduce the levels of permissible catch. Stricter catch rules should also be introduced in certain areas and at certain times. Strengthening international control is an equally important step. For the successful recovery of tuna, it is important to apply the agreed rules uniformly and to ensure a level playing field for all fishermen, including foreign ones. Without the same rules, we cannot achieve the desired result for non-EU fishermen.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to transpose into EU law the measures of the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The plan was adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, of which the EU is a member. The text provides for favourable treatment of artisanal and traditional fishermen when allocating fishing quotas for bluefin tuna.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although there are some good ideas in this report, the plan for the European fishing industry as a whole must be viewed critically. That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – One of the success stories of the conservation of ocean fish stocks is that international restrictive measures have increased the stocks of bluefin tuna over the past decade to such an 20% increase per year. The aim of the proposal should be supported because it is intended to merge the different regulations of the relevant ICCAT Committee, thereby ensuring that they are binding on all Member States. The rapporteur rightly criticises the Commission for some of its actions in making EU fleets more difficult and for operating with delegated regulations to a greater extent than is strictly necessary.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, as the scientifically justified results of the limits on total allowable catches imposed in 2006 are more than promising. The positive development of the situation of bluefin tuna biomass stocks warrants an increase in the total allowable catches, however it remains at levels well below the same level before the entry into force of the Recovery Plan.  In order to ensure the effective and uniform application throughout the European Union of the measures of the Recovery Plan, they are hereby included in a Regulation. This ensures a level playing field for all operators fishing for tuna, including those operating outside the EU, as otherwise the efforts and restrictions applied to Community fishermen will not work if different rules apply to external fishing fleets.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The proposal being analysed aims to introduce into a single regulation all the measures that have been taken up to 2014 in order to ensure their implementation throughout the European Union. It provides for the Multiannual Recovery Plan for Bluefin Tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean (BFT). The measures provided for in the plan adopted in 2006 by ICCAT (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas), which will end in 2022, had, in fact, required necessary but onerous sacrifices. In view of the process of gradual recovery of the bluefin tuna stock in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, there was then a sustainable increase in catches, with an annual increase of 20 %, which means, for Italy, that the amount of fish caught has increased from 2 302.8 tonnes to 2 752 tonnes. Preserving the ecosystem and increasing the reserve, without losing sight of employment levels, was the objective we set ourselves and that we can say today that we have achieved. Thanks to EU environmental policies and fishermen's efforts to limit bluefin tuna catches, we are now in a position to raise fishing levels.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is intended to protect bluefin tuna stocks, which have been replenished by previous measures.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted for the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks. These stocks have been replenished. The debate is about a simple transposition of the Convention of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. Only a few tuna fishers take advantage of the stocks; artisanal fishing is largely excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it. However, both the European Commission and MEPs in the Committee on Fisheries stress the protection that must be afforded to traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly. The Commission specifies that it will provide these traditional fishing methods with a specific advantageous regime. Overall, the amended project allows the codecision procedure to be respected, to defend artisanal fishing methods (madrague) and not to go beyond ICCAT's recommendations.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of this report. It tends to apply the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas) which recommends better protection of tuna and traditional fishing methods. The text as a whole is part of The European Multi-Year Plan to Rebuild BlueFin tuna Stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. In this context, however, the Commission is trying to take more prerogatives and go beyond ICCAT's recommendations, which is opposed by the text put to the vote.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014, ensuring uniform and effective application of them throughout the European Union. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete, which addresses some poor technical aspects and which was dealt with with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries. However, I would like to stress that the text resulting from interinstitutional negotiation is much less ambitious than the text left Parliament itself. Since, although the importance of artisanal fishing is important, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba, which I understand, deserves a specific mention in this regulation have been removed.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014, ensuring uniform and effective application of them throughout the European Union. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete, which addresses some poor technical aspects and which was dealt with with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries. However, I would like to stress that the text resulting from interinstitutional negotiation is much less ambitious than the text left Parliament itself. Since, although the importance of artisanal fishing is important, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba, which I understand, deserves a specific mention in this regulation have been removed.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. I believe that the objective of transposing ICCAT recommendations is uniform implementation across the EU. This uniform application should aim at ensuring a level playing field for all operators involved in tuna fishing, including third-country operators. Otherwise, if different rules apply to foreign fleets, all efforts made and all restrictions on EU fishermen will have been in vain. This transposition is also especially important due to the role of artisanal fishing gear in the conservation of stocks. I believe that the European Union should pay particular attention to them, as they have very little impact on marine ecosystems thanks to the low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. For the reasons described above, I vote favorably for the adoption of this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report that acknowledges the role of traditional gears and techniques in the conservation and rebuilding tuna fish stock.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I regularly stay with these reports, as the Czech Republic does not have a sea.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 In January this year, parliament had already debated the issue at issue, but after the relevant vote, the draft legislative resolution was returned to the profile committee. The main objective of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is to promote a more effective overall fisheries policy for bluefin tuna stocks in the Atlantic and Mediterranean. This would be, among other methods, feasible by supporting 'traditional' fishermen who use various types of recreational fishing gear, such as the 'almadraba' trap, whose low impact on affected ecosystems is a very important plus. In terms of economic and consumption, bluefin tuna is a fundamentally important species and should therefore be protected in general terms, at least for these reasons. Bluefin tuna is classified as an endangered species and therefore a number of measures are regularly implemented to promote the maintenance of existing biological equilibrium and the respective stabilisation and enhancement of stocks. Consequently, recreational and sport fishing is also awaiting some changes.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the EP approved the inclusion of measures adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas for Breeding and Catching Bluefin Tuna in the Regulation. The aim is to ensure the uniform and effective application of all measures throughout the European Union, which is why I supported the proposal. Given the effectiveness of the measures applied, there has been a positive trend in the recovery of fish stocks in recent years, therefore higher catch quotas have been authorised for 2015-2017.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 302/2009) because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report.  This is a simple transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas), which takes note of the rebuilding of bluefin tuna stocks. Contrary to the original decision of the European Commission, the codecision procedure allows the european Parliament's opinion to be fully taken into account. In addition to these two reasons for satisfaction, we welcome the European Commission's announced intention to introduce a specific regime that benefits traditional fishing, which is the big loser in the management of tuna stocks.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009. The proposal aims to transpose into Community law the measures of the multiannual plan for the reconstruction of bluefin tuna in the Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by ICCAT. With this plan, it is possible to rebuild the bluefin tuna stock by means of a selectivity of catches for biodiversity and a reduction in the total allowable catches.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 Tuna is currently protected by many international treaties and also by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICTAT). This committee, to which the EU is a party, has as its main responsibility the adoption of decisions on the strengthening and conservation of Atlantic fisheries resources, including tuna. The timetable for measures to this end is by 2022 with objectives such as the reconstitution of stocks through the gradual reduction of authorised fishing including tuna.  ICAT has already managed to reduce the total allowable catches, resulting in an increase in tuna stocks.  Fishermen themselves, who comply with the Commission's decisions, have also contributed to this result. I would therefore like to vote in favour of this resolution, since it aims to incorporate technical measures into a European regulation, so as to achieve uniform and effective implementation of the Commission's decisions throughout the European Union.

name: Georg MAYER
