text: Writing. Sustainable fisheries make a very positive contribution to the reconstruction of tuna stocks. However, I cannot fully support this proposal for a regulation. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is simply a transposition of the Convention of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). The problem is that only a few tuna fishers take advantage of the stocks; artisanal fishing is largely excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it. The amendments voted allow the codecision procedure to be enforced in order to limit the Commission's want to go beyond the measured recommendations of ICCAT. This text in favour of small-scale fishing seems to me to be balanced. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is intended to transpose into Union law the measures of the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan (BFT) in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT)1 at its annual sessions between 2012 and 2014.  This legislative initiative aims to ensure the uniform and effective implementation of the latest measures of iccat's multiannual BFT recovery plan across the European Union. The relevant conservation and management measures laid down by iccat recommendations do not apply directly to individual vessels or Union nationals.  It is therefore necessary to transpose into EU law the ICCAT measures relating to bft adopted in 2012, 2013 and 2014.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it strikes a positive balance between the realities of environmental and ecosystem conservation and the needs of the EU fishing industry and SMEs.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the regulation on a multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. This step will enable the transposition into European law of the measures taken at the level of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas - CICTA - in order to replenish bluefin tuna stocks. While a few years ago these stocks had fallen so dramatically that the survival of the species was compromised, it had become urgent to adopt the necessary measures to reverse the trend. I am pleased that these new measures are in addition to the efforts already made by the stakeholders concerned to ensure a sustainable bluefin tuna fishery and thus ensure the sustainability of our fishing opportunities.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas is a regional fisheries management organisation responsible for the management of tuna and related species in the Atlantic Ocean and the European Union is a member of that organisation. In 2006, the Commission adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, which will expire in 2022. In order to restore the stock, the plan provided for a gradual reduction in total allowable catches between 2007 and 2011, fishing restrictions in certain areas and periods, a new minimum size, measures relating to sporting and recreational fishing activities, as well as measures relating to breeding and fishing capacity. Bluefin tuna biomass has shown a markedly positive trend since 2008. The regional organisation decided in 2014 to increase the total allowable catch by 20 % for the next three years, as there is reliable scientific data showing that stocks have reached healthy levels. The aim of transposing the recommendations of the International Commission is to ensure uniform application throughout the European Union. This should in particular aim at ensuring a level playing field for all tuna operators, including non-EU operators. Otherwise, the efforts and restrictions applied to EU fishermen will not benefit any if different rules apply to foreign fleets. I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because I am in agreement with the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for Bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean repealing Regulation.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is a contracting party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). In 2006, ICCAT adopted a multiannual plan with a maturity of 2022 to restore bluefin tuna stocks. The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 302/2009 and to summarise in a regulation the measures of the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014. In its report, the Committee on Fisheries recommends that parliament approve the draft at first reading with 40 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Overall, the amended project respects the codecision procedure, defends artisanal fishing methods (madrague) and does not go beyond the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.  It can therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) of the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP), responsible for the management of tuna and related species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas, of which the EU is a Contracting Party, has the authority to adopt decisions ('recommendations') for the conservation and management of fisheries in its area of competence. These acts are binding and must be transposed into EU law. Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT. Fishermen have made efforts to adjust their catches to the total allowable catch from 33 000 tonnes before the recovery plan to the minimum value in 2012 (12 900 tonnes). Stocks have evolved positively and the TAC has been increasing, and in 2015 it is 15 821 tonnes, with the EU being 9 372.9 tonnes. I endorse the rapporteur's position, in particular on three points: the first on the importance of the exact transposition of iccat's recommendations and their non-extrapolation; second, to regret the EP's absence from international negotiations; and finally, I would like to make it essential to take account of the specificities of the different tuna fishing gears, in particular artisanal and traditional frames.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Overall, the amended project allows the codecision procedure to be respected and to defend artisanal fishing methods. I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to include in a regulation all the measures of plans to replenish bluefin tuna stocks, in order to ensure a uniform and effective application. The report includes technical measures, such as the use of stereoscopic cameras to examine tuna quantities, but also requirements, including the implementation of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna Conservation Regional Observer Program.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the need to protect bluefin tuna from overfishing in the Atlantic and given the importance of cooperating in maintaining the consumption of this species at maximum sustainable levels, I welcome the proposal to incorporate into Union law all changes to the recovery plan adopted by ICCAT in 2012, 2013 and 2014 that have not yet been transposed. In fact, in 2006, ICCAT adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, which is expected to be completed in 2022. In order to replenish the stock, the plan provides for a progressive reduction in total allowable catches (TACs), restrictions on fishing activity in specified areas and periods, a new minimum size, measures applicable to recreational and recreational fishing activities, measures concerning fishing and breeding capacity and a strengthening of ICCAT's joint international inspection programme. Since 2008, bluefin tuna biomass has been on a markedly positive trend. In the light of these improvements, I believe it is important to support ICCAT's decision to bring forward to 2016 the TAC planned for 2017, which would still be well below the TAC in force before the recovery plan enters into force.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The positive development of the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014 is a welcome development, as one of its important objectives is to increase the bluefin tuna population in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. I voted in favour of the proposal, which aims to bring together the various measures in a regulation so that we can continue to maintain these positive trends. The established healthy tuna stock allows all tuna operators to continue their activities.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal aims at transposing into Union law measures of the multiannual Bluefin Tuna (BFT) recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014. I have voted for this report that contains technical measures such as those on transfer and caging operations of live BFT, including also measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of BFT and releases, catch reporting requirements, and the Implementation of the ICCAT Regional Observer Programme.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report in my vote today because I believe it is extremely important that these multiannual plans for the various fish stocks are adopted as soon as possible. The negotiation and adoption of this multiannual plan for bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean is part of the process of drawing up these multiannual plans for fish stocks in the EU seas as part of the CFP. Multiannual plans are the basic instrument of the CFP, without which we will not be able to meet the objectives of sustainable fishing and the protection of fish stocks set by the CFP. In this respect, the unblocking of this situation, which is reflected today in the adoption of this multiannual plan, gives us hope that we will be able to achieve the objectives set.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report, which was concerned with technical measures concerning caging operations in the Mediterranean.  The report which was a multi annual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean put in place by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) in 2006 to address the alarming depletion in stock levels. However, it should be noted that the provisions contained within the recovery plan do not apply to Ireland.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In principle, I believe that the European Union should pay particular attention to traditional clay sonins in order to play a part in the reconstruction of tuna stocks. However, there are a number of points in the report that I cannot agree with, which is why I have abstained from voting on this report.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that Mr Mato's proposal should be voted on in a positive way. The Role of the European Union in ICCAT indicates the particular attention that the Union gives to the recovery of the bluefin tuna stock. The results achieved so far go far beyond the expectations and objectives initially set. I therefore agree with my colleague's proposal to include in a regulation all the measures taken between 2012 and 2014, as this would allow for uniform and effective implementation of these measures in all EU Member States. Similarly, I think it is worth emphasising that the Commission's proposal to transpose future changes to the recovery plan by means of delegated acts risks further marginalising the role of the European Parliament in such an important issue at international level. I therefore feel that I must vote in favour of this proposal, as my fellow Member has said.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – All species are important in an ecosystem. The Bluefin tuna, which has been endangered for several years, has suffered a catastrophic decline in stocks in the Northern Pacific Ocean, of more than 96%. In order to preserve it the future we have to be cautious. Changes have to be made so that we ensure the continuity of the Bluefin tuna fish population. Therefore, I vote in favour of the recovery plan for Bluefin tune in the Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas adopted measures of the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan (BFT) in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas, which applies from 2007 to 2022. This Plan includes management measures, technical measures, measures on sport and recreational fishing, which contain general rules of application aiming at achieving biomass corresponding to the maximum sustainable yield by 2022. Such common fisheries policies are a necessary precondition for preserving the good state of the fish stock and to ensure the exploitation of marine resources as efficiently as possible.  I particularly welcome the two segments of this report. First, advocating the role of traditional tools and techniques for the preservation of fish stocks, as I believe that in implementing the bluefin tuna recovery plan, the EU should take particular account of these tools and techniques because of their selectivity. Secondly, I welcome the inclusion in this plan of catch vessels flying the flag of the Republic of Croatia, which expands the existing number established in 2008 and takes into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU and its efforts to preserve bluefin tuna.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Each Member State shall take the necessary measures to ensure that the fishing effort of its catch vessels and tuna traps is proportionate to the fishing opportunities for bluefin tuna available to that Member State in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas. The maximum number and corresponding gross tonage of fishing vessels flying the flag of a Member State engaged in bluefin tuna fishing in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea shall not exceed the number and total total gross toning of flagged fishing vessels of that Member State and which are vessels, on board, tranloading, transporting or unloading bluefin tuna between 1 January 2007 and 1 July 2008. This restriction shall apply according to the type of fishing gear for catch vessels. A Member State which is a flag State shall revoke the authorisation for bluefin tuna fishing and may require the vessel to immediately head to the port designated by it if it considers that the vessel has received the quota allocated to it. In my view, in addition to the amendments attached, the proposal for a Regulation by the Council and the European Parliament on the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean sea and on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 100/2013 is a good idea. 302/2009 much needed if we want to see progress in terms of recovery of bluefin tuna in these areas.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In light of the positive evolution of the state of bluefin tuna stocks in recent years, the International Commission for the Conservation of Tuna (ICCAT) has decided to increase the maximum allowable catch limits by 20 % for the following three years (from 2015 to 2017), as scientific data have shown that stocks are at optimal levels of abundance. In mid-December 2015, the EU Council of Ministers responsible for fisheries and agriculture finally decided on the 20 % increase and allocated the COMMUNITY quota among the Member States concerned. In addition, the ICCAT recommendations take into account the specificities of the different tuna fishing gears. In this context, the role of artisanal tuna, such as traditional tuna, in the conservation of stocks is important. I believe that, in implementing the recovery plan, the European Union should pay particular attention to these traditional tuna tonnes, which contribute to the recovery of tuna stocks thanks to their considerable selectivity. In addition, such gears have a very small impact on marine ecosystems due to their low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. For all this, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proposal aims to transpose into EU law the measures contained in the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings in 2012 and 2014. A multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan was established in 2006 and entered into force in 2007.  In order to ensure uniform and effective application across the EU of all the measures contained in the recovery plan adopted in 2012-2014, the current proposal will include them in the Regulation on the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The proposal includes technical measures such as rules governing the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the number of bluefin tuna specimens and the number of specimens released, provisions on live bluefin tuna transfer operations and their placing in ponds, as well as requirements for the implementation of the ICCAT regional observer programme and catch reports. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Union is a party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA), which adopted a multi-year bluefin tuna stock recovery plan in 2006 until 2022. I voted in favour of this text, which allows for the adoption of all the measures adopted as part of the inventory recovery plan.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. With the vote this lunchtime on the Mato report, Parliament is committed to the conservation of bluefin tuna and against overfishing.  Today, two of the three species of bluefin tuna listed in the world are considered threatened by overfishing, that is to say the urgency of the situation. This report associates the Union with the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA) and its multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks from 2007 to 2022.  This plan includes a gradual reduction in the total allowable catch (TAC) of bluefin tuna, new fishing criteria and measures to regulate sport and recreational fishing while strengthening the international inspection program adopted by CICTA.  The report itself provides for the transposition into European law of the measures of the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014: transfer and cage operations, measures to estimate the quantities of tuna and the number of re-sea rebates.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meetings held between 2012 and 2014, ensuring uniform and effective application of them throughout the European Union. This new Regulation will repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, which was already amended in 2014 to incorporate the measures in relation to the fishing seasons adopted by ICCAT in 2012 and 2013.  I consider it appropriate to support this initiative to review a regulation which was obsolete, which addresses some poor technical aspects and which was dealt with with great consensus in the Committee on Fisheries. However, I would like to stress that the text resulting from interinstitutional negotiation is much less ambitious than the text left Parliament itself. Since, although the importance of artisanal fishing is important, specific references to a traditional and sustainable fishing art such as almadraba, which I understand, deserves a specific mention in this regulation have been removed.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved the compromise text between EU institutions on the multi-year programme to restore bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. In adopting this document, Parliament approved the text of the regulation which transposes into EU law various measures taken by the INTERNATIONAL Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCA) in 2012, 2013 and 2014. The objective of the regulation is to achieve bluefin tuna biomass that is the maximum sustainable yield by 2022, with a probability of at least 60% of achieving this target. The multi-year bluefin tuna recovery program began in 2007 and is expected to continue until 2022.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. Tuna is a crucial component of the fish supply. Unfortunately, many fishing countries have sufficient capacity to destroy most of the tuna stock in the world without regulating fishing. To that end, today we are adopting a multiannual recovery plan for tuna stocks. When I look at the document, I can identify three of its shortcomings. The first is that the plan is quite irresponsible. It pays very little attention to the recovery of fish stocks, the essential condition of which is to fish far less than the growth of fish. The second drawback of the plan is socially irresponsible: poorer EU Member States are treated in the same way as the richer, despite the fact that even the development of fishing, but its revival, after irresponsible action to reduce THE EU's fishing capacity, could become one of the engines of sustainable regional development of regional growth. And the third drawback is that the plan does not pay sufficient attention to working with non-EU countries, especially those known for their failure to comply with international agreements. Nevertheless, it is better not quite a good plan than none. I am therefore voting in favour, while calling on the Commission to take into account the comments made in the future.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) which is the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP) responsible for the management of tuna and related species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT, which in 2006 adopted a multiannual recovery plan for this species by 2022. Following this plan, it is verified that bluefin tuna biomass has been growing in recent years. This plan provides for a gradual reduction in the level of total allowable catches (TACs), fishing restrictions in certain areas and certain periods, a new minimum size for catches, measures related to sport and recreational fishing activities, as well as fishing and culture capacities and the strengthening of iccat's joint international inspection programme. Following the assessment of the measures taken by this recovery plan between 2012 and 2014, this proposal decides to incorporate them into a Regulation with a view to ensuring more effective and simpler implementation – as it is uniform – of these measures in the waters of the whole European Union. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the PPE Group, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal to adopt a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna. The frequent use of intensive fishing practices has severely compromised the number of red tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. In order to tackle this problem, ICCAT, the regional fisheries management organisation, has drawn up a multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna in the areas mentioned. Needless to say, without action at Community level the problem will be almost unsolvable. I would also like to point out that the incisive intervention by Mr Mato, the GROUP of the European People's Party, has made it possible to open negotiations with the Council on this text and to adopt an amendment in favour of small-scale small-scale fishing, a sector which is also increasingly in distress in the Italian economy, and which the European Parliament is trying to protect.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted abstention because while the report underlines the role of artisanal fishing gear, such as traditional almadrabas, we believe that when implementing the recovery plan, the EU should emphasize further the use of traditional traps that contribute to the restoration of tuna stocks and have very little impact on marine ecosystems thanks to the low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. We also believe it is necessary to denounce that in practice the distribution of quotas in Member States does not apply Article 17 of the CFP urging distribution on the basis of "transparent and objective criteria, including those of an environmental, social and economic nature".

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ Stocks of Bluefin tuna are particularly vulnerable to over-exploitation and therefore need careful management. I have been a rapporteur on this issue in the past and I am aware of the tensions and difficulties which can arise when setting quotas. However, if strict rules are not applied to ensure that catches are below maximum sustainable yields then the future of the fishing industry itself is put at risk. Management of fisheries and enforcement of these regulations at sea remain big challenges with important social, economic and environmental consequences.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Multiannual Recovery Plan for Bluefin Tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean'.  As early as 2006, the first plan of its kind was adopted by ICCAT (the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). The plan, which Parliament has now approved, is intended to monitor bluefin tuna stocks and limit total catches so that stocks can recover.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this report because it was a serious step backwards in favour of industrial tuna fishing and a fair allocation of fishing quotas. This report represents the outcome of the trilogs with commission and council on the recovery plan for bluefin tuna. The parliament's initial position, which we support, contained provisions for traditional, sustainable and small-scale arts. However, all these references have been erased in the trilog process. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The new bluefin tuna recovery plan aims to transpose into European Union law some measures taken by ́ICCAT for better management of this important species present in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The new regulation, which I supported, recognises the need to pay more attention to craft equipment, such as tuna, which has a low impact on marine ecosystems, a high level of selectivity and contributes to job creation. The proposal includes technical measures, such as the transfer and clogging of live red tuna, measures involving the use of stereoscopic cameras, provisions concerning the declaration of catches and the implementation of the ICCAT regional observation programme.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is a contracting party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). The ICCAT Commission has the power to take decisions ('recommendations') in order to protect and manage fishery resources in its area of competence (including the setting of total allowable catches over a certain period). These acts shall be binding. They must be taken into account in Union law. In recent years, there has been a significant recovery in the bluefin tuna stock, which could mean that the total allowable catch will increase more than originally planned. I voted in favour.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is a contracting party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), the regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) responsible for managing tuna and tuna-like species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT. Fishermen have made considerable efforts to adapt their catches to the reduced ALLOW that resulted from the decisions taken in 2006 by complying with the strict fishing conditions set out in the plan. In view of the positive development of stocks, ICCAT decided to slightly increase the total allocation to 13 400 tonnes in 2013. The total allowable catch in 2014 has not been changed. The regional organisation has decided to increase the allowable fishing for the next three years (2015-2017) by 20 %, as there are reliable scientific data on the bluefin tuna stocks. The approved proposal aims to apply a level playing field across the EU for all operators involved in tuna fishing. The same rules should apply to all operators and outside the EU.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) and the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of tuna and similar species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. Although the Commission's proposal generally transposes the relevant ICCAT recommendations accordingly, it in some cases goes beyond ICCAT decisions and even EU area legislation. Bluefin tuna is economically important for the European Union, especially for mediterranean Member States. Although the catch is quite small, bluefin tuna is a highly prized fish on the Japanese market, where prices are also astronomical as a result. The report concerns the amended format of the ICCAT plan, describes improving rear control, restrictions and types of fishing equipment. The proposal for a Regulation includes technical measures such as measures relating to the transfer and rearing of live bluefin tuna in a caging cage, including measures concerning the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantity of bluefin tuna and emissions, catch reporting requirements and the implementation of the ICCAT Regional Observation Programme. The report stresses that, when implementing the recovery plan, the European Union should pay particular attention to traditional traps that contribute to the recovery of tuna stocks, as they are extremely selective. I believe that the report is good, which is why I supported it.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. The report recommends more concrete measures regarding landing, transfer, caged installation, use of stereoscopic cameras to analyse bluefin tuna more efficiently, requirements for catch reports, as well as the implementation of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) regional surveillance programme. Taking into account that bluefin tuna biomass show positive signs of recovery since 2008, ICCAT decided in 2014 to raise the quota by twenty percent from 2015-17.  I support this report as I consider it necessary to improve the protection of one of the most important fish species for Union fishermen. I support the committee's view that the European Union must strive to ensure equality for all operators engaged in bluefin tuna fishing, and non-EU operators. Otherwise, all efforts and limitations will not produce the desired results. It is extremely important to note that the report focuses on the need to protect traditional fishing practices, on the grounds that their impact on the ecological system is negligible. In the protection of the principle of open market and equal opportunities, more comprehensive regulation of bluefin tuna should be adopted.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is a contracting party to the International Commission for the Protection of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), the Regional Fisheries Economy Organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of tuna and tuna-like species in the Atlantic and neighbouring seas. The proposal contains technical measures such as those for caged live tuna transfer operations, including measures to use stereoscopic cameras to estimate tuna volumes and inform the public. ICCAT has the power to take decisions (Recommendations) for the conservation and management of fisheries within its competence. Such decisions shall be binding and must be incorporated into EU law.  I support parliament's position adopting the Report, as I consider Parliament competent enough to assess whether a report is sufficiently clear and well-worded.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean and repealing the Regulation. The report contains technical measures to ensure the uniform and effective implementation of all recovery plan measures adopted between 2012 and 2014. The proposal, for example, contains a measure relating to the transfer and rearing activities of live bluefin tuna in a caged cage. In 2006, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, in force until 2022.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of fish stocks and the adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets must take into account the specificities of the marine areas concerned and the States concerned.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the recovery plan for bluefin tuna stocks in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean. In my decision, I took into account the fact that, according to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), bluefin tuna biomass has been following very positive trends since 2008 and solid scientific data show that bluefin tuna stocks have reached a healthy level of abundance. Based on the regional organisation's data, the decision to bring forward the TACs (23 155 ton) planned for 2017 and still much lower than the TACs in place before the start of the recovery plan is eligible for 2016. I also approve of the fact that the ICCAT recommendations take into account the specificities of the different types of tuna fishing equipment and that, in this context, the report draws attention to the role of small-scale traditional traps in the conservation of stocks. Indeed, in implementing the recovery plan, the EU should pay particular attention to traditional traps, as these instruments have a very low impact on marine ecosystems due to their low energy needs and low by-catches. I also welcome the fact that the reporter highlights the lack of EP participation in international negotiations. I support the fact that the transposition of the recommendations of regional fisheries management organisations should remain a joint responsibility of the European Parliament and the Council under the ordinary legislative procedure.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing is one of the important economic activities of the European Union, generating significant jobs, income and food resources for Member States. One of the components of this activity is tuna fishing in the Atlantic Ocean region, which provides appreciable quantities to the Member States concerned. At the same time, however, the EU is a signatory to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT), a regional fisheries management organisation, which regulates the maximum level of catches in order not to affect the biodiversity of the marine fauna in that area. Following scientific studies carried out in recent years, it has been concluded that bluefin tuna stocks have experienced spectacular regeneration, allowing for an increase in quotas set for the EU. In these circumstances, the Commission proposed a uniform and effective approach to Union-wide ICCAT regulations, including technical measures for the transfer and declaration of bluefin tuna catches, the use of stereoscopic cameras, the landing obligation in the event of quota overshoot. This is a constructive proposal, but the role of the European Parliament could be more important in this area which directly concerns European citizens. For these reasons, I support the adoption of the current report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I followed the group in this vote on the preservation of bluefin tuna. Although, on the whole, the Commission's proposal correctly transposes the relevant recommendations of CICTA, in some cases it goes beyond what has been decided by CICTA, but also to what IS provided by EU legislation. This is the case, for example, when the individual quota for bluefin tuna is considered exhausted: the CICTA recommendations and the EU regulation establishing a control regime provide that the flag member state can request - not "order" as proposed by the Commission - the ship to sail immediately to a port it has designated. In this regard, it should be remembered that the aim of transposing the CICTA recommendations is to have uniform application throughout the Union; it is not a question of reopening the debate on what has already been decided, often after long negotiations, where every word and comma counts.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Bluefin tuna is one of the top predators in the Mediterranean Sea, a crucial species for its ecosystem, and has a very high economic value, both in the European and Japanese market. In the late 90s however, the Mediterranean stock dramatically decreased to levels compromising the future of the species and the viability of the fishing sector. The multi-annual Bluefin Tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean established in 2006 by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) was very efficient in contributing to the recovery of the stock. This is why I voted in favour of transposing this plan into EU law, as I hope that it will contribute to ensuring the exploitation of living aquatic resources under sustainable economic, environmental and social conditions. I particularly agree with the decision to ensure equitable distribution between the various fleets and support small scale and artisanal fisheries, which usually practice sustainable fishing practices and ensure the livelihood of many local communities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea and on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 302/2009. The aim of this proposal is to transpose into Union law the measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at the annual sessions from 2012 to 2014.  This Regulation lays down the general rules of the tuna recovery plan, while also taking into account the specifics of the different tools, with particular attention paid to traditional and sustainable fishing gears and fishing gears used in small coastal fishing, such as tuna traps. This legislative initiative will address the issue of ensuring the uniform and effective application of the latest measures of the multiannual ICCAT Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan across the European Union.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the current proposal for a regulation which seeks to transpose into Union law the recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean. In 2006, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, ending in 2022. For the recovery of stocks, the plan provides for a gradual reduction of the total allowable catch level from 2007 to 2011, restrictions on fishing in certain areas and time periods, new minimum sizes, measures relating to sport and recreational fishing activities and fishing capacity. The proposal also contains technical measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna. The role of craft and traditional tools and techniques in stock conservation is important. In implementing the economic recovery plan, the European Union should pay particular attention to these tools and techniques that have contributed to the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted ABSTENTION because while the report underlines the role of artisanal fishing gear, such as traditional almadrabas, we believe that when implementing the recovery plan, the EU should emphasize even more the use of traditional traps that contribute to the restoration of tuna stocks and have very little impact on marine ecosystems thanks to the low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. We also believe it is necessary to denounce that in practice the distribution of quotas in Member States does not apply Article 17 of the CFP urging distribution on the basis of "transparent and objective criteria, including those of an environmental, social and economic nature".

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution. The fishing industry in Europe is very important for many coastal areas. The fishermen are the first who want, and should care about, sustainable fishing. The recovery plan should take into account the specificities of the different types of gears. When implementing the recovery plan, the EU and Member States should pay particular attention to non-industrial fishing activities and to the most artisanal and sustainable gear types, such as traditional traps (‘almadrabas’, ‘tonnare’), which contribute very positively to the rebuilding of tuna stocks, due to their high level of selectivity and low environmental impact in marine ecosystems, and which are valuable in scientific terms.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Bluefin tuna stocks have been replenished. The debate today is about a simple transposition of the ICCAT convention. Problems: - The European Commission, wanting to act very quickly, asks to be able to do delegated acts - Only a few tuna boats take advantage of the stocks; artisanal fishing is largely excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it. However, both the European Commission and MEPs in the Committee on Fisheries stress the protection that must be afforded to traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly. The Commission specifies that it will provide these traditional fishing methods with a specific advantageous regime. - The Commission wanted to go beyond ICCAT's recommendations. Members of the Committee on Fisheries opposed it by amendment. Overall, the amended project allows the codecision procedure to be respected, to defend artisanal fishing methods (madrague) and not to go beyond ICCAT's recommendations. So I voted FOR.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation aims to transpose into European law the measures of the multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted in 2006 by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT), an organisation to which the European Union is a Contracting Party. In order to replenish stocks, reconstitution plans shall provide for a progressive reduction in the level of the allowable total catch, a limitation of fishing in certain areas and during certain periods, and measures relating to sport fishing and recreational fishing. The proposal contains technical measures concerning the transfer and retention of live bluefin tuna, as well as measures for the use of stereoscopic cameras to be able to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna. The purpose of implementing these ICCAT recommendations is to take uniform action at European Union level with a view to restoring bluefin tuna stocks. The report provides, in this regard, for the use of artisanal tools and techniques on stock conservation through the implementation of the recovery plan. I therefore voted in favour of the multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) adopted at its meetings in 2012 and 2014 a multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The resolution aims to apply the plan uniformly throughout the European Union. Every possible step should be taken to restore the stock of bluefin tuna, and I therefore supported the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), the regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of tuna and tuna-like species in the Atlantic Ocean and its bordering seas. ICCAT has the right to take conservation and management decisions in its area of competence ('recommendations'); these acts must be observed and brought into Union law. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted abstention because while the report underlines the role of artisanal fishing gear, such as traditional almadrabas, we believe that when implementing the recovery plan, the EU should emphasize further the use of traditional traps that contribute to the restoration of tuna stocks and have very little impact on marine ecosystems thanks to the low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. We also believe it is necessary to denounce that in practice the distribution of quotas in Member States does not apply Article 17 of the CFP urging distribution on the basis of "transparent and objective criteria, including those of an environmental, social and economic nature".

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – In implementing this plan, Member States should pay particular attention to non-industrial fishing activities and non-industrial sustainable gear types such as traditional traps (isp almadraba, tonnare), which contribute very positively to the recovery of tuna stocks, as they have very high selectivity and have low environmental impacts in marine ecosystems and have scientific value.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009.  The European Union is Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of tuna and tuna-like species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjoining seas. Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT. The proposal contains technical measures such as those on transfer and caging operations of live bluefin tuna, including also measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and releases, catch reporting requirements, and the implementation of the ICCAT Regional Observer Programme.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This report confirms the political agreement reached by the European institutions responsible for this matter. We are talking about a report which incorporates into EU rules the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and by which the European Parliament gives a clear message in defence of these fisheries, further establishing that artisanal and sustainable fisheries have specific treatment in deciding the quotas for catching bluefin tuna. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this report because it was a serious step backwards in favour of industrial tuna fishing and a fair allocation of fishing quotas. This report represents the outcome of the trilogs with commission and council on the recovery plan for bluefin tuna. Parliament's initial position, which we support, contained provisions for traditional, sustainable and small-scale arts, specific to almadraba. Parliament's proposal would have allowed an improvement in the situation of almadrabas with an increase in quotas for them which represent an increase in the sustainable exploitation of tuna. However, all these references have been erased in the process of trilogs relegating the almadraba to a mere reference without any binding power. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'The European Parliament calls on the European Commission to take into account non-industrial fishing activities and the most artisanal and sustainable types of fishing gear, such as traditional tuna traps, in its recovery plan for bluefin tuna. They contribute specifically to the recovery of tuna stocks, as they are highly selective and have a low environmental impact in marine ecosystems. The European Parliament also calls on the Commission to be involved in future international negotiations. I agreed to that.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This is a report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The proposal contains technical measures relating to the processes of transposition and insertion of live tuna into net cages. Since we are not directly affected by the content of this issue, we do not want to interfere in the concerns of the Member States that are actually actively concerned.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by Mr Matos, chairman of the Committee on Fisheries, on the restoration of tuna in the maritime areas of the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Cat report because I agree with the balance achieved in the multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. I would like to point out the amendments proposed by the European Socialist Group to pay particular attention to the preservation and prosperity of small-scale, artisanal and traditional fishing professionals using frames and other selective fishing methods, and to encouraging such methods so that they are not penalised by the criteria for allocating national quotas.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean and repealing the Regulation. The proposal for a regulation lays down general rules for the application of the recovery plan, taking into account the specific characteristics of the different types of fishing gear, and pays particular attention to traditional, more sustainable and artisanal gear.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2008, the European Union has started a cod stock management plan aimed at the sustainable development of fishing activity. Last March, however, the Council signed the new multiannual fisheries pact for Mal Baltic, not only updating the rules for the management of certain fish species, but above all introducing new concepts of sustainability. The ecosystem approach, which enhances biological interaction between species, is accompanied by the provision of maximum sustainable yield, where a maximum allowable amount of fishing is required. I therefore voted in favour, believing that protecting the biodiversity of our seas and the environment is undoubtedly one of Europe's priorities.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The "Multiannual Plan for Cod, Herring and Spurin Populations of the Baltic Sea and for the fish farms exploiting these stocks" is the first of the multiannual plans submitted following the 2013 CFP reform. These plans are intended to be the tools for the management and recovery of Community waste. Despite the need for plans to manage fisheries in our seas and oceans, I have not been able to vote in favour of it as the original proposal has been downgraded following the three-way negotiations between the Council and the Commission. I am particularly concerned about the true application of an ecosystem-based approach or the correction of overpesca. That's why I abstained.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. Due to overfishing, stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are at risk. I voted in favour of this text, which insists that the most recent studies of the ICEM (International Council for the Exploration of the Sea) be taken into account and that the relevant advisory councils be consulted. It is also expected that when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the Baltic cod, herring and papalina stocks, because this plan provides for a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks as well as the stability of fishing opportunities in the region.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Due to overfishing, stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are at risk. Scientific advice has established that the current exploitation of stocks is inconsistent with the goal of maximum sustainable yield.  The Commission did not want to wait for further studies from the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea before implementing the multi-year plan. The draft provides for many technical measures to be delegated to the Commission.  The draft, as amended, insists that the most recent studies of the CIEM be taken into account and that the relevant advisory councils be consulted. It is also expected that when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 A version of a report previously sent back to the Commission, as amended in its entirey, is the subject of the vote. Cod, herring and sprat stocks are interdependence subsystems of the Baltic Sea ecosystem. Even the Commission's original proposal seeks to address the interdependence of species. The amending proposal further deepens the development of legislation with a complex approach, with references and justifications from scientific backgrounds. The proposal tries to ensure the sustainability of the fish species in question while taking into account the livelihoods of small coastal fishing.  The Commission's new complex approach, further honed by the reporter and the modifier, is, inter alia, a sign that it provides a framework for the establishment of a management plan that takes into account not only changes in the stock of a species, but also the conditions of reproduction, living conditions and fishing of all interdepending species. On this basis, I supported the adoption of the motion.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Due to overfishing, stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are at risk. Scientific advice has established that the current exploitation of stocks is inconsistent with the goal of maximum sustainable yield.  The draft, as amended by the Members of the Fisheries Committee, insists that the most recent studies of the ICEM (International Council for the Exploration of the Sea) be taken into account and that the relevant advisory councils be effectively consulted. It is also expected that when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council. I therefore voted in favour of this project, which respects our marine fauna and the prerogatives of Parliament, the only elected body in the Union.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Just as I approved for bluefin tuna, I approve this multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks, which takes into account the elements of the Baltic Sea ecosystem, environmental conditions and socio-economic impact.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Baltic Sea is an extremely sensitive ecosystem, a virtually closed reservoir in which the mutual relations between the various marine species are extremely important. The Wałęsa report, which I supported in Parliament today, improves the Commission's proposal, while at the same time emphasising the importance of the multiannual plan presented. The multispecies management of cod, herring and sprat stocks is a key step forward in the management of fish stocks and is a model for future cod stocks. The regionalised approach provided for in the reform of the common fisheries policy must be strengthened, while at the same time allowing a timely reaction to those sudden changes affecting the state of stocks of the species in question. Ensuring flexibility in the plan is crucial, and that is why the plan must be reviewed in three years' time.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention as we understand the implementation of multi-specific management as a step forward, much more effective than separate species management. We understand that management plans need to ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these wastes, based on scientific opinions, as well as it is essential that all these regulations meet the specificities of the territories and their peoples, which unfortunately are not always collected by EU policies, so we still do not share the criteria for the implementation of the CFP in the territories.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I wanted to vote in favour of the Committee on Fisheries' report on the multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. Members of the Fisheries Committee had the merit of amending the original proposal to include the most recent studies of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, which showed that the current exploitation of stocks was incompatible with the objective of maximum sustainable yield. In addition, the Committee on Fisheries has ensured that there is more transparency in the delegated acts, and that the Commission sends the relevant documents to the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to establish a framework for the "multispecies" management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea in areas where fishing is mainly aimed at these three species. Although I support the 'multispecies' approach of this plan, I cannot fully support this text, as it does not provide sufficient information on the impact it will have on the economies of the areas concerned, so I abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against the report. The Commission's original proposal was a good plan to make Baltic Sea fisheries more sustainable. Unfortunately, the report was watered down, for example it is permissible to fish above the maximum sustainable yield, and we can never support that. This report threatens both biodiversity and the fisheries sector because fish populations are decreasing by overfishing. Allowing fishing above the recommended levels also weakens the Common Fisheries Policy framework. That is why I have voted against the report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This multiannual plan aims to establish a multi-specific management framework for cod, herring and spurin stocks in the Baltic Sea, where they account for more than 94% of catches in recent years.  On 15 March 2016, representatives of the Commission, Council and Parliament reached an agreement for this multiannual plan, which is expected to enter into force before the end of August 2016. This is the first of several plans required in Article 9 of the CFP Regulations.  The agreed plan contains a number of coherent requirements for the new requirements of the common fisheries policy and introduces the concept of "ranges" for the calculation of fishing mortality.  It considered this regulation of paramount importance, taking into account the interactions between the affected species. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it aims to establish a management plan for cod, herring and sprat in the Mixed Baltic Sea, as the region mainly has these three types of fishing. In recent years, 94 % of catches in the Baltic Sea were cod, herring and sprat. The Baltic Sea is essentially a closed waters where these three species are widespread and interact constantly with each other. It is therefore important to develop rules that take into account the interaction between these species, the impact of cod on herring and sprat stocks, and the impact of the latter on cod stocks. In view of the significant impact of biological interaction and environmental conditions on resources in the Baltic Sea, it is desirable that the extent and models of exploitation of these stocks be adapted to take account of revised scientific data on such interactions and changes in environmental conditions.  In addition, such an approach would be consistent with the principle of ecosystem fisheries management. In order to achieve this adaptive management, the first step would be the Commission's proposal to include all relevant resources in a single management plan.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The draft, as amended by the Members of the Fisheries Committee, insists that the most recent studies of the ICES be taken into account (unlike the Commission which did not want to wait for them) and that the relevant advisory councils be consulted. It is also expected that, when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council. Therefore, I voted for it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Cod, herring and sprat are the subject of important fishing activities in the Baltic Sea. The scientific opinion of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) indicates that for some of these stocks the current exploitation rates are not compatible with the achievement of the maximum sustainable yield, as foreseen by the CFP. While a management plan has been in place for cod stocks in the Baltic Sea since 2007, herring and sprat stocks are not yet subject to a management plan. This plan is the first to be approved since the CFP came into force and is an example to follow.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for fishing activities exploiting those stocks is intended to establish a framework for the management of multispecies in the abovementioned stocks. Given that herring, cod and sprat in the Baltic Sea account for more than 94% of catches in recent years, regulation is needed to allow recognition of interactions between the species concerned. Even if there has been a plan for the management of cod stocks in the Baltic Sea, it is not sufficiently adapted to the new conditions, especially since herring and sprat stocks are not included in any management plan. Thus, a multi-species management approach is needed, taking into account sustainable and responsible exploitation and, at the same time, ensuring the stability of fishing opportunities. Given the importance of cod, herring and sprat for the Baltic Sea ecosystem, as well as the strong influence of biological interactions and environmental effects on stocks in the Baltic Sea, I believe that the multiannual plan should be in place with a view to the correct management of these stocks, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Multi-year management plans are the main fisheries management instruments of the Common Fisheries Policy. They allow for a long-term programme of measures, including fishing opportunities. This management plan is the first developed under the rules of the new Common Fisheries Policy (reformed in 2013), which requires, among other things, to manage fish stocks at maximum sustainable yield (MMR). It has been a very difficult case. Parliament and the Council negotiated in a trilogue for 10 months before reaching an agreement. The agreement reached is balanced. Above all, it unlocks management plans for the other marine basins, which were conditional on an agreement on this first next-generation plan. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today to express my satisfaction that the Member States and the European Parliament have reached a good agreement on the new multiannual plan for the Baltic. Since 2008, there has already been a plan for the management of cod stocks in the Baltic Sea. However, it is widely considered inadequate in relation to the current situation of cod stocks and the fishing activities that depend on it. Given the strong influence that biological interactions and environmental effects have on baltic sea stocks, I think it is desirable to be able to adapt the patterns and rates of exploitation of these stocks in the light of the progress made in scientific understanding of interactions and variations in environmental conditions. This would give the plan much-needed flexibility. I would also stress the importance of ensuring that the new plan makes use of the contribution of those who know the region best because they will be able to adapt measures at regional level to the specificities of the fisheries in question.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that proposes a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. The stock of the three species dominates local fishery and the geographic feature of Baltic Sea to be a rather closed environment makes the three species interact frequently. This tailored plan is expected to be more effective in securing sustainable exploitation because it incorporates all related species in a single set of rules. I support the call for greater supervision and an update of the current legislation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The new multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea includes new concepts such as the ecosystem approach and biological interaction between catchable species. This is an important innovation, because for the first time account is being taken of the calculation of catchable quotas, which will be matched by an increase in their natural prey. Overall, the plan is much better than the existing measures, and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report considering that the general line of thought of the Commission's proposal, namely that there is a need for a management plan for many species in the Baltic Sea, is correct.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the report on the establishment of a multiannual plan for the baltic sea cod, herring and papalina stocks and for the fishing activities of these stocks is part of the effort to protect and support specific species threatened by human activity. I think it is our duty to seek solutions to such problems and this project can help to address them. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Baltic Sea is an area with a very high amount of fishing, in particular cod, herring and sprat. I think it is important that a control plan is created because biological interactions and environmental effects have a strong influence on fisheries. I agree with this proposal, which aims to establish a framework for the multispecies management of stocks of the three species mentioned above. In my opinion, this instrument can bring many advantages both to recognise interactions between regulated species and to understand the influence of cod on herring and sprat stocks and vice versa. Better information on these issues will certainly improve the balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks, ensure the stability of fishing opportunities and consequently bring multiple benefits to fishermen. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support balanced and sustainable management of our seas. We have a responsibility for future generations and we must live up to that responsibility.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The "Multiannual Plan for Cod, Herring and Spurin Populations of the Baltic Sea and for the fish farms exploiting these stocks" is the first of the multiannual plans submitted following the 2013 CFP reform. These plans are intended to be the tools for the management and recovery of Community waste. Despite the need for plans to manage fisheries in our seas and oceans, I have not been able to vote in favour of it as the original proposal has been downgraded following the three-way negotiations between the Council and the Commission. I am particularly concerned about the true application of an ecosystem-based approach or the correction of overpesca. That's why I abstained.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text is the result of a lot of work and represents a compromise that was not easy to find. This is the first multiannual plan that takes into account the interactions between species, in order to ensure balanced and sustainable exploitation of fisheries and better economic conditions for fishermen in the long term. Thanks to Parliament, strong safeguards have been ensured to keep stocks at sustainable levels and to ensure a rapid return to acceptable levels in the event of depletion. The management plan must enter into force immediately, as stocks are shrinking, with negative consequences for fishermen as well. A model for sustainable fisheries management, in ecological, economic and social terms, in the long term is the only approach capable of averting cyclical crises which, in addition to serious environmental damage, have repercussions on the sector, putting the work and safety of thousands of families at risk.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 As a Contracting Party to the United Nations Convention of 10 December 1982 on the Law of the Sea, the European Union shall promote a cautious and ecosystem approach to the regulation of fisheries and aquaculture activities. Therefore, in order to ensure the socio-economic and environmental sustainability of the policies covered by the Multiannual Plan, permanent, effective and transparent collaboration between the co-legislators and the European Commission is necessary. Thus, in order to minimise the negative effects of fishing activities on the marine ecosystem, technical support measures should be introduced, improved the selectivity of gear and practices, established conservation reference levels and developed a global fisheries plan. I voted in favour of this report, wishing to express the importance of institutional collaboration, consultation with experts and specialised bodies with a view to creating sustainable fisheries policies.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main premise of the Commission's proposal that a multi-species management plan for the Baltic Sea is needed is correct. The multi-species management approach is more effective than species management. This plan should ensure the sustainable sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities and thus the stability of the livelihood of fishermen. At the same time, this management is based on the most up-to-date scientific advice on the state of the stocks covered by the plan, interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries. It should also be borne in mind that the plan is the first of its kind in the very sensitive baltic sea ecosystem. In fact, it can be seen as an 'ongoing production' as scientists work on more advanced multi-species approaches, which may be necessary at a later stage. It is therefore important that the first review be carried out relatively early, especially as the multi-species management plan is a new and evolving concept. I believe that the first review of the plan should take place three years after its entry into force, and if the plan has a positive effect, it should be reviewed again after five years. This will also provide the desired flexibility in the implementation of the plan. In view of the above-mentioned phenomena and their consequences for the Baltic Sea ecosystem, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the first multiannual management plan under the reformed Common Fisheries Policy, which consists of a set of rules for managing European fishing fleets and for conserving fish stocks. Designed to manage a common resource, it gives all European fishing fleets equal access to EU waters and fishing grounds and allows fishermen to be able to compete. This plan aims to ensure a sustainable exploitation of the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea taking into account the most up to date scientific information.  It is  important that these multiannual plans are in line with the Common Fisheries Policy objectives.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report focuses on multi-year plans that are essential instruments for sustainable management and recovery of fish stocks. These long-term strategies aim to improve not only stock conservation, but also long-term visibility for fishermen. In October 2014, the Commission proposed a multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. One of the major reforms to the new multi-species management plan is the staggering of authorized catch quotas to ensure the sustainability of fisheries. Considering that this multi-year plan will establish an economically viable model of fishing while ensuring the sustainability and reasonable management of fishing activities in the Baltic Sea, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. As the stocks concerned are interdependent, a multi-species management plan in the Baltic Sea is required. The multi-year plan includes safeguards to reduce fishing opportunities when scientific advice indicates that a stock is at risk. This reduces the negative impact of fishing activities on the ecosystem.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are threatened by overfishing, as current stock exploitation is incompatible with the goal of sustainable maximum yield. The Commission did not wish to wait for further studies by the INTERNATIONAL Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICEM) before implementing this multi-year plan. The draft provides for many technical measures to be delegated to the Commission.  The draft, as amended by the Members of the Fisheries Committee, insists that the most recent studies of the ICES be taken into account as well as the opinion of the advisory councils concerned. It is also expected that, when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council. In view of these conditions, I voted for this text, which is in line with the preservation of fisheries resources.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am amazed how so far we have made plans for the stocks of cod, herring and spca individually. As we can see from the textbooks already in the first classes at school, in nature everything is connected and I do not know how they managed to cope with their implementation of the plan, since these three fish are in constant interaction, and the habitat they inhabit is the same. I hope that now that efforts are joined and all three species of fish are considered, and as the report makes clear for everyone else, we will achieve parity between nature and man and be able to both preserve the livelihoods of fishermen and allow nature to act on its laws.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of fish stocks and the adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets must take into account the specificities of the marine areas concerned and the States concerned.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. 'u2012 Cod, herring and sprat account for more than 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years.  The Baltic Sea is a nearly closed body of water, in which these three species are ubiquitous and interact continuously. It is therefore extremely important to ensure regulation to recognise the interactions between the species concerned, in particular the influence of cod on herring and sprat stocks and the reverse. In view of the strong influence that biological interactions and environmental effects have on stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea, it is advisable to be able to adapt the rates and patterns of exploitation of these stocks in the light of developments in scientific knowledge on such interactions and on the evolution of environmental conditions.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: the draft, as amended by the Members of the Committee on Fisheries, insists that the most recent studies of the ICES be taken into account and that the relevant advisory councils be consulted. It is also expected that, when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council.

name: João FERREIRA
