text: in writing. \u2012 The multiannual plan, one of the instruments on which the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is based – reform 2012 – presents as its primary objective the maintenance of stocks above the levels that will allow a maximum sustainable yield. The proposed amendments to this effect have some positive points, such as the reduction of the periods between evaluations, which could allow for environmentally appropriate catch levels, facilitating a socio-economic approach to fisheries in this region and an equally appropriate approach to the protection of by-catch species. The report limits the Commission's powers to carry out antave acts without consultation with Parliament and the Council. We advocate the practice of consultation and participation not only of regional advisory councils, but also of the Member States. There is a tendency to relax the limits and time periods to reach the levels necessary for the sustainability of stocks, namely by increasing the ranges of target mortality rates, and the minimum level of reproductive biomass, or by making the proposed limits for 2015 be met only in 2020. The figure of the multiannual plans has the potential, but suffers from some of the limitations and constraints inherent in the CFP itself.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal. A multispecies management approach is certainly more beneficial and effective than managing a single species. This vision has the merit of aiming for a balanced and sustainable management of stocks, and ensuring a level of fishing that ensures a stable income for fishermen.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as I do not believe the common fisheries policy is Ireland’s interests.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from this report because the European Union should leave greater autonomy in fisheries to the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the multiannual plan for the baltic sea cod, herring and papalina stocks and for the fishing activities of those stocks. The protection of fish stocks and the adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets must take into account the specificities of the marine areas concerned and the States concerned.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Multiannual plans are fundamental to reduce fishing mortality to rate which can maximise long-term sustainable yield. The current management regimes do not allow sufficient predictability concerning the proper conservation of the stocks, or concerning fishing opportunities for the fisherman. I therefore support changes in order to cover, in a single management plan, the three main fished species distributed in eight stocks in the Baltic Sea, namely two for cod, five for herring and one for sprat, with the aim to achieve and maintain Maximum Sustainable Yield (MSY) for these stocks. Moreover, I support the proposal to set a target range of fishing mortality in line with the MSY principle as from 2015, and a minimum level of the spawning stock biomass which fishing management measures should strive to conserve.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the report of the multiannual plan for fishing for the listed fish stocks. The aim of the proposal is to establish a multi-species management framework for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. Cod, herring and sprat accounted for more than 94% of the Baltic Sea catches in recent years. In fact, the Baltic Sea can be considered a closed body of water, and all three species can be found in it. It is therefore essential to adopt a Regulation acknowledging the interactions between the species concerned, including the impact of cod on herring and sprat stocks.  On the basis of a regionalised approach to the common fisheries policy, the additional measures necessary to achieve maximum sustainable yield for the stocks concerned should be laid down. However, the rules should be more closely linked to the principle of specific regionalisation and should allow for a timely response in the event of a sudden change in the situation of the stocks concerned. In the case of multiannual plans, the voice of the region must be heard and acted upon, with the involvement of the European Parliament at the appropriate stage.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for cod stocks, Herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for fishing activities exploiting these stocks, amends Council Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005 and repeals Council Regulation (EC) No 1098/2007 because it is the first real implementation plan for the reform of the common fisheries policy and can serve as a model for future negotiations. The difficulties of the approach linked to the common fisheries policy arise from the need to find a compromise between the two opposing requirements for the sustainability of fish stocks, on the one hand, and the necessary flexibility for operators in the sector and the Member States in applying the rules on the conservation of fish species, on the other. The compromise reached between Parliament and the Council in the trialogue is a good agreement, which will enable the parties concerned to assess the effects and practical consequences of the measures and their transferability to other species. In particular, I am in favour of including in the Plan forecasts relating to the régionalisation and economic, social and environmental sustainability of fishing activities.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. Fishing is and remains an important economic activity for my home region of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and other regions along the Baltic Sea. Biodiversity is the basis of this sector, which is mostly medium-sized. That is why the preservation of this diversity is also in the economic and regional interest. It was therefore clear to me that I was voting in favour of the 'multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for the fisheries that fish these stocks'.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea is an essential instrument for the sustainable management and recovery of fish stocks. Such long-term approaches are intended to improve the conservation of stocks. At the same time, however, it must also guarantee the economic viability of the farm for fishermen.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Due to overfishing, stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are at risk. Scientific advice has thus established that the current exploitation of stocks is incompatible with the objective of maximum sustainable yield, that is, with the objective of responsible fishing that allows the best possible replenishment of resources. It is therefore necessary to act, but without confusing speed with haste. To speed up the process, the European Commission did not want to wait for further studies from the INTERNATIONAL Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICEM) before implementing the multi-year plan. Fortunately, the draft regulation, as amended by MEPs, insists that scientific studies be taken into account and that local advisory councils be consulted. It is regrettable, however, that the draft delegates a great deal of powers to the European Commission, to the detriment of the prerogatives of the European Parliament.  However, I voted for this text because fishermen need multi-year plans that give them long-term visibility.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention as we understand the implementation of multi-specific management as a step forward, much more effective than separate species management. We understand that management plans need to ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these wastes, based on scientific opinions, as well as it is essential that all these regulations meet the specificities of the territories and their peoples, which unfortunately are not always collected by EU policies, so we still do not share the criteria for the implementation of the CFP in the territories.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fishing exploiting those stocks, amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005 and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1098/2007. I support the creation of a framework for the multi-species management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, where the three species are mainly fished. A multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for fishing exploiting these stocks has already been published by the European Commission in 2014. Multi-species management for the Baltic Sea appears to be a more effective plan than managing each of these fish species separately. The proposed plan will ensure a sustainable, sustainable exploitation of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, which will directly translate into the stability of the livelihood for fishermen.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Multiannual plans for fisheries management are an essential tool to ensure the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks and marine ecosystems. European Parliament supported a proposal for multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for the fisheries exploiting them. This Baltic multiannual and multispecies plan is the first proposed plan to build on the principles of the 2013 reform of the Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the above resolution. The ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management which is put forward in this resolution is essential to the maintenance of European marine wildlife systems. The resolution sets the fishing mortality target so that it takes into account the most recent scientific advice and should continue to do so, on a progressive, incremental basis, until 2020 at the latest. Moreover, the resolution provides for the temporary cessation of fishing activities in the region to allow for the replenishment of fish stock levels. I believe that maintaining fish stocks above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield is essential to the economic and environmental development of the EU and its regions.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, as it is a pre-emptive measure and a tool for ensuring the sustainable management of our fish stocks.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which is of high importance in ensuring regulation enabling the identification of interactions between the species concerned, the influence of the cod species on herring and sprat stocks and vice versa and for the exploitation of fishing activities. The Commission should include all fish stocks in the Baltic Sea in a single management plan. This plan would study much more thoroughly the issue of the resources of fish species in the Baltic Sea area in order to address fisheries management in an ecosystem.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks, amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 2187/2005 and on the repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005. 1098/2007 (COM(2014)0614 – C8 0174/2014-2014/0285(COD)), as it is a multiannual management plan that takes into account several types that are interconnected and interacting. It is also important because these three species – cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea account for over 94% of catches in recent years, and there are risks of overfishing and ecosystem consequences due to baltic sealing.  Such a plan may serve to develop other management and exploitation plans for fish stocks in other seas, in fish interacting with each other. This management approach involving at the same time more fish species is much more efficient than species-only management, and should ensure a balanced, sustainable use of the quantity of fish species, stability of fishing opportunities as well as income for fishermen.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text highlights the consequences of overfishing endangering stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. The draft, as amended by the Members of the Fisheries Committee, insists that the most recent studies of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea be taken into account and that the relevant advisory councils be consulted. It is also expected that, when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council. To that extent, I voted for the text.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 This report comes with a long-awaited plan for fisheries policy, which no longer focuses on one species, but takes into account the evolution of different fish species and their interaction with each other. The plan should help to fish for these species in a balanced and sustainable way, as well as to the stability of opportunities and therefore the livelihoods of fishermen. An important part of the proposal is the guarantee of the use of up-to-date scientific knowledge concerning both stocks of the species concerned, interactions between them and other aspects of sustainable fisheries. I believe that this baltic sea plan is a major step in the right direction towards reforming the common fisheries policy and sustainable fisheries, and I was therefore happy to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, which ensures sustainable management and recovery of fish stocks. The text aims not only to improve the conservation of fish stocks, but also to give long-term visibility to fishermen.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although there are some good ideas in this report, the plan for the European fishing industry as a whole must be viewed critically. That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Seafood is an indispensable part of a healthy diet. Fish caught in the Baltic Sea are available both freshly and in canned form in most EU countries, such as my country. The stability of the regional ecosystem must be supported, and complex legislation is likely to solve the sustainable fishing of cod, herring and Sprotn stocks. An important socio-economic aspect is also the preservation of traditional small-fishing activities along the coast.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Environmental effects and biological interactions have an effect on maritime stocks, which is why it is necessary to implement rules for the protection of certain species. In fact, in 2014 the Commission published a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for fishing activities exploiting these stocks. This proposal, granted after months of negotiations, now seeks to regulate a framework for the multi-species management of the abovementioned stocks, in the seas where they are most exploited, and sees a transition to new adaptive management. Agreement has finally been reached on the first multiannual plan under the new CFP and, for these reasons, I am voting in favour of the Commission's proposal for sustainable stock fishing in the Baltic Sea.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted for the multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. Due to overfishing, stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are at risk. Scientific advice has established that the current exploitation of stocks is inconsistent with the goal of maximum sustainable yield. The draft, as amended by members of the Fisheries Committee, insists that the latest studies of the ICES be taken into account and that the relevant advisory councils be consulted. It is also expected that, when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The main objective of the text is to define and implement the multi-year plan proposed by the Commission to combat overfishing in the Baltic Sea. Indeed, many scientific opinions warn the authorities against depletion of stocks. In particular, the INTERNATIONAL Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICEM) is developing new studies for their preservation. The text requires the Commission to take this research into account before drawing up its final annual plan. Nevertheless, he delegated many technical measures to him. Despite this the whole text being positive, I logically voted FOR.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The "Multiannual Plan for Cod, Herring and Spurin Populations of the Baltic Sea and for the fish farms exploiting these stocks" is the first of the multiannual plans submitted following the 2013 CFP reform. These plans are intended to be the tools for the management and recovery of Community waste. Despite the need for plans to manage fisheries in our seas and oceans, I have not been able to vote in favour of it as the original proposal has been downgraded following the three-way negotiations between the Council and the Commission. I am particularly concerned about the true application of an ecosystem-based approach or the correction of overpesca. That's why I abstained.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The general principle on which the Commission's proposal is based is the need for a multi-specific management plan in the Baltic Sea. Multi-specific management is much more effective than separate species management. This plan should ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks as well as the stability of fishing opportunities and thus the livelihoods of fishermen.  I think it is important to stress that when multiannual plans are drawn up, the voice of the region must be heard and implemented, with the participation at the opportune time of the European Parliament. Similarly, it should be noted that the plan is a pioneering proposal in a very sensitive ecosystem of the Baltic Sea, therefore the first revision takes place relatively soon, precisely because the multispecific management plan is a new and developing concept.  From the above I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report that seeks to ensure the sustainability and conservation of future fish stocks in the Baltic sea.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I regularly stay with these reports, as the Czech Republic does not have a sea.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The primary objective of this plan is to establish a basis for the management of the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea, where mainly these three species fish are caught (around 94 % of all annual catches). The plan currently adopted in 2008 no longer corresponds to the reality in terms of cod catches, while sprat and herring are not affected at all. Given the biological and geographical specificities of the Baltic Sea, it is necessary to put into practice the new model for the exploitation of these species stocks, which this new plan also offers to a large extent. The recovery and maintenance of inventories and their preservation and taking into account interaction are key components of the new Regulation. It is worth noting that, with the entry into force of the Regulation, one of the primary springboards must be given not only to fish, but to those employed in the fisheries sector, especially in the Baltic States, where these areas have been severely affected by the introduction of counter-sanctions by the Russian Federation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The essence of the Commission's proposal is the multi-species planned management of fish farming and recovery in the Baltic Sea. The aim is to ensure a balanced relationship between fish farming and recovery and ensuring work and livelihoods for fishermen. This proposal has positive effects on ecosystems and, at the same time, on maintaining jobs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and papalina in the Baltic Sea and for the fishing activities of those stocks, amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be repealed. For the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 22/6/2016 and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. We agree with this project, which has been extensively amended by the European Parliament's Fisheries Committee. In this case, the aim was to insist on taking into account the studies of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea on the stocks of cod, herring and sprats of the Baltic Sea, which are hard hit by overfishing. In addition, the draft takes into account another requirement of the parliamentary committee: that of the transmission to Parliament of documents relating to decisions taken by the Commission in the context of delegated management. Indeed, through this method of management, the European Commission was arrogating important decision-making powers, particularly in the area of technical measures. The satisfaction of these claims corresponds to our expectations.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the multiannual plan for cod, herring and baltic sea sprat stocks. The aim of the proposal is to establish a multispecies stock plan which is much more effective than managing a single species. This plan allows for the balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and ensures the establishment of fishermen's fishing opportunities and livelihoods, while ensuring that management is based on the most up-to-date scientific advice on the state of the stocks in question, interactions between species and other aspects relating to the ecosystem and fishing activities.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 Stocks of cod, herring and papalina in the Baltic Sea are at serious risk of decline from fishing activities. The Commission has therefore already proposed the establishment of a framework regulating the range of fishing opportunities while ensuring stability in the stocks of these three species of catches. These three species are important elements of the Baltic Sea ecosystem, which is why I consider it of major importance to protect and control their stocks. I therefore vote in favour of this resolution, which aims at the sustainable exploitation of these species as part of the overall effort to protect the marine ecosystem.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report deals with the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. Sustainable ecological economy is of immense importance for our future. However, in some places this report is inconclusive. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Because of intensive fishing, these fish species are at risk. The draft basically proposed that the Commission should have many technical measures in place. It planned to implement the multi-year plan without waiting for the report of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea. The amendments seemed to me to be a good move in that they put the expertise of this council back at the centre of the debate. That seems to me to be a prudential measure. I also appreciate the fact that the Commission is finally obliged to inform Parliament when it prepares to take delegated acts. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to establish a management plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. The plan should ensure the sustainable exploitation of these stocks as well as the stability of fishing opportunities, while ensuring that management is based on the latest scientific information on interactions within and between stocks, as well as other elements of the ecosystem and environment. The initiative's specific objective is to ensure that stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are exploited in a sustainable way in accordance with the principles of maximum sustainable yield and an ecosystem approach to fisheries management. To this end, the stocks concerned should be caught at levels likely to generate maximum sustainable yield. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because of its utilisation of a multispecies management plan to ensure sustainable fishing and support for both conservation of several Baltic fish species and for the economic livelihood of those in the fishing industry.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the regulation on a multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. The inclusion in multi-year plans of responsible resource management concepts such as the ecosystem-based approach, maximum sustainable yield or the precautionary principle perfectly reflects the European conception of fishing activities, and I am delighted. Only this approach can reverse the trend that has led to overfishing and therefore to unsustainable exploitation of our fisheries resources, which seriously jeopardizes any sustainability of fishing activities in any region of the world concerned.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – In 2014, the European Commission published a multi-annual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting those stocks. The aim of the proposal is to establish a framework for multi-species management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, where fishing primarily targets these three species. A multi-species management approach is much more effective than species management. The plan should ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities – and thus the livelihoods of fishermen. At the same time, it should ensure that management is based on the most up-to-date scientific advice on stock status, species interaction and other aspects related to ecosystems and fisheries. In view of the above, I agree with the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks, which aims to establish a framework for the multispecies management of the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea, where fishing primarily targets these three species. Cod, herring and sprat account for over 94 % of Baltic catches in the recent years. The Baltic Sea is a virtually closed body of water in which these three species are omnipresent and interact continuously. Therefore it is of utmost importance to deliver regulation making it possible to recognize interactions between the species covered, inter alia the cod's influence on herring and sprat stocks and the other way round. The plan should provide for a balanced, sustainable exploitation of those stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities – and thereby of the livelihoods of fishers. At the same time it should guarantee that the management would be based on the most up-to-date scientific advice regarding the status of stocks covered, interactions between species and other aspects related to ecosystem and fisheries.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The management plan for cod stocks in the Baltic Sea has been in place since 2008, but this does not yet apply to herring and sprat stocks. However, since cod feed on sprat and herring, the size of the cod stock affects the size of herring and sprat stocks and vice versa. In October 2014, the Commission published a multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and their fisheries with a view to creating a single management framework for the three stocks. It proposes to Parliament and the Council to repeal Regulation (EC) No 1098/2007, to amend Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005 and to include in the Regulation a multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and spratt in the Baltic Sea and their fishing.  In its report, the Committee on Fisheries recommends that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal at first reading with almost 50 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The report addresses the problem of overfishing, which causes stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea to be at risk.  The Commission wishes to act quickly, without waiting for the latest opinions of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea.  However, as amended by MEPs on the Committee on Fisheries, the report insists that the most recent studies of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea be taken into account. It is also expected that, when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council. As a result, it is possible to vote in favour of the report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to establish a framework for the management of multiple species of stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea, where fishing focuses mainly on these three species. Cod, herring and sprat account for more than 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the multi-species management plan for the Baltic Sea as the right option. The multispecies management approach is much more effective than managing individual species. The plan should provide for a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities and, consequently, of the livelihoods of fishermen. I also share the rapporteur's position on the position on the protection of cod stocks during sow and on the defence of small-scale artisanal fishing. In view of the innovative and pioneering nature of the multi-species management plan, I support its analysis and, consequently, revision after the third year of validity, in order to ensure the flexibility desired to the plan.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This project as amended is satisfactory and will preserve cod, herring and sprats. I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the multi-year plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. This plan, which is the first developed under the rules of the new fisheries policy, requires the management of fish stocks with maximum sustainable yield, which, according to this text, is assessed according to a range of values.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the direction of the proposal, which foresomes a long-term economic plan for the Baltic Sea, to be very important. Balanced multi-species regulation takes into account a number of problems that arise. It must be shown that responsible and sustainable goals are needed to protect the environment. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal, which could lead to a guiding stability in a highly sensitive ecosystem. This brings us closer to ensuring that fishing opportunities continue to be provided for those living in fishing activities.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The CFP is a set of rules for managing European fishing fleets and for conserving fish stocks. This is the first multiannual management plan under the reformed CFP. I have voted for this report that aims to ensure the sustainable exploitation of the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea, while ensuring that management is based on the most up to date scientific information on interactions within and between the stocks and with other aspects of the ecosystem and environment.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I think it is extremely important that these multiannual plans for the various fish stocks enter into force as soon as possible. Negotiating and adopting this multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea has been a very long and arduous process, due to disputes between the European Parliament and the Council over the powers held in this case. The adoption of multiannual plans for these fish stocks is the basic instrument used to achieve the objectives of sustainable fishing and the protection of fish stocks established by the CFP. In this respect, unlocking this situation by adopting this plan will help to adopt, within a reasonable time, future multiannual plans for the other EU seas, including the Black Sea.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea is the first new plan among the new common fisheries stocks. This plan is intended to bring clear objectives and predictability for fishermen. The common fisheries policy pursues the common objective of long-term economic viability. Fisheries and aquaculture must be environmentally sound and socially sustainable. This is the only way in which European citizens will benefit, with healthier food and a better quality of life. The report contains very good approaches, but there are a number of points on which I cannot agree, and I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this multiannual management plan for cod, sprat and herring in the Baltic Sea. In particular, this plan will ensure that fishing in the Baltic Sea is sustainable and more predictable, as well as balanced use of stocks and stability of fishing opportunities. It is also the first plan, which actually covers different fish stocks, ensuring that their management is based on the latest scientific information. The additional sustainable fisheries fuses envisaged will help to respond appropriately to the changing situation of stocks.  It should be noted that the measures provided for in this long-term plan will help to preserve the small-scale fisheries sector and will ensure a reliable revenue from fishing. For fishermen, the rules will become clearer and simpler. There will be clear, predictable and long-term savings-oriented management of fish stocks.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Having considered the European Commission's Multiannual Plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea; whereas the three species account for 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years and whereas, although there is a cod stock management plan, this is not appropriate to the current situation; whereas, with regard to the other two species, there is a lack of legislation and regulation and that this deficiency must necessarily be corrected, also in the light of the protection of the ecosystem; Given, therefore, that the drawing up of a single plan, which would also include other species of fish and based on up-to-date scientific studies, would be an appropriate way of filling the regulatory gap and ensuring greater protection of stocks, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The mortality rates of cod, herring and sprat are essential to the preservation of the marine ecosystem. The proposed agreement suggests that the fishing activities will be conducted in a sustainable way so that a balance is achieved. Thinking for tomorrow we have to act today if we are to sustain stability in our ecosystems. Hence, I vote in favour of the trilogue agreement as I believe that it is our duty to preserve the animal species populations.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The regulations for managing stocks in the Baltic Sea so far have covered only the cod stock and have been assessed as not proportionate to the current situation of cod stocks and fishing dependent on it, which may undermine the stability of ecosystems in the Baltic Sea. Since herring and sprats are also present in the Baltic Sea and are constantly interacting with cod and are thus an inseparable part of the Baltic Sea ecosystem, I think it is important to adopt a regulation that will recognise the mutual impact of these species and regulate the management of their stocks accordingly, and for this reason I voted to adopt the Multiannual Plan for Cod, Herring and Sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea.  The balance of ecosystems needs to be properly addressed and I consider it a good move to include all stocks of relevant fish species in a single management plan that can ensure a more efficient and balanced exploitation of these stocks and the stability of traditional fishing, as the current rates of exploitation of cod, herring and sprat stocks are not in line with achieving maximum sustainable yield. Under the model of this multiannual plan, similar fisheries plans could be prepared in other geographical areas, with constant knowledge of the latest scientific research.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒the United Nations Convention of 10 December 1982 on the law of the sea, to which the Union is a Contracting Party, provides for conservation obligations, including the maintenance or restoration of populations of caught species at levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield, as determined by appropriate environmental and economic factors. The management plan for a large number of species established by this Regulation requires that the different ecological roles and functions of the species covered by the plan be taken into account more; whereas various species are largely interacting, catches cannot be maximally viable for all species simultaneously and decisions need to be taken on which species will be prioritised. The exploitation of cod and pelagic stocks must not jeopardise the sustainability of stocks taken as an overfishing in that fishery, i.e. stocks of goldpies, chipboard, weaving and leaf smooth in the Baltic. Therefore, the plan should also aim to ensure that these stocks are maintained above biomass levels corresponding to a precautionary approach and an ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management that can produce maximum sustainable yield.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this first multiannual plan under the reformed common fisheries policy. Precisely because this is the first multiannual plan that will logically be a model for other similar plans for other seas, setting conditions is extremely important. This is also why it has been so difficult to reach agreements and concessions between Parliament and the Council. The plan aims to ensure sustainable fishing for cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. Last year, Parliament decided to postpone the vote on the subject, in particular because of the impossibility of reaching a compromise on fish mortality rates. Parliament has pushed for much stricter measures. While it has managed to impose only partial flexibility restrictions proposed by Member States in the trilogues, I welcome the fact that, at the same time, stronger insurance measures have been enforced with regard to sustainable catches. The Social Democrats have done an excellent job within the Committee on Fisheries in this regard. I welcome the fact that the committee's position was also confirmed today by the plenary session.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that a management plan, covering several species, in the Baltic Sea is more effective than managing a single species, because it allows for the balanced and sustainable exploitation of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and ensures the stability of fishing opportunities and, consequently, of fishermen's livelihoods. In addition, there are strong arguments in favour of maintaining certain rules that are already in force, which protect cod stocks during the breeding period and protect small-scale small-scale small-scale fishing. That is why I voted in favour of this multiannual plan and I hope that such a solution will allow for a more flexible approach to the annual determination of fishing opportunities.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main premise of the Commission's proposal that a multi-species management plan for the Baltic Sea is needed is correct. The multi-species management approach is more effective than species management. This plan should ensure the sustainable sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities and thus the stability of the livelihood of fishermen. At the same time, this management is based on the most up-to-date scientific advice on the state of the stocks covered by the plan, interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries. This plan is the first of its kind in the very sensitive baltic sea ecosystem. In fact, it can be seen as an 'ongoing production' as scientists work on more advanced multi-species approaches, which may be necessary at a later stage. It is therefore important that the first review be carried out relatively early, especially as the multi-species management plan is a new and evolving concept. The first review of the plan should take place three years after its entry into force and, if the plan has a positive impact, it should be reviewed again after five years. This will also provide the desired flexibility in the implementation of the plan. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for this multi-year management plan for the Baltic Cod, Herring and Sprat stocks for fisheries exploiting these stocks. This management plan is the first developed under new rules arising from the Common Fisheries Policy, reformed in 2013, which requires, among other things, to manage fish stocks at maximum sustainable yield (MMR).

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The European Parliament supports the practice of reasoned fishing in the Baltic Sea and the protection of cod, herring and sprat stocks.  These three species are essential to the Baltic Sea ecosystem because of their strong biological interactions. Indeed, the size of the cod stock can affect the size of herring and sprat stocks and vice versa. Unfortunately, they are overexploited.  It is therefore essential to put in place a management plan for herring and sprat stocks as has already been in place since 2007 for cod. The Walesa report voted by Parliament this afternoon is therefore in line with this logic and takes a further step by integrating all the stocks concerned into a single management plan. The latter will ensure sustainable stock use in accordance with the principles of sustainable maximum yield and the ecosystem approach to fisheries management.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This multiannual plan aims to establish a multi-specific management framework for cod, herring and spurin stocks in the Baltic Sea, where they account for more than 94% of catches in recent years.  On 15 March 2016, representatives of the Commission, Council and Parliament reached an agreement for this multiannual plan, which is expected to enter into force before the end of August 2016. This is the first of several plans required in Article 9 of the CFP Regulations.  The agreed plan contains a number of coherent requirements for the new requirements of the common fisheries policy and introduces the concept of "ranges" for the calculation of fishing mortality.  It considered this regulation of paramount importance, taking into account the interactions between the affected species. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted this compromise text negotiated with the Council establishing a multi-year plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. This report was adopted by a large majority. The Baltic Cod Recovery Plan is the first multi-year plan incorporating the provisions on the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The text of the regulation stipulates that the plan should aim to contribute to the achievement of the CFP's objectives, in particular to achieve and maintain an RMD (maximum sustainable yield) for the stocks concerned (cod, herring, sprat). The MDR should be achieved as soon as possible, and by 2020 at the latest. The regulation also applies to bycating, fling, turbot and bearded catch. In addition, and I am pleased to do so, geographical restrictions on fishing are maintained in the Baltic to protect breeding and juveniles. Finally, the plan implements the ecosystem approach to fisheries management to ensure that the negative impacts of fishing activities on the marine ecosystem are "minimized".

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Fishing is essentially a very sensitive issue in the internal sea of the European Union , in the Baltic Sea. Sensitive to it is not only for us, for the representatives of the Baltic Sea countries, but also for the entire Baltic ecosystem. Countries around the sea have sufficient capacity to destroy all fish stocks in this sea without regulating fishing. To that end, today we are adopting a multiannual plan for the management and fishing of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea.  When I look at the document, I can identify three of its shortcomings. The first is that the plan is quite irresponsible. It pays very little attention to the recovery of fish stocks, the essential condition of which is to fish less fish than they grow. The second drawback of the plan is socially irresponsible: poorer EU Member States are treated in the same way as the richer, despite the fact that even the revitalisation of fishing, rather than the development of fishing, but its revival after irresponsible action to reduce THE EU's fishing capacity could become one of the engines of sustainable regional development for regional growth. The third drawback is that the plan does not pay sufficient attention to working with non-EU countries in the Baltic Sea region, which are known for their failure to comply with international agreements.  Nevertheless, it is better not quite a good plan than none. I am therefore voting in favour, while calling on the Commission to take into account the comments made in the future.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Given the characteristics of the water mass of this sea, these three species are ubiquitous and interact continuously, so it is extremely important to ensure regulation that recognizes the interactions between them. Cod, herring and sprat are important components of the Baltic ecosystem and, in view of the strong influence that biological interactions and environmental effects have on the stocks of these species, it is advisable to be able to adapt the patterns of exploitation of these stocks in the light of the evolution of the latest scientific knowledge on these interactions and on the evolution of environmental conditions. This report reflects the agreement with the Commission's proposal on the integration of a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these species, with which I agree, and i therefore voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by Mr Walesa (EPP) on the proposal for a regulation establishing a multiannual plan for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for fishing activities exploiting these stocks. The text presented in plenary is the result of a series of negotiations between Parliament, the Council and the Commission (trialogue), which have made it possible to reach a compromise on a controversial point, namely the highest acceptable level of mortality caused by fishing activities. The Baltic Sea Stock Plan is the first of its kind to be adopted under the new common fisheries policy. it shall ensure that the fishing activities carried out in the area concerned are environmentally friendly and economically sustainable. For these reasons, the plan will be used as a model to be applied in other areas, first and first of all the North Sea and the Atlantic. I believe that these are very good reasons for supporting the text presented in plenary.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention as we understand the implementation of multi-specific management as a step forward, much more effective than separate species management. We understand that management plans need to ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these wastes, based on scientific opinions, as well as it is essential that all these regulations meet the specificities of the territories and their peoples, which unfortunately are not always collected by EU policies, so we still do not share the criteria for the implementation of the CFP in the territories.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that a management plan for several species is needed in the Baltic Sea and I welcome the Commission's proposal to revise the regulation in this regard. , of course, fishermen's sources of income. Multiannual plans should also ensure that the management of cod and herring stocks is based on the latest scientific recommendations on the situation of the stocks concerned, interactions between species and other ecosystem-related issues and fishing activities. I also support the Commission's position that the regulation should include rules on by-catches of flat fish. Flat fish, such as Baltic flounder, flounder, turbot and smooth turbot, may constitute significant amounts of by-catches during cod fishing and do not expose cod, herring and sprat to any major risk.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Multiannual Plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for the fisheries fishing for these stocks'. This multiannual management plan is aimed primarily at sustainable fishing. Among other things, it sets maximum catches and provides for various technical measures to safeguard and better control stocks.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The "Multiannual Plan for Cod, Herring and Spurin Populations of the Baltic Sea and for the fish farms exploiting these stocks" is the first of the multiannual plans submitted following the 2013 CFP reform. These plans are intended to be the tools for the management and recovery of Community waste. Despite the need for plans to manage fisheries in our seas and oceans, I have not been able to vote in favour of it as the original proposal has been downgraded following the three-way negotiations between the Council and the Commission. I am particularly concerned about the true application of an ecosystem-based approach or the correction of overpesca. That's why I abstained.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the establishment of the multiannual plan for cod, herring, and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. The aim of the regulation is to allow for the balanced and sustainable exploitation of these fish species, which together account for 94% of total catches. The multispecies management plan established by this Regulation requires greater account to be taken of the different ecological functions and roles of the species covered by the plan.  As this is the first plan of its kind adopted under the new CFP, I hope that it will serve as a model or a test case for future multiannual plans for the management of fishing activities in other European seas.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Cod, herring and sprat stocks account for more than 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. The general focus of the Commission's proposal on the need for a multi-species management plan in the Baltic Sea is correct. A multi-species management approach is much more effective than species management. The plan should ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities – and thus the livelihoods of fishermen. I voted in favour.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed with the proposal for a regulation by which the Commission intends to regulate cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, as it is these three fish species that account for more than 90% of catches in this area. The Baltic Sea is essentially a closed body of water, in which these three species are ubiquitous and constantly interact with each other. It is therefore of the utmost importance to allow for the management of their population to take account of their interactions. Cod stocks are affected by the size of herring and sprat stocks, as cod is a predator of sprat and herring. Given that cod, herring and sprat are important components of the Baltic ecosystem, it is desirable to adapt the rates and techniques of their use to new scientific knowledge on interactions and changes in environmental conditions. The proposal for a regulation addresses precisely these biological interactions and the environmental effects of fish stocks in the Baltic Sea. The first step towards flexible management of the stocks of these three species is the proposal to include all relevant stocks in a single management plan. This will allow for more flexible access to resources during the annual setting of fishing opportunities and improve responses to changing situations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In October 2012, the European Commission published a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. The proposal aims to establish a framework for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, where fisheries are primarily targeted at these three species. In recent years, cod, herring and sprat accounted for more than 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea. The Baltic Sea is a near-closed body of water in which these three species are present everywhere and constantly co-influence each other. It is therefore of the utmost importance that the European Union has this area well regulated so that it can be co-influenced between the species covered by the plan, including the impact of cod on herring and sprat stocks, and vice versa. The report was significantly weakened compared to the drafts. For example, it allows fishing in larger quantities than was limited in the Common Fisheries Policy, which is unacceptable. Although the report explicitly mentions the good environmental status of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive and also allows for the restriction of fishing equipment with a view to preserving non-commercial fish species, which I support, I think the report is quite poor. For this reason, I voted against it.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Since 2008, a provision has been in force to control cod outfishing in the Baltic Sea, but it is the Fisheries Committee's assessment that the current provision does not take into account the current fishing condition of the Baltic Sea and that an amendment is needed. Existing provisions also do not cover the state of the Herring and Sprats of the Baltic Sea.  Taking into account fishing and the continuing ecological changes in fish habitat, the Committee considers that a comprehensive plan for the management of cod, herring, and Baltic sprat is needed. It is proposed that the management be carried out using state-of-the-art scientific methods, taking into account the implications for other fish species and the ecology of the Baltic Seabed. If management or fishing shows significant implications for so-called flat fish, the Committee proposes to put them under the control of the Commission's plan as well. The first review of the plan should take place three years after entry into force, and if the plan carries positive effects, a second review would follow five years after the establishment. Given that the current provisions cover only one species of Baltic fish, that the Baltic Sea is a sensitive habitat and of great economic importance to member states and covers the possibility of expansion to other fish species, I support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ A multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea and on fisheries and exploitation of these fish stocks was published by the European Commission in October 2014. The aim of the project is to establish a framework for managing the stocks of cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea, where fishing is primarily concentrated on these three species. The management plan for the Baltic Sea has been in place since 2008, but is estimated to be not in proportion to the current situation of cod stocks. Herring and sprat stocks are not yet covered by the management plan. Cod, herring and sprats are important components of the Baltic ecosystem. Cod, herring and sprats are estimated to take up more than 94% of Baltic catches in recent years. It is important to bear in mind that the plan is only an introductory proposal in a highly sensitive Baltic Sea ecosystem. The first review of the plan should take place three years after its entry into force, and if it will have positive effects, it will be revised again after 5 years. This will also provide much-needed flexibility to the plan. I support parliament's position adopting the Report, as I consider Parliament competent enough to assess whether a report is sufficiently clear and well-worded.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting these stocks, amending Regulation No 2187/2005 and repealing Regulation No 1098/2007. I support the Commission's multiannual plan of 2014, which published a multiannual plan for cod and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. In doing so, it has established a framework for the management of several species for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, where fisheries are primarily targeted at these three species. The Baltic Sea is a near-closed body of water in which these three species are present everywhere and constantly co-influence each other.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of fish stocks and the adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets must take into account the specificities of the marine areas concerned and the States concerned.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report establishing a multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and their fisheries, as I consider the Commission's proposal, recognised by the reporter, to require a multi-species management plan for the Baltic Sea. This approach is more effective than single species farming and provides greater security for balanced and sustainable exploitation of fish stocks, stability of fishing opportunities, and thus for fishermen's livelihoods. I also agree with the view that the measures necessary to achieve maximum sustainable yield on the stocks concerned should be taken in accordance with the principle of regionalisation. This would ensure that a sudden change in the situation of stocks can be responded to in a timely manner. I also support the motions for the protection of cod stocks during spawning, the conservation of small-scale fishing and the early review of the new management plan.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union's multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks is the first plan under the new EU fisheries policy, which takes into account species interactions. Until now, in order to protect shoals from over-fishing, the Union managed individual species, which could lead to their extinction. This approach did not take into account that cod hunts herring and sprat, and the latter feed on cod. In practice, this means that the size of cod shoals affects the size of the shoals of herring and sprat, and vice versa. The basic principle of the new management plan taking into account interspecies dependencies is the establishment of ranges according to which the Council may set catch limits and fishing quotas. Management is to be based on the most up-to-date data provided by scientists on the state of fish stocks, interactions between species, as well as any other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries. The new law aims to ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of resources and to guarantee stable fishing opportunities and maintenance for fishermen. As a result, m.in situation of Polish fishermen can improve significantly. In addition, the plan will ensure that fishing activities in the Baltic sea are carried out in a sustainable, reasonable and above all economically viable manner, without straining the environment too much. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing in the Baltic Sea area provides an important contribution to carrying out this activity throughout the European Union. Within this nearly closed water mass, no less than 94% of catches concern cod, herring and sprat, only by accident flat fish and other species. In this context, the Commission considered, as early as 2008, that integrated catch management of the three main species was needed in order not to affect the sustainable development of the marine ecosystem concerned. Scientific studies in recent years have shown that fish stocks among the three species are interdependent, the code being predatory for the other two. In these circumstances, the Commission has proposed a common regulation for the management of the respective stocks in the Baltic Sea, which includes the maximum permitted stocks for each of the three species, but also for the domestic fish, such as turbot. The document also includes a multiannual approach, encourages small artisanal fishing enterprises and provides for regular reviews every five years for more flexibility. I believe that this is an important document for the Baltic sea ecosystem, in line with the new common fisheries policy, so I support its adoption.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I agree with the general idea contained in the Commission's proposal that a multi-species management plan in the Baltic Sea is necessary. The multi-species management approach is much more effective than a single-species approach. The plan is expected to allow for a balanced and sustainable use of these stocks as well as stable fishing opportunities and therefore resources for fishermen. At the same time, it should ensure management based on the latest scientific advice on the status of the stocks involved, the interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Cod, herring and sprat represent 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea and are important components of the very sensitive Baltic ecosystem. This is why I voted in favour of establishing a multiannual plan, whose aim is to establish a framework for the multispecies management of these stocks and the fisheries exploiting them, in order to reverse the effects of their overfishing in the EU. Based on sound scientific advice and an innovative long-term perspective, it strives to become a pioneer tool in fisheries management policies. The plan will thus provide for a balanced, sustainable exploitation of cod, herring and sprat stocks promote the stability of fishing opportunities and thereby guarantee the livelihoods of fishers. Beyond the content of this plan, I also welcome the increased participation of the European Parliament in European fisheries policies.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks, amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 2187/2005 and on the repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005. 1098/2007 The aim of this Regulation of the European Parliament is to lay down a fisheries plan for a large number of species taking into account the dynamics between cod stocks, herring and sprats and the in-fisheries stocks, i.e. leaf of goldpies, chipboard, sheaths and leaf smooth in the Baltic.  Although the Baltic Sea Cod Stock Management Plan has been in place since 2008, it is estimated that it is not in proportion to the current cod stock situation and that sprats and herring are not covered by the plan. There is therefore a need for a new approach covering several species and ensuring a balanced, sustainable use of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a regulation establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. Multiannual plans are a basic tool for the sustainable management or recovery of fish stocks. Such long-term approaches are not only aimed at improving the conservation of stocks, but also to increase predictability for fishermen in the long term. The multiannual management plan is an instrument to ensure the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks and marine ecosystems. The multi-annual plans aim at keeping the size of stocks within safe biological limits. They shall determine the maximum allowable catches and the type of technical measures, taking into account the characteristics of each stock and the effects of economic measures on the fisheries concerned.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention as we understand the implementation of multi-specific management as a step forward, much more effective than separate species management. We understand that management plans need to ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these wastes, based on scientific opinions, as well as it is essential that all these regulations meet the specificities of the territories and their peoples, which unfortunately are not always collected by EU policies, so we still do not share the criteria for the implementation of the CFP in the territories.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Stocks of cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea are now at risk due to overfishing. - Scientific advice has established that the current exploitation of stocks is incompatible with the goal of maximum sustainable yield.  - The Commission did not want to wait for further studies from the ICEM (International Council for the Exploration of the Sea) before implementing the multi-year plan. - The draft provides for many technical measures to be delegated to the Commission.  The draft, as amended by members of the Fisheries Committee, insists that the latest studies of the ICES be taken into account and that the relevant advisory councils be consulted. It is also expected that, when preparing delegated acts, the Commission will ensure that the relevant documents are forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council. So I voted FOR this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 In October 2014, the Commission proposed a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fishing activities exploiting those stocks. This plan is the first to be proposed, based on the principles of the reform of the 2013 common fisheries policy. A multiannual management plan must ensure the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks and marine ecosystems. In accordance with the principle laid down in Article 2 of the basic Regulation on the common fisheries policy, exploitation must enable the populations of species to be restored and maintained at levels higher than those which enable a maximum sustainable yield to be achieved. The multiannual management plans for these stocks – which are interdependent – aim to keep the size of stocks within biologically safe limits. These plans shall provide for a maximum catch and a number of technical measures, taking into account the characteristics of each stock and the economic impact of the measures on the fishing activities exploiting these stocks. I therefore voted in favour of the multiannual plan on stocks of cod, herring and sprat.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cod, herring and sprat are the main species that are fished in the Baltic Sea and account for nearly 94% of all catches. For this reason, it is essential to create a new fisheries management programme that is appropriate to today's problems. The current plan, dating back to 2008, is not adapted to the current situation and has not included herring and cod. A new and comprehensive management plan for the baltic sea fish stocks should be created, which will cover all species. This resolution is a response to today's challenges, which is why I supported it in the vote.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 A multiannual plan for stocks and fisheries of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea was published by the European Commission in October 2014. The aim of the proposal is to establish a multi-species management framework for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. Cod, herring and sprat accounted for more than 94% of the Baltic Sea catches in recent years. I supported the document that is now on the agenda.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention as we understand the implementation of multi-specific management as a step forward, much more effective than separate species management. We understand that management plans need to ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these wastes, based on scientific opinions, as well as it is essential that all these regulations meet the specificities of the territories and their peoples, which unfortunately are not always collected by EU policies, so we still do not share the criteria for the implementation of the CFP in the territories.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The objective of this plan should be to restore, achieve and maintain populations of the species concerned above the levels at which sustainable yield of the stocks concerned can be ensured, minimising the impact on other species.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks, amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005 and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1098/2007. The aim of the plan is to establish a framework for the multispecies management of the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea, where fishing primarily targets these three species. Cod, herring and sprat account for over 94 % of Baltic catches in the recent years. The Baltic Sea is a virtually closed body of water in which these three species are omnipresent and interact continuously. Therefore, it is of utmost importance to deliver regulation making it possible to recognize interactions between the species covered, inter alia the cod's influence on herring and sprat stocks and the other way round. I voted in favour because I believe that the plan provides for a balanced, sustainable exploitation of those stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities – and thereby of the livelihoods of fishers.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 Multiannual plans are an essential element for sustainable management and reconstitution of populations. We are talking about the first multiannual plan proposed on the basis of the principles of the reform of the 2013 common fisheries policy, which replaces the existing 2008 plan, which treated only cod and did not treat herring and the spurin of the Baltic Sea. This is a document which has been the subject of lengthy negotiations in order to give rise to a consensual and balanced text, so I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The "Multiannual Plan for Cod, Herring and Spurin Populations of the Baltic Sea and for the fish farms exploiting these stocks" is the first of the multiannual plans submitted following the 2013 CFP reform. These plans are intended to be the tools for the management and recovery of Community waste. Despite the need for plans to manage fisheries in our seas and oceans, I have not been able to vote in favour of it as the original proposal has been downgraded following the three-way negotiations between the Council and the Commission. I am particularly concerned about the true application of an ecosystem-based approach or the correction of overpesca. That's why I abstained.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 In October 2014, the European Commission published a multi-annual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. The proposal aims to establish a framework for multi-species management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, where fishing is mainly focused on these three species. Cod, herring and sprat have made up more than 94% of the catch in the Baltic Sea in recent years. I rightly voted in favour of this.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This report deals with the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for the fisheries fishing for them. Sustainable organic fisheries are of immense importance to the seas.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This initiative concerns fishing activity in the Baltic sea area, in particular cod, herring and papalina fishing. The plan submitted is groundbreaking for this area and the first review will take place over three years.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Wałęsa report on the multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea, as I believe it represents a crucial step towards the implementation of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy. This plan is the EU's first multiannual management plan in the framework of the reform of the common fisheries policy and will serve as a model for other sea basin plans. The aim is to establish a multi-species fishing plan aimed at reconstituting, reaching and maintaining the populations of cod, herring and sprat species in the Baltic Sea above levels that can generate maximum sustainable yield, in addition to minimising, as far as possible, the impact on other species, such as seabirds, and on the marine environment in general.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting these stocks, amending Regulation No 2187/2005 and repealing Regulation No 1098/2007. The proposal for a Regulation shall contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the Common Sustainable Fisheries Policy as set out in Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013, in particular by using a precautionary approach in fisheries management. It aims to ensure that, in the exploitation of living marine biological resources, populations of hunted species are restored and maintained above levels that allow maximum sustainable yield.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because, as we know, reality is running much faster than rules and the legal systems must adapt quickly to the challenges and, above all, to the new balances of society. Schengen, Erasmus and mobility between States have helped to create and spread more and more European couples – we can call them that – families living in one Member State, ing homes in another State, inheriting assets in another. It is a society which, fortunately, has had the courage to break down borders and which therefore needs new rules today. The European Union must support these European families, above all by facilitating dialogue between Member States and by clearly deciding on competences in the field of property regimes, in order to give certainty to couples, to clarify which court is competent.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the globalised and international character of modern society, family law must necessarily adapt to the new needs of citizens. To this end, following the approval of the enhanced cooperation procedure, the Commission has made a new proposal on property regimes between spouses. The aim is, in short, to regulate and clarify, in the case of cross-border decisions, which court has jurisdiction, what rule is applicable and, finally, how the award and enforcement of the judgment should take place. Legal certainty, especially in the management of family matters, is a fundamental right of citizens. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. Faced with the finding that there is a legal uncertainty regarding the property rights of international couples, the Commission has been working on a proposal for a European regulation to standardise the legal rules on matrimonial regimes. I voted against this proposed regulation, because the EU is not intended to legislate on family law. It remains the exclusive competence of Member States, which can, if they wish, enter into international conventions to establish rules for cooperation with other states. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws.

name: Martina ANDERSON
