text: in writing. ‒ As these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but simply set out opaque rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes, I voted in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens and the saving of legal costs

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Parliament adopted its position on these regulations during the last term of office. The Council took a long time to take a stand. We welcome the enhanced cooperation and hope that other Member States will decide to join this process. This regulation will make the lives of European international couples much easier and guarantee them better legal certainty.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of property relations of registered spouses. I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation because it is clearly in the interests of the Union and couples facing many delays, as it will in many cases be possible to avoid confusion and legal uncertainty.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. With increasing mobility in an area without internal borders, international couples are no longer uncommon. International couples are defined as those who are made up of citizens of 2 EU Member States and then remain in a country of which both do not have citizenship.  These international couples often face difficulties both in their daily lives and in the division of their common property as a result of a separation or death of a person. The new regulation aims to make this easier for married couples by determining the court responsible for them and the law applicable to their property rights.  I have also voted in favour of it because the new regulation will benefit many people living in border regions.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In 2010, the Commission identified uncertainty about the property rights of international couples as one of the main obstacles that EU citizens face in their daily lives. After the negotiations have stalled, with any agreement to be unanimous on family law, this proposal is up to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation involving only 17 Member States.  The regulation enshrines the principle of the unity of applicable law, the same law for all property held by the couple, wherever they are. The regulation also allows the choice of the law applicable on the condition that it maintains a certain closeness to the situation of the spouses.  The EU is not intended to legislate on family law. Member States are free to conclude international conventions to establish rules for cooperation with other states. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws.  I therefore voted against the draft resolution.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report deals with a regulation determining the jurisdiction and the law applicable to matrimonial claims. Apart from the fact that there is already the Convention of 14 March 1978 under the Hague Convention, there is no authorise on the EU to legislate on family law. Member States are free to conclude international conventions to establish rules for cooperation with other states. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws, which called for an unfavourable vote.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The aim here is to use enhanced cooperation between the Member States in favour of the matrimonial regimes of international couples. The proposal aims to establish a comprehensive body of rules of private international law applicable to the subject of matrimonial regimes. I approved of that point.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. When we talk about the importance of the Union and how the decisions we take in the European institutions directly affect the lives of citizens, we refer to measures such as those contained in the Commission proposal adopted in this Resolution. There are some 16 million "cross-border" couples in Europe who will benefit from future Property Rights Regulations. There is no doubt that these regulations are a step forward that will make the lives of many international couples easier. However, due to enhanced cooperation, there will be two Europes for these couples: one where their property rights are recognized and one not. I voted in favour of this resolution, as they are a step forward. But it's not enough. My commitment is to continue working for a Europe without barriers for couples and families, including all forms of family that exist in our society, and therefore without discrimination for LGTBI citizens. We must ensure free movement within the EU. In order to achieve this without discrimination, it is also essential that any marriage or registered union of same-sex couples be recognized in another Member State.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Cavada report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes between spouses. After the deadlock in the negotiations, the launch of enhanced cooperation led to a proposal much more in line with the indications expressed by Parliament in 2013. The text presents important innovations, clearly establishing which court has jurisdiction to rule on applications for property regimes between spouses.  A great step forward can then be found in the principle of the unity of applicable law, which provides that the law of property regimes between spouses applies to all assets held within the union, wherever they may be. In general terms, this new regulation is an effective response to overcome cases of confusion and legal difficulties, which is why I decided to support it with my vote.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I have chosen to oppose this report and the Council's proposed regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of matrimonial regime decisions. I find this intrusion into national family law unacceptable. On the other hand, while the situation of international couples and in particular with regard to their property rights must of course be considered, I would like to point out that there is already an international Convention on the subject, that of 14 March 1978, which all Member States are free to ratify. The regulation in question does not add anything to the existing framework, since it excludes from its domain questions concerning the capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, as well as the support obligations and estate of the deceased spouse.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it is a well-structured and acceptable report, there are still passages that could open up to future critical issues and exploitations that prevent me from fully supporting this text. I therefore abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Freedom of movement within the Union has led to a significant increase in international marriages or marriages which must resolve cross-border issues. However, these couples often face property-related problems, either within marriage or when it comes to distributing property in the event of divorce. This Regulation, developed through the enhanced cooperation procedure and applicable to eighteen Member States (Sweden, Belgium, Greece, Croatia, Slovenia, Spain, France, Portugal, Italy, Malta, Luxembourg, Germany, Czech Republic, Netherlands, Austria, Bulgaria, Finland and Cyprus) that have requested it, aims to provide clear instructions to help international couples choose the law applicable to them, the jurisdiction of the courts and the terms of recognition and the scope of decisions taken in other States Members.  This Regulation will improve the legal status of international couples or who must resolve cross-border issues by establishing a clear legal framework for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes within marriage, so I voted in favour of it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because this proposal is for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, law and enforcement of matrimonial property regimes. This regulation will be a very useful tool for international couples living in the European Union. It governs the jurisdiction, law and recognition and enforcement of judgments applicable in the area of matrimonial property regimes.  However, matters relating to the capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, maintenance obligations and the succession of the deceased spouse's property do not fall within the scope of the Regulation. The independence of the Member States in the area of family law is therefore preserved. Furthermore, the Regulation does not affect the substantive law of the Member States relating to matrimonial property regimes.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text is undoubtedly a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. There are fears of future interference in national family laws.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – As these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but simply set out opaque rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes, I voted in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens and the saving of legal costs.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation, presented within the framework of enhanced cooperation involving the vast majority of Member States, which aims to clarify and better regulate, within the countries concerned, the competences, the applicable law and the procedures for recognising and implementing decisions on property effects between spouses, represents an important step forward that will facilitate access to rights and make life easier for a large number of European citizens. The new proposal for a regulation would allow for greater flexibility (for example in the choice of applicable law or in facilitating the movement of official acts) which would meet the needs, in particular, of couples made up of citizens from different Member States, while clarifying certain legal situations that are currently unclear and thus providing greater legal certainty. This is in fact a further step towards the ever more effective movement of acts and decisions between Member States capable of strengthening the creation of a homogeneous, harmonised and functional legal area capable of responding to the challenge of increasing mobility and capable of promoting the development of effective European citizenship.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 This initiative concerns the jurisdiction and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial property regimes, determining which court has jurisdiction to rule on applications for matrimonial property regimes. This proposal comes against the background of increased mobility of people, which generates an increase in the number of couples made up of citizens of different Member States living in a Member State different from their home Member State. Following various studies, a number of difficulties encountered by these transnational couples, difficulties caused by certain incompatibilities between the applicable rules governing the property effects of marriage, both substantive and private international law. However, the approach to the proposal in question is not common at the level of all Member States, and the reason is that the provisions are insufficient to create a homogeneous framework that takes into account all the situations that may arise in this sector, which is why I chose to abstain on the final vote on this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The matrimonial regime is that system of legal rules governing the rights and property obligations of spouses, both in their relations and in their relations with third parties. This Regulation shall set out clearly the competent court to rule on applications for matrimonial property regimes. If a Member State does not approve that marriage, the courts of that State shall be given the opportunity to refer the case to the courts of another State of the Union which recognise the marriage in question. I support this report on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters of matrimonial property regimes, because I believe that the regulation meets the requirements of the European Parliament concerning both the movement and enforceability of authentic instruments and judicial transactions. The agreement is clearly for the benefit of the Union and is also an important step for international couples in the EU, providing them with new means of transmitting basic legal information.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and discussion in the Chamber, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes between spouses. Today that the Italian Supreme Court, in confirming the adoption of the same-sex couple, has stated that this "does not in the abstract determine a conflict of interests between biological parent and child adopting, but requires that any conflict be ascertained in concrete by the judge", has placed principles of living law that, as they apply to domestic law, pose questions, progressively more and more important , also within the law of international couples of the European Union. Consequently, I agree with the rapporteur and have voted in favour.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This file follows on from another file voted on at the last plenary on property regimes of international couples. It seeks to define the rules applicable for jurisdiction, applicable law and the enforcement of decisions for international matrimonial property regimes. The last vote was consent of the Parliament for 17 Member States to proceed through the enhanced cooperation system, i.e. not through the normal EU legislative process. The Parliament now has to give its consent to the framework content of proposals by the European Commission, after which, negotiations between these countries will begin outside of the normal EU legislative process. The resolution basically asks the Council to notify Parliament if negotiations depart from the framework presented today. As these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but merely set out clear rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes. I was happy to vote in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that proposes a detailed regulation touching on judicial and legal affairs on matrimonial property regimes for international couples. This regulation clarifies uncertainties and eliminates gaps among different national family law without depriving Member States of sovereignty. I am especially satisfied that the regulation sets a clear measure on determining which court has the jurisdiction tackling the lawsuits. I would like to call for a rapid implementation of this well-prepared regulation to provide a useful tool for many international couples in Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation, as it provides greater clarity and lays down specific rules for the identification of the competent court and applicable law in the case of cross-border decisions on property regimes between spouses.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the progress made by the Process of European Integration, millions of citizens linked by marriage or international registered partnership encounter practical problems in the management of their assets. In fact, it is often difficult for such couples to know which court has jurisdiction and what property regime is applicable to the situation of their assets, especially in the event of separation or succession. In the field of family law, legislative acts are adopted by the Council unanimously. However, in this particular case, in the absence of unanimous approval of the proposals, 18 Member States requested a strengthened cooperation procedure. I supported the vote in this House, which gave its agreement to the Council to authorise enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of international couples, so as to provide states party to European legislation with a clear and comprehensive legal framework relating to the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes, which will facilitate the resolution of problems in this area for many international couples.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that the proposal for a regulation on matrimonial property relations under consideration is clearly in the interests of the Union and the international couples subject to it.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of property relations of spouses concerns issues that thousands of European citizens face every day. I believe that the changes proposed are necessary in order to facilitate the daily lives of these citizens, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 International couples currently still have too few security on their property regimes. Too often, spouses find unclear legislative blocks that over-prolong waiting times, which can lead to a number of problems for couples. I believe it is necessary to ensure greater protection of the rights of those in this situation, and this proposal is precisely intended to put an end to the many cases of confusion and legal difficulties. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote, which covers jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. Its scope does not cover such matters as the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, maintenance obligations or succession to the estate of a deceased spouse in order to preserve the Member States’ autonomy in family law, nor does the regulation affect the Member States’ substantive law on matrimonial property systems.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2011, the Commission submitted a proposal on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on matrimonial property regimes. This measure is part of a set of instruments aimed at making life easier for transnational couples, which are increasingly frequent within the European Union.  However, it was not possible to reach a consensus in the Council, which was solely competent in these matters and bound by unanimity. Thus, a group of 18 Member States, including Portugal, wanted to move forward with the measures, helping to do so from the enhanced cooperation mechanism. It is this enhanced cooperation that is adopted today, the text of which welcomes significant proposals from the European Parliament, made during the first negotiating process between all Member States In the context of enhanced cooperation, the European Parliament must assess, among other criteria, respect for national competences, which is the case in this case. The powers of the Member States in the context of Family Law are fully respected, in particular with regard to the recognition of marriage.  I therefore support this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution approves the Commission's proposal on property regimes between spouses. In particular, jurisdiction and the court of jurisdiction, the applicable law and how to resolve legislative gaps, recognition and enforcement of decisions on schemes of property regimes between spouses are defined. By voting in favour of the resolution, I intend to support these measures, which limit situations of confusion and legal uncertainty. Greater clarity of the rules on property regimes between spouses is undoubtedly in the interests of European citizens and international couples.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The disappearance of European internal borders has led to increased mobility, both for tourism and professional purposes, with a significant impact on the number of couples made up of citizens of different nationalities. However, these transnational couples face a number of practical and legal difficulties, particularly in matters of matrimonial regimes and property effects in the event of the termination of couple life. I believe that the legal certainty of European citizens can be guaranteed by the adoption of common rules within the framework of material regimes, which contain concrete provisions on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments on the property regimes of international couples. I voted in favour of this report, wishing to reiterate the need for the rules for establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and for the investigation of related procedures in order to ensure legal certainty and predictability for citizens.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the Regulation is to establish a clear legal framework in the EU for determining jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial and property matters. Issues relating to the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, maintenance obligations and the succession of the estate of the deceased spouse are excluded from their scope. The main controversy with this package is the fact that the decision authorising enhanced cooperation obliges Member States to link up at the same time with two instruments - one on civil partnerships and the other on marriage. Still, a number of Member States do not know the institutions of the partnership (Italy, Bulgaria, Romania, Slovakia, Poland, Lithuania, Latvia) and, in order to be covered by the Regulation on matrimonial property regimes, they must accede to both regulations implementing enhanced cooperation and agree to recognise the effects of partnership institutions which they do not recognise under their internal law and which may be considered contrary to their public policy (e.g. the principle of protection of marriage and the family). Due to the controversy indicated, I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ With the free movement of people, we can see an increase in the number of couples that move from one member state to another. These couples are thus obliged to deal with cross-border issues. The aim of this regulation is to have a clear legal framework in matters of matrimonial property regimes. I voted in favour of this report as it takes into account the Member States’ autonomy in family law matters, however it will provide clear instructions to international couples and will help them  choose the law that is applicable to them. It will make it possible to put an end to many cases of confusion and legal uncertainty.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report focuses on the decision to establish enhanced cooperation between the voluntary Member States, i.e. 23 Member States.  The Commission's proposed regulation aims to simplify administrative procedures for matrimonial regimes between Member States and will give international couples legal certainty.  Considering that harmonization of the rules on matrimonial regimes is necessary to avoid disconcerting legal uncertainty for European international couples, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With the freedom of movement and establishment inherent in the European area, the number of couples of nationals from different Member States has increased. It is important that European legislation adapts to this trend, with all the legal consequences that this entails. In order to enable the many European nationals to have a clear legal framework for their matrimonial regime, I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In 2010, the Commission identified uncertainty about the property rights of international couples as one of the main obstacles that EU citizens face in their daily lives. It has therefore been working on a proposal for a European regulation to standardise the legal rules on matrimonial regimes.  After the negotiations have stalled, with any agreement to be unanimous on family law, this proposal is up to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation involving only 17 Member States. As a reminder, there is already the Convention of 14 March 1978 under the aegis of the Hague Conference, which commits only France, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, but which remains open to all other ratifications.  The EU is not intended to legislate on family law. Member States, on the other hand, are free to conclude international conventions. This text constitutes an unjustified interference in national legislation concerning the family. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to abstain on this dossier. This is a proposal for partnerships, but nevertheless it is part of a larger legislative package, which also includes a proposal on the concept of partnership. This concept is not known in many countries. The mandatory application of the package as a whole means that Member States Italy, Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Poland, Lithuania and Latvia will be subject to rules that do not exist at the heart of their national laws. Family and inheritance law is the competence of the Member States and the adoption of this package will undermine the national sovereignty of a number of EU Member States. In my opinion, this is not justified.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report attempts to establish a regulatory framework for the family law affairs of international couples. We are opposed to the involvement of EU legislation in the layout of family affairs, as each Member State adequately covers these issues with its own legislation. With regard to the specificities that arise in international couples, private international law provides the necessary security with regard to the effective regulation of these relationships.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The Union is an area of freedom, security and justice in compliance with the fundamental rights and different legal systems and traditions of the Member States. In this regard, this proposal pursues the principle of unity of legislation at Union level, where by which the law applicable to the matrimonial regime applies to all property under that scheme, wherever it is located. This is intended to materialize enhanced cooperation in the field of jurisdiction and economic regimes of international couples.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation will be a very useful tool for international couples in the European Union.  It covers, in matters of matrimonial property regimes, the jurisdiction and law applicable, as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions. However, it excludes from its domain, in particular, questions relating to the capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, the obligations of dietary and the succession of the deceased spouse. The autonomy of the Member States in the field of Family Law is therefore safeguarded.  I believe that this proposal for a regulation is clearly in the interests of the Union and its international couples. It will put an end to many cases of legal confusion and difficulty.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: this is unjustified interference in national family laws.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report approves the European Commission's proposal on jurisdiction, applicable legislation and recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes in marriage. The Regulation will be a useful tool for international couples in the EU. Today, as a result of a large mobility of people between EU Member States, couples face various bureaucratic difficulties when it is necessary to deal with issues relating to ownership or division of the same, when they divorce or when one of the members of the couple dies. There are problems when property is acquired in different Member States, for example.  This Regulation covers jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on matrimonial property regimes. However, its scope does not cover issues such as the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, the obligations of a deceased spouse or the succession of property of a deceased spouse. The Regulation also does not affect social security rights or pension rights in the event of divorce. The autonomy of the Member States in the field of Family Law is preserved. Nor does the Regulation affect the substandlaw of The Member States in matrimonial systems. We have supported the opening up of the cooperation process between States on this matter and we voted in favour of this report.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the framework of private law which it establishes will be very useful for the Member States and, among them, Spain, to ensure compliance with the principle of non-discrimination. I also consider it appropriate to unequal the rules achieved by this report.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal on the table includes many of the changes proposed by the European Parliament following the presentation of the original proposal from the European Commission back in 2011. The European Union also thinks about the property regimes of international couples who live in all its Member States. The regulation in question clearly and precisely states which court has jurisdiction to rule on applications in matters of matrimonial property regimes. If an application relating to matrimonial property regimes is linked to an inheritance following the death of one of the spouses or to an application for divorce, legal separation or marriage annulment, it is the court having jurisdiction to act on matters specific to these matters, which also has jurisdiction to decide on the matrimonial regime. For other cases, the Regulation lists the criteria that apply when deciding on jurisdiction, while in some cases the couples concerned have the option of choosing a different court. With this proposal, the European Union seeks a clear adjustment of the property regimes of international couples and to provide solutions for many complex legal cases in the future.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from this report.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report attempts to establish a regulatory framework for the family law affairs of international couples. I am opposed to the involvement of EU legislation in the layout of family affairs, as each Member State adequately covers these issues with its own legislation. With regard to the specificities that arise in international couples, private international law provides the necessary security with regard to the effective regulation of these relationships.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the regulation is to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. Due to the free movement of people in the EU there has been a significant increase in the numbers of international couples or couples that need to deal with cross-border issues. These couples are currently facing legal problems in dealing with property, both inside their marriage, and when dividing property in case of divorce. Matters already covered by existing EU regulations, such as maintenance obligations, especially between spouses, and matters arising from the law of succession, are excluded from the scope of the regulation. The regulation aims at providing clear instructions that will help international couples choose the law that is applicable to them, the jurisdiction of the courts and also in terms of the recognition and enforcement of decisions adopted in other Member States. The regulation does not affect the existence or validity of marriage under national law or the recognition in one Member State of a marriage concluded in another Member State. I supported the report in the vote in plenary.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have adopted the Report of the Committee on Legal Affairs on matri matri matri matrial property regimes. The report shall cover jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in an appropriate manner. However, its scope is not competent for the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity and recognition of the marriage, maintenance obligations and inheritance after the deceased spouse. The autonomy of the Member States in the field of family law is therefore guaranteed. The regulation can be a very useful tool for international couples living in the European Union.  In agreement with the rapporteur, the proposal for a regulation on matri matria matrial property regimes is clearly in the interests of the Union and of international couples living in the Union. It allows you to put an end to many confusing cases and legal difficulties. The current second proposal on this subject includes a significant part of the amendments previously proposed by Parliament.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes between spouses in transnational situations because I believe it is essential to complete the path begun during the last parliamentary term and blocked in the Council due to the reticence of some Member States.  The freedom of movement and movement of persons, and therefore of couples, implies the need for a clear and binding legal framework at European level on jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition of decisions, as is the case with divorce, filiation and maintenance obligations. Unfortunately, however, the reticence of some States still prevents general regulation and European recognition of marriages contracted in another Member State.  The choice of enhanced cooperation, with which I fully agree, was necessary in order to advance this important legislation in the interests of European citizens and, in particular, of couples who are increasingly composed of spouses of different nationalities. I therefore hope that the Council will act quickly and put an end to the many cases of confusion and legal difficulties.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the Cavada report "Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of matrimonial property law" – even though, as part of a consultation process, it only welcomes the COM 2016/0106 proposal. However, it is erroneous in paragraph II of the legal statement of reasons when it claims that the autonomy of the Member States is preserved in the area of family law. That is definitely not the case. I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as a vehement interference with the subsidiarity of the Member States, which I condemn in its form.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The report deals with jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters of matrimonial property regimes. However, the substantive law of the Member States with regard to matrimonial property regimes is not affected. Ensuring sovereignty for the Member States was crucial to my positive vote.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in international partner ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because the regulation will be a very useful tool for international couples in the EU. Member States' autonomy in matters of family law is thus protected in view of the fact that the Regulation excludes from its scope, in particular, matters relating to the capacity of the partners, the existence, validity or recognition of the partnership, the maintenance obligations and the succession of a deceased partner. Nor shall the Regulation affect the substance of the law of the Member States with regard to registered partnerships or their property effects. The property effects of registered partnerships proposed in the Regulation are clearly in the interests of the Union and international couples, helping to eliminate many cases of confusion and legal difficulties.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The proposal aims to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union, both harmonising and streamlining the determination of jurisdiction and the law applicable to matrimonial property and registered property regimes for cross-border cases and facilitating the movement of decisions and instruments among the Member States according to a single scheme.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report, which helps international couples within the European Union on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of property relations of spouses.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of the EU’s free movement of persons and the absence of internal borders there have been an increase in the number of couples formed by nationals of different Member States who live in a Member State other than their own or acquire property in more than one Member State. This Regulation facilitates this by establishing a comprehensive set of rules of international private law applicable to matrimonial property regimes. It therefore aims to enable citizens to have their various related procedures handled by the courts of the same Member State.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, as I had no objections to it.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. I have followed the recommendation of my group colleagues and abstained from voting on the Cavada report 'Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of matrimonial property law'.  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together.  However, I cannot support uniform European regulation. On the contrary, I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as an interference with the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report with direct and positive effects on international couples and on the European Union on matrimonial regimes. By applying this regulation on jurisdiction, the applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters of matrimonial property regimes, confusion swaying and legal difficulties will be eliminated.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. I voted for the Proposal for a Council Regulation on Jurisdiction and Applicable Law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes, as I consider this proposal for a regulation on matrimonial property regimes to be in the interest of the Union and its international couples. It will remove many legal dilemmas and uncertainties.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. In 2010, the Commission identified uncertainty about the property rights of international couples as one of the main obstacles that EU citizens face in their daily lives. It has therefore been working on a proposal for a European regulation to standardise the legal rules on matrimonial regimes.  After the negotiations have stalled, with any agreement to be unanimous on family law, this proposal is up to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation involving only 17 Member States.  The EU is not intended to legislate on family law. Member States are free to conclude international conventions to establish rules for cooperation with other states. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family legislation, and I have obviously opposed it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the property conditions of international couples, which concerns some 16 million such couples in the EU. This report dealt with the case of international marriages or registered partnerships and property settlements in the event of divorce, legal separation or death. The new legal framework provides for couples from 18 EU countries to choose which jurisdiction to deal with in their case in order to avoid parallel proceedings in two states and possible conflicting court decisions. This will give international couples legal certainty, harmonisation of rules and better access to fair trial. The same rights will be ensured for both married couples and registered partners.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation, which aims to establish a full body of rules of private international law applicable to matrimonial regimes. There is an urgent need to address the practical and legal difficulties faced by transnational couples in the Union both in the day-to-day management of their property and in the time of their division in the event of separation or death.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ It is a matter that needs to be addressed and the report is addressing it in an appropriate way setting up the next future steps. This proposal for a regulation on matrimonial property regimes is clearly in the interest of the EU and of its international couples. It will make it possible to put an end to many cases of confusion and legal uncertainty. The current proposal, the second on this topic, has incorporated a large proportion of the amendments proposed earlier by Parliament. Your rapporteur therefore proposes that Parliament issue a favourable opinion on this proposal, without any substantive amendments at this stage.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. The Regulation will resolve the issues of matrimonial property regimes with regard to jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments. The scope of application excludes questions about the legal capacity, business and legal capacity of the spouse, the existence, validity and recognition of the partnership, maintenance obligations and legal consequences. The resolution of these issues on the status of goods is clearly in the interests of the Member States concerned.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the Cavada report 'Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of matrimonial property law'.  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together.  However, I cannot support uniform European regulation. On the contrary, I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as an interference with the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on matters relating to matrimonial property regimes. Free movement contributes, in addition to a free and facilitated exchange of goods and services, and to creating preconditions for the emergence of international partnerships. The need to adopt the report concerns 16 million euro. european couples who coexist in a cross-border situation or have a cross-border dispute. It is estimated that the annual costs of parallel legal proceedings amount to EUR 1.1 billion. amount, which will undoubtedly be reduced with the entry into force of the new Regulation.  The designation of a competent court in matters such as the existence, validity or recognition of marriage, maintenance and succession obligations of a deceased spouse, as well as cross-border inheritance, is an important progress that will have a direct positive effect in many households. They will enjoy better access to justice and harmonised rules that will be tailored to each case and country. The new rules will apply in 18 EU countries that have agreed to join this "enhanced cooperation" initiative, including Bulgaria.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes between spouses. This regulation does not interfere with the laws of the Member States on registered partnerships, but lays down which court has jurisdiction in registered partnerships. This will be a useful tool for international couples, as it will give the couple the opportunity to choose which law, and which state, to refer to. Finally, the regulation lays down the necessary tools to give international couples access to the necessary legal information. Our society is becoming increasingly multicultural, with extraterrestrial marriage unions, and that is why we must protect their rights in the best possible way.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the European Union does not have to interfere with family law, which is the responsibility of the States.  In addition, there is already a 1978 Hague Convention on the issue, which does the trick. It would have been better to encourage states to ratify it.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. The European Union, by creating a space without internal borders and facilitating mobility within it, has contributed to a significant increase in the number of transnational couples. These couples are now facing practical and legal difficulties, due to differences in procedures and a lack of coordination between the courts of the Member States. That is why I voted in favour of the Cavada report on enhanced cooperation between 18 Member States on matrimonial regimes (as well as its double in the heritage effects of registered partnerships), on which Parliament had been referred for advice.  With this vote, I would like to support a text which aims to simplify the lives of citizens and transnational couples by supporting the creation of a clear legal framework to determine the competence and the applicable law in these situations.  Finally, I would like to point out that this text applies only in transnational situations. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, it will have no impact on the recognition in one Member State of the validity of a registered marriage or partnership in another Member State, nor on the law of the national family.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of matrimonial regime decisions. The European Union is not intended to legislate on family law. Member States are free to conclude international conventions to establish rules for cooperation with other states. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report focuses on the creation of a specific jurisdiction for international matrimonial couples. According to the Commission, uncertainty about the property rights of these couples is a major obstacle to their daily lives. This is why, since 2010, it has tended to standardize the legal rules in this area.  The text proposes new regulations, which require couples to follow the local law on property held. It does not address certain aspects such as the validity and recognition of marriage, the estate of the deceased spouse... 17 Member States join it, in the form of enhanced cooperation. Family law is a sovereign right that is inalienable to every state. The Commission therefore has no power to legislate in this area. Moreover, it remains possible for countries to resolve these legal aspects through international agreements, without necessarily going through the EU.  I vote strongly against this text.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this regulation because its objective is to establish a clear legal framework in the EU to determine jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes within marriage. Freedom of movement within the EU has led to a significant increase in international partners or couples who must resolve cross-border issues. The regulation is intended to provide clear instructions to help international couples choose the applicable law, the jurisdiction of the courts and the terms of recognition and scope of decisions taken in other Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This proposal for a Regulation aims to facilitate the management of the economic aspects of international couples within the European Union by introducing improvements to the Commission's initial proposal for 2011 and 2013. The Regulation seeks to preserve the autonomy of Member States in the field of family law by excluding certain matters from its scope. It also lays down which body has jurisdiction to rule on applications and declares that in the event that a Member State does not recognise the marriage in question, the courts of that State may entrust the matter to those of another Member State which does recognise it. I believe that this proposal for a Regulation is clearly in the interests of the Union and its international partners, since it will put an end to many cases of confusion and legal difficulties, and make the lives of citizens easier. I therefore agree that Parliament should give a favourable opinion on the proposal.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the Cavada report 'Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of matrimonial property law'.  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together. However, I cannot support uniform European regulation, as in some cases it would disregard national values.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that provides greater clarity to which courts have jurisdiction to rule on proceedings on matrimonial property regimes.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I am in support if states want to voluntarily agree with each other on the recognition of decisions in matters of matrimation. In my opinion, this is a classic example for using intergovernmental cooperation without the need for the involvement of the European Parliament and the EU.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 At the end of last year, the Council meeting failed to achieve the desire of all Member States to establish maximum integrated cooperation on the issues covered, with the result that 17 Member States chose to develop closer cooperation between them. The scope of the future Regulation will govern the matrimonial property regime, jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions. At the same time, issues such as the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence of marriage, legal force and recognition, maintenance obligations and the succession of the deceased spouse will be excluded in order to guarantee the autonomy of the Member States in these areas. Although various issues are not covered by the Regulation, its adoption and subsequent entry into force will establish a format for rather productive cooperation, to which other Member States could gradually join. Given the importance of the issues raised, this would be quite desirable and welcome.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation addresses the jurisdiction of courts to decide on property matters of international married couples. It regulates the applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions. This regulation will affect those Member States which, in accordance with the relevant definition of the Council Regulation implementing enhanced cooperation in the field of the law applicable to divorce and legal separation, participate in enhanced cooperation in the field of applicable law (Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Spain, France, Italy, Latvia, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, Austria, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Lithuania and Greece). As the proposal for a regulation removes legal fragmentation and strengthens the legal certainty of international married couples in the countries concerned, I supported the proposal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of property relations of spouses, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 22/6/2016 and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report and therefore against the draft resolution.  The Commission wants to change the property rights of international couples and standardise legal matrimonial standards. In family law, the rule is that of unanimity, so for the moment there are only enhanced agreements or cooperations.  In this case, the text determines rules of procedure, such as the competent jurisdiction or the applicable law, and broad principles such as the unity of applicable law. However, the European Union is not intended to govern family law.  We are opposed to it ousting the Member States, which are intended to conclude international conventions in this area.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes between spouses. Having approved the enhanced cooperation procedure for the regulation of international couples, it was necessary to regulate certain important procedural aspects, such as , competence, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property effects between spouses. This regulation is a good instrument for all international unions, thereby protecting autonomy in the field of family law.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the proposal on the regulation of matrimonial economic regimes. The new Regulation will be very beneficial for international couples, as it will put an end to numerous cases of confusion and legal difficulties.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation on international couples relates to jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the assets of registered couples. Thus, although family law issues are primarily regulated at national level, the above-mentioned issues are regulated by this regulation. With regard to jurisdiction, the Regulation regulates the court competent to deal with disputes concerning the property of the spouses. In relation to the applicable law, this Regulation brings unity, since the competent court will have jurisdiction over all assets regardless of the location of the property and thus there will be no longer a separation of the applicable law for each element individually. Finally, as to the recognition, enforceability and enforcement of judgments, a decision is enforceable only after the Member State concerned has declared its enforceability, but it is obliged to do so unless there is a good reason for public policy. I would like to vote in favour of this resolution, considering it to be a way to facilitate international couples through the simplification and consolidation of the legislation concerning them.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The rapporteur's legislative resolution endorses the Commission's proposal. The Regulation will resolve the issues of matrimonial property regimes with regard to jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments. I have therefore taken a positive view of this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The problem with the text is the uncertainty of the property rights of international couples. According to the 2010 EU Citizenship Report, this is one of the main obstacles facing EU citizens.  The regulation also allows the choice of the law applicable on the condition that it maintains a certain closeness to the situation of the spouses. The regulation excludes from its domain, however, matters concerning the capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, the support obligations and the estate of the deceased spouse.  More than anything, I believe that the EU does not have to legislate on family law; Member States are free to agree on conventions, at their convenience. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is intended to create in the European Union a clear regulatory framework for the determination of the competent court and the law applicable to matrimonial property regimes and to facilitate the movement of decisions and acts in this area between the different Member States.  The aim of this proposal is to establish a complete set of rules of private international law applicable to matrimonial property regimes. It therefore covers jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial property regimes. The rules laid down apply exclusively to situations of a transnational nature. The cross-border impact requirement of Article 81(3) is thus fulfilled.  This proposal concerns only the property effects of marriage and does not define the marriage institute or impose recognition of a marriage in another Member State.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, as it clearly defines which courts have jurisdiction to rule on matrimonial property regimes, and furthers cooperation, uniform efficiency, and clarity of law between member states. International couples will benefit from having clearly defined applicable laws and jurisdiction pertaining to matters of property regimes.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I supported this regulation on matrimonial regimes which establishes enhanced cooperation, because it was time to have a clear legal framework for transnational situations within the European Union, covering the determination of the competent jurisdiction, the applicable law, the recognition and enforcement of decisions made in this area.  In a globalised world, the mobility of people within an area without internal borders continues to increase, leading to a significant increase in unions between nationals of different Member States and, more often than not, the acquisition of property located on the territory of several EU countries. This legislation is, as the rapporteur rightly says, in the interests of transnational couples.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – This proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes is a second proposal in this area. As any agreement relating to the area of family law must be unanimous, the proposal in question is in the form of enhanced cooperation. The Slovak Republic is not one of the states that recognises this enhanced cooperation. The definitional features of marriage vary considerably from one Member State to another. This Regulation could provide for a broad interpretation of the concept of marriage, which the Slovak courts should take into account, and I consider this to be a mixture in the internal affairs of the state. Issues relating to the area of family law should remain solely within the competence of the Slovak Republic and should be covered by Slovak law. In view of the above, I do not support the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation aimed at establishing a clear legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. This will help international couples choose the law that is applicable to them, the jurisdiction of the courts and also in terms of the recognition and enforcement of decisions adopted in other Member States.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council Decision on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters relating to matri matriity property regimes has not been adopted, in the absence of any consensus necessary for any agreement in the field of family law. However, since 23 Member States agreed in principle to the proposal, the Council adopted a decision authorising enhanced cooperation, with which Parliament agreed at its meeting on 7 June 2016. The Commission has now proposed to the Council the adoption of a regulation regulating this, which should consult Parliament to do so.  In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs notes that the proposal for a regulation on matri matrial property regimes clearly serves the interests of the Union and international couples living in the Union. It will allow them to put an end to many confusing cases and legal difficulties. It includes a significant part of the amendments previously proposed by Parliament. It therefore proposes that Parliament give a favourable opinion on the proposal. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The regulation determines the jurisdiction and the law applicable to applications for matrimonial regimes of international couples. The EU is not intended to legislate on family law. Member States are free to conclude international conventions to establish rules for cooperation with other states. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation covers, in the field of matrimonial property regimes, the jurisdiction and law applicable, as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions. However, questions relating to the capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, the obligations of the deceased spouse are excluded from their domain. It is important to highlight that the autonomy of the Member States in the field of Family Law is safeguarded. The Regulation also clearly determines which court has jurisdiction to rule on applications for matrimonial property regimes.  I believe that this proposal is in the interests of the European Union, since it guarantees legal clarity, certainty and confidence, especially for so-called international couples.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The EU is not intended to legislate on family law. Member States are free to conclude international conventions to establish rules for cooperation with other states. This is an unjustified interference in national family laws. So I'm voting against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the recognition and enforcement of matrimonial regime decisions. This report, whose recommendations apply to transnational situations, is essential in order to put in place a clear legal framework to avoid conflicts of laws and better dissemination of decisions and actions relating to these issues in the Member States.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the free movement of people in the EU there has been a significant increase in the numbers of families that need to deal with cross-border issues. These families are currently facing legal problems in dealing with property, both inside their marriage, and when dividing property in case of divorce. I have voted for this report that aims to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it aims to simplify the legal rules on matrimonial property in the Member States of the European Union with regard to international couples. In this respect, the report voted on today introduces a new regulation with clear provisions regarding the assignment of property rights in the event of divorce or death of one of the partners in the matrimonial institution. The regulation voted on today also introduces a right with universal application, which provides flexibility for the application of the law of the third state. This regulation therefore puts an end to the fractionation of the law applicable to the marriage regime of the EU couple, a subject of major importance for many Romanians in such situations. Through this initiative, the Council and the European Parliament contribute to clarifying the jurisdiction between national and European courts to rule in cases relating to property rights in matrimonial property regimes in the EU.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a regulation relating to matrimable property conditions. The main benefit of this proposal is the clarification of the status of international married couples. As this type of union is becoming increasingly common due to the free movement of persons, it is important that it is properly legally treated on all issues, including property issues. An important reason for supporting this proposal is also its compromise form, which does not interfere with the autonomy of the Member States on family law and thus prevents this proposal from being rejected by the Member States, as has already happened once before.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – As these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but simply set out opaque rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes, I voted in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens and the saving of legal costs.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This Regulation resolves the question of matrimonial property regimes, in relation to the jurisdiction of the applicable law, and the recognition and enforcement of judgments. The Regulation does not concern questions of the spouse's legal capacity, ability to act, the existence, validity and recognition of the partnership, dependants and successors in title. The resolution of these issues on the status of goods is clearly in the interests of the Member States concerned.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  It should be noted that the unification of jurisdiction in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes will enable international couples to deal with property issues without splitting it, and by applying a common law to all assets, regardless of the location of the property. This will ensure a fair settlement of disputes, since it is clearly established which court has jurisdiction to rule on applications for matrimonial property regimes. In addition, this Regulation allows the spouses themselves to choose the applicable law subject to certain restrictions.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of property relations of spouses is brought back by the Council before Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation, since any decision concerning family law should be unanimous. I supported this proposal because the existence of a common legislative framework between Member States facilitates and accelerates the resolution of property disputes. It also ensures the application of a judicial framework for the adoption of a judgment which will be recognised and enforcement in the Member States.  Decisions of one Member State relating to property matters will be recognised and enforced directly in another Member State.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the procedure followed so far for the proposal for a regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes between spouses; Whereas the proposal extends to decisions concerning the capital effects of registered partnerships; whereas the Regulation is a useful instrument for property regimes between spouses and does not affect the competences of the Member States in this area; Finally, given that the proposal contains all the indications previously provided by the European Parliament and is aimed at protecting international couples, I support my colleague's proposal and, therefore, I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The Union is to constitute an area of freedom and justice with respect for fundamental rights and the different legal systems and traditions of the Member States. The increased mobility of persons leads to a marked increase in the number of couples made up of nationals of different Member States who may live in a Member State of which they do not have the nationality and often acquire property in more than one Union country. The divorce is a difficult time for anyone, who have to go through it, and European citizens should not be burdened even more by complicated administrative or legal procedures that cost time and money. Therefore, I support the report and vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Although the Council regulation on jurisdiction and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes would greatly facilitate legal proceedings for international spouses who find themselves in a situation of separation or death of one of the spouses, I did not support the proposal for a regulation, as the regulation is not sufficiently precisely defined legally and legal ambiguity and emptiness leads to unintended consequences of attaching equal rights to matrimonial and other living communities and puts undue pressure on the family law of the Member States.  If a unified European legislative act is to be adopted, it must first and foremost clearly define what is considered marriage, that is, that marriage is the union of one man and one woman, which in this case is not specified in the regulation. As nine Member States of the European Union equate same-sex unions with marriage, the adoption of this regulation would equate marriage and other life communities in a completely inappropriate way across the EU. This would also undermine the national family policy of Member States which have a precisely defined institution of marriage and clearly distinguish, or do not regulate at all, other life communities. Each Member State must retain the freedom of legal protection of the institution of marriage, and the distinction between matrimonial and other living communities must be indicated very precisely.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 From today, the life of international couples in Europe will be easier. The adoption of this regulation will, in fact, guarantee legal certainty with regard to property regimes between spouses, in particular as regards the competence, recognition and enforcement of decisions. Parliament had already adopted these regulations during the last parliamentary term. Finally, the Council has also taken a position and many Member States are showing the right level of cooperation. I hope that other states will soon join the enhanced cooperation procedure. The autonomy of the Member States in matters of family law is completely safeguarded. The regulation is concerned exclusively with providing certainty for procedural matters: applicable law, competent court, recognition and enforcement of judgments. An important step forward is the affirmation of the principle of the unity of applicable law, according to which the law of property regimes applies to all assets held within the union, thus putting an end to the division of the system of the couple's assets. The regulation, putting an end to many cases of confusion and legal uncertainty, is clearly in the interests of international couples and the proper functioning of the European Union. For this reason, I am voting in favour.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to matrimonial property regimes is the second in a row in this regard. Following the blocking of negotiations between Member States, and as any agreement must be unanimous in family-legal matters, this proposal shall be returned to Parliament in the context of enhanced cooperation. The Regulation will be a very useful instrument for international couples within the European Union. In the area of the matrimonial property regime, it covers jurisdiction and applicable law as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions. However, issues of the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, maintenance obligations and the succession of the deceased spouse are excluded from its scope. Member States' autonomy in family-legal matters has therefore been preserved. The Regulation also does not affect member states' substantive law on matrimonial property regimes. In other words, parliament's demands have been met. In conclusion, I agree with the rapporteur, Mr Jean-Marie Cavad, that this proposal for a regulation on matrimonial property regimes is undoubtedly in the interests of the Union and its international couples. It will remove many legal dilemmas and uncertainties.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to establish a clear legal framework in the EU for determining jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial and property matters. Issues relating to the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, maintenance obligations and the succession of the estate of the deceased spouse are excluded from their scope. Within the framework of the Regulation, mutual recognition of administrative documents must not be contrary to the principle of subsidiarity– this Regulation must not impose on Member States the harmonisation of their national family law, including matrimonial property regimes. This solution raises concerns in the context of Article 4(2) of the TOU guaranteeing member states respect for their national identity, in this particular case as regards the definition of family law institutions whose effects Member States wish to recognise under their legal order. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 The present proposal affects 16 million couples with an international element. I support the proposal because it is not a transfer of powers, but de facto procedural and conflict-of-law rules that will clarify the position of these married couples. Moreover, I personally believe that a common arrangement could also be made here. However, the enhanced cooperation presented here by only some Member States will also bring about an improvement in the legal situation.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing.
