I voted in favour of these new provisions, which will apply to the 18 European states that have been part of a process of enhanced cooperation in the area of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the matrimonial regimes of international couples, i.e. of two different nationalities.  Although marriage and partnership continue to be defined by national laws, these new EU rules will increase the security of international couples.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The increased mobility of people within a European area without internal borders leads to a significant increase in the number of couples of nationals of different Member States living in a Member State other than their own or acquiring property located on the territory of several Member States.  If we, as Europeans, can welcome this as the manifestation of an increased mixing of the European peoples, this raises several legal and practical questions - because of the great disparity between the rules applicable to the heritage effects of marriage - to which this report intends to respond. In particular, it aims to establish a clear legal framework, where couples will be able to choose the jurisdiction and the applicable law for their possessions and properties, thus avoiding subsequent conflicts of jurisdiction. Undoubtedly, this legislation will allow for better clarification, stability and predictability of the legal framework for international couples. In line with these political lines, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Freedom of movement within the EU has led to a significant increase in international marriages or marriages that must resolve cross-border issues. However, these couples often face property-related problems, either within marriage or when it comes to distributing property in the event of divorce. This regulation, drawn up through the enhanced cooperation procedure and applicable to 18 Member States (Sweden, Belgium, Greece, Croatia, Slovenia, Spain, France, Portugal, Italy, Malta, Luxembourg, Germany, Czech Republic Netherlands, Austria, Bulgaria, Finland and Cyprus) who have requested it, aims to provide clear instructions to help international couples choose the applicable law, the jurisdiction of the courts and the terms of recognition and scope of decisions taken in other Member States.  This regulation will improve the legal status of international couples or who must resolve cross-border issues by establishing a clear legal framework for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions on property regimes within marriage, so I voted in favour of it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report, which will put an end to parallel proceedings costing almost EUR 1.1 billion a year in various Member States whose courts have to settle property disputes. They will apply to the 18 countries that wished to join this enhanced cooperation (i.e.: Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Spain, France, Croatia, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Portugal, Slovenia, Finland and Sweden). The two regulations passed, one on matrimonial regimes and the other on the heritage effects of registered couples, will determine which court will have jurisdiction and which law will be applicable in the case of proceedings concerning the ownership of international couples. They will also simplify the recognition and strengthening of a Member State's ruling on ownership in another Member State.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Families, or in broader terms – couples who originate or live in different countries – are becoming more and more a global phenomenon of everyday life. It is therefore necessary to ensure the specific, clear and transparent regulation of civil relations between such couples, the protection of property interests, as well as standards for the protection of children's rights. I welcome this initiative, I invite colleagues to vote in favour and the Commission and the Member States to continue their dialogue with stakeholders on improving regulation in this area.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on matrimonial property regimes was blocked for lack of unanimity in negotiations between Member States and was sent to Parliament after a procedure for enhanced cooperation. In the case of a special legislative procedure under Article 81. TFEU(3), the European Parliament was consulted to give its opinion. The Regulation deals with matters relating to Family Law, with cross-border implications, establishing a set of measures of significant importance for international couples in the European Union with regard to jurisdiction, scope, recognition and enforcement of decisions. The autonomy of the Member States shall be safeguarded, taking into account Parliament's request to maintain jurisdiction over matrimonial property regimes, the capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, as well as the maintenance obligations and succession of the deceased spouse.  As a regulation of the main interest for the EU and international couples, in that it eliminates ambiguities and facilitates the simplification and interpretation of cross-border matrimonial property regime, and because all the proposals put forward by Parliament have been met, I voted in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments on matrimonial property matters', as it is important to define and clarify this legality now at EU level. More and more citizens have residence in more than one EU Member State, which can lead to problems with the case law.  The proposed regulation is intended to clarify at last which country and court have jurisdiction over the issues of matrimonial property regimes and what powers they have in this regard. Many jurisdictions, such as the legal powers of a spouse or the rules after the death of one of the spouses, are still left to the national courts and authorities.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Just as I supported the report on the property consequences of registered partnerships, I also voted in favour of this report, because I consider property relations and the upbringing of children to be the two most fundamental issues of marital relationship. I also consider it extremely important because the phenomenon of eu international couples is becoming more pronounced and there is an increasing increase in the number of marriages between citizens of different Member States in the mobility of persons within a borderless area. Although certain measures have already been taken in the area of property regimes for marriages thus contracted, I believe that it is essential to adopt further adaptations to the legislation of substantive law as well as to private international law governing the area of the property consequences of marriages. Given the nature and scale of the problems faced by EU citizens, which I, as an MEP, also face, there needs to be more pressure on the part of the Union to apply the existing international conventions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. As the differences between Member States are still huge, I expect the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, to continue to work towards a clear legal framework, which will include the determination of the relevant barrel and the applicable law in matters of matrimonial property regimes.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of matrimation decisions. Although the increasing number of marriages with an international element has become an unquestionable everyday reality of the Union, international married couples are still faced with practical problems when settling their property, such as what law a particular property situation will be governed by or which court will have jurisdiction to settle their property. The result is legal uncertainty, delays in the case and the associated disproportionate costs. Enhanced cooperation will create a clear legal framework for the settlement of the assets of thousands of international marriages in the participating Member States. The property conditions of international marriages will thus be dealt with in a coherent manner, within one applicable law and by one judicial authority. In particular, I appreciate the flexible arrangements for the jurisdiction of the court for the settlement of assets and the principle of uniformity of the applicable law, where the applicable law applies to the property as a whole. This avoids fragmentation of the rules, where different parts of the spouses' property would be the case under different legal systems. I am also pleased that, although the proposal for a regulation brings progressive practical elements, it preserves member states' autonomy in the area of family law. Thus, the Regulation will not intervene in any way and will not change the Czech substantive legislation of the Institute of Marriage and its legal consequences.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the matrimonial property regime is already second in this area. The report says that the proposal for a regulation on matrimonial property regimes is in the obvious interest of the Union and the international couples within it. The regulation will eliminate a number of cases of ambiguity and legal uncertainty. In the areas of recognition, enforceability and enforcement of matrimonial property regime decisions, the current text is largely based on the 2013 position of the European Parliament. It thus reproduces the very precise provisions of Regulation No 650/2012 on cross-border succession. Even if recognition is automatic, the decision is therefore enforceable only after obtaining a declaration of enforceability in the Member State concerned. However, a declaration of enforceability may be refused only in very specific cases, for example where enforcement is contrary to public policy. In view of the above, I consider that the report on jurisdiction, the applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the area of matrimonial property regimes is welcome, which is why I supported it.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. I have followed the recommendation of my group colleagues and abstained from voting on the Cavada report 'Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of matrimonial property law'.  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together.  However, I cannot support uniform European regulation. On the contrary, I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as an interference with the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Slovakia is not a member of enhanced cooperation and therefore it is not possible to refer to the cooperation.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The Recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs simplifies the court's previously unclear and sketchy jurisdictions in terms of matrimonial property for married couples coming from different Member States. On the occasion of this recommendation, the legal entity is entitled to choose the state of which the citizen, i.e. whose spouse is a citizen, and to resolve the issues of the acquis according to the laws of the selected country. The recommendation states that any judicial decisions concerning the acquis are binding, except in "very specific circumstances". The recommendation calls for the establishment of an effective way of communicating these rights to all married couples who are not citizens of the same State.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for the Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial ownership regimes is the second on this topic. The proposal for Regulation 2016 differs from the Commission's initial proposal in 2011. On the contrary, it contains many of the amendments proposed by Parliament in 2013. The Regulation does not cover matters such as the legal capacity of the spouse, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, the obligation of maintenance. Member States' autonomy in family law matters has thus been preserved.  I support the proposal for this Regulation as I think it will be a very useful instrument for the rights of international couples in the Union. The Regulation will allow to put an end to a number of legal uncertainty cases so far in this area.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the area of matrimonial property regimes. In the area of matrimonial property regimes, the regulation covers the powers and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of judgments, and excludes in particular issues of the legal and commercial capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity and recognition of the marriage, the maintenance obligation and the succession of the deceased spouse. Member States will thus continue to have the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report attempts to establish a regulatory framework for the family law affairs of international couples. We are opposed to the involvement of EU legislation in the layout of family affairs, as each Member State adequately covers these issues with its own legislation. With regard to the specificities that arise in international couples, private international law provides the necessary security with regard to the effective regulation of these relationships.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report, which endorsed the Commission's proposal on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters relating to matri matriity property regimes, as it is clearly in the interests of the Union and international couples living in the Union. I agree with the objective of the proposal, which aims to reduce the practical and legal difficulties faced by international spouses living within the Union in the day-to-day management of their assets, or even in the separation or division resulting from the death of one of the parties. These difficulties are often caused by the fact that the provisions governing the property effects of marriages vary considerably in both the legal provisions of the Member States and private international law. Although all Member States have not joined the initiative, 17 EU Member States have decided to provide greater predictability and legal certainty for international couples living in the EU through a strengthened cooperation procedure, while at the same time complying with the principle of proportionality.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal and against the amendment adopted in committee, because I believe it is superfluous. The Commission's proposal identifies Member States which are involved in intensified cooperation and explicitly emphasise that the regulations apply only to those Member States.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The overall aim of this regulation is clear legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. This is a necessary procedure in light of the fact that the free movement of people has led to a significant increase in the numbers of international couples. These couples have to deal with a number of cross-border issues, and are facing legal problems in dealing with property and when dividing it in case of divorce. Therefore, the present regulation will provide clear instructions which will help international couples by allowing them to choose the law that is applicable to them, the jurisdiction of the courts and also as regards the recognition and enforcement of decisions adopted in other Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This proposed Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of matrimonial regime decisions is the second. After the deadlock in negotiations between Member States - any agreement that must be unanimous on family law - this proposal is the responsibility of Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation. With regard to the procedural aspects of enhanced cooperation, the reader is invited to consult the specific recommendation on the subject. This proposal also has a double, which concerns the jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage effects of registered partnerships. This proposal for a regulation on matrimonial regimes is clearly in the interests of the Union and its international couples. The proposed regulation will put an end to many cases of confusion and legal difficulty. The current proposal, which is the second in this regard, has incorporated many of the amendments previously proposed by Parliament.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the increased mobility, cooperation and exchange inside the EU, the EU now counts 16 million international couples, most commonly bound by the ties of marriage. This is why I voted in favour of a new legal framework that will clarify and simplify property rules in cases of divorce, legal separation or death for international married couples, by determining the jurisdiction and the law applicable to their property regimes. This is an indispensable measure to put an end to the practical and legal difficulties and costs these couples have to face, in line with the principle that every European citizen has the right to equal treatment in front of our national institutions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Due to the increasing mobility of people in an area without internal borders, there has been a significant increase in the number of couples consisting of nationals of different Member States living in a Member State other than their own or gaining property in several Member States. The number of international couples within the Union is high and has identified the practical and legal difficulties they face in the day-to-day management of their property and in the division of assets following the separation of a couple or the death of one of the couple's members, and this proposal aims to establish a clear legal framework for the European Union to establish the competence and law applicable to matrimonial property regimes and facilitate the circulation of decisions and documents between Member States.  Since I believe that this area should remain within the competence of the Member States and that the entry of this Regulation will lead to a breach of the principle of subsidiarity, I voted with restraint.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a regulation governing the jurisdiction of the judicial authority, the applicable legislation and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial property matters. In order to preserve the autonomy of the Member States in the field of family law, the Regulation does not cover areas such as the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of the marriage, the maintenance obligation or the succession of the deceased spouse's estate. The Regulation shall also not affect or prejudice the substantive law of the Member States on legal obligations and property systems. It is provided that, if a Member State does not recognise the law, the courts of a Member State shall be granted a discretion conferring jurisdiction in the present case on the courts of another Member State which recognises that marriage. The proposal also takes into account the principle of uniformity of the applicable legislation in the area of matrimonial property regime, which applies to all immovable property under that legislation, regardless of where they are located. The regulation makes it possible to choose the law applicable to the property consequences between spouses, but that choice is limited by the requirement that the spouses are nationals of the State or have at least habitual residence in the country whose law has been chosen. The Regulation also provides for the means to communicate the necessary and basic legal information intended for international couples.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The European Union does not have to legislate in the area of family law, it violates the principle of subsidiarity and constitutes unjustified interference in national family laws. I am resolutely AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Jurisdiction and applicable law in the field of international marriages should be left to the EU Member States. The changes that have taken place compared to the twin proposal for registered partnerships in 2011 should be commended. However, they are not sufficient. Moreover, the resolution does not define marriage, and this means that it may include same-sex unions, which makes it unacceptable for other Member States, m.in. Polish. Polish. I therefore voted against the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Council Decision on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters relating to matriity property regimes is the second in this respect. Following the blocking of negotiations between Member States, as all agreements on family law must be adopted unanimously, this proposal returns to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – This regulation will be a very useful tool for international couples living in the European Union. It governs the jurisdiction, law and recognition and enforcement of judgments applicable in the area of matrimonial property regimes. The adoption of this Regulation will no longer result in many cases of insularities and legal difficulties.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. The regulation covers jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. I voted in favour because I believe that this regulation will be a very useful instrument for international couples in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this decision, the plenary adopts a European instrument to manage the economic regimes for marriages to be used to determine which court has jurisdiction and which legislation should be applied in each case. We are therefore talking about a very important step in facilitating the management of these regimes affecting some 16 million international EU partners. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This report is basically about jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in the field of matrimonial property law. It refers to the fact that more and more citizens from different Member States are entering into ties with each other and that these couples are settling in one Member State. The proposed amendment makes sense here to clarify the Member States concerned, so that the Member States themselves are free to accept these rules within the framework of enhanced cooperation.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Council regulation. EU citizens are increasingly moving around the EU, working, living, marrying and buying property across EU Members states, other than their own. This makes things complicated if these couples separate, or when one of the two partners deceases, etc. This regulation provides clarification on which court has jurisdiction in such cases. To ensure consistency and enhance simplification, this regulation enables one regime to be applicable to property that is located outside the EU. Under certain conditions, it also allows for the law of third countries to apply. Citizens should be allowed to choose for themselves as to which regime will apply to their property. This will also facilitate things for citizens of third countries and for EU citizens that live outside the EU. The establishment by the regulation of means to communicate basic information to international couples will only enhance this. All of this makes life easier for people, during times that are usually the hardest to people. It puts an end to legal uncertainty for many of them and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have no doubt that the proposed legislation will facilitate the situation in dealing with the property affairs of spouses who are each from a different Member State or who have married in a state other than that in which they currently live. However, it should be borne in mind that the conditions for marriage vary in the EU Member States. It is therefore good that the resolution adopted so far concerns only those states that have opted for enhanced cooperation in this area of legal harmonisation. Slovakia is not one of them, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This initiative concerns international couples in the EU and settles property issues with certain exceptions mentioned in the text. The report was voted on by a large majority in the european Parliament's committee on legal affairs. I voted in favour.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I am in favour of this package of proposals on family law, as I believe that all of them are very useful in terms of forming a strengthened private international law regime, supplementing other instruments of this legislative branch. International couples and couples are a phenomenon that, by factors such as globalisation and the economic crisis (which in many cases has led European citizens to have had to change their place of residence in search of a better working life) are becoming more common. All this undoubtedly requires a revision of the legislation, which allows this profile of couples to have legal support and recognition, so that those in this situation do not receive disadvantages for this union of international profile and have the same rights and duties as a couple belonging to the same state.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because the regulation will be a very useful instrument for international marriage within the European Union, while maintaining member states' autonomy on family law. I appreciate that Parliament's demands have therefore been heard. I believe that this proposal for a regulation on matrimonial property conditions is certainly in the interest of the Union and its international married couples and that it will resolve a number of ness and legal problems.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support Mr Cavada's report on the property regime of international couples married in this case. While I agree with the idea that the rules for dealing with property issues following legal separation or divorce of an international couple are currently lacking, and with the overall increase in mobility and thus the number of international couples, this is a very important legal area, but I do not agree with the principle of how the draft regulations were tabled. By accepting the marriage regulation, states must also automatically adopt a regulation concerning registered partnerships. And although this phenomenon exists in the world and rules are needed to deal with the property situation of registered couples, I think that this raises a number of legal problems in Member States whose legal order is not known by the registered partnership institute, as is the case in Slovakia, for example. In my opinion, these legal issues, and in particular the question relating to the potential contradiction of the proposal with the principle of subsidiarity, since family law is the exclusive competence of the Member States, have not been given sufficient attention in the proposal for a regulation. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the area of matrimonial property regimes. I believe that the regulation will remove a number of cases of ambiguity and legal uncertainty for international couples within the European Union. In the area of matrimonial property regimes, it covers the powers and the applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of judgments. In particular, questions of the spouses' legal and commercial capacity, the existence, validity and recognition of marriage, maintenance obligations and the succession of the deceased spouse are excluded from its scope. It also retains the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported both of these reports, both of these regulations. I did not have time to say in the debate yesterday that it is very good that the regulations have passed, but it is a great memento that, after a debate that has lasted more than five years between Parliament and the Council, a plan has finally passed, which is not, in principle, so ambitious. It regulates only certain conflict-of-law rules and certain procedural rules, and the problem is that it has not been adopted by all the States of the European Union, but only by 18 states.  So it's a big warning, a big memento for the future. At a moment when we are not adjusting the substantive law itself and thus not interfering with the competence of individual states, then I am a little sorry that for conflict-of-law rules and procedural standards, which regulate, for example, the jurisdiction of the court, or the law that will be applicable, that we are not all able to agree. This is, on the one hand, a good project, but the fact that only 18 countries have adopted it is extremely weakened and therefore applies only to part of the European Union. So I have some regrets to express.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 There are approximately 16 million international couples currently present in Europe. This percentage is a symptom of the profound changes that have characterised civil society, making a change in family law a top priority. In fact, international couples often come across unforeseen and unintended consequences in the management of their assets, because of the differences between the various legal systems. In the absence of unanimous agreement on this matter, 17 Member States requested and obtained a strengthened cooperation procedure aimed at clarifying and harmonising the rules on capital effects for registered partnerships. I therefore voted in favour, because I believe that revising legislation in this area, attempting to harmonise it, will make life easier for European citizens and families.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I abstained on this text on the jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage effects of registered partnerships. Indeed, even if this regulation states that it excludes material law issues from its field, it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent the obstacle.  Member States' autonomy in family law will therefore be hampered. This text constitutes an unjustified interference in national legislation concerning the family.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This file is the same as the previous file. It follows on from another file voted on at the last plenary on property regimes of international couples. The resolution asks the Council to notify Parliament if negotiations depart from the framework which has been presented. Similar to the previous files, as these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but simply set out opaque rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes, I voted in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens and the saving of legal costs.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Parliament adopted its position on these regulations during the last term of office. The Council took a long time to take a stand. We welcome the enhanced cooperation and hope that other Member States will decide to join this process. This regulation will make the lives of European international couples much easier and guarantee them better legal certainty.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the property relations of registered partners. I personally voted in favour of this report alongside the Group of the Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament, as it will contribute to improving European legislation in this area and make life easier for many European citizens.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. With increasing mobility in an area without internal borders, international couples are no longer uncommon. International couples are defined as those who are made up of citizens of 2 EU Member States and then remain in a country whose nationality is not both.  These international couples often face difficulties both in their daily lives and in the division of their common property as a result of a separation or death of a person. The new regulation aims to make this easier for couples in a registered civil partnership by determining the court responsible for them and the law applicable to their property rights.  I have also voted in favour of it because the new regulation will benefit many people living in border regions.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In 2010, the Commission announced a proposed regulation making it easier for international couples to know which courts have jurisdiction over their property rights and what legislation applies to them. After the negotiations have stalled, this proposal returns to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation involving only 17 Member States.  The regulation covers the jurisdiction and applicable law in terms of the heritage effects of registered partnerships. The text also allows the choice of applicable law provided that it is that of the state of which one of the partners is a national, or the state in which it has its usual residence. Partners will also be able to choose the Law of the State registration of the partnership. Even if the regulation states that it excludes from its domain matters relating to material law (capacity, maintenance obligations, succession...), it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent the obstacle. This is partly due to the generously developed ability to choose the applicable law. The autonomy of Member States in family law is therefore not safeguarded in the end. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws. So I voted against the report.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this report to approve a regulation that aims to make it easier for international couples (married or registered partners) to know which courts have jurisdiction over their property rights and what legislation applies to them. However, even if the regulation states that it excludes from its domain matters relating to material law (maintenance obligations, succession, etc.), it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages, notably by the generously arranged possibility of choosing the applicable law. The autonomy of Member States in family law is therefore ultimately not safeguarded. This is an unjustified interference in national family laws.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The aim here is to use enhanced cooperation between the member states in favour of it to establish a comprehensive body of rules of private international law applicable to the heritage effects of registered partnerships with regard to transnational couples. I approved of that point.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. When we talk about the importance of the Union and how the decisions we take in the European institutions directly affect the lives of citizens, we refer to measures such as those contained in the Commission proposal adopted in this Resolution. There are some 16 million "cross-border" couples in Europe who will benefit from future Property Rights Regulations. There is no doubt that these regulations are a step forward that will make the lives of many international couples easier. However, due to enhanced cooperation, there will be two Europes for these couples: one where their property rights are recognized and one not. I voted in favour of this resolution, as it is a step forward. But it's not enough. My commitment is to continue working for a Europe without barriers for couples and families, including all forms of family that exist in our society, and therefore without discrimination for LGTBI citizens. We must ensure free movement within the EU. And in order to achieve this without discrimination, it is also essential that any marriage or registered union of same-sex couples be recognized in another Member State.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Cavada report on the proposal for a Council regulation on the jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property effects of registered partnerships.  After the deadlock in the negotiations, the launch of enhanced cooperation led to a proposal much more in line with the indications expressed by Parliament in 2013. A major step forward is the principle of the unity of applicable law, which provides that the law of property regimes between spouses applies to all assets held within the union, wherever they may be.  The text also presents important innovation in the recognition, enforceability and enforcement of decisions on the capital effects of registered partnerships, taking up the very precise provisions of Regulation No 650/2012. In general terms, this new regulation is an effective response to overcome cases of confusion and legal difficulties, which is why I decided to support it with my vote.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this draft report on the Council's proposed regulation on the jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage effects of registered partnerships. Of course, everyone can recognize the difficulties faced by couples in registering their partnership, in particular because of the wide disparities in the rules applicable to heritage effects. It should be noted that in France, the issue of foreign-registered partnerships has never been decided, while in the rest of Europe there is a wide variety of foreign-registered partnerships. However, this regulation carries within it the risk of opening a loophole and allowing a kind of "heritage exile", allowing partners to anticipate blockages and choose the applicable law. As a result, it is an endangerment of the autonomy of Member States with regard to their family rights.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it is a purely procedural vote, I believe that there are grey areas in the report that could open up to future critical issues, so I have decided to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Freedom of movement within the Union has led to a significant increase in international de facto couples or de facto partners who must resolve cross-border issues. However, these couples often face property-related problems, either while they remain together or when it comes to distributing goods in the event of separation. This Regulation, developed through the enhanced cooperation procedure and applicable to eighteen Member States (Sweden, Belgium, Greece, Croatia, Slovenia, Spain, France, Portugal, Italy, Malta, Luxembourg, Germany, Czech Republic, Netherlands, Austria, Bulgaria, Finland and Cyprus) that have requested it, aims to provide clear instructions to help international couples choose the law applicable to them, the jurisdiction of the courts and the terms of recognition and the scope of decisions taken in other States Members.  This Regulation will improve the legal status of international couples or who must resolve cross-border issues by establishing a clear legal framework for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on de facto couples' ownership regimes, so I voted in favour of it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because this proposal is for a Council regulation on the jurisdiction, law and enforcement of the jurisdiction, law and enforcement of the property consequences of a registered partnership. This regulation will be a very useful tool for international couples living in the European Union. It governs the jurisdiction, law and recognition and enforcement of judgments applicable in the area of the property consequences of a registered partnership. However, the scope of the Regulation does not include matters relating to the capacity of the partners, the existence, validity or recognition of the partnership, the maintenance obligations and the succession of the assets of the deceased partner. The independence of the Member States in the area of family law is therefore preserved. Furthermore, the Regulation does not affect the substantive law of the Member States relating to the registered partnership or its material consequences.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text is undoubtedly a prerequisite for the standardization of legal rules concerning the matrimonial regimes of international couples, whether they are married or bound by a registered partnership. There are fears of future interference in national family laws.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – This file is the same as the previous file. It follows on from another file voted on at the last plenary on property regimes of international couples. The resolution asks the Council to notify Parliament if negotiations depart from the framework which has been presented. Similar to the previous files, as these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but simply set out opaque rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes, I voted in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens and the saving of legal costs.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation, presented within the framework of enhanced cooperation involving the vast majority of Member States, which aims to clarify and better regulate, within the countries concerned, the competences, the applicable law and the procedures for recognising and implementing decisions on the capital effects of registered partnerships, represents an important step forward in facilitating access to rights and simplifying the lives of a large number of European citizens. The new proposal for a regulation would allow for greater flexibility (for example in the choice of applicable law or in facilitating the movement of official acts) which would meet the needs, in particular, of couples made up of citizens from different Member States, while clarifying certain legal situations that are currently unclear and thus providing greater legal certainty. This is in fact a further step towards the ever more effective movement of acts and decisions between Member States, capable of strengthening the creation of a homogeneous, harmonised and functional legal area capable of responding to the challenge of increasing mobility and capable of promoting the development of effective European citizenship.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen cooperation between EU Member States in order to facilitate the administrative procedures of international couples. The text covers, in terms of the heritage effects of registered partnerships, the jurisdiction and applicable law as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions. It also gives these couples the opportunity to choose the applicable law provided it is that of the state of which one of the partners is a national. In short, partners will be able to choose the Partnership Registration State Act.  While this report excludes material law issues such as succession, it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent legal obstacles. The autonomy of Member States in family law is therefore not safeguarded in the end.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 This initiative concerns the jurisdiction and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of judgments on the property effects of registered partnerships, determining which court has jurisdiction to rule on claims for property effects of registered partnerships. This proposal comes against the background of increased mobility of people, which generates an increase in the number of couples made up of citizens of different Member States living in a Member State different from their home Member State. Following various studies, a number of difficulties encountered by these transnational couples, difficulties caused by certain incompatibilities between the applicable rules governing the property effects of marriage, both substantive and private international law. However, the approach to the proposal in question is not common at the level of all Member States, and the reason is that the provisions are insufficient to create a homogeneous framework that takes into account all the situations that may arise in this sector, which is why I have chosen to abstain on the final vote on this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In contemporary society, although marriage is the most common form of couples, we meet with new forms of union, including registered partnership. This involves formally recording the union of two persons in a stable relationship in the records of public authorities. This proposal for a regulation on the property effects of registered partnerships is of major interest to the EU, as it clarifies a number of confusions in the application of previous law law applicable to international couples. We live in a mobile world, and the recognition of the rights of international partners, wherever they are, will end the division of the legal regime of the couple's assets. The major achievement of this proposal for a Council report, which I support, is the unit of applicable law, according to which the law of the property effects of registered partnerships applies to all assets held in the partnership, wherever they are. The Regulation allows the choice of the law applicable to the property effects of registered partnerships, but that choice is limited by the requirement to be a citizen of the Member State concerned or to–and be habitually resident thereof. In addition, this regulation respects the autonomy of the Member States in matters of family law and does not affect the substance of the law of the Member States with regard to registered partnerships or their property effects.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and discussion in the Chamber, I gave my vote in favour of the report on competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the capital effects of registered partnerships on the following grounds: – we need a close debate on careful and inclusive regulation, which affirms in a unified and respectful way the choices of the Member States, the delicate issues concerning the capacity of the partners , the existence, validity or recognition of a union, maintenance obligations and the succession of the pre-death partner; – the great step forward is the principle of the unity of applicable law, which provides that the law of property regimes between spouses applies to all assets held within the union, wherever they may be. I therefore support the report and the need for uniform regulation, real aid for the development of family issues.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This file follows on from another file voted on at the last plenary on property regimes of international couples. It seeks to define the rules applicable for jurisdiction, applicable law and the enforcement of decisions for international registered partnerships concerning property regimes. The last vote was consent of the Parliament for 17 Member States to proceed through the enhanced cooperation system, i.e. not through the normal EU legislative process. The Parliament now has to give its consent to the framework content of proposals by the European Commission, after which, negotiations between these countries will begin outside of the normal EU legislative process. The resolution basically asks the Council to notify Parliament if negotiations depart from the framework presented today. As these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but merely set out clear rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes. I was happy to vote in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that proposes a detailed regulation touching on judicial and legal affairs on the property consequences of registered partnerships. The regulation covers a wide range of areas and clarifies many uncertainties. The only areas which are not covered are those that remain solely within the competences of the Member States, such as the recognition of a partnership or maintenance obligations. This proposal mostly follows its parallel proposal on matrimonial property regimes and they share the same objective of creating a consistent system across the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because the measure ensures that cross-border issues relating to the capital effects of registered partnerships are regulated and, therefore, it is in the interests of citizens.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that the proposal for a regulation on the property relations of registered partners is clearly in the interests of the Union and the international couples subject to it.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the property relations of registered partners. This issue affects thousands of European citizens and the promotion of flexible solutions such as this serves their needs. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The variety of family rights in the Member States means that, in the case of couples from two different States who decide to legalise their union in alternative forms to marriage, there could be serious problems of recognisability and cross-border viability of such a union. On the other hand, when we talk about the four fundamental freedoms, the financial consequences of sentimental unions must be homogeneous and safeguarded. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote, which covers jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of the property consequences of registered partnerships.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2011, the Commission submitted a proposal on the jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property effects of registered partnerships, commonly referred to in our scheme as 'de facto unions'. This measure is part of a set of instruments aimed at making life easier for transnational couples, which are increasingly frequent within the European Union.  However, it was not possible to reach a consensus in the Council, which was solely competent in these matters and bound by unanimity. Thus, a group of 18 Member States, including Portugal, wanted to move forward with the measures, helping to do so from the enhanced cooperation mechanism. It is this enhanced cooperation that is adopted today, the text of which welcomes significant proposals from the European Parliament, made during the first negotiating process between all Member States In the context of enhanced cooperation, the European Parliament must assess, among other criteria, respect for national competences, which is the case in this case. The powers of the Member States in the field of Family Law are fully respected, in particular with regard to the recognition of de facto unions.  I therefore support this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution approves the Commission proposal on the capital effects of registered partnerships. In particular, jurisdiction and the court of jurisdiction, applicable law and how to resolve legislative gaps, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property effects of registered partnerships are defined. By voting in favour of the resolution, I intend to support these measures, which limit situations of confusion and legal uncertainty. Greater clarity of the rules on the capital effects of registered partnerships is undoubtedly in the interests of European citizens and international couples.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The possibility of free travel within the Union and labour mobility have led to an increase in the number of couples whose members have different nationalities. Along with marriage, registered partnerships offer rights and duties to couples who decide to formalize their relationship before the authorities of the State of residence. However, this form of formalisation of the relationship is not recognised in all Member States, and there are major differences between the laws of the States allowing registered partnerships. I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments on the property effects of registered partnerships because I believe that this is an important step in facilitating the legal and administrative procedures faced by a large proportion of international couples.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This regulation aims to establish a clear legal framework in the EU for the determination of decisions on the property consequences of a registered partnership. This solution raises concerns in the context of Article 4(2) of the TOU guaranteeing member states respect for their national identity, in this particular case as regards the definition of family law institutions whose effects Member States wish to recognise under their legal order. The draft authorisation decision also raises doubts in the context of its compatibility with the principle of loyal cooperation between the European Union and the Member States. I therefore voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this regulation is to have a clear legal framework which is needed in matters of matrimonial property regimes which also promotes enhanced cooperation between member states and the European Union. I voted in favour of this report as it will make it possible to put an end to many cases of confusion and legal uncertainty.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report focuses on the establishment of enhanced cooperation on heritage effects between the voluntary Member States, i.e. 23 Member States. The Commission's proposed regulation aims to simplify administrative procedures for heritage schemes between Member States, and will give international couples legal certainty.  Considering that harmonization of the rules on matrimonial regimes is necessary to avoid disconcerting legal uncertainty for European international couples, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With the freedom of movement and establishment inherent in the European area, the number of registered partnerships between nationals of different Member States has increased. I voted in favour of this text so that European legislation could facilitate the establishment of these partnerships.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In 2010, the Commission announced a proposed regulation making it easier for international couples (married or registered partners) to know which courts have jurisdiction over their property rights and what legislation applies to them.  After the negotiations have stalled, with any agreement to be unanimous on family law, this proposal is up to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation involving only 17 Member States.  Of course, the regulation states that it excludes from its field matters relating to material law (capacity, support obligations, inheritance, etc.). Nevertheless, it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent the obstacle. This includes the ability to choose the applicable law. Member States' autonomy in family law is therefore not safeguarded. For this reason, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to abstain on this dossier. In the aftermath of recent discussions and votes on this topic, there have been some improvements. However, we are now voting on the rules and the same issues that I have raised before and which are still present. Many Member States are not familiar with the partnership institution (Italy, Bulgaria, Romania, Slovakia, Poland, Lithuania, Latvia). Moreover, we are now voting on the real proposals. While it is not so problematic to vote on proposals for enhanced cooperation on matrimonial property regimes for married couples, this is a completely different topic when it comes to partnerships. While some countries support the proposal for enhanced cooperation, they are obliged to transpose both instruments and introduce measures for both concepts into their national legislative framework. This not only means a subsequent incompatibility with certain national policies; this is also a clear disregard for the sovereignty of some Member States, as well as undermines the principle of subsidiarity, while promoting enhanced cooperation for the benefit of citizens. While I am generally in favour of this initiative, I cannot support the conflict it brings with it to some Member States, and that is why I abstained.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report attempts to establish a regulatory framework for the family law affairs of international couples. We are opposed to the involvement of EU legislation in the layout of family affairs, as each Member State adequately covers these issues with its own legislation. With regard to the specificities that arise in international couples, private international law provides the necessary security with regard to the effective regulation of these relationships.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. A number of studies have revealed the high number of transnational couples in the Union and the practical and legal difficulties faced by these couples, both in the day-to-day administration of their assets and in their division when the couple separates or one of its members dies. These difficulties are often the result of the wide disparity of applicable rules, both substantive law and private international law, which regulate the economic effects of marriage. The objective of this proposal is to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union for the determination of jurisdiction and the law applicable to matrimonial economic regimes, and to facilitate the movement between Member States of judgments and other acts in this area

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. There are around 16 million international couples in the EU. Parallel legal proceedings in different countries, the complexity of the proceedings and the resulting high legal costs represent costs estimated at EUR 1.1 billion per year.  I consider it important to clarify which national court is competent to help international couples - united by marriage or a registered partnership - to manage their property or to share them in the event of divorce, separation or death (rules on jurisdiction) and which law applies when laws of different countries are potentially applicable to the procedure (rules on applicable law).  The new rules should also facilitate the recognition and enforcement in one Member State of a judicial decision on property aspects given in another Member State.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: this is unjustified interference in national family laws.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has repeatedly, through its non-legislative resolutions, called on the other European institutions, but also on the Member States, to guarantee equal rights for couples, both heterosexual and homosexual, who opt for so-called civil unions. Full mutual recognition of the capital effects of registered partnerships within the European Union is therefore a fundamental step towards the recognition of the much-claimed equality of rights and is also essential in order to reduce discriminatory legal and administrative obstacles for citizens exercising their right of free movement. The proposal for a regulation on the capital effects of registered partnerships will, after all, put an end to many cases of confusion and legal difficulties, thereby guaranteeing greater legal certainty.  As has already been pointed out, this is a concrete commitment by the Union to equality and equal rights.  A concrete commitment that we cannot help but share.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report approves the European Commission's proposal on jurisdiction, applicable legislation and recognition and enforcement of decisions on ownership schemes in registered partnerships. The Regulation will be a useful tool for couples/international partnerships in the EU. Today, as a result of a large mobility of people between EU Member States, couples face various bureaucratic difficulties when it is necessary to deal with issues relating to ownership or division of the same, when they divorce or when one of the members of the couple dies. There are problems when property is acquired in different Member States, for example.  This Regulation covers jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on matrimonial property regimes. However, its scope does not cover issues such as the legal capacity of the spouses, the existence, validity or recognition of a marriage, the obligations of a deceased spouse or the succession of property of a deceased spouse. The Regulation also does not affect social security rights or pension rights in the event of divorce. The autonomy of the Member States in family law is preserved. Nor does the Regulation affect the substumy law of the Member States in registered matrimonial/partnership systems. We have supported the opening up of the cooperation process between States on this matter and we voted in favour of this report.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the framework of private law which it establishes will be very useful for the Member States and, among them, Spain, to ensure compliance with the principle of non-discrimination. I also consider it appropriate to unequal the rules achieved by this report.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because the proposal provides for the free circulation of decisions, authentic instruments and court settlements concerning matrimonial property regimes.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a very similar proposal in this particular case to the modification of the property regimes of international couples and will only apply to those Member States of the European Union that have registered partnerships in their national legislation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from this report.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report attempts to establish a regulatory framework for the family law affairs of international couples. I am opposed to the involvement of EU legislation in the layout of family affairs, as each Member State adequately covers these issues with its own legislation. With regard to the specificities that arise in international couples, private international law provides the necessary security with regard to the effective regulation of these relationships.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I find it extremely important to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of matrimonial property regimes. Due to the free movement of people in the EU there has been a significant increase in the numbers of international couples or couples that need to deal with cross-border issues. These couples are currently facing legal problems in dealing with property, both inside their marriage, and when dividing property in case of divorce. Parliament adopted its position on these Regulations during the last mandate, and it is very regretful the fact that the Council took such a long time to take a position. I welcome the enhanced cooperation and hope that other Member States will decide to join, as this regulation will make life of European international couples much easier and offer them legal certainty.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the law applicable to the property aspects of registered partnerships. This proposal is the same version of the case concerning matri matri matriith property regimes. In matters relating to the property effects of registered partnerships, jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments shall be covered. However, it does not cover the legal capacity of the partners, the existence, validity and recognition of the partnership, maintenance obligations and succession after the deceased partner. The autonomy of the Member States in the field of family law is therefore guaranteed. The Regulation shall be without prejudice to the substantive rights of Member States in registered partnerships or their property effects.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council regulation on the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property effects of registered partnerships between persons from different Member States, because I believe that we need to move forward along the path of extending and conferred rights in the EU. Equal treatment between married couples and registered partnerships is in fact an indispensable principle for me. It is therefore essential that, in addition to the negotiations on the regulatory framework for matrimonial systems, negotiations should take place in parallel with the negotiations on the regulatory framework for registered partnerships. This is also an issue on which Parliament has a clear and decisive position, unfortunately hampered by the reticence and short-sightedness of some Member States. I therefore strongly support the choice of enhanced cooperation between a majority of Member States, because I believe that we need to move forward with this important legislation.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the Cavada report "Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of the property regime of registered partnerships" – even though, as part of a consultation process, it only welcomes the COM 2016/0107 proposal. However, it is erroneous in paragraph II of the legal statement of reasons when it claims that the autonomy of the Member States is preserved in the area of family law. That is definitely not the case. I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as a vehement interference with the subsidiarity of the Member States, which I condemn in its form.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament has today supported the second proposal in this area concerning jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judicial decisions on the property consequences of registered partnerships. Simplification of procedures will facilitate the identification of the court competent to deal with cases concerning the property regimes of international couples, which will put an end to costly parallel proceedings in different Member States. The new rules will apply in 18 Member States which have declared their willingness to undertake so-called enhanced cooperation, which unfortunately do not belong to Poland. The European Commission estimates that there are 16 million international couples living in the 18 EU countries covered by the above-mentioned cooperation, and this Regulation will be a useful instrument for them to ensure legal protection and easier access to justice.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The report deals with jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the quality law of registered partnerships. However, the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to matters relating to family law remains, as does the substantive law of the Member States with regard to the property regime of registered partnerships.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because the property effects of registered partnerships concern international couples, but also the principle of unity within the Union, as it will reduce confusion and legal obstacles. Thus, access of international couples to basic legal information will be facilitated, although obligations relating to the existence, validity or recognition of partnerships and obligations relating to maintenance duties or the succession of a deceased partner will remain the responsibility of the Member States. In this context, the legal regime of the couple's assets will be clarified and well delineated. Thus, data subjects will be able to choose the law applicable to property effects with regard to registered partnerships, but will be limited by the requirement of nationality or residence in a given Member State.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The proposed Regulation provides for the free movement of decisions, authentic instruments and court settlements concerning matrimonial property regimes introducing mutual recognition based on the mutual trust arising out of the integration of the Member States within the European Union.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report, since it fills in legal loopholes that existed regarding jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the property relations of registered partners.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Many international couples of separate Member States face practical and legal difficulties, both in the daily management of their property and in its division if the couple separate or one of its members dies. The European Union has set itself the objective of maintaining and developing an area of freedom, security and justice in which the free movement of persons is ensured. The aim of the proposal is to establish a clear, legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction and the law applicable to the property consequences of registered partnerships. It therefore deals with matters of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions regarding the property consequences of a registered partnership. I believe that couples who are registered partners will be protected under EU law.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal as I had no objections to the final proposal.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. I have followed the recommendation of my group colleagues and abstained from voting on the Cavada report 'Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of the property regime of registered partnerships'.  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together.  However, I cannot support uniform European regulation. On the contrary, I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as an interference with the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, whose proposal for a regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments has a beneficial and positive effect on the property effects of registered partnerships and on the European Union. It is intended that, with this vote, Parliament will express a favourable opinion on this proposal, without substantial changes at this stage.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written.
