I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Council Regulation on Competence, Applicable Law and the Recognition and Enforcement of Decisions in Matters Relating to the Property Consequences of Registered Partnerships, as this proposal will contribute to the elimination of a number of dilemmas in this area, which is certainly in the interest of the European Union and the international couples living therein.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. In 2010, the Commission announced a proposed regulation making it easier for international couples (married or registered partners) to know which courts have jurisdiction over their property rights and what legislation applies to them.  After the negotiations have stalled, with any agreement to be unanimous on family law, this proposal is up to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation involving only 17 Member States.  Even if the regulation states that it excludes from its domain matters relating to material law (capacity, maintenance obligations, succession...), it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent the obstacle. This is partly due to the generously developed ability to choose the applicable law. The autonomy of Member States in family law is therefore not safeguarded in the end.  This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family legislation, and I have obviously opposed it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the property conditions of international couples, which concerns some 16 million such couples in the EU. This report dealt with the case of international marriages as well as registered partnerships and their property settlement in the event of divorce, legal separation or death. The new legal framework provides for couples from 18 EU countries to choose which jurisdiction to deal with in their case in order to avoid parallel proceedings in two states and possible conflicting court decisions. This will give international couples legal certainty, harmonisation of rules and better access to fair trial. The same rights will be ensured for both married couples and registered partners.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation, which aims to establish a comprehensive body of rules of private international law applicable to the heritage effects of registered partnerships. There is an urgent need to address the practical and legal difficulties faced by transnational couples in the Union both in the day-to-day management of their property and in the time of their division in the event of separation or death.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted this proposal for a regulation on the property consequences of registered partnerships as it is clearly in the interest of the EU and of its international couples. It will make it possible to put an end to many cases of confusion and legal uncertainty. The current proposal, the second on this topic, has incorporated a large proportion of the amendments proposed by Parliament. Your rapporteur therefore proposes that Parliament issue a favourable opinion on this proposal, without any substantive amendments at this stage.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. The Regulation will resolve the issues of matrimonial property regimes with regard to jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments. The scope of application excludes questions about the legal capacity, business and legal capacity of the spouse, the existence, validity and recognition of the partnership, maintenance obligations and legal consequences. The resolution of these issues on the status of goods is clearly in the interests of the Member States concerned.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the Cavada report 'Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the property regime of registered partnerships'.  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together.  However, I cannot support uniform European regulation. On the contrary, I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as an interference with the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of matrimation and registered partnership decisions, I voted in favour of the proposal. Within the EU, the number of partnerships with the international element is increasing. The regulation therefore aims, above all, to simplify the regime of joint property of spouses and registered partners, both in everyday life and in the event of divorce or death of one of the partners. The Regulation ensures a greater degree of legal certainty within these volumes, including through the easier identification of a common court and the mutual recognition by individual Member States of judgments in related cases. Thus, regardless of the nature of the property, all property conditions of international couples originating in EU member states will be managed by the courts of one Member State, both within their daily circumstances and in the event of divorce or death of one of the partners. In the absence of agreement between all Member States in this respect, the Regulation will only be applied between 17 Member States through so-called closer cooperation. In view of the increasing number of marriages and registered partnerships with the international element, it is important, in my view, to simplify the resulting processes, including the property conditions of these persons. I therefore supported the proposal for a regulation.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, reiterating what was said in the previous declaration, I welcome the proposal for a Council regulation on the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the assets of registered partnerships. This is an important measure, which aims to regulate the capital effects of relations between couples, which need clarity, simplification and legal certainty.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the European Union does not have to interfere with family law, which is the responsibility of the States.  Moreover, the recognition of 'registered partnerships' within couples, which it promotes, is fraught with threats to the sovereignty and identity of European states, as not all have the same conception of these 'partnerships'. 10 out of 28 states have categorically refused to apply it.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. The European Union, by creating a space without internal borders and facilitating mobility within it, has contributed to a significant increase in the number of transnational couples. These couples are now facing practical and legal difficulties, due to differences in procedures and a lack of coordination between the courts of the Member States. That is why I voted in favour of the Cavada report on enhanced cooperation between 18 Member States on the heritage effects of registered partnerships (as well as its double in matrimonial regimes), on which Parliament had been referred for advice.  With this vote, I would like to support a text which aims to simplify the lives of citizens and transnational couples by supporting the creation of a clear legal framework to determine the competence and the applicable law in these situations.  Finally, I would like to point out that this text applies only in transnational situations. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, it will have no impact on the recognition in one Member State of the validity of a registered marriage or partnership in another Member State, nor on the law of the national family.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the heritage effects of registered partnerships.  Even if the regulation states that it excludes from its domain matters relating to material law (capacity, maintenance obligations, succession...), it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent the obstacle. This is partly due to the generously developed ability to choose the applicable law. The autonomy of Member States in family law is therefore not safeguarded in the end.  This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Based on a Commission initiative in 2010, the report creates a clear legal framework for international couples regarding their property rights. The basis of the text gives them the opportunity to choose the applicable law of one of the countries from which one of the partners is from, or from one of the countries in which he has his usual residence.  It is true that this text highlights the absence of jurisprudence in this area. However, family law is an inherent area of each state. It is the responsibility of Member States to set specific legislation, for example by developing cooperation agreements with third countries. In this regard, the Commission is outside its jurisdiction.  I oppose this text by voting against it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this regulation because the aim is to establish a clear legal framework in the EU to determine jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions on de facto couples' ownership regimes. Freedom of movement within the EU has led to a significant increase in international partners or couples who must resolve cross-border issues.  The regulation is intended to provide clear instructions to help international couples choose the applicable law, the jurisdiction of the courts and the terms of recognition and scope of decisions taken in other Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This Regulation will be a very useful tool for international couples within the European Union. With regard to the economic effects of registered companies, it covers jurisdiction and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of judgments.  The Regulation unequivocally lays down which court has jurisdiction to rule on applications for the economic effects of registered associations.  With this regulation we put an end to the division of the legal regime of the couple's assets. The Regulation allows the choice of law applicable to the economic effects of registered unions, but this choice is limited by the requirement to be a citizen or habitual resident of the State concerned.  I vote for the adoption of this Regulation as it is clearly in the interests of the Union and its international partners. It will put an end to numerous cases of confusion and legal difficulties.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the Cavada report "Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the property regime of registered partnerships".  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together. However, I cannot support uniform European regulation, as in some cases it would disregard national values.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report that establishes clearly the jurisdiction, law and recognition of decisions of courts in matters of property consequences of registered partnerships.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I am in support if states want to voluntarily agree with each other on the recognition of decisions on the property conditions of registered partnerships. In my opinion, this is a classic example for using intergovernmental cooperation without the need for the involvement of the European Parliament and the EU.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Hundreds of thousands (if not millions) of married couples living in the EUROPEAN Union, where husband and wife come from different countries, whether the couple live not in their home countries, but in a third country. Although there are different types of cross-border guarantees, agreements and other agreements in the Union in this area, there is still no comprehensive legislative framework that can effectively complement the internal legislation of the Member States. Consequently, the legislation affecting a registered partnership is primary for the Member States, regardless of where that couple lives and where the husband or wife comes from. It is worth noting that while the 17 Member States, following the December 2015 Council meeting, chose to develop closer cooperation on these issues, 23 Member States were prepared to support the text of the proposal for a regulation, which is quite in line with what is currently being discussed today. This gives hope that, with the adoption of the regulation, the maximum broad composition of the Member States could join its functioning.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation of some Member States does not allow and recognise registered partnerships as a matrimonial union (Slovakia, Italy, Bulgaria, Lithuania, Latvia, Poland and Romania). Therefore, their national rules also do not explicitly address the property situation of registered partnerships. However, in countries where this institute is recognised and accepted, the proposal for a regulation presented will help to remove existing barriers to property matters and will contribute to strengthening legal certainty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the property relations of registered partners, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 22/6/2016 and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report and therefore against the draft resolution.  The context is the same as that of the previous text: the Commission wants to change the law of international couples and standardise legal standards, but this time in a particular area, that of registered partnerships. The text defines procedural rules, such as the competent jurisdiction or applicable law, major principles such as the unity of applicable law, or the question of the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the context of registered partnerships. It also provides for the possibility for partners to choose the state of registration of the partnership.  This text, if it does not directly affect material law (capacity, support obligations, succession, etc.), will circumvent certain legislative obstacles by choosing, among other things, the applicable law. In conclusion, it promotes unjustified interference with national rules and deprives Member States of their autonomy in family law, which we oppose.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation on international couples relates to jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the field of the assets of registered couples. Thus, although family law issues are primarily regulated at national level, the above-mentioned issues are regulated by this regulation. With regard to jurisdiction, the Regulation regulates the court competent to deal with disputes concerning the property of the spouses. In relation to the applicable law, this Regulation brings unity, since the competent court will have jurisdiction over all assets regardless of the location of the property and thus there will be no longer a separation of the applicable law for each element individually. Finally, as to the recognition, enforceability and enforcement of judgments, a decision is enforceable only after the Member State concerned has declared its enforceability, but it is obliged to do so unless there is a good reason for public policy. I would like to vote in favour of this resolution, considering it to be a way to facilitate international couples through the simplification and consolidation of the legislation concerning them.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The Regulation will resolve the issues of property status with regard to jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments. With this legislative resolution, the rapporteur endorses the Commission's proposal. This is where bureaucracy is to be cut. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. In 2010, the Commission made a proposal for international couples to know more quickly which courts have the power to deal with property rights and the legislation that applies to them. This was not unanimous, as enhanced cooperation had been established for 17 states.  In any case, the EU has no legitimacy to legislate on family matters. This constitutes an intrusion into national family laws. That's something I can't tolerate. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is intended to create in the European Union a clear regulatory framework for the determination of the competent court and the law applicable to the property effects of registered partnerships and to facilitate the movement of decisions and acts in this area between the different Member States.   The aim of this proposal is to establish a complete set of rules of private international law applicable to the property effects of registered partnerships. It therefore covers jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments on the property effects of registered partnerships. The rules laid down apply exclusively to situations of a transnational nature. The cross-border impact requirement of Article 81(3) is thus fulfilled.  This proposal concerns only the property effects of registered partnerships, not defining the registered partnership institute or imposing recognition of a registered partnership in another Member State.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, as it clearly defines which courts, laws, and rules of enforcement are applicable in property consequences, and furthers cooperation, uniform efficiency, and clarity of law between member states. International couples will benefit from having clearly defined applicable laws and jurisdiction pertaining to judicial matters of said property consequences.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It was necessary to move forward in a globalised world of clarifying matrimonial regimes for the millions of international couples/partners in the EU. To put an end as soon as possible to this uncertainty about the law applicable in the case of wealth management or division in the event of divorce or death, we have opted for enhanced cooperation between 18 Member States, including Belgium. This cooperation will enable EU legislation to be adapted in an area that affects the very lives of citizens.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – This proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property consequences of registered partnerships is the second proposal in this area. As any agreement relating to the area of family law must be unanimous, the proposal in question is in the form of enhanced cooperation. The Slovak Republic is not one of the states that recognises this enhanced cooperation and also does not recognise registered partnerships and is not covered by any legal protection. The definitional features of marriage vary considerably from one Member State to another. This Regulation could provide for a broad interpretation of the concept of marriage, which the Slovak courts should take into account, and I consider this to be a mixture in the internal affairs of the state. Issues relating to the area of family law should remain solely within the competence of the Slovak Republic and should be covered by Slovak law. In view of the above, I do not support the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation which aims to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of the property consequences of registered partnerships. The regulation will help international couples to choose the law that is applicable to them, the jurisdiction of the courts and also in terms of the recognition and enforcement of decisions adopted in other Member States.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 This draft regulation is a match to the draft regulation discussed in the previous paragraph. Its adoption in this form is justified by the same circumstances and is equally clearly in the interests of the Union and of international couples living in the Union. The Committee on Legal Affairs therefore proposes in its report that Parliament, like the previous one, give a favourable opinion on this proposal. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The regulation covers the jurisdiction and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions, in terms of the heritage effects of registered partnerships (such as the Pacs in France). Even if this text states that it excludes from its domain issues relating to material law (capacity, maintenance obligations, succession...), it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent the obstacle. This is partly due to the generous opportunity to choose the applicable law. The autonomy of Member States in family law is therefore not safeguarded in the end. This is therefore an unjustified interference in national family laws, calling for an unfavourable vote.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation covers, as regards the property effects of registered partnerships, the competence and law applicable, as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions. However, it excludes from its field, in particular questions relating to the capacity of the partners, the existence, validity or recognition of a partnership, the obligations of food and the succession of the deceased partner. It is important to highlight that the autonomy of the Member States in the field of Family Law is safeguarded. The Regulation also clearly determines which court has jurisdiction to rule on claims for the property effects of registered partnerships. I believe that this proposal is in the interests of the European Union, since it guarantees legal clarity, certainty and confidence, especially for so-called international couples.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The autonomy of Member States in family law is not safeguarded by this text. It is therefore an unjustified interference in national family legislation, and I am voting against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the recognition and implementation of decisions on the heritage effects of registered partnerships. This report, whose recommendations apply to transnational situations, is essential in order to put in place a clear legal framework to avoid conflicts of laws and better dissemination of decisions and actions relating to these issues in the Member States.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the free movement of people in the EU there has been a significant increase in the numbers of families that need to deal with cross-border issues. These families are currently facing legal problems in dealing with property, both inside their marriage, and when dividing property in case of divorce. I have voted for this report that aims to establish a clear legal framework in the European Union for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of registered partnerships property regimes.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report concerning a proposal for a Council regulation on the jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments on the property effects of registered partnerships. The personal opinion was favourable, as this regulation will allow for the elimination of numerous confusions and legal difficulties in regulating the legal aspects of international couples in the European Union. In this respect, the report voted on today clearly sets out which court has jurisdiction to rule on the claims for the property effects of registered partnerships. At the same time, this regulation will give flexibility in the legal regulation of the status quo of international couples in the EU, giving them the opportunity to pass the case on to another court.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a regulation, which I believe will be a very useful tool for international couples in the European Union. In matters of the property consequences of a registered partnership, it concerns jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions. However, issues of legal capacity of the partners, the existence, validity and recognition of partnerships, maintenance obligations and inheritance of the deceased partner's assets are excluded from its scope. Member States' autonomy in the field of family law is thus preserved. Nor does the Regulation concern member states' legislation on registered partnerships or its legal consequences. The EP was an active participant in the negotiations and managed to achieve a substantial improvement in the content of the Regulation.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This file is the same as the previous file. It follows on from another file voted on at the last plenary on property regimes of international couples.  The Resolution asks the Council to notify Parliament if negotiations depart from the framework which has been presented.  Similar to the previous files, as these regulations will not affect national family law in the participating Member States, but simply set out opaque rules to determine what jurisdiction is applicable and ensure enforcement of decisions in the case of international matrimonial disputes, I voted in favour. I am disappointed that the Irish Government has chosen to opt out given the added value this could have for citizens and the saving of legal costs.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This Regulation resolves the question of matrimonial property regimes, in relation to the jurisdiction of the applicable law, and the recognition and enforcement of judgments. The Regulation does not concern questions of the spouse's legal capacity, ability to act, the existence, validity and recognition of the partnership, dependants and successors in title. The resolution of these issues on the status of goods is clearly in the interests of the Member States concerned.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal tabled. The proposal correctly transposes the relevant ICCAT recommendations to ensure a level playing field for all tuna operators. In order to ensure the effective implementation of the measures, it is important to progressively reduce the total allowable catch, limit fishing in certain areas and periods, introduce new minimum fish sizes, measures relating to sport and amateur fishing activities, measures for fish farming and fishing capacity, and to strengthen the ICCAT joint international inspection system.  The new legal regulation will close existing legal loopholes, help to harmonise the applicable law in regional fisheries and differentiate regulation, taking into account the characteristics of the various tuna fishing gears.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to Mr Cavada's proposal, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour given the scope of this regulation. While covering the property effects of registered partnerships, jurisdiction and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions, this Regulation aims to safeguard national competences in the field of family law, while ensuring that the principle of the unity of law applicable to all assets within the territory of the Union is respected. In the belief that the proposal as formulated is to be welcomed, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. —Since in addition to this proposal on jurisdiction and applicable law, a similar proposal relating to matrimonial property regimes has been adopted in addition to this proposal on jurisdiction and applicable law in matters relating to the property consequences of registered partnerships, and which has been taken over almost entirely, such an attempt to equalise marriage and other living communities is problematic. The inevitable question is whether some future act will similarly try to equalise marriage and other living communities in matters of parental care, adoption of children and the like. While the proposal for property issues of registered partnerships states that Member States of the European Union that do not have a regulated institute of registered partnerships will not even have to define it, there are difficulties in understanding how the law of another Member State, where the institute of registered partnership is regulated and which is therefore relevant for resolving related property matters, will apply in the Member State where the institute is not known. Therefore, it appears that a registered partnership is intended to be imposed on all countries.  I did not support the proposal on jurisdiction and applicable law in matters relating to the property consequences of registered partnerships, as I consider that not all legal elements are sufficiently clearly and precisely defined and this proposal opens the door to the almost forced agreement of other issues at issue relating to registered partnerships.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to the property consequences of registered partnerships is the second in a row on this matter. Following the blocking of negotiations between Member States, and as any agreement must be unanimous in family law matters, this proposal shall be returned to Parliament in the context of enhanced cooperation. The Regulation will be a very useful instrument for international couples within the European Union. In the area of property consequences of registered partnerships, it covers jurisdiction and applicable law as well as the recognition and enforcement of decisions. However, it excludes, in particular, issues of the legal capacity of the partner, the existence, validity or recognition of the partnership, maintenance obligations and the succession of the deceased partner. Member States' autonomy in family law matters has therefore been preserved. The Regulation also does not affect member states' substantive law on registered partnerships or their property consequences. Consequently, Parliament's requests were met. In conclusion, I agree with the rapporteur, Mr Jean-Marie Cavad, that this proposal for a regulation on the property consequences of registered partnerships is undoubtedly in the interests of the Union and its international couples. It will remove many legal dilemmas and uncertainties.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The great step forward in this new regulation is the principle of the unity of applicable law, which provides that the right to the property effects of a registered partnership applies to all assets held within the union, wherever they may be. This therefore puts an end to the division of the legal system of the couple's assets. The Regulation allows the choice of law applicable to the capital effects of registered partnerships, but is limited by the requirement to be a regular citizen or resident of the State in question. The difference from the regulation on property regimes between spouses is that registered partners can choose the law of the state of registration. In the absence of a choice, the applicable law is that of the place of registration. I voted in favour of the new regulation because it is in the interests of international couples and put an end to many cases of confusion and legal difficulties.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to establish a clear legal framework in the EU for determining jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property consequences of a registered partnership. The European Parliament, in its vote in Strasbourg on 9 June 2016, gave its consent to the decision on enhanced cooperation on the property regimes of marriages and the property consequences of the registered partnership. The main controversy is that the decision authorising enhanced cooperation obliges Member States to link up with two instruments at the same time , one on civil partnerships and the other on marriage. A number of Member States are not familiar with the institutions of the partnership and, by extending their effects to the Regulation on matrimonial property regimes, they require the accession of both regulations implementing enhanced cooperation and consent to the recognition of the effects of partnership institutions which they do not recognise under their domestic law and which may be considered contrary to their public policy. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these new provisions, which will apply to the 18 European states that have been part of a process of enhanced cooperation in the area of competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the matrimonial regimes of international couples, i.e. of two different nationalities.  These new EU rules, which will increase the security of international couples, will also simplify recognition and strengthen a Member State's ruling on ownership in another Member State.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property effects of registered partnerships creates a simplified European regulatory framework, ensuring compliance with the principle of unity of law, within the framework of the legal regime applicable to the property of couples composed of citizens of different Member States. In fact, these couples have been gaining increasing representation within the European Union.  Following Parliament's recommendations, which are now timely met by the Commission, and in order to ensure compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, the proposal appears, in my view, balanced, not in dispute with the competences of the Member States, in particular as regards registered partnerships and their property effects.  Moreover, the document enshrines the so-called public policy clause, the provision of which appears, in my view, essential, to ensure that, in this context, the application of a provision of the law of a Member State can only be removed if such application is manifestly incompatible with the public policy of the forum (see Article 31 of the proposal). For the foregoing, my vote is in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament voted in favour of a clearer legal framework for the management and division of property for the 16 million international couples in the EU who have entered into a registered marriage or partnership. This proposal for enhanced cooperation aims to establish clear rules in the event of divorce or separation of these European couples by putting an end to the employment of parallel and sometimes competing procedures in several Member States. A procedure that is often akin to a fighter's journey.  In practical terms, the improvements consist of the ability of a couple to determine the jurisdiction with jurisdiction to assist them in the management or sharing of these assets. The agreement will also determine the applicable law where the laws of several countries may potentially apply to the case in question. Above all, it will facilitate the recognition and implementation, in one Member State, of a heritage court decision made in another Member State.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The increased mobility of people within a European area without internal borders leads to a significant increase in the number of couples of nationals of different Member States living in a Member State other than their own or acquiring property located on the territory of several Member States.  If we, as Europeans, can welcome this as the manifestation of an increased mixing of the European peoples, this raises several legal and practical questions - because of the great disparity between the rules applicable to the heritage effects of marriage - to which this report intends to respond. In particular, it aims to establish a clear legal framework, where couples will be able to choose the jurisdiction and the applicable law for their possessions and properties, thus avoiding subsequent conflicts of jurisdiction. Undoubtedly, this legislation will allow for better clarification, stability and predictability of the legal framework for international couples. In line with these political lines, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Freedom of movement within the EU has led to a significant increase in international de facto couples or de facto partners who must resolve cross-border issues. However, these couples often face property-related problems, either while they remain together or when it comes to distributing goods in the event of separation. This regulation, drawn up through the enhanced cooperation procedure and applicable to 18 Member States (Sweden, Belgium, Greece, Croatia, Slovenia, Spain, France, Portugal, Italy, Malta, Luxembourg, Germany, Czech Republic, Netherlands, Austria, Bulgaria, Finland and Cyprus) who have requested it, aims to provide clear instructions to help international couples choose the applicable law, the jurisdiction of the courts and the terms of the recognition and scope of decisions taken in other Member States.  This regulation will improve the legal status of international couples or who must resolve cross-border issues by establishing a clear legal framework for determining jurisdiction, applicable law and recognition and enforcement of decisions on de facto couples' ownership regimes, so I voted in favour of it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report, which will put an end to parallel proceedings costing almost EUR 1.1 billion a year in various Member States whose courts have to settle property disputes. They will apply to the 18 countries that wished to join this enhanced cooperation (i.e.: Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Spain, France, Croatia, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Portugal, Slovenia, Finland and Sweden). The two regulations passed, one on matrimonial regimes and the other on the heritage effects of registered couples, will determine which court will have jurisdiction and which law will be applicable in the case of proceedings concerning the ownership of international couples. They will also simplify the recognition and strengthening of a Member State's ruling on ownership in another Member State.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Families, or in broader terms – couples who originate or live in different countries – are becoming more and more a phenomenon of everyday life. It is therefore necessary to ensure the specific, clear and transparent regulation of civil relations between such couples, the protection of property interests, the recognition of judgments of courts as well as standards for the protection of children's rights. I welcome this initiative, I invite colleagues to vote in favour and the Commission and the Member States to continue their dialogue with stakeholders on improving regulation in this area.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the other proposal on matrimonial property regimes, here too we are dealing with a report in which Parliament is consulted in the framework of the proposal for a Council Regulation (also in enhanced cooperation), on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property effects of registered partnerships.  In practice, what this regulation, in casu, seeks to do is to clarify the rules applicable to partnerships registered in cross-border situations, thereby including couples who own property in another Eu (EU) country.  It is therefore an extremely advantageous tool for international couples in the EU, covering the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property effects of registered partnerships.  Outside are issues relating to the capacity of partners, the existence, validity or recognition of a partnership, as well as the obligations of the deceased partner and the succession of the deceased partner, in order to ensure the autonomy of the Member States in the field of Family Law.  Given that this legislative proposal will bring more certainty and legal certainty, clarifying and simplifying a matrimonial regime and previously dubious partnerships, I considered it essential to vote in favour of its adoption.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regime of registered partnerships', as the increasing mobility of EU citizens makes it important to define such competences and legislation directly at EU level.  Registered partnerships are thus recognised in all participating Member States, at least for the legal issues identified in this report. This is about the ownership of both partners. The law is intended to clarify which courts in which country have jurisdiction over these legal issues, depending on where both partners reside, their nationality and the country in which the partnership was concluded.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the free movement of people between Member States is one of the EU's fundamental objectives, I believe that citizens still face many obstacles encountered in exercising their rights. As this also affects international marriages and registered partnerships, I supported the report because I believe that it is necessary to look for ways of phasing out these problems, which they are encountering, particularly in the day-to-day management of joint property, but also at a time of demise caused by partner separation or the death of one of them. I consider the call for change in this area to be extremely important, because recently more and more citizens have been moving across national borders to other EU countries in order to form marriages and registered partnerships. I agree that, in the interests of legal uncertainty to date and, in many cases, discrimination against international couples, legislative measures should be adopted that not only ensure a uniform and simplified legal framework, but also protect their property regime and property consequences. I expect that these changes will help to eliminate cumbersome and costly formalities relating to the cross-border recognition of various documents, which are often not recognised by individual Member States ( marital status, life events).

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. This proposal for a Council Regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the area of property consequences of registered partnerships is the second proposal of its kind. Following the stalemate of negotiations between Member States, the proposal is returning to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation. The applicable law part is subject to universal application and therefore also allows the law of third countries to be applied. The principle of uniformity of the applicable law, according to which the law on the property consequences of registered partnerships applies to all assets within the partnership, regardless of where it is located, is the greatest step forward. This eliminates the system of apportioning the legal regime of the matrimonial property situation of the couples. The Regulation allows for the choice of the law applicable to the property consequences of a registered partnership, but the choice is limited as citizenship or habitual residence must be made in the chosen country. The difference between this proposal for a regulation and the proposal for a regulation on matrimonial property regimes is that registered partners will be able to choose the law of the country in which the partnership is registered. The report stresses that the proposal for a regulation on the property consequences of registered partnerships is in the interest of international couples living in the EU, as it will eliminate many cases of ambiguity and legal uncertainty. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. I have followed the recommendation of my group colleagues and abstained from voting on the Cavada report 'Jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of the property regime of registered partnerships'.  There are clear differences in the way in which a lifelong partnership between two persons of the same sex is recognised by the legal systems. Lesbian and gay partners can therefore encounter problems abroad. I therefore consider it desirable to have bilateral or even multilateral agreements which the Member States themselves initiate in order to bring national rules closer together.  However, I cannot support uniform European regulation. On the contrary, I see the proposal by the European Commission and the Council as an interference with the autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The Recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs should simplify the court's previously unclear and sketchy jurisdictions on matters of the acquis commuictiveness for life partnerships coming from different Member States. On the basis of the recommendation, the legal entity should be entitled to choose the state of which the citizen is a citizen, i.e. whose life partner is a citizen, and resolve the issues of the acquis by the laws of the selected country. The recommendation states that any judicial decisions concerning the acquis are binding, except in "very specific circumstances". The recommendation calls for the establishment of an effective way of communicating these rights to all registered couples who are not citizens of the same Country.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This regulation is a very useful instrument for international couples in the European Union. The Regulation covers issues of competence, application of law, recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of ownership of registered partnerships. The Regulation clearly determines which court has jurisdiction in the procedure for ownership disputes of international couples. Also, the regulation establishes ways to communicate the necessary basic legal information to international couples. I support this report because I consider it to be in line with the interests of the European Union and international couples. I believe that the implementation of this proposal will eliminate ambiguities and put an end to many cases of legal uncertainty.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of the property consequences of registered partnerships. The regulation also clearly specifies which court has jurisdiction to hear claims in the area of the property consequences of registered partnerships. I also supported the report because the regulation covers the powers and applicable law, as well as the recognition and enforcement of judgments in the area of the property consequences of registered partnerships, but in particular issues of the legal and commercial capacity of the partners are excluded from its scope.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report attempts to establish a regulatory framework for the family law affairs of international couples. We are opposed to the involvement of EU legislation in the layout of family affairs, as each Member State adequately covers these issues with its own legislation. With regard to the specificities that arise in international couples, private international law provides the necessary security with regard to the effective regulation of these relationships.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report, which endorsed the Commission's proposal on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters relating to the property effects of registered partnerships. In my opinion, the adoption of the proposal is in the interests of the Union and of international couples living in the Union, as is the party to the proposal, which seeks to make the property regime for married couples more predictable. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides that the Union should facilitate access to justice, in particular on the principle of mutual recognition of judicial and extrajudicial decisions in civil matters.  Although the Council concluded that unanimity could not be achieved with regard to the adoption of proposals for regulations on the property aspects of registered partnerships, by February 2016 17 Member States had indicated their intention to establish enhanced cooperation in this area. I welcome this decision, as the increasing mobility of persons in an area without internal borders leads to an increase in the number of couples of different Nationalities, who must also be given predictability and legal certainty.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The overall aim of this regulation is to create a clear legal framework in the EU for determining the jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of the property consequences of registered partnership. This is a necessary procedure in light of the fact that the free movement of people has led to a significant increase in the numbers of international couples. Thse couples have to deal with a number of cross-border issues, and are facing legal problems in dealing with property and when dividing it following separation. Therefore, the present regulation will provide clear instructions which will help international couples by allowing them to choose the law that is applicable to them, the jurisdiction of the courts and also as regards the recognition and enforcement of decisions adopted in other Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I supported my colleague, Mr Cavada's proposal. This proposed regulation on the heritage effects of registered partnerships is clearly in the interest of the Union and its international couples. The proposed regulation will put an end to many cases of confusion and legal difficulty. The current proposal, which is the second in this area, has incorporated much of the amendments proposed by Parliament

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of increased integration between European countries, the EU now counts 16 million international couples, namely 32 million citizens. While marriage remains the most common type of union, new forms of partnerships have emerged, including the registered partnership, by which two people in a stable relationship formally register their union with a public authority. These couples often encounter great difficulties when it comes to the property rights of their union, because of the significant difference regarding the rules governing registered partnerships between the different EU countries. This is why I voted in favour of the proposal that will enable international couples in the EU to benefit from legal security, a better access to justice and harmonised rules regarding property rights. Concretely, it will allow citizens in international couples to have the various procedures related to property rights, namely divorce, legal separation and death procedures, handled by the courts of the same EU country.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to the property consequences of registered partnerships is the second in a row on this matter and aims to establish a comprehensive set of rules of private international law applicable to the property consequences of registered partnerships.  As in the case of matrimonial property regimes, property relations between registered partners and between partners and third parties stem from the previous existence of a registered partnership. The property consequences of registered partnerships arise from the registration of a partnership, such as the matrimonial property regime resulting from marriage, and cease to terminate the partnership. By registering a partnership before a public authority, the partners establish a stable and legally recognised relationship. However, I did not support this report, as the establishment of a comprehensive set of European Union rules on this issue would lead to a breach of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a regulation governing the jurisdiction of the judicial authority, the applicable legislation and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters relating to the property consequences of registered partnerships. The scope of the Regulation does not cover matters such as the legal capacity of the partners, the existence, validity or recognition of the partnership, the maintenance obligation or the legacy of the deceased partner. The autonomy of the Member States in the area of family law is therefore preserved. The Regulation shall also not affect or prejudice the substantive law of the Member States on registered partnerships and property systems. The Regulation clearly determines which court has jurisdiction in proceedings in the area of the property consequences of registered partnerships. Furthermore, if a Member State does not recognise a partnership, a court of a Member State shall be granted a discretion conferring jurisdiction in the present case on the courts of another Member State which recognise that partnership. The proposal also takes into account the principle of uniformity of the legislation in force, with the Law on the Property Consequences of Registered Partnerships applicable to all assets created during the partnership, regardless of where it is located.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Regulation states that it excludes from its field matters relating to material law (capacity, maintenance obligations, succession...), but it will inevitably allow partners to anticipate possible blockages and circumvent the obstacle, notably by the possibility of choosing the applicable law.  Member States' autonomy in family law is therefore not safeguarded. This is an unjustified interference in national family laws. So I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Council decision on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters concerning the property aspects of registered partnerships is the second in this respect. Following the blocking of negotiations between Member States, as all agreements on family law must be adopted unanimously, this proposal returns to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We propose to vote in favour of this report, as its purpose is to open enhanced cooperation in the field of competition, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments in international couples' ownership regimes, covering the issues of marriage regimes and the economic consequences of registered partnerships. These are measures that will make it easier for international couples to manage.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The Regulation makes it possible to choose the law applicable to the property consequences of a registered partnership, but this choice is limited to the requirement to be a national or permanent resident of the State concerned. This Regulation differs from the matrimonial property regime regulation in that registered partners will also be able to choose the law of the country in which the partnership is registered.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of the property consequences of registered partnerships. The regulation covers jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matters of property consequences of registered partnership. I voted in favour because I believe that this regulation will be a very useful instrument for international couples in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this decision, the plenary adopts a European instrument to manage the economic regimes of de facto couples to be used to determine which court has jurisdiction and what legislation should be applied in each case. We are therefore talking about a very important step in facilitating the management of these regimes affecting some 16 million international EU partners. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to regulate the competence, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of judgments relating to the economic regimes of international couples, both in matters of matrimonial economic regimes and the economic effects of registered unions. I voted in favour of the same position as this will facilitate the recognition of the marriage regimes of cross-border couples.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 This proposal for a Council Regulation on applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property impact of registered partnerships is the second on this subject. After the negotiations between the Member States became stuck – after all, agreements in the field of family law require unanimity – this proposal is now being submitted to Parliament in the context of closer cooperation. As regards the procedural aspects of closer cooperation, reference is made to the specific recommendation on this subject. So here too my approval.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This report is basically about jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions on the property regime of registered partnerships. It refers to the fact that more and more citizens from different Member States are entering into ties with each other and that these couples are settling in one Member State. The proposed amendment makes sense here to clarify the Member States concerned, so that the Member States are free to accept these rules within the framework of enhanced cooperation.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this proposal for a Council regulation because I believe that our system needs to evolve with modern times. As Europe's internal barriers disappeared and our citizens started exploring their continent more and more, an increasing amount of people started meeting their life partners abroad. Together with the Council regulation on matrimonial property regimes, it aims at the simplification and flexibility of legislation and procedures, for international couples, in the case of decease, divorce, etc. As with its complementary one, this regulation clarifies what the procedure, the scope, the jurisdiction, as well as the applicable law will be in such cases. At the same time, it enables, for example, the enforceability of authentic acts. This will also enhance legal certainty and predictability. Finally, I welcome the fact that many of the EP's previous recommendations in this matter have been taken into account.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have long opposed registered partnerships enjoying the same protection and support from the state as marriages made up of one man and one woman. Such marriages have the potential to bring children into the world. The extraordinary legal regime granted by the State to the marriage of a man and a woman is not an expression of recognition of the love of two people, but a practical response to the existential insecurities associated with parenthood. Registered same-sex partners cannot bring offspring into the world, so I do not consider it fair or right for them to enjoy the same benefits as spouses who can become parents. That is why I voted against the motion for a resolution tabled.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I followed the proposal of the rapporteur responsible, as adopted by colleagues in the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs, by voting in favour.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I am in favour of this package of proposals on family law, as I believe that all of them are very useful in terms of forming a strengthened private international law regime, supplementing other instruments of this legislative branch. International couples and couples are a phenomenon that, by factors such as globalisation and the economic crisis (which in many cases has led European citizens to have had to change their place of residence in search of a better working life) are becoming more common. All this undoubtedly requires a revision of the legislation, which allows this profile of couples to have legal support and recognition, so that those in this situation do not receive disadvantages for this union of international profile and have the same rights and duties as a couple belonging to the same state.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Like Mr Cavad's first report on the matrimonial property regime, I abstained in my second report on the property regime for international registered partnerships. Although I believe that rules are needed to deal with the property situation of registered partnerships, since registered partnerships are a normal part of the legal systems of many Member States, on the other hand, seven Member States, among them the Slovak Republic, do not know this institute at all, whether in relation to same-sex or opposite-sex couples. That is why I find it very unfortunate that the legal issues arising from this fact, including the question of the proposal's compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, since substantive family law falls under the exclusive competence of the Member States, have not been given sufficient attention, although, moreover, it is also an extremely sensitive subject. Likewise, I consider the fact that the two regulations are interconnected and that, by accepting one, the Member States will have to adopt the other, I consider it a not very politically correct solution in this regard.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions in the area of the property consequences of registered partnerships. The regulation clearly specifies, inter alia, which court has jurisdiction to rule on claims relating to the property consequences of registered partnerships, and I therefore believe that it will eliminate a number of cases of ambiguity and legal uncertainty for international couples within the European Union.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this resolution because it is right that the cry of alarm should start from Brussels, followed immediately by concrete action by Europe for what is happening in Congo. Tens of thousands of displaced people, thousands of dead, atrocious violence against women and children. , the lucky families who managed to survive. It is very worrying that there should also be UN blue helmets on the ground, engaged in a mission, and that they have not been able to stop the massacres. The situation in Congo, in addition to creating unjust civilian casualties, risks discrediting the UN and the international community as a whole. That is why European policy must be stronger and more coherent. No Migration Compact will be possible without the pacification of Africa first.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, no mercy for those who commit these atrocious crimes. The European Parliament has shown great courage in calling for a light to be shed on the massacres that are devastating entire territories in eastern Congo. A spiral of violence that does not stop in good time must only be stopped with a much more authoritative voice, with timely intervention. If it does not stop, it risks triggering the first outbreaks of genocide and destabilising the entire Great Lakes region. The massacre that has been taking place in this region for years, Mr President, is an essential feature of the people who live in these lands. Today we are not in shame and from today this Parliament is with the Beni, Lubero and Butembo people.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Violation of human rights, war crimes and crimes against humanity are just some of the violence that, unfortunately, continues to take place on Congolese territory. The north-east of the country, in particular, continues to be the scene of the action of armed groups, on several occasions denounced for massacres, child recruitment and sexual violence. The resolution before us calls on the international community to launch a thorough investigation, to prepare targeted and effective sanctions, putting an end to the indifference that has characterised it so far. Since I believe that, in order to combat the repeated violations of human rights, it is a must and a priority, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution — an initiative promoted by the Socialist Group — because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and more than because of its supposed status as a "low-voltage" conflict , suffers above all from the "low attention" it receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance whose main objective, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote of the joint resolution mainly because it does not recognize genocide, calls for the reinforcement of MOUNSCO and in particular through patrols and mobile operations bases, even if some paragraphs with which I agree call for an assessment, and does not reflect information on the responsibilities of multinationals in the financial support of the conflict and the illegal exploitation of natural resources

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against the resolutions and abstention for the GUE resolution, which is by far the most studied and marks a real mastery of the issue. The other resolutions are marked by a clear ignorance of what is happening in Congo. It is clear that, in order to understand the situation in Great Lakes Africa, it is necessary to refer to the end of the Cold War and the American decision to reinvest this reason at the expense of France (with the support of Canadian, British and Israeli diplomats). It is in this context that we must first understand the Rwandan crisis and then the use of Rwanda as Well as Uganda to destabilize the DRC today, based on ethnic divides.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ The initiative put forward by the European Parliament calling for peace in the Congo region was progressive, however, the Joint Motion for a Resolution was not critical enough on the interference of certain countries and companies in destabilising the country.  My Group, GUE/NGL tabled an alternative resolution which was much more critical and got to the root of the issues. However, as the majority of MEPs voted in favour of the Joint Resolution, I did not have an opportunity to endorse this alternative one and therefore, I was left with no choice but to abstain on this Resolution.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Following the conflict that has killed six million people in 20 years and killed more than 800 people every day, we call for an international investigation. European leaders must stop hiding their faces about the horrors perpetrated over the past two decades in the Democratic Republic of Congo by armed militias. The latter, in fact, continue to displace indigenous peoples for the sole purpose of taking control of natural and mineral resource operations. We urge Federica Mogherini, the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to call for an international investigation into the massacres, in collaboration with the United Nations and the International Criminal Court. We also call on members of the European Union who are part of the Security Council to take all possible measures to stop these crimes.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The security situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to deteriorate in the north-east of the country, where dozens of armed groups are operating, leaving thousands dead. According to many reports, there are massacres, underage children are victims of forced recruitment and violence, and often there are incidents of sexual violence. Because of this situation, which is getting worse every day, this joint motion for a resolution was drafted, which I voted in favour of.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Dozens of armed groups are still active in the north-eastern part of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the security situation is steadily deteriorating. There are numerous reports of massacres, recruitment and use of children by armed groups, as well as widespread sexual and gender-based violence. However, the international community is mostly indifferent.  The appalling conditions in this area of Congo are very regrettable and worrying.  Together with Parliament, I would like to see an end to the violence. The uncertainty as to whether the next elections will now be held at the right time is deplorable. In addition, widespread impunity for perpetrators of human rights violations, war crimes, crimes against humanity, sexual violence against girls and women, or for those responsible for recruiting child soldiers is also outrageous.  I fully agree with Parliament's call for such criminals to be punished under national and international criminal law. The EU must ensure a continuous dialogue between the countries of the Great Lakes region and contribute actively to the stabilisation efforts.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. These resolutions follow an increase in abuses in the Democratic Republic of Congo.  With the exception of the extreme left, the resolutions are marked by a clear ignorance of what is happening in Congo. Indeed, to understand the situation of Africa in the Great Lakes, we must refer to the end of the Cold War and the American decision to reinvest this region at the expense of France, with the support of Canadian, British and Israeli diplomats. It is in this context that we must first understand the Rwandan crisis and then the use of Rwanda and Uganda to destabilize the DRC today on the basis of ethnic divides.    I therefore voted against all the resolutions and abstained in favour of the resolution of the extreme left which, although it is difficult to follow by its recommendations on the family, remains the most studied.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against these motions for a resolution, which follow an aggravation of abuses committed in the former Zaire, but which are conspicuous by their ignorance of the situation in the present Democratic Republic of Congo. Indeed, to understand the situation of Africa of the Great Lakes, we must refer to the end of the Cold War as well as the American decision to reinvest this region at the expense of France with the support of other Western diplomats. It is in this context that we must first understand the Rwandan crisis and then the use of Rwanda and Uganda to destabilize the DRC by building on ethnic divides, a tactic which we can now see the disastrous consequences for local populations.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Massacres by violent militias are taking place in the east of the country, particularly in North Kivu province. The humanitarian situation there is alarming. The joint resolution, which I supported, therefore calls for a thorough, transparent and independent investigation by the international community and recalls that there can be no impunity for those responsible for serious human rights violations, war crimes, crimes against humanity, acts of sexual violence against women and girls and the recruitment of child soldiers.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Democratic Republic of Congo has for a long time been facing a very serious situation involving in particular the north-east of the country. Violence, massacres, disappearances and repeated violations of the most basic human rights are now a sad daily occurrence. These are incidents linked to clashes between regional and national policy, the exploitation of ethnic tensions and the exploitation of resources.  The resolution adopted today by Parliament, and supported by me, strongly calls for a cessation of hostilities in the African country and for a thorough, independent and transparent investigation into the massacres, involving actively the UN government and forces on the ground. The peace process must be one of the first stages in holding the free elections provided for in the Constitution at the end of the presidential term.  The European Union has a duty to foster dialogue between african union countries in order to prevent further destabilisation in the Great Lakes area and must provide for the possibility of imposing targeted sanctions, including travel bans and asset freezes, against those responsible for the massacres in eastern Congo.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted to abstain in this resolution because despite condemning recent dramatic events in the Democratic Republic of the Congo it can be considered partial by not addressing the root causes of the current situation of instability, namely the inequality and role of large extractive transnationals in the territory.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. U2012 I support the text of this joint resolution because the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo requires intense and immediate action by the international community and in particular the European Union. Among the key aspects of this pronouncement is my special support for the execution of an investigation by the International Criminal Court on crimes in the Beni region, the possibility of applying selective sanctions including a ban on travel to the EU and the freezing of assets of all those responsible for repression and killings in the democratic republic of The Congo and the call for accountability of European companies operating in the area. I also consider it essential to call for elections and the end of President Kabila's term of office.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this joint resolution on massacres in eastern Congo. Like everyone else, I am sensitive to the security situation of the Congolese, especially with regard to the tragedy of child soldiers, forcibly enlisted in armed groups and sent to massacre.
