It is also tragic that between October 2014 and May 2016 in the territories of Beni, Lubero and Butembo, more than 1,160 people were brutally murdered, with numerous disappearances, destruction of school and medical facilities and sexual violence. However, this European resolution, far from solving the problems, is content with a posture of interference based on sentimentalism which, understandably, is irresponsible in foreign policy. As such, I welcome some of the amendments tabled by the GUE, which underlines in particular that one of the realistic solutions is the need for Congo to regain its sovereignty over its resources and on the responsibility of foreign multinationals in disposing of them.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly condemn the massacres that have persisted for more than 20 years in eastern Congo, I believe that the EU should act firmly to support these populations and restore justice and democracy in this country.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution - an initiative promoted by the Socialist Group - because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and more than because of its supposed status as a "low-voltage" conflict , suffers above all from the "low attention" it receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance whose main objective, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it expresses serious concern about the escalation of violence and the alarming and deteriorating humanitarian situation in the Democratic Republic of congo (DRC), which has been caused in particular by armed conflicts in the eastern provinces, which have been continuing for more than 20 years, regret the loss of lives and express its condolences to the people of the DRC. The resolution calls for the international community to launch a comprehensive, independent and transparent investigation into the massacre and calls for a continuous political dialogue between the countries of the Great Lakes Region in order to prevent further destabilisation. Calls also on the EU to send an observer to assess the humanitarian situation and to draw the attention of the international community to the massacre, to consider targeted sanctions, including travel bans and asset freezes for persons who have been subjected to violent crackdowns in the DRC, and calls on the EU and its Member States to continue to provide support to the people of the DRC. It is recalled that neutralising all armed groups in the region will make a significant contribution to peace and stability and that the EU must pursue a coherent policy in a wide range of areas and promote peace, stability, development and human rights in the negotiations on agreements in the region.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The escalation of violence affecting eastern Congo, with the forced recruitment of children by armed groups and the protracted massacres in large parts of the country, cannot go unnoticed. This is a humanitarian emergency that cannot be ignored if we do not want a new genocide in a region, such as the Great Lakes region, which has long been at the centre of ethnic and territorial tensions, but which has also been the subject of conflicts linked to the exploitation of the many natural resources, especially mining, of which the area is extremely rich.  In the light of this, the European Parliament has today expressed its call for an end to the hostilities and violence still taking place, to call for the restoration of a legal situation and to call on the parties to the conflict to dialogue and to seek a peaceful solution.  In the resolution adopted today, we also stated the need to bring those responsible for human rights violations to justice, in order to counter the climate of substantial inertia and impunity that has facilitated the implementation of further crimes. It is important for the international community to launch a thorough investigation as soon as possible, so as to clarify and ascertain all the responsibilities at stake.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against all the resolutions and abstained on the GUE resolution, which, although it is difficult to follow, among other things, by its recommendations on the family, is by far the most studied and marks a genuine mastery of the issue.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – The initiative put forward by the European Parliament calling for peace in the Congo region was progressive, however, the Joint Motion for a Resolution was not critical enough on the interference of certain countries and companies in destabilising the country.  My Group, GUE/NGL tabled an alternative resolution which was much more critical and got to the root of the issues. However, as the majority of MEPs voted in favour of the Joint Resolution, I did not have an opportunity to endorse this alternative one and therefore, I was left with no choice but to abstain on this resolution.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 There is a risk of further genocide in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The people of Beni province in eastern Congo are the victims of massacres and serious persecutions on which there is still a cape of silence which we Europeans have a political and moral duty to raise. We call on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, to launch an international inquiry into these massacres involving the United Nations and the International Criminal Court. for the EU to send a special representative to the Kivu area to draw up an urgent report to be submitted to the European Parliament and the highest European institutions; France and the United Kingdom to take action on the UN Security Council to adopt a binding resolution to stop these massacres as soon as possible. More than two thousand families have been killed and at least as many have been lost: the international community, present with the UN mission Monusco, cannot stand by inertly. If we do not intervene, the region will be destabilised with new innocent victims and new waves of migrants fleeing to more well-off and safer countries.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Democratic Republic of Congo is currently plagued by serious internal unrest, particularly in the north-east of the country where armed groups are guilty of massacres, murders, sexual violence and kidnappings. This situation is all the more intolerable as the government struggles to act to eradicate these criminal organizations. While we strongly condemn all the abuses committed in this region, we consider that the European Union has no legitimacy and credibility to interfere in the internal affairs of that country. We would also like to point out that foreign policy is an exclusive competence of the Member States. As such, international institutions should play a more consequential role in putting an end to these barbaric practices. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Democratic Republic of the Congo is in an alarming situation. The military and human crisis has caused the deaths of about 5 million people. Children were attacked, women abused, a number of territories in eastern Congo were occupied by armed groups. Various actors estimate that more than 7 million people require assistance and support services. The humanitarian crisis is intensifying, with hundreds of thousands of Congolese forced to leave the country. The vulnerability of the Congolese peaked amid the military crisis, and they needed immediate support. I cannot fail to welcome the efforts made by the Congolese authorities to combat this crisis, but the improvements must be much more visible. Immediate action must be taken against the violation of human rights and freedoms, urgent and political solutions are needed to resolve the crisis in the eastern Republic of Congo in order to establish public security and security and to strengthen peace, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution — an initiative promoted by the Socialist Group — because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and more than because of its supposed status as a "low-voltage" conflict , suffers above all from the "low attention" it receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance whose main objective, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The escalation of violence in the northeastern region of Congo must stop immediately. This country is facing a very alarming humanitarian situation. The local population is the target of unbearable massacres. Its security must be the Congolese government's top priority. There is a need for a thorough investigation by the international community. Those responsible for these massacres must be tried and punished without delay. The stabilization of the country is conditioned by the holding of new elections. The European Union and its Member States must respond to promote peace, stability and respect for human rights. So I voted for this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the massacres in eastern Congo Because the situation in the country has plummeted worryingly in recent months, the chronicles speak of a territory in which blood has returned and this serious situation could have consequences for the entire region. The population is the victim of massacres, documented in the reports of international bodies operating in the area, caused by an invasion by armed gangs that are carrying out a real genocide.  Missionaries and religious, together with the Peace Network for congo, are calling for an international investigation into what is happening in North Kivu, the region bordering Rwanda. Now more than ever, the international community and the European Union need to intervene to put an end to the massacres. We must respond to the appeal of voluntary associations in the area calling for a serious and neutral international inquiry to put an end to this tragedy.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which is concerned with ongoing violence in eastern Congo and calls for action to help end it. Congo has known armed conflicts for a very long time, mostly due to it being a mineral rich country. Although happy with the initiative by the European Parliament to call for peace, the Joint Motion for a Resolution was not critical enough on the interference of certain countries and companies in destabilising the country. My own European political group had tabled an alternative resolution which was much more critical, however as the majority of MEPs voted in favour of the Joint Resolution, I did not have an opportunity to endorse this alternative one.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this resolution as it strongly reaffirms issues that as Europeans we take for granted, namely the fact that businesses’ activities must comply fully with international human rights standards. The DRC is a state with high numbers of vulnerable people, particularly internally displaced ones. I believe that trade could be of benefit to the country by improving its standards of living, resulting in less chance of any massacres in the future.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution firmly condemning and demanding justice in relation to the recent massacres in eastern Congo.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We express our deep concern about the current security and human rights situation in the eastern part of the DRC, which remains extremely unstable, with continuous attacks against the civilian population by the various armed groups.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the massacres in Eastern Congo concerns an issue that concerns us all and we are called upon to deal with it for the benefit of innocent people. The expression of our deep concern about rising tensions and inhumane practices against civilians in this region is the least we can do in an effort to de-escalate tension and end violence. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am deeply concerned about the worsening situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. There is no longer any security in the country, too many people are killed, massacred or forced to join armed groups without any choice. I believe that this situation is wrong and immoral, and although there are armed forces trying to contain this phenomenon, they are not enough. Although hundreds of thousands of people managed to escape the country, thousands more were brutally killed. I believe it is necessary for the European Union and all its Member States to provide assistance to Congo so that this horrific situation can end as quickly as possible.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for resolution on massacres in Eastern Congo.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The Democratic Republic of Congo is currently facing a serious humanitarian and security situation, showing signs of deterioration in the eastern part of the country, where dozens of armed groups carry out massacres and acts of widespread sexual violence and recruitment of children, with an estimated 7.5 million people in need of assistance. I support this Resolution condemning these acts and calling for an end to belligerent violence with a view to a peaceful and sustainable resolution of the conflict and calling on the International Criminal Court to carry out the analysis of these abuses, and those responsible for war crimes, crimes against humanity, recruitment of child soldiers and sexual violence against minors and minors of legal age be identified and punished in accordance with National and International Criminal Law. I also commend attacks on humanitarian officials and blockades of access to humanitarian aid.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote of the joint resolution mainly because it does not recognize genocide, calls for the reinforcement of MOUNSCO and in particular through patrols and mobile operations bases, even if some paragraphs with which I agree call for an assessment, and does not reflect information on the responsibilities of multinationals in the financial support of the conflict and the illegal exploitation of natural resources

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. The north-east of Congo is currently the scene of massacres, recruitment of children into armed groups, sexual violence and arbitrary village occupations. This situation has seriously undermined the minimum level of security of citizens, due to the inability or lack of political will on the part of the Congolese authorities to bring those responsible to justice, under the silence of the national government and the international community. In addition, there is a humanitarian crisis of 7.5 million people in need of assistance, 1.5 million displaced persons as a result of the ongoing conflict and 400 000 refugees.  I voted in favour of this resolution, because it brings international attention to the dramatic situation in eastern Congo and makes a number of demands that I consider important in order to restore peace and justice in the country. These include the call for rapid and active resuming cooperation between MONUSCO and the national armed forces, in particular to ensure greater operational capacity for the protection of civilians; the conduct of a transparent investigation into the massacres committed in cooperation with the international community; and, finally, the full implementation of the Strategic Framework Agreement for the Great Lakes Region, for Peace, Security and Cooperation, of February 2013.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past 20 years, more than 6 million people have lost their lives in the civil conflict in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and the situation continues to worsen, despite the efforts of international organisations. The causes of the persistence of this climate of violence are diverse, including the lack of state institutions that could allow dialogue and increased interethnic cooperation, conflict between paramilitary and armed groups or the struggle of organised crime groups to gain control of numerous natural resources and borders in order to facilitate illicit trafficking. The deterioration of living conditions and the lack of a development in respect for human rights, together with the state of insecurity and uncertainty to which the citizens of that State are subject, indicate the need to increase the importance given to this conflict. I strongly condemn the massacres in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, the recruitment and use of minors in armed struggles, the physical or sexual violence to which children, women and men are subjected, attacks on employees of humanitarian organisations and the silence of the media. The assistance of the European Union must continue, in particular with a view to the development of state institutions and the promotion of inclusive social dialogue, in the context of the organisation of the next presidential elections, which will play a major role in stabilising the political situation.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Violence in eastern Congo is estimated to have killed 1,116 people between October 2014 and May 2016, while a further 1,470 people were abducted and 34,297 families were forcibly displaced or dissassed. These mass murders in eastern Congo are the result of complex links between politics, ethnic divisions and conflicts over the extraction of natural resources. There has been a very serious political tension in the country since President Kabila, who has been in power since 2001 and is constitutionally obliged to step down before the end of the year, is accused of delaying the presidential elections in November this year in order to stay in power for as long as possible. The draft ECR resolution calls on the DRC Government to ensure the safety of all its inhabitants and to resume joint activities within the FARDC and MONUSCO missions in order to neutralise armed groups in eastern Congo. It also calls for an international investigation that can help identify the perpetrators and accomplices and initiators of the massacres. The ECR resolution also renews its call on the DRC authorities to make a clear commitment to the constitutional provisions in order to hold elections in a timely manner at the end of 2016. I fully agree with the resolution's provisions calling for respect for human rights and democratic principles in the DRC, which is why I voted yes.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am very concerned about the reports of widespread massacres, sexual violence and child-soldier recruitment by active armed groups in the north-eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo. These armed groups have allegedly taken the lives of over 1,000 people throughout the territories of Beni, Lubero and Butembo, while a further 1,000 are said to be missing. Furthermore, reports have also suggested that a number of schools, health centres and homes were burnt down during the attacks. For this reason, I voted in favour of this resolution which reiterates the parliament’s call to end the violence in Congo, for all parties to lay down their arms and work towards a peaceful solution and most imperatively, release all child-soldiers from their ranks.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. This resolution and the abuses it denounces still resonate in our Chamber, which regularly draws attention to the plight of child soldiers and the violence of all kinds against civilians in Congo. I am deeply concerned by this humanitarian situation with entire villages occupied by armed groups blocking any possibility of aid. It is very difficult to reconcile peoples and ethnic groups when everyone deplores the violence of the other side. An investigation must take place in order to break the deadlock, inaction and silence, so that justice can be done and those responsible for the massacres are identified and tried. This topic is also economic and commercial, with massacres taking place against a background of resource exploitation and arms trafficking. That is why this resolution calls for the recently agreed European agreement on mandatory blood ore controls to be translated into ambitious, rapidly applicable legislation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it demonstrates a clear ignorance of the situation in Congo. To understand Great Lakes Africa, we must look at the end of the Cold War and the American decision to reinvest this region at the expense of France, with the support of Canadian, British and Israeli diplomats. It is in this context that we must first understand the Rwandan crisis and then the instrumentalization of Rwanda and Uganda to destabilize the DRC today, based on ethnic divides.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against. Although every reasonable person can only condemn the events in Congo, our firm position is not to involve in the internal third states, which we are now following.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Between October 2014 and May 2016, in the territories of Beni, Lubero and Butembo, more than 1160 people were brutally killed, more than 1470 people are missing, many homes, health centres and schools have been burned down and many women, men and children have been victims of sexual violence. Humanitarian officials estimate that 7.5 million people are currently in need of assistance and the ongoing conflict and military operations have also led to the internal displacement of 1.5 million people and forced more than 400,000 to flee the country. I therefore express my deep concern at the escalation of violence and the worrying and increasingly serious humanitarian situation in the DRC, in agreement with the call on the belligerents to put an immediate end to violence, lay down arms, release all the children in their ranks and promote dialogue with a view to a peaceful and sustainable resolution of the conflict.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against all resolutions and abstain on the GUE resolution.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Being worrying and serious the situation in the Democratic Republic of congo (DRC), the intentions of this resolution do not come to signal this concern. This resolution is part of a process of interference and destabilisation of the region, which aims to restore the power and control of the former European colonial powers over the country's immense natural wealth, thereby exploiting the conflicts that exist there, using them in their favor.  The resolution hides the destabilising role of European countries in the DRC, for example Belgium. It is not called responsibility, nor are multinationals attacked and their role in financing armed groups. It has not a single word to condemn NATO's militaristic and interventionist role, nor to strengthen its military presence through Us military command – AFRICOM.  Under criticism of the UN mission – MONUSCO, whose role and intervention must naturally be controlled, is the will to put other forces and perhaps NATO on the ground. It is also aimed at contributing to the destabilization of the political situation of the country as the elections approach.   We advocate the non-proliferation of weapons, the non-militarization of the region, support for a political and peaceful solution to conflicts, the sovereignty of the peoples and the dismantling of AFRICOM.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the massacres in Eastern Congo. The inhumane treatment in Congo is the result of unhealthy interrelationships between politics, ethnic groups and the exploitation of resources. Europe must first commit itself to enforcing the provision of transparent and credible presidential elections by 2016, in order to eliminate further political tensions. The European Union must commit itself to carrying out an international investigation which will help to identify those responsible for, the accomplices and the instigators of these crimes against humanity and the human rights violations suffered by the people of that country.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The ongoing humanitarian and military crises in Congo have already caused the deaths of around five million people. The European Parliament is deeply concerned about the current security and human rights situation in eastern Congo, which remains very unstable, with constant attacks against the civilian population by various armed groups. The government in Congo must take responsibility for guaranteeing security on its territory and ensuring the protection of its citizens, as a result of which the responsible authorities must take all necessary decisions and measures to end the armed conflict.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against all the reports. Although every reasonable person can only condemn the events in Congo, my firm position is not to involve in the internal affairs of third states, which I am following now.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I am extremely concerned by the deteriorating security situation in the north-eastern part of the Democratic republic of Congo, by the numerous reports of massacres, recruitment and use of children by armed groups and widespread violence.  I strongly support the call on the DRC government and the the ONU Peacekeeping mission MONUSCO to conduct an investigation on the failures of the Congolese and MONUSCO forces to protect civilians in the region of Beni. A thorough, independent and transparent investigation to be launched by the international community into the massacres is urgently needed, in order to find out who is behind these attacks beside the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF).  The neutralisation of all armed groups, safety for all citizens and stability in the territories of Beni, Lubero and Butembo has to be our priority. Perpetrators of human rights violations, war crimes, crimes against humanity and sexual violence must be reported, identified, prosecuted and punished in accordance with national and international criminal law.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution — promoted by the Socialist Group — because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). More than his supposed "low-voltage" conflict status, he suffers mainly from the "low attention" he receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance, the main objective of which, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is sending a strong message condemning the massacres and crimes against humanity that continue to rage in eastern Congo and supports with the same conviction the motion for a resolution calling for the smooth, free and transparent conduct of the next presidential elections, so that stability and the reconstruction of the rule of law can affect a path of democratic recomposition of the country. , managing to counter the criminal activities of armed groups.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. We are constantly getting sick news from the resource-rich east of Congo: there are reports of new, horrific massacres. In the Beni region, for example, in North Kivu, 50 civilians were killed in another carnage a few days ago. Up to 1,000 people have been killed in the past 18 months. The ADF, an Islamist unit from Uganda with links to al-Shabaab in Somalia, is blamed for this. Europe must help put an end to these atrocities. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted to abstain in this resolution because despite condemning recent dramatic events in the Democratic Republic of the Congo it can be considered partial by not addressing the root causes of the current situation of instability, namely the inequality and role of large extractive transnationals in the territory.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution — an initiative promoted by the Socialist Group — because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and more than because of its supposed status as a "low-voltage" conflict , suffers above all from the "low attention" it receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance whose main objective, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour for the report. The report declares that President Kabila, who has been in power since 2001, is required to step down on 20 December 2016 as the mandate of the President of the DRC is limited under the Congolese Constitution to only two terms. By not yet having declared that he will do so, he is exacerbating political tensions in the country.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution — an initiative promoted by the Socialist Group — because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and more than because of its supposed status as a "low-voltage" conflict , suffers above all from the "low attention" it receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance whose main objective, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 As a group we have taken a position of abstention in the joint resolution, because we believe that the resolution tabled by our group is more complete. In any case, we consider the situation in eastern Congo to be very serious and needs to be addressed by the international community.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am deeply concerned the regarding the escalation of violence and the alarming and deteriorating humanitarian situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. An independent and transparent investigation should be launched in order to assess the human rights violations and war crimes. The European Union should work closely with the African Union to ensure a permanent political dialogue in order to prevent any further destabilisation of the region. I welcome the any effort to implement and maintain peace in the region on the part of the Congolese Authorities.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Dear Fellow Members, The decades-long civil war unfolding in eastern Congo is now Africa's worst armed conflict. The wave of unresisted killings and violence also has a dramatic impact on the lives of Christian churches, which make up the majority of the population. One of the region's most powerful militias, the International Muslim Defense Force, is particularly ruthless in its use of Christian denominations and churches in the eastern Congo region. In this place, too, we must repeat the desperate cry for help of the Christian denominations in Congo: like many places around the world, the extremist followers of Islam are committing genocide in Africa. The aggression of the Muslim Defence Force fits well with the overarching Islamist advance that has unfolded in many parts of Africa. Militias that follow the ideology of international jihadist movements aim to proclaim Caliphate under Islamic law across the continent in countries with significant Christian traditions. The latest atrocities and executions in May have forced thousands of families to flee eastern Congo, but religious leaders are trying to hold on to the severely traumatised faithful to the end. The survival of communities is made more difficult by the fact that the constant intimidation has led to the end of ceremonies in churches of Catholic, Anglican and other Christian denominations. The international community, such as Europe, has a moral obligation to exert immediate political pressure for peace in congo. While the persecution is ongoing, all available humanitarian and development resources must be mobilised to prevent another wave of refugees.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on massacres in eastern Congo, as the international community and the DRC government have not done enough to condemn and combat the deteriorating security situation in the northeastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo, where armed groups continue to operate and numerous massacres, recruitment of children to armed groups and sexual and gender-based violence have been reported. The EU should consider imposing targeted sanctions on those responsible for massacres in eastern Congo and violent repression in the DRC. The EU should continue to provide assistance to the DRC population to improve the living conditions of the most vulnerable populations, in particular internally displaced persons. The international community needs to urgently launch a thorough, independent and transparent investigation into the massacre.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The resolutions follow an increase in abuses in Congo. With the exception of the GUE resolution, the resolutions are marked by a clear ignorance of what is happening in Congo. Indeed, to understand the situation of Africa in the Great Lakes, we must refer to the end of the Cold War and the American decision to reinvest this reason at the expense of France with the support of Canadian, British and Israeli diplomats. It is in this context that we must first understand the Rwandan crisis and then the use of Rwanda and Uganda to destabilize the DRC today on the basis of ethnic divides. I voted against the resolutions.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported a joint resolution responding to the worrying escalation of violence and the deteriorating humanitarian situation in the Democratic Republic of congo caused in particular by long-standing armed conflicts in the eastern provinces. Parliament calls on all parties to the conflict to put an immediate end to the violence and to establish a dialogue towards a peaceful solution to the situation. At the same time, it urges a thorough, independent and transparent investigation into the massacres with full cooperation from the DRC. However, this situation should not hinder the holding of the planned elections precisely because the successful and timely holding of elections will be crucial for the long-term stability and development of the country.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which denounces the recurrent massacres taking place in eastern Congo, where Ugandan rebels and the Congolese army oppose each other.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the motion as it addresses an issue of the utmost importance for the people of Congo. Should the Council and the Commission act upon what we ask them to do, we will witness a change benefiting the lives of the locals.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the joint motion for a resolution on massacres in eastern Congo. It has not expressed its concern about the increase in actions that destabilise the situation and constitute joint interference by various governments and multinational enterprises in the affairs of several countries on the African continent. It did not condemn the fact that the basic needs of the people of the Democratic Republic of congo are systematically sacrificed to the economic and geopolitical interests of multinational supranational companies and foreign powers. It did not call for an independent investigation into how businesses, in particular European ones, comply with social and environmental standards in the natural resources sector and what links they may have to the financing of armed groups, nor did it call for an international investigation to be launched to shed light on alleged links between structural change programmes, financial subsidies from international financial institutions and crimes committed in that country. We criticize governments all the time, but we often don't dare corporations, even if they are the ones who often do the most harm in Africa. Congo is a very clear example.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The security situation in the Eastern Congo is a matter of great concern. Unfortunately, the armed conflicts in the eastern provinces of Beni, Butembo and Lubero have been continuing with numerous reports of massacres, recruitment and use of children by armed groups, widespread of sexual and gender violence. There also reports of destruction of many houses, health centres and schools as well as violent attacks against local and international staff of humanitarian actors working in the region. It is a disturbing fact that the escalation of violence has often occurred in front of the eyes of Congolese army and MONUSCO which are present in the region to maintain stability, fight the armed forces and protect civilians. Given the risk of further destabilisation in the Eastern Congo, the EU should actively work with the Congolese authorities and the UN mission in the country (MONUSCO) to protect the civilian population, to neutralise the armed groups, to identify those responsible for the violence and to bring them to justice. Last but not least, the EU should maintain its assistance to the people of the DRC in order to improve the living conditions of the most vulnerable sections of the population.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because despite some good passages, notably on the role of multinationals, it interferes in congo's internal affairs.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the massacres in eastern Congo. This follows an increase in abuses committed on the ground, but shows a clear ignorance of what is happening in Congo. Indeed, to understand the situation of Africa of the Great Lakes, we must refer to the end of the Cold War to the American decision to reinvest this region at the expense of France. It is in this context that we must first understand the Rwandan crisis and then the use of Rwanda as Well as Uganda to destabilize the DRC today, based on ethnic divides.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome Parliament's motion for a resolution on the massacres in eastern Congo. The proposal condemns the acts of violence suffered by communities in the region. It expresses solidarity with these populations, which have been violated for years and cause a division of the population, and stresses the urgent need to focus on the circumstances of women and children, who are the most vulnerable groups. It also called for an international investigation to find those responsible, for all necessary measures to be taken to put an end to the genocide, and for compensation to be paid to the victims of the massacres. Furthermore, it explains that only by implementing a regulation on the management of natural resources will the conflict be able to end, and therefore calls for swift cooperation with the Council on the ratification of these rules. In order to help promote a more united and equitable world, I am voting in favour of Parliament's proposal.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The texts put to the vote by the various political parties in Parliament deal with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The context is particularly tense, the massacres multiply and tear the population apart. This situation is the result of the Post-Cold War U.S. policy supported by Canada, England and Israel to destabilize the DRC. It relied on Uganda and Rwanda as destabilizing elements, emphasizing the ethnic divides already present in the country, which is producing the current massacres. The proposals for a resolution of the political parties ignore this essential historical causality, so I vote AGAINST. However, the GUE/NGL report is distinguished by the mastery of the subject, but its proposals on the family tarnish it which prompted me to THE ABSTENTION on the latter.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution — an initiative promoted by the Socialist Group — because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and more than because of its supposed status as a "low-voltage" conflict , suffers above all from the "low attention" it receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance whose main objective, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote of the joint resolution mainly because it does not recognize genocide, calls for the reinforcement of MOUNSCO and in particular through patrols and mobile operations bases, even if some paragraphs with which I agree call for an assessment, and does not reflect information on the responsibilities of multinationals in the financial support of the conflict and the illegal exploitation of natural resources

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I am sorry that there is violence in congo, but the European Parliament resolution will not change the situation. I do not think it is the task of the European Parliament to adopt resolutions on all conflicts in the world.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. Although the Second Congolese Civil War ended in 2003, there are still a number of groups in the eastern part of the country, whose hostilities between and against government forces often include neighbouring countries, particularly Uganda. Between October 2014 and May 2016, 1,160 people were killed in border areas, while another 1,470 were missing. Several homes, hospitals and schools were burned down. Sexual violence, especially against women and children, and actual slavery are widespread. What is more, there is information that not only rebel armed groups, but also the country's military forces, often take part in these vows. In the territory of the Democratic Republic of Congo, some 7.5 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, more than 400 thousand have fled the country. Since the series of conflicts has existed in the region for some 20 years, at least one generation has been growing in its conditions and knows only war and violence. I join in calling on the Government of the DRC and all other parties to the conflict (in particular regional governments, neighbours of the DRC and African Union bodies) to put an end to the ongoing violence as closely as possible. In parallel, I congratulate the efforts to minimise the financial support of illegal groups through the trade in conflict minerals.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 I condemn all attacks on humanitarian workers and obstacles to access to humanitarian aid. Both sides must respect the independence, neutrality and impartiality of humanitarian workers. I support the proposal that the European Union should use all diplomatic and commercial efforts to achieve and ensure internal stability in the Congo, the establishment and development of democracy and the rule of law, and help to eradicate corruption and the illegal trade in the country's mineral wealth through development cooperation policies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the joint motion for a resolution on massacres in eastern Congo for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 22/6/2016 and because this report is well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against all resolutions.  All of these resolutions reflect a profound lack of awareness of the geostrategic situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The destabilization of this great African state is largely due to American influence, via Rwanda and Uganda. Given this lacking mastery of the subject, we cannot support these texts.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. From this Parliament, we strongly condemn the massacres and crimes against humanity that continue to be committed in the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is necessary that the criminal activities of all armed groups be put to an end at once without exception in the eastern region of the country and that the situation of democratic control should be recovered in that country, for which both the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the international institutions that must ensure peace in that region must intervene. In addition, MEPs have asked, with my support, for the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court to also investigate the atrocities in North Kivu since October 2014, and to prosecute the most clearly held persons of responsibility.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The proposals for a resolution by the various groups indicate their ignorance of reality, with the exception of that of the GUE group. To understand the situation in Africa in the Great Lakes region, we must refer to U.S. decisions to reinvest these decolonized regions. This was done at the expense of France with the support of the Anglo-Saxon powers of Canada and the United Kingdom. It is in this context that we must understand the instability created in these regions and the crisis in Rwanda, and then its use as well as that of Uganda to destabilize the Democratic Republic of Congo. As a result I voted against the motions for resolutions and abstained on that of the GUE which cannot be followed for its recommendations on the family

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. Security in the DRC continues to deteriorate in the eastern part of the country, where dozens of armed groups remain active, with many reports reporting massacres, recruitment and use of children by armed groups, widespread sexual violence and gender-based violence.  Therefore, the international community as a whole must endeatry to find a peaceful solution to this serious conflict with serious consequences for the populations, particularly the most unprotected - women, the elderly and children.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as a matter of human rights. The institutions of the European Union must recognise and formulate a proper response to the violence currently occurring in the Congo, and call for peace and the immediate end of all armed aggression in the area.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. As Koffi Annan said in 2003, "Democracy is more than just elections. It requires that everyone, including the government and the ruling party, respect the rule of law. It requires viable institutions that guarantee the fundamental rights of all citizens, including minorities. It requires the constant vigilance of a vibrant civil society." Increasing restrictions on freedom of expression and political freedoms are limiting the capacity of civil society, the media and the opposition to act. Any restriction of democratic space and political participation is not tolerable. Inter-Congolese dialogue must be part of the constitution. It must be in line with UN Resolution 2277, namely open, unifying and democratic; this is the path favoured by the international community (African Union and the European Union). Action must be developed to prevent this latent crisis, in a tense pre-election climate, from leading to violence threatening the stability of the country and the sub-region and turning into a security crisis.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Conflict between various Congolese and foreign militias has persisted in the north-eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo for more than 20 years. The region was marred by massacres around the towns of Beni, Butembo, Miriki and Lubero in North Kivu province in October 2015, which claimed many victims and forced tens of thousands to flee their homes. I consider the greatest problem to be the absence of legislative or judicial institutions that can function effectively and deal with the situation that has arises. One of the other problems is the fact that President Kabila is trying to stay in power even after a constitutionally determined term of office, which could provoke violence on a much larger scale than in Burundi, which would destabilise the entire Great Lakes region. I believe that free, transparent and fair elections could contribute to ending the ongoing crisis in eastern Congo, allow for closer scrutiny of agreements relating to the extraction of mineral resources and the misuse of income derived from this activity, thereby improving the human rights situation in Congo. I therefore support the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on the massacres in eastern Congo, which highlights that the security situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo continues to deteriorate in the north-eastern part of the country, where dozens of armed groups remain active, with numerous reports of massacres, of recruitment and use of children by armed groups, and of widespread sexual and gender‑based violence. The resolution calls for all parties to the conflict to put an immediate end to the violence, lay down their arms, release all children from their ranks and promote dialogue towards a peaceful and sustainable resolution of the conflict. It also calls notably for quick and active resumption of collaboration between MONUSCO and the RDC armed forces (FARDC), on the basis of the military cooperation agreement signed on 28 January in Kinshasa, in order to re-establish and consolidate peace and security in both the eastern area and the country as a whole

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 A motion for a resolution was tabled by the ECR, PPE, S&D, GUE/NGL, EFDD, Verts/ALE and ALDE groups on the subject indicated. With the exception of the GUE/NGL, the other six groups reached an agreement and adopted a joint compromise motion. That's what I voted for.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. In 2013, the Congolese army controlled the rebel group designated m23, casting the hope that the environment of insecurity in eastern Congo would evolve towards pacification. Nevertheless, several armed groups remained active, so the environment of insecurity, ethnic and political divisions and conflicts in the mining sector remains. Recently, radical groups have committed several human rights violations, including massacres of civilians and the abduction of collaborators from humanitarian aid organizations.  The EU provides humanitarian aid to the Democratic Republic of Congo and, in this context, must use its influence to promote permanent political dialogue, both with the other international institutions accompanying this situation, and with the countries of this region and the Congolese authorities, in order to put an end to situations of violation of human rights, crimes against humanity, and to restore peace and security in the region. In this regard, I am voting in favour of this report, as I believe it is important for the European Union to play an active role in respectfor human rights and in the political pacification and stabilisation of this region.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Most of the resolutions presented here are marked by a clear ignorance of what is happening in Congo. Indeed, to understand the situation of Africa in the Great Lakes, we must refer to the end of the Cold War to the American decision to reinvest this reason at the expense of France with the support of Canadian, British and Israeli diplomats. It is in this context that we must first understand the Rwandan crisis and then the use of Rwanda and Uganda to destabilize the DRC today on the basis of ethnic divides.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on massacres in eastern Congo, which calls on the parties to the conflict to stop the violence and dialogue. Between October 2014 and May 2016, more than 1,160 people were murdered and more than 1,470 disappeared.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Democratic Republic of Congo now faces serious problems, the main cause of which is the humanitarian catastrophe in the eastern part of the country. Radical armed groups persecute and humiliate thousands of people who are forced to flee their homes as a result. As stated in the resolution, respect for human rights is paramount. We can't stay silent. Violence must stop, and I believe that the creation of stability in the region depends largely on fair action by state power. The stakes of the upcoming elections are to establish the constitutional rule of law, hold perpetrators accountable and stop hatred. I support the European Union in continuing to help this already suffering country.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The security situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo continues to deteriorate in the north-eastern part of the country, where dozens of armed groups remain active, with numerous reports of massacres, of recruitment and use of children by armed groups, and of widespread sexual and gender-based violence. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls for all parties to the conflict to put an immediate end to the violence, lay down their arms, release all children from their ranks and promote dialogue towards a peaceful and sustainable resolution of the conflict.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Parliament's motion for a resolution on the massacres in eastern Congo. In view of the worrying deterioration of the situation in the country, the international community needs to take appropriate measures. It is therefore right that Parliament has supported safeguards already in place in the country, such as THE UN MONUSCO mission, and has called on international organisations and states to do more to address the situation.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – The initiative put forward by the European Parliament calling for peace in the Congo region was progressive, however, the Joint Motion for a Resolution was not critical enough on the interference of certain countries and companies in destabilising the country.  My Group, GUE/NGL tabled an alternative resolution which was much more critical and got to the root of the issues. However, as the majority of MEPs voted in favour of the Joint Resolution, I did not have an opportunity to endorse this alternative one and therefore, I was left with no choice but to abstain on this resolution.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution.  As the security situation in the north-east of the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to deteriorate, appropriate measures were necessary. It is essential that all relevant authorities take immediate action to bring the perpetrators to justice. Urgent action is needed to stabilise the situation and guarantee human rights in eastern Congo and to properly implement the principles of legality and impunity. All armed groups must be stopped immediately.  It needs to be noted that the current situation should not prevent elections as provided for in the Constitution. It is also essential that the international community takes action and launches a thorough, independent and transparent investigation into the massacre.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The escalation of violence in eastern Congo has serious political, economic, social, humanitarian security implications in the Democratic Republic of Congo and throughout the region, which is already fragile and unstable. The region continues to be plagued by the presence of dozens of armed groups competing for gold, tin and tantalon stocks. The accounts of the wars are millions dead and impoverished mainly by hunger and outbreaks of disease. The humanitarian situation in the region is tragic. Millions of internally displaced people, millions of people in need of food and emergency aid. Anger is caused by the massive increase in forced recruitment of children in the fierce fighting raging in eastern Congo and the widespread use of rape as a weapon of war. I supported the motion for a resolution which, among other things, calls on all parties involved to put an end to violence by promoting dialogue to find a sustainable, structural and peaceful political solution to the crisis. It is also important to carry out impartial investigations into all past and present cases of human rights violations and to prosecute and punish perpetrators of human rights violations, war crimes, crimes against humanity, acts of sexual violence against women and the recruitment of children.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Highlighting how in the Democratic Republic of Congo there are more and more armed groups operating in the north-east of the country, it is noted that the number of massacres, rapes and recruitment of minors is increasing. In this respect, aid workers estimate that 7.5 million people currently need assistance. Therefore, I cannot but support the request made in this document to neutralise these groups and, at the same time, to carry out an in-depth analysis on this issue. In calling for more protection for the civilian population, I support the vision of my group. I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Thousands of people have been massacred in Bunia, north-eastern Congo, as part of the long-running civil war in the country. This violence and the alarming and deteriorating humanitarian situation have to be stopped. I urge for a peaceful resolution of the conflict and I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Congo is a country that has been unadjusted for decades by conflicts wreaking havoc on it, primarily due to its natural resources (ores, forests, oil fields...). Because it is rich in coltan, a black metal used in the manufacture of numerous electronic devices, but also other natural riches, wars to date have caused the deaths of more than 5 million people.  I supported the resolution on massacres in East Congo because basic human rights are shamefully violated in that country on a daily basis and we are obliged to act on it. An average of 60 people lose their lives in one month, some people are even burned alive, more than 30,000 people have been forcibly displaced, many villages have been occupied and many women and children have been raped. The value of human life in the East Congo has been reduced to an all-time low, and material benefit is a motive for the rebels to ravage this country to the limit.  Therefore, we are obliged to engage and specifically help these unfortunate people, in which the adoption of this resolution is only the first step. Eastern Congo has been tormented by years of warfare and will hardly become a country of peace again, but all the world's institutions must engage effectively so that the horrors committed are no longer ignored and the suffering of the people of East Congo will finally end.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Reports of massacres and violence from the north-east of the Democratic Republic of Congo are increasingly alarming. The killing and abduction of thousands of people, village fires, health centres and schools, sexual violence against women and children and the forced recruitment of children continue to take place in a climate of impunity and general indifference on the part of the media, the national government and international organisations. I join the resolution's call for an immediate end to the violence between all parties to the conflict, laying down their arms and opening dialogue for a peaceful and lasting solution to the conflict. I call on the UNITED Nations contingent, MONUSCO, to make full use of its mandate to protect the civilian population.  And, finally, I call on the European Union to adopt coherent policies in the region, in particular with regard to the trade in arms and raw materials, with a view to promoting peace, stability, development and human rights.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The security situation in the Democratic Republic of congo continues to deteriorate, especially in the northeastern part of the country. News of massacres, recruitment and use of children by armed gangs and widespread sexual violence is coming from the country. In the areas of Beni, Luber and Butembo more than 1,160 people were savagely killed between October 2014 and May 2016, more than 1,470 people were missing, many houses, health centers and schools were burned. A large number of women, children and men have fallen victim to sexual violence. The current conflict and military operations have forced 1.5 million people to relocate within the country, as well as 500,000 people to move out of the country. I am saddened by the fact that these terrible events are accompanied by silence by the international community and the media. I express my deep concern at the escalating violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the alarming humanitarian situation created by the armed conflict in the eastern provinces that has been going on for more than 20 years. I believe that such a situation must not affect the holding of democratic elections within the foreseen constitutional deadline.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I unequivocally supported this resolution as I am deeply concerned about the situation in the Democratic Republic of congo. In 20 years of conflict, thousands of lives have been measured, and sexual and other violence against women and children occurs daily. On 28 January, military cooperation agreements were signed in Kinshasa between MONUSCO and the DRC (FARDC) armed forces in order to restore and consolidate peace and security in the eastern region and throughout the country, but this agreement is not respected. Cooperation must be restored as a speed in order to neutralise all armed groups, which, moreover, often abuse children to fight in their ranks. Elections must be held as soon as possible, which are a prerequisite for the further functioning of the country.  I believe that the European Union has not yet exhausted all possibilities to help resolve the conflict, in particular through enhanced cooperation with the African Union, support for civil society, trade in arms and raw materials, but also in supporting the DRC Government in the application of legislation prohibiting trade in and processing of minerals in areas where illegal extraction (so-called conflict minerals) takes place. In particular, in the last, we must do much more, in particular to translate the European arrangement on mandatory controls on suppliers of conflict minerals into legislation that needs to be adopted urgently.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo is worrying. Several armed groups recruit and use children and there are numerous reports of massacres in the country. We are facing an escalation of violence and an alarming humanitarian situation. We must therefore put an end to the violence and promote dialogue for a peaceful solution, involving the international community in organising an emergency meeting in order to ensure transparency in the elections, which will be crucial for the long-term stability and development of the country. For all this, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's efforts to draw attention to the tragic situation in eastern Congo. This conflict, which is rightly compared to world wars, deserves not only attention, but above all an effort to end it and help the victims of violence in this part of the world. In particular, the EU must put real pressure on the Government of the DRAs to try to really address the crisis.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The situation in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) is extremely worrying as it is marked by ongoing violence between armed groups and widespread impunity. This situation must be fought forcefully so that order and peace will enable the country to quickly return to the path of stability.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation of insecurity in the east of the Democratic Republic of congo is today - as it is, moreover, for several decades - deeply alarming.  In eastern provinces, armed conflicts, which have lasted for more than 20 years, have been escalating, with reports of massacres, recruitment of children, discrimination on the basis of sex and widespread sexual violence frequent. Regarded as the bloodiest conflict since World War II, the persistent humanitarian and military crisis in the Democratic Republic of Congo has already claimed the lives of some 5 million people.  In fact, I sentence all those responsible for those conflicts and stress the importance of proceedings aimed at their denunciation and punishment in accordance with the rules of National and International Criminal Law. I also note that attacks on officials of humanitarian organizations, which excel in the imperatives of independence, neutrality and impartiality, are truly regrettable. As far as this common resolution is to be exposed, and I stress the importance of the European Union and its Member States maintaining assistance to the people of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported this resolution calling for an end to the massacres in eastern Congo. The security situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to deteriorate in the north-east of the country due to armed conflicts that have lasted for more than 20 years. The abuses committed by armed groups are intolerable: massacres, recruitment and use of children, and sexual violence. The humanitarian situation, already alarming, is also deteriorating and the increase in abductions, attacks and attacks on humanitarian workers is delaying the delivery of aid.  In the face of this situation, the inaction and silence of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo and the media, as well as the indifference of the international community, are unacceptable. All parties are called to end conflict and violence, lay down their arms, free all children and promote dialogue. The perpetrators of human rights violations must be brought to justice and the international community should launch a thorough, independent and transparent investigation. Finally, let us remember the need for the elections to be conducted and to be held on time.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution — an initiative promoted by the Socialist Group — because I believe that the international community, and in particular the European Union, must do much more in the face of a conflict like the one that has continued to affect, for decades, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and more than because of its supposed status as a "low-voltage" conflict , suffers above all from the "low attention" it receives from the rest of the world.  Over the past 20 years, this conflict has caused six million dead at the hands of multiple armed groups that engage in brutal violence on civilians. Hundreds of women and girls are raped every day. The massacres of civilians have become routine, as part of an inter-ethnic struggle and the dispute over control of the region's abundant natural resources. In this resolution we call on the High Representative to encourage an international investigation into the latest massacres in the Beni area, in collaboration with the UN and the International Criminal Court. We also call for an evaluation of MONUSCO's performance whose main objective, the protection of civilians, must be strengthened.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The text of the resolution, adopted by the European Parliament, aims to raise awareness among the international community and the silent media, while between October 2014 and May 2016, more than 1,160 people were brutally murdered in Beni, Lubero and Butembo, more than 1,470 people disappeared, many houses, clinics and schools were burned and many women burned and many women burned. , men and children have been victims of sexual violence. We called on all parties to the conflict to immediately cease violence, to lay down their arms, to release all the children who serve in their ranks. We also called for the rapid and active resumption of cooperation between Monusco and the Congolese armed forces on the basis of the military cooperation agreement reached on 28 January. The voted text calls on the Congolese authorities to make the neutralization of all armed groups in the region a priority, to ensure the safety of all citizens and to restore stability. In addition, a thorough, independent and transparent investigation into the killings was called for by the international community and for the group of envoys and international representatives for the Great Lakes region to meet urgently.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. In the heart of Africa, congo, continued violence often pales closer to europe in the context of military conflicts. Nevertheless, we Europeans must do our utmos to bring peace and stability to one of Africa's largest countries. This would also contribute to the formation of stability across the continent. We cannot allow Islam or other extremists to continue to rage in Congo, human rights are being violated, and the backstage trade in fossils in the pockets of war criminals is being investigated.  At the same time, we must enable africans themselves to become masters of their destiny. We must promote joint efforts by African Union countries to resolve conflicts and ensure peace.  I am therefore voting in favour of this resolution and I call on my colleagues to support it. I would say even more: the draft resolution could have focused more on supporting the efforts of Africans themselves – Congolese and neighbouring countries – to cope in their own backyard.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The climate of civil war by armed groups in eastern Congo remains extremely worrying, with recruitment and use of children for war scenarios and systematic sexual violence among vulnerable population groups. It is important that the European Parliament expresses its strong repudiation of these atrocities and expresses a deep sense of solidarity with the Congolese people, giving a clear signal that it is monitoring this catastrophic humanitarian situation closely and with high concern. The International Criminal Court should carry out investigations into the existence of abuses and examine the need to carry out an inquiry into the crimes allegedly perpetrated. For its part, the EU must adopt a coherent policy on trade in arms and raw materials, while also ensuring that negotiations on agreements in this region are consistent with the values of peace, stability, development and human rights. It should also consider the possibility of imposing sanctions on those responsible for these massacres in eastern Congo.  Because I believe that we are facing the most serious and essential human rights and because I endorse the content of the measures contained in this motion for a resolution, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the massacres taking place in eastern Congo. It calls on all parties to end violence, lay down their arms, free all children from their ranks and promote dialogue towards a peaceful solution. The Democratic Republic of Congo is experiencing an unprecedented escalation of violence and an alarming humanitarian situation. Today, dozens of armed groups remain active, recruiting and using children, with numerous reported massacres.  In order to ensure the return of stability in Congo, there is an urgent need to end this violence and to hold democratic elections in December 2016.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution tabled by the PPE, S&D, ECR, ALDE, Greens and EFDD Groups on the massacres in eastern Congo. The European Parliament is concerned about the recent events which have shaken the country, which has become the scene, particularly in the north-east, of massacres against the civilian population by factions belonging to different ethnic groups. In the face of increasing violence, total denial of human rights and consequent political instability, the agencies on the ground have sounded the alarm.  It should be remembered that the European Union is an important player in the region, as the EU is one of the main providers of humanitarian aid to the Democratic Republic of Congo. Europe-funded cooperation programmes in the country focus mainly on infrastructure and better governance, while through CSDP missions the EU aims to strengthen the security sector. In this state of alarm, I support a stronger intervention in the country aimed at putting an end to the current massacres and restoring a climate of peace and security.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted to abstain in this resolution because despite condemning recent dramatic events in the Democratic Republic of the Congo it can be considered partial by not addressing the root causes of the current situation of instability, namely the inequality and role of large extractive transnationals in the territory.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution on the worrying situation in Congo. Lately, there has been an escalation of violence, which has led to the deteriorating humanitarian situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The humanitarian crisis is mainly caused by armed conflicts in the eastern provinces of the country, which have been going on for more than 20 years. Unfortunately, too many human lives are paid tribute in this interminable conflict and today, with this vote, I wish to express my solidarity with the people of the DRC. I call on the EU and its Member States to maintain their assistance measures for the drC residents in order to improve the living conditions of the most vulnerable segments of the population, especially internally displaced persons. At the same time, I would like to condemn any attack against personnel involved in humanitarian actions, as well as the prevention of access to the rescue of lives or the distribution of humanitarian aid.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing.
