There is a need to improve the quality of education and training systems so that there are opportunities for all, especially vulnerable groups. We need the involvement of all actors in the long-term learning/preparation process. Good governance and close cooperation between Member States are key elements in achieving these objectives.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 European cooperation in vocational education and training is voluntary, but a strategic framework sets out the objectives to be achieved by 2020. This framework structures communication in the field of education between Member States at European Union level. In this context, the report at issue provides for a detailed work programme and benchmarks approved in successive documents between 2001 and 2003. I believe that vocational education and training should not only be aimed at meeting the needs of the labour market, but should be a value in itself, because education plays an important role in the development of civic and ethical virtues. For this reason, I support with my vote the recommendations set out in the report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The intensification of intra-European mobility and the current refugee crisis have placed national education and training systems in the face of major challenges. Today's classrooms are more heterogeneous than ever and include students who need additional help to adapt to new curricula, academic requirements, teaching methods and often also new languages and cultural norms. Teachers need additional support, at the beginning of their training and throughout their careers, through continuous professional development courses, so that they can teach immigrant children effectively, to facilitate their integration into the host society while encouraging them to preserve and maintain their cultural heritage. There is an urgent need to agree on measures at national and European level, also within the framework of ET2020, in the area of education and training for adult asylum seekers who have recently arrived in Europe. Education is the key to integration and employability, and if national systems are unable to meet this challenge, it risks exacerbating social divisions and cultural segregation and thus reinforcing the already latent emergence of parallel societies.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Faced with high youth unemployment and the new challenges of migration, it is essential to rethink our take on European cooperation in education and training. That is why I voted in favour of improving the Strategic Framework for European cooperation in Education and Training 2020 (ET2020), which is an umbrella for all EU-level policy exchanges on education and training between EU countries. It is important that we enhance the quality of education and training by extending cooperation with more stakeholders from civil society, by ensuring coherent, transparent and inclusive education for a diverse group of learners, and by promoting a new agenda for adult learning. This is also an opportunity to reiterate the importance of creating access for migrants to language courses, basic skills training and higher education, in order to facilitate their integration into society and the labour market. Finally, better cooperation between EU Member States would certainly be very helpful in establishing new, innovative and interactive methods of teaching, training and learning.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. At a time of high youth unemployment, which also affects graduates, the most important step is to assess the European ET2020 framework with a view to increasing its added value and optimising its effectiveness. I therefore supported the motion for a resolution to continue the strategic framework for European cooperation in the field of education and training. The resolution contains a set of political priorities and positive recommendations.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. In 2014, the Commission took stock of the education and training strategy, ET 2020, in cooperation with Member States. On the basis of the conclusions of the resulting report, the Commission set priorities for the period 2016–2020. While these priorities address unquestionable aspects such as inclusive education, equality, equity, non-discrimination, civic competences, well-being, social cohesion, intercultural dialogue, innovation and support for teaching, they remain a wrap with which to prestige a neoliberal conception of education and training. The Krasnodebski report, in line with the Commission, does not hide the conversion of education and training into business, and guides them to employability rather than knowledge development. It is necessary to recognize the inclusion in the report of aspects such as the reception in this area of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, as well as the gender perspective. However, these necessary inclusions should not pay the toll on the commodization of education; that's why we voted against it.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The own-initiative report analyses the strategic framework of "Education and Training 2020".  Each EU country is responsible for its own education and training systems, as this is not a core competence of the EU. The role of EU policies is to support national actions and help address common challenges. This report is basically about evaluating the Education and Training 2020 framework and making recommendations at the level of cooperation, quality and efficiency. Countries receive advice and support for political reforms. The ALFA agrees with the core content of this report and supports a large number of the improvements mentioned in the report. All that should be mentioned here are better communication, better quality of education, support and further development of teachers, recognition of qualifications and integration of migrants entitled to reside in our education systems. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report. However, if the European Commission were to launch a draft law on this matter in the future, I will weigh much more critically whether this is not an attempt to impose common rules on the Member States.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Education should contribute not only to young people’s acquisition of professional skills but also to their personal development and growth. I see only positive outcomes in this regard, as are explained in the resolution. That is why I support it, and I would urge that the ET2020 Strategic Framework be promptly implemented in order to optimise its effectiveness.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. I preferred the abstention on this report because if it tries to strike a balance between the work of the European institutions and respect for national competences in education, it unfortunately remains a promotion of the European model of migrant integration.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 A summary evaluation of the Education and Training 2020 framework was prepared by the Commission in 2014 in cooperation with the Member States. Stakeholders have made a number of recommendations to the Commission and the Council in order to increase the added value of the framework and optimise its effectiveness. The role of informal governing bodies has been strengthened and feedback loops have been put in place between working groups, DGs or high-level groups. Some Member States should improve the way they interact with formal and informal organisations by sending the right person to the right meeting and making the least use of substitution. I voted to follow S&D's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. In 2014, the Commission took stock of the education and training strategy, ET 2020, in cooperation with Member States. On the basis of the conclusions of the resulting report, the Commission set priorities for the period 2016–2020. While these priorities address unquestionable aspects such as inclusive education, equality, equity, non-discrimination, civic competences, well-being, social cohesion, intercultural dialogue, innovation and support for teaching, they remain a wrap with which to prestige a neoliberal conception of education and training. The Krasnodebski report, in line with the Commission, does not hide the conversion of education and training into business, and guides them to employability rather than knowledge development. It is necessary to recognize the inclusion in the report of aspects such as the reception in this area of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, as well as the gender perspective. However, these necessary inclusions should not pay the toll on the commodization of education; that's why we voted against it.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the ET 2020 review and stress the need to take its conclusions into account and implement them without delay in order to increase the added value of the programme and optimise its effectiveness by strengthening country-specific aspects and peer learning.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on follow-up to the Strategic Framework for European Cooperation in Education and Training (ET2020). The stocktaking exercise on the ET2020 framework was conducted in 2014 by the Commission in cooperation with the Member States. The report urges that greater attention be devoted to the quality of education, starting in the kindergarten and throughout life. It calls for the development of good practices in assessing qualitative progress and investment in the use of quality data with stakeholders at local, regional and national level. The report emphasises the importance of providing high-quality early childhood education and of its timely modernisation. It calls on the Member States to channel investment into inclusive education that responds to societal challenges with regard to ensuring equal access and opportunities for all. I voted in favour because I believe that education and training are important in helping people to acquire the knowledge and professional skills they need to become competitive and innovative employees.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. At a time of high unemployment that also affects graduates, it is very important to assess the strategic framework for European cooperation in the field of education and training to increase its added value and optimize its effectiveness.  This follow-up concludes with a number of recommendations that need to be taken into account in order to further advance cooperation in education and training. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The Strategic Framework is a multiannual plan related to the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy that aims to increase student mobility, equity, cohesion and active citizenship, as well as an approach to "creativity and innovation, including entrepreneurship". The results of recent years show that the mercantilist orientation of the education system, the standard-setting of educational programmes to increase the competitiveness between pupils and centres, as well as the cuts in austerity programmes implemented in economies such as Spain, have led to an obvious imbalance between the very objectives set by the Commission and the Council, which no longer represent my position in favour of public education , free and quality. This adopted resolution, which assesses a joint report by the Commission and the Council, seeks to legitimize these practices through Parliament, adding minor positive nuances (e.g. by calling for promoting multidisciplinary and adapted training of teachers in the face of new social challenges, or the review of evaluation working groups). That is why, since the report does not address the fundamental problems that lead to an increase in social inequalities, I voted against it.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Education and training are important to help people acquire the knowledge and professional skills they need to become competitive and innovative workers. Moreover, they can play an important role in the formation of people with an open mind. The fact should be welcomed that the Paris Declaration of the Ministers of Education of 17 March 2015 was reflected in the joint report and that ET 2020 has been updated by placing the objectives of employability and the promotion of social cohesion, equality, non-discrimination and civil skills at an equal level. It could count on my full support.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the monitoring of the strategic framework for European cooperation in education and training (ET 2020) is broadly worth supporting, and it is important to ensure that education and training systems ensure that people are integrated into society. However, I abstained on some points because I believe that education policy is a matter for the Member States and is not part of the EU's decision-making power.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I strongly endorse this EP resolution, because it represents our views on the Commission’s evaluation of ET2020 very well. It is important to follow up on such frameworks and programmes in order to observe whether the predetermined objectives are being achieved – and, if not, what action is needed. This framework is important as the future of our workforce depends on education and training. These will be the tools that will help the EU in maintaining one of the most competitive and innovative workforces in the world. In this regard, the Erasmus programme plays a significant role, which the resolution recognises.  I welcome the resolution’s call for quality assurance in education at all levels and its emphasis on the importance of the quality of educators, who need to be supported through continuing professional development programmes. The resolution also stresses the importance of exchange of good practices between Member States.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I think it is right that political strategies in the field of education emphasise the fundamental responsibility of parents for their children's education. No educational programme that ignores parental responsibility can succeed. I would very much like the recommendation for better cooperation between schools and parents contained in this report to be taken into account for all legislative and non-legislative proposals by both the Commission and this House. I also find it inspiring to consider the importance of courses for parents from disadvantaged backgrounds that could help them better manage parental responsibility when choosing the best education for their children.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as a member of the Culture and Education Committee, which concerns the implementation of the strategic framework for European cooperation in different sectors of society in the light of education and training.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's known objectives for education serving the Europe 2020 strategy, i.e. the profits of monopolies, reiterated the resolution on "implementation of the strategic framework for European cooperation in the field of education and training (EC2020)".  The resolution promotes 'lifelong learning' and the continuous acquisition of 'appropriate and high quality skills and competences' 'promoting employability', i.e. fragmentation of knowledge, in order to adapt workers to the needs of business groups for specific skills over a specific period of time. The Bologna Treaty, which was the beginning of a series of reactionary changes in universities, is being praised. The perception that permeates the resolution is that education is a commodity. Grassroots families, young workers should put their hand in their pockets and, if they don't, resort to scholarships, but also to .... loans as proposed.  For these reasons, the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against this resolution.  With respect to the education of refugees - although the general direction of the resolution is part of the logic of supporting the competitiveness of businesses - the JRC voted for those proposals which give even a little relief to the immediate problem of educating the children of refugees who are still in the air.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report. Education and training are important in helping people acquire the knowledge and expertise that make them competitive and innovative employees. I personally appreciate, in particular, the fact that support for teachers has been included among the priority areas of the ET 2020 framework. The quality of teacher training programmes and their continuous professional development is still insufficient in view of the increasing scale of complexity and competences currently required for teaching. I am in favour of paying particular attention to the needs of different types of pupils, such as pupils from national or religious minorities or children from low-income families or migrant families, who are now back in the spotlight as a result of accelerated mobility within Europe and the current refugee crisis.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on follow-up to the strategic framework for European cooperation in education and training. In my opinion, this report has been very well compiled and, although it deals with the subject of education, which falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States, it is explicitly recommendative in nature and thus does not interfere with national sovereignty. In addition, the report identified very well the problems faced by education and training and proposed measures to improve them, to better access education for disadvantaged groups, but also to strengthen the training and position of teachers. It is also important that the report proposes flexible measures based on the situation in individual countries and does not seek to adopt a single system for all, which I consider to be a much more sustainable solution compared to the often used 'one size fits all' approach.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the further consideration of the strategic framework for European cooperation in education and training. Education and training must adapt to labour market needs, as this is the only way to help increase the employment of young people and the elderly and to strengthen the economy. At the same time, education and training must also contribute to the development of individual ethical and civic competences and humanities. Member States should focus investment in inclusive education that responds to societal challenges and enhance lifelong learning opportunities.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this resolution because I am sure that renewable energies are the future of Europe, not only because of their environmental value but also because of their economic value. There are regions, such as my own, Sicily, in the south of Italy and Europe, which could become experimental hubs for the development of renewable energies and could even aspire to energy self-sufficiency and instead have very high levels of pollution and there is still talk of oil. It is clear that the development of clean energy in Europe requires strong political will. First of all, we need to assist the regions in the spending of the Structural Funds, because in the current cohesion policy the percentage of funds for renewable energies is only 1.4 %. And then we need to channel and direct the huge funds allocated to renewable energies to those regions that are rich in resources, but which are weaker in terms of planning and planning. Renewable energy is the key to growth, to creating cleaner cities, a healthier environment and a better Europe.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: – Mr. President, I am very pleased that Croatia is among those countries that are close to meeting the objectives set by the Commission. Nevertheless, I would like to stress the importance of informing consumers and their role as energy producers. The consumer should be able to read the consumption at all times in order to control it. It is estimated that an average household only on heating and cooling could save 10 - 30%. Likewise, switching suppliers are very expensive, and in some countries there has been a wait for replacement for months.  I am particularly pleased with the new initiative to simplify energy classes to help consumers manage. Likewise, the Energy Committee adopted S&D's proposal to test the devices under natural conditions rather than in laboratories. I consider this extremely important and I propose that studies on programmed spoilage be also considered. However, there is a long deal ahead of us, both in terms of renewables and energy efficiency. I believe that consumer empowerment should be at the heart of energy reform.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo mar a rinne an chuid is mó de na Feisirí – 80% díobh, 444 i bhfabhar agus 103 i gcoinne. Taispeánann sé sin go bhfuil na Feisirí sa Pharlaimint dáiríre faoin sprioc atá romhainn anois tar éis COP 21 i bPáras – mar a rabhas féin páirteach ar son na Parlaiminte roimh an Nollaig.  Dar ndóigh, tá seans iontach againn fuinneamh in-athnuaite a chur ar fáil trasna na hEorpa go léir mar a dúirt Uachtarán an Choimisiúin Juncker ag tosach a thréimhse agus caithfimid ceannasaíocht a thabhairt faoi sin. Go háirithe tá seans againn níos mó a dhéanamh maidir le taighde, taighde atá á dhéanamh i mo cheantar féin in Ionad Taighde Beaufort i Rinn an Scidígh i gCorcaigh, maidir le taoide, maidir le tuilte agus maidir le gaoth ar an bhfarraige. Déanfaidh sé sin an-difríocht nuair a bheidh an teicneolaíocht sin againn.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today I voted on the own-initiative report 'Progress report on renewable energy'. The report contained problematic proposals for binding targets of at least 30% renewable energy and national milestones. The report also contained a problematic point about bioenergy from forests and its alleged negative impact on the environment. I believe that it is the competence of the Member States to control their own energy mix, and that the percentage targets already decided should be maintained, but chose to support the report in the final vote in plenary, as the report was broadly carried out by messages on the importance of renewable energy supply solutions.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is committed to developing environmentally friendly policies and strategies, inspired by a sustainable energy model. Climate change, social and security policies and, finally, the renewal of production systems, have highlighted the need to put renewable energy at the heart of the EU's priorities. The new strategy for 2030 aims to create a decentralized model, able to implement the energy transition, obtaining better results in terms of independence, efficiency and sustainability. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees. Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents significant support for the development of the renewable energy sector and an important call to Member States that are not meeting the objectives of the Directive. The report echoes the progress of the sector but also of the problems they encounter in certain member states such as "sun tax", the retroactivity of support measures, difficulties in accessing the network. etc. also refers to the need to generate quality employment and to include trade unions and civil society in the development of these energies. Specific proposals are also made on the definition of prosumers, support for modal change in transport, development of renewable refrigeration technologies, public investment in the sector, etc. This makes the text an important reference for the development of the next directive, which is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on progress in renewable energy. Despite some interesting points, notably on users in precarious situations or the emphasis on training, which is a key issue in this sector, we regret the far too integrationist tone of this report. While we are in favour of renewable energy, we cannot support a text which is made up of very binding targets and which calls on the European Commission to strengthen its role.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report was a positive and progressive one, which highlighted the need for a modal shift and for higher energy efficiency of renewables in order to improve the sustainability of transport. Furthermore, it criticises the promotion of biofuels for transport, which competes with the food production sector. The report also analyses how Member States have done in achieving their renewable energy targets. There is currently an EU target of 20%, which is shared by Member States and broken down into national targets. Ireland has fallen short of the heat energy target. While this is not acceptable, the report correctly expresses concern that some Member States may have to revise policies and instruments in order to achieve their targets. For these reasons outlined above, I voted in favour.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on progress in the field of renewable energy sources because it refers to the progress made towards the EU 2020 targets and the framework for the 2030 targets.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The development of renewable energies necessitates a reorientation that will make them the cornerstone of the Union's energy model. Climate change must be combated, and we have a responsibility to do so.  Dependence on energy resources from other countries must be reduced if we are to achieve the objective of taking a leading role in building strategic technologies for the energy transition, structuring a successful and realistic energy production model and thus creating high-quality jobs.  This takes account of Parliament's request, which I can only agree with.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. As soon as we talk about the environment, the European Parliament enters into federalist delusions. This is the case here, where we are talking about renewable energy. The whole first part consists only of binding objectives, legislative proposals and constraints for states. Not to mention the incomprehensible gibberish where hot water is reinvented, when our states had patiently built an affordable and coherent electricity and gas utility. Although I am in favour of renewable energy, the clearly integrationist tone of the report does not allow it to be voted on as it stands. So I objected.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of renewable energies requires a new approach, which makes them the main pillar of the European Union's energy model. Moving towards a sustainable energy production model is a social priority that cannot be solved by the market alone. Regulation and democratic participation are also necessary if social and environmental negative effects are to be avoided. The EU's legal instrument is Directive 2009/28/EC on renewable energies, which has been adopted by the EU to transform the energy mix of the Member States. This sets binding targets and sets clear rules on supervision and monitoring.  The commitment to promote biofuels in transport has clearly harmed the food sector, rather than sparking an in-depth debate on the lack of coordination of logistics and urban planning policies and the need for comprehensive planning for their sustainability. Unfortunately, in many cases, the report establishes a requirement that would make it possible for the Commission to set binding targets, to control them and to penalise them if they are not met. This is clearly an intervention in the energy mix of the Member States. In many cases, the reporter speaks veiledly or openly in favour of giving the Commission the power to adopt tax legislation that promotes renewable energy production within member states' tax policies and does not support fossil fuel production, and to achieve tax harmonisation in this area at EU level. Against all these aspects, I abstained at the time of the vote.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report, which looks at progress in renewable energy, is certainly interesting, but its integrationist tone, bordering on federalism, makes it uncomfortable by making it appear more as a pretext than as an end in itself. This starts at point 2, where it is stated that Parliament "invites the Commission to strengthen its role". Similarly, its entire first part consists only of objectives bordering on the unachievable, legislative proposals and constraints on states. Member States are the likely to dismantle the affordable and coherent electricity and gas utilities they had put in place. I therefore voted against this destructive report, far from favouring the current use of renewable energy.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this report which, while welcoming its efforts in favour of renewable energy, encourages the Commission to guarantee the implementation of the Renewable Energy Directive and to propose an ambitious legislative framework after 2020. It stresses the need for a stable long-term regulatory framework with national renewable energy targets that are consistent and effective in meeting the EU's long-term climate targets (2050). It also stresses the importance for the renewable energy sector of sharing best practices, support schemes and access to capital, especially for SMEs.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has long embarked on the path of the energy transition in favour of renewable energies. It is a vision, medium and long-term, with great strategic value that aims not only to promote the achievement of international objectives, including those established with the recent COP21, but above all to ensure the Old Continent a true energy independence based on a sustainable system and projected towards the future. My support for the López Bermejo report stems from the conviction that it is essential to ensure the success of the path taken, so that it is not left to market forces alone. We need to simplify administrative procedures, strengthen legislation to create a more integrated energy market, facilitate mechanisms for sharing good national energy policies and invest in electricity storage systems. The targets set for 2020 must be achieved and, at the same time, a long-term regulatory framework must be established for achieving the Union's 2050 climate targets.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Paloma López Bermejo's report because it lays a good basis for the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive. It underlines the potential for job creation, the benefits to the economy, as well as the centrality of renewable development to combat climate change. It sets ambitious targets and calls for them to be binding. It also promotes self-consumption and the democratization of the energy system.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I objected to this report on progress in the renewable energy sector. This is regrettable, especially since several good proposals were included: the consideration of users in situations of energy insecurity, the exclusion of public investments from deficit targets, or the suggestion to simplify administrative and tax rules for producer-consumers. Unfortunately, these good wishes are being perverted by the federalist will of the rapporteur, who feels obliged to give the Commission the role of gendarme to guide Member States on the path of renewable energy through binding objectives and legislation. Moreover, the text aims to teach a lesson in this area, calling into question our public service of electricity and gas, which is nevertheless efficient and of quality.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we are voting on is unbalanced and I can therefore support it, so I have decided not to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees. Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports parliament's support for the development of renewable energy to be subject to a new approach that makes it a key pillar of the European energy model. If we want to develop our production model and create quality jobs, and to promote the development of strategic technologies that underpin the transition to new energy, we must reduce our dependence on the rest of the world's energy resources. The transition to a sustainable energy production model is a social priority issue that cannot be resolved solely by market-based instruments. It must be understood that democratic regulation and participation are necessary in order to avoid serious external social and environmental impacts. Energy oligopolys must not be allowed to determine the future of Europe's energy. Sector regulation at EU level must address many of the problems that hinder its development, promote public investment, democratic control and a stable investment system that facilitate collective and democratic energy management with a view to establishing a fully independent, efficient and clean energy model by 2050.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's commitment to make Europe a world leader in renewable energy. This is not only necessary from an industrial policy point of view, but it can also contribute to reducing the dependence of certain Central and Eastern European Member States on a single supplier of fossil fuels, thereby enabling the energy independence and energy security of Europe, the world's largest importer of energy. In addition, we have a responsibility to take action against climate change, which can be greatly contributed by an increase in the share of renewable energy sources. In the long term, a policy on energy sources based on national objectives guarantees industry and investors the security they need to invest in electricity generation capacity and transport and distribution infrastructure.  It is important that the definition of member states' energy mixes remains a national competence, and each Member State can develop its own renewable energy sources and shape its energy mix. State aid measures have helped to achieve the EU's objectives in many Member States, but a decisive political push is needed if further, even more serious results are to be achieved. In order to create an efficient energy model based on renewable energy sources by 2050, regulation at European level must solve a number of problems that are in the way of development: promoting investment and democratic supervision and creating stable investment frameworks.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of renewable energy is a key factor in achieving our climate and energy goals, representing a key element on our path to decarbonisation. The European Union as a whole is on track to meet the 2020 renewable targets, but further efforts are needed from Member States that have lagged behind the most. These efforts are all the more necessary in the light of the progressive reduction in the costs associated with these energies, which, in line with technological advances in production and storage, has made renewable energies increasingly competitive and the use of renewable energies increasingly cost-effective.  It is therefore important that support for these energy sources continues beyond 2020, maintaining the effective combination of binding targets and national action plans that have enabled us to achieve tangible results so far, within an ambitious and effective regulatory framework, capable of sending appropriate and long-term signals to investors. The Commission, for its part, must continue to actively monitor progress in the field of renewables, promoting transparency, coherence and the absence of technical barriers to the development of these fundamental energies.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Although I am in favour of the development of renewable energies, the clearly integrationist tone of the report does not allow me to vote as it stands. So I voted against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – This report was a positive and progressive one, which highlighted the need for a modal shift and for higher energy efficiency of renewables in order to improve the sustainability of transport. Furthermore, it criticises the promotion of biofuels for transport, which competes with the food production sector. The report also analyses how Member States have done in achieving their renewable energy targets. There is currently an EU target of 20%, which is shared by Member States and broken down into national targets. Ireland has fallen short of the heat energy target. While this is not acceptable, the report correctly expresses concern that some Member States may have to revise policies and instruments in order to achieve their targets. For these reasons outlined above, I voted in favour.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Renewable energy is the future of the EU's long-term development. We must implement economic policies that transform them into the fundamental pillar of the European Union's energy model. We have a historic task: to combat climate change and reduce dependence on energy resources in the rest of the world to restructure our production model and generate quality jobs, as well as to safeguard our territory and the future of our descendants. The transition to a sustainable energy production model is also a social priority that cannot be entrusted solely to the market: we must understand that regulation and democratic participation are necessary to avoid serious social and environmental crises. We must prevent the energy oligopolies from defining the future of energy for Europe, but that we can instead guarantee an integrated, efficient and clean European energy model for 2050.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to provide an overview of the state of progress in the renewable energy sector. While the rapporteur has the merit of raising some relevant issues such as the situation of consumer producers for whom administrative and tax rules should be simplified, I have opposed this text, which will strengthen binding legislation to the detriment of The Member States. While it is essential for future generations to invest in renewable energy, the fact remains that the strengthening of administrative and legal constraints in the Union will exacerbate the current unfair competition for our businesses. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of renewable energy needs a new approach that transforms it into the main pillar of the EU's energy model. It is a fundamental responsibility to combat climate change, it is a historical duty that must be fulfilled. The transition to a sustainable production model is a social priority that cannot be solved by the market alone, and democratic participation and regulation are necessary elements to avoid serious environmental and social externalities, which does not allow us to define Europe's energy future. The EU has a legal instrument to help achieve this objective through the Renewable Energy Directive. With the adoption of this Directive, Europe initiated a process of transforming the energy mix in the Member States, a legal instrument that enabled the establishment of a favourable framework for the development of the renewable energy sector and contributed to the development of a diversified and varied sector. We voted in favour of the report on progress in renewable energy because this renewable energy source is needed for all EU Member States, both to create progress in terms of bio energy, but also to combat climate change in the EU and beyond.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. ‒ The shift towards renewable energies is of the utmost importance for the European Union’s energy model. We need to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels in order to combat climate change effectively. With this, we must ensure the creation of quality jobs and the development of necessary technologies in order to ensure a successful and smooth energy transition. The adoption of the Renewables Directive has provided a legal instrument to create a varied and diversified sector, through binding targets and clear rules on supervision and monitoring. This has allowed many of the Member States to work more effectively to achieve the targets set for 2020. Since reducing greenhouse gas emissions also depends on achieving the goals in renewable energy, it is important that the measures adopted improve support mechanisms for renewable energy sources to ensure that consumers benefit from the technological advances. Thus, I voted for the resolution on the renewable energy progress report to ensure that we will reach the targets set for 2020 and those of the COP 21 Paris agreement.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees. Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. One of the EU's priorities is to succeed in the energy transition in the fight against global warming. From this perspective, the development of renewable energies is very important. Another challenge remains to reduce the European Union's energy dependence on third countries. Member States already have a legal framework to meet the 2020 targets. Regulation of the renewable energy sector must foster a stable framework for investment and effective democratic control, conducive to their development. The report raises key questions about Europe's energy future. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report to ensure that the EU renewable energy target – 20% of total consumption by 2020 – is achieved by all EU Member States.  The Commission should ensure the full implementation of the 2020 Renewable Energy Directive and should present an ambitious regulatory framework for the period after 2020. I stress, in this regard, the need for a stable long-term regulatory framework, including renewable energy targets at national and EU level, enabling the eu's long-term climate targets to be achieved (2050). I would remind you that the European Parliament's request for binding targets of at least 30% of renewable energy in energy consumption must be implemented by means of national targets in order to guarantee the necessary security for investors and the necessary legal certainty. I also believe that, in the light of the recent COP 21 agreement, a considerably higher ambition with clear objectives is desirable in order to ensure a leading position for the EU at world level in the field of renewables.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which analyses how Member States have done in achieving their renewable energy targets. There is currently an EU target of 20%, which is shared by Member States and broken down into national targets. Some Member States have been quicker to implement their targets than others. For instance, Ireland is set to fall short of its heat energy target, but to reach others. The report expresses concern that some Member States may have to revise policies and instruments to achieve their targets. Overall, the report is quite good, criticising the promotion of biofuels for transport, which competes with the food production sector. The report highlights the need for a modal shift and for higher energy efficiency of renewables in order to improve the sustainability of transport. And it rightly criticises the reliance on market mechanisms to get us all to use renewables. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report in order to show my support for the EU’s energy efficiency target through the development of renewable energy. I especially welcome combing the EU objective for renewable energy with national targets. We have the obligation to combat climate change and I am glad to see all Member States have made efforts in this fight. The EU is on the path to shift from traditional energy resources to renewable energy and, in order to be successful, we need a more consistent framework at EU level.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on progress in the field of renewable energy. The report addresses a critical review of the framework resulting from Directive 2009/28/EC and provides ideas for using the decentralised and democratised energy model to implement the energy transition and derive its results in terms of independence, efficiency and sustainability.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress once again that the development of renewable energy sources requires a new orientation that makes them the fundamental pillar of the European Union's energy model. We have the primary responsibility to fight climate change, as we are faced with a historic commitment. We must reduce the dependence on energy resources of the rest of the world if we are to support our production model and create quality jobs, spearheading the development of technologies of strategic importance for the energy transition.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on progress in the field of renewable energy sources. I think it is obvious that such reports promote the processes of selecting new, more environmentally friendly sources of energy, and possibly towards restarting the economy, by creating investment and job prospects. I therefore think that this is a positive effort and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 While fossil fuels are still economically irreplaceable at the moment, the development of renewable energy is strategic for the future of a Europe that does not have oil but has sun and wind. The progress made so far is encouraging and citizens, if properly encouraged, react positively by showing openness to new technologies. However, it is important that these incentives do not place an excessive burden on communities' pockets and that they are always used transparently so that businesses know how much each technology costs, including in terms of taxes and public money that could also be used for other objectives.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which examines Member States’ policies for implementing renewable energy initiatives.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The development of renewable energy sources requires a new approach that will make them the fundamental pillar of the European Union's energy model. We have a responsibility to fight climate change and reduce our dependence on energy resources from the rest of the world so that we can organise our production model, create quality jobs and be at the forefront of developing energy transposition technologies. The transition to a sustainable energy production model is therefore a social priority that cannot be entrusted only to the market, we must understand that regulation and democratic participation are necessary to avoid social and environmental externalities. The development of renewable energies will help to ensure energy security and sovereignty, end energy poverty and foster economic development and technological leadership in the EU by combating climate change. The future R&D strategy should focus on facilitating the development of smart networks and cities. Transport electrification, intelligent vehicle charging and "vehicle-network" technologies will contribute to improving energy efficiency and absorbing the potential of renewable energy sources. I have for the foregoing supported this report.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. Today we voted in favour of the report on the progress report on renewable energy. Renewable energy is a prerequisite for achieving environmental and climate objectives and requires an energy market built on open and free competition, market prices and incentives to invest in new technology and transmission. The report adopted by Parliament proposes a binding target of at least 30% renewable energy with national milestones. However, we believe that it is, and should continue to be, the exclusive competence of the Member States to control their own energy mix. The report also contains a point that identifies bioenergy from forestry as potentially harmful to the environment and the climate. Sweden has long and broad experience of farming forests in an efficient and environmentally friendly way, which utilizes forest resources with the least possible climate and environmental impact. That is why we do not share the report's problem formulation, but on the contrary, we see sustainable forestry as part of efforts to reduce emissions.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents significant support for the development of the renewable energy sector and an important call to Member States that are not meeting the objectives of the Directive. The report echoes the progress of the sector but also of the problems they encounter in certain member states such as "sun tax", the retroactivity of support measures, difficulties in accessing the network. etc. also refers to the need to generate quality employment and to include trade unions and civil society in the development of these energies. Specific proposals are also made on the definition of prosumers, support for modal change in transport, development of renewable refrigeration technologies, public investment in the sector, etc. This makes the text an important reference for the development of the next directive, which is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The target of 20% of total renewable energy consumption by 2020 is implemented differently from one Member State to another. That is why I support the call for full implementation of the legislation in order to achieve the objectives uniformly on the internal continent. At the same time, I support the relaunch of the 2050 targets towards a sovereign, efficient and clean energy model. We must be ambitions. We have a duty and a responsibility to combat climate change by reducing the dependence on resources that we are forced to import from the rest of the world. We must increasingly guarantee sustainable and indigenous energy production, which is a fundamental element in the recovery of our economy, in the light of job creation. The EU Renewables Directive is a legal instrument that must be supported and implemented, with binding targets and clear rules. But it's often not enough. We must act at a lower level, raising awareness and stimulating the active contribution of our citizens and consumers, through campaigns and incentives that can make them truly protagonists of a season of reviving the sustainability of our continent.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Technological advances in the production and storage of energy from renewable sources, awareness of the need to reduce the environmental impact for sustainable development, and the need to increase the autonomy of Member States at a time when energy is used in constraint policies indicate the importance of generalising the use of these resources. In this context, I believe that the European Union and the Member States must set more ambitious climate and energy targets, exceeding the quota set by the European Council at 27% of renewable energy in energy consumption by 2030. I voted in favour of this report, wanting to stress the importance of diversifying energy sources with a view to forming a genuine energy union at European level. Responsible, efficient and transparent monitoring of the implementation of existing European legislation, encouraging public investment and democratic control over the energy sector will allow for the disappearance of energy oligopolies and ensure the existence of an autonomous, sustainable and efficient energy model.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Renewable Energy Directive adopted in 2009 requires a progress report every two years. The progress report currently being debated is a mid-term review of this Directive and contains a preliminary assessment of it under refit. The European Commission's report concludes that twenty-five Member States are on track to meet binding renewable energy targets and five have already achieved or are about to meet their targets. The INI report welcomes closer coordination between Member States and regions, which is in line with the Commission's assessment that cooperation mechanisms should be better used if renewable energy targets are to be achieved. While the INI report concludes that the definition of the energy mix of Member States is a national competence, it also makes several references to binding national targets and taxation, criticises the lack of country-specific recommendations, advocates a greater role for the Commission in monitoring Member States' actions by increasing surveillance capacity, and proposes to increase the EU's renewable energy targets. I cannot agree with many points in this report, which is why I voted against the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The use of renewable energy in the Member States is an essential element in working towards a cleaner environment which is sustainable and which takes into account the health of our citizens. The progress made under the Europe 2020 strategy in meeting the 20% renewable energy target represents a step in the right direction. However, in order to have sustainable use of energy we must ensure more ambitious targets, leaving room for manoeuvre for small Member States like Malta, which may have certain specificities.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. \u2012 There is an urgent need to reduce dependence on fossil fuels, in order to facilitate widespread self-handling and energy self-sufficiency.  The EU's commitment to reducing CO2 emissions, but also the necessary drastic reduction of pollutants such as heavy metals and dioxins in air, water and soil, should oblige all EU states to put effective measures into practice in good time. Our health and our environment are at the heart of our health, but also of our financial resources, given the health and social costs of an environment devastated precisely by dependence on fossil sources such as oil and its derivatives, coal and gas.  A rapid transition requires research, innovation and the effective and effective use of all available European funds for energy efficiency and the production of energy from renewable sources. And we must avoid curbing structural reforms which, in fact, result in austerity policies or senseless cuts.  In short, Europe's cities and regions need to make a paradigm shift, but for this to happen there must be precise and binding commitments to rely on an energy mix based on truly renewable sources. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that it is important to exchange best practices on national renewable energy policies in order to promote their adoption under a more convergent European model, fostering increased cooperation and coordination between Member States.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's commitment to make Europe a world leader in renewable energy. This is not only necessary from an industrial policy point of view, but it can also contribute to reducing the dependence of certain Central and Eastern European Member States on a single supplier of fossil fuels, thereby enabling the energy independence and energy security of Europe, the world's largest importer of energy. In addition, we have a responsibility to take action against climate change, which can be greatly contributed by an increase in the share of renewable energy sources. In the long term, a policy on energy sources based on national objectives guarantees industry and investors the security they need to invest in electricity generation capacity and transport and distribution infrastructure.  It is important that the definition of member states' energy mixes remains a national competence, and each Member State can develop its own renewable energy sources and shape its energy mix. State aid measures have helped to achieve the EU's objectives in many Member States, but a decisive political push is needed if further, even more serious results are to be achieved. In order to create an efficient energy model based on renewable energy sources by 2050, regulation at European level must solve a number of problems that are in the way of development: promoting investment and democratic supervision and creating stable investment frameworks.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. This report gives the temperature of the state of play in the equipment and production of renewable energy, which can be summed up in the phrase "glass half full and half empty". On the other hand, it is regrettable that it is not accompanied by country-by-country recommendations and remains at a very general meta level. For my part, I am very attentive to the issue of investment in research, particularly on the issue of electricity storage, which is an instrument for managing renewable energy. This requires the involvement of local authorities, a simplification of the administrative framework and financing procedures and the installation of intelligent equipment that can demonstrate to end consumers the value of switching to clean energy.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Admittedly, this report does not forget to refer to users in situations of energy insecurity, to the importance of training as a key issue of these policies. It also wants to exclude public investment from deficit targets and involve citizens in national renewable energy plans. Finally, it looks at the situation of consumer producers, for whom administrative and tax rules should be simplified. However, it is a federalist text that "invites the Commission to strengthen its role" and contains so many binding targets, legislative proposals and constraints for states. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on progress in the field of renewable energy, as this report calls for less member states' involvement and more regulation through EU legislation. I consider it unacceptable to argue that the transition to a model of sustainable energy production is a public priority that cannot be entrusted solely to the market, because we can set an example for Finland, where it is the market that forces producers to promote innovation in the field of renewable sourcing.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against. Although the report contains too many good elements, it gives the Commission super powers, which we cannot accept.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's commitment to make Europe a world leader in renewable energy. This is not only necessary from an industrial policy point of view, but it can also contribute to reducing the dependence of certain Central and Eastern European Member States on a single supplier of fossil fuels, thereby enabling the energy independence and energy security of Europe, the world's largest importer of energy. In addition, we have a responsibility to take action against climate change, which can be greatly contributed by an increase in the share of renewable energy sources. In the long term, a policy on energy sources based on national objectives guarantees industry and investors the security they need to invest in electricity generation capacity and transport and distribution infrastructure.  It is important that the definition of member states' energy mixes remains a national competence, and each Member State can develop its own renewable energy sources and shape its energy mix. State aid measures have helped to achieve the EU's objectives in many Member States, but a decisive political push is needed if further, even more serious results are to be achieved. In order to create an efficient energy model based on renewable energy sources by 2050, regulation at European level must solve a number of problems that are in the way of development: promoting investment and democratic supervision and creating stable investment frameworks.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on progress in the field of renewable energy because, in addition to containing a number of important recommendations for the new Renewables Directive for 2030, it refers to 'prosumers', a revolutionary new model of energy production and consumption that sees the full involvement of citizens in models of cooperation and self-handling. An important step towards the energy transition referred to by the 5 Star Movement, a decentralized and democratic energy model that guarantees independence, efficiency and sustainability.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The regulation of the sector at European level must address the many problems that are undermining its development, favouring public investment, democratic control and a stable investment framework, in order to facilitate collective and democratic energy management and ensure a fully sovereign, efficient and clean energy model for 2050. The transition to a sustainable energy production model is a social priority that cannot be entrusted so only to the market. On the contrary, we must understand that democratic regulation and participation are necessary to avoid serious social and environmental externalities.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against it because the clearly integrationist tone of the report does not allow it to be voted on as it stands.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The rapporteur's intentions have been partly frustrated by a difficult context, which stems from the composition and relationship of forces in this Parliament. The changes made to the initial version of the report have not improved it, on the contrary. Nevertheless, the report retains positive aspects that lead us to support it. The report rightly states that the transition to a sustainable energy production model is a social priority that cannot be entrusted only to the market. On the contrary, we must understand that democratic regulation and participation are necessary to avoid serious social and environmental externalities. We must prevent energy oligopolies from defining Europe's energy future. We would add that one condition of this democratic regulation of the sector is the public, democratic, ownership and management of the sector. This regulation of the sector, in which the sovereign options of each Member State must be decisively weighed, must address the many problems that are undermining the development of renewable energies. Public investment, democratic control and a stable investment framework should be favoured in order to facilitate collective and democratic energy management and ensure a fully sovereign, efficient and clean energy model, according to the report, by 2050. The report advocates an ambitious political impetus to meet the targets set.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the development of renewable energies demands a different approach that transforms them into the fundamental pillar of the European Union's energy model. Our fundamental responsibility, as representatives of European citizens, is to combat climate change, an historic duty that we have an obligation not to neglect. It is also crucial to reduce dependence on energy resources in the rest of the world if we are to structure our production model and generate quality jobs, as well as to guide the development of strategic technologies for energy transition.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been very actively involved in the fight against climate change. The development of renewables is an integral part of the European Union's commitments in this area, but this will require a new approach and the necessary investments in the future, which can contribute to creating quality jobs for the citizens of the Member States of the European Union. If we are to meet the ambitious targets for 2020, we need to add in many areas and give new political impetus in several Member States.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Voting against the report, which is confused and excessive liberalisation, risks weakening sovereignty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on progress in the field of renewable energy sources. Although the report contains a great deal of good evidence, it gives the Commission too much powers, which I cannot accept.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Continued investment in renewables requires ambitious leadership and commitment and a long-term, stable and reliable policy framework consistent with the climate commitments made by the EU in Paris. In order to achieve our goals, the Commission has to ensure full implementation of the 2020 Renewable Energy Directive and put forward an ambitious post-2020 legislative framework. The fact that the European Council decided to abandon the binding national targets and set a relatively low target of 27% for 2030, binding purely at European level, is highly disappointing. I support an EU that is on track to meet its 2020 targets thanks to the use of binding national targets. I will not accept getting rid of these targets and I will not accept the European Council’s low 2030 target.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I accepted my fellow Member Bermejo's report on renewable energy. It is to be welcomed that the Commission is committed to making Europe a world leader in the field of renewable energy. This is not only necessary from an industrial policy point of view, but it can also contribute to reducing the dependence of certain Central and Eastern European Member States on a single supplier of fossil fuels, thereby enabling the energy independence and energy security of Europe, the world's largest importer of energy. In addition, we have a responsibility to take action against climate change, which can be greatly contributed by an increase in the share of renewable energy sources. In the long term, a policy on energy sources based on national objectives guarantees industry and investors the security they need to invest in electricity generation capacity and transport and distribution infrastructure.  It is important that the definition of the energy mix of the Member States remains a national competence, and each Member State can develop its own sources of renewable energy and shape its energy mix. State aid measures have helped to achieve the EU's objectives in many Member States, but a decisive political push is needed if further, even more serious results are to be achieved. In order to create an efficient energy model based on renewable energy sources by 2050, regulation at European level must solve a number of problems that are in the way of development: promoting investment and democratic supervision and creating stable investment frameworks.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. U2012 I support the majority position of the European Parliament - more ambitious than that adopted by the Council - in favour of 30% renewables by 2030 through binding national targets. Objective not shared by the European People's Party (EPP) and Commissioner Cañete, pending to appear before this chamber by the scandals that dot it. Despite the vote against the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, I regret that an amendment defending the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, i.e. those in energy poverty, has been rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. it is surprising, once again against the general feeling of this chamber, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against climate change is made up of concrete commitments to be followed up year after year by the EU and the Member States. It is therefore very important to monitor the progress made in the field of renewables, which are one of the key sectors in achieving the objectives set in Paris at COP21. Unfortunately, some countries are still lagging behind in this process. I therefore agree with the report's request that we are voting today to increase the Commission's overall political commitment, precisely in order to monitor the action of the Member States and, above all, to introduce concrete instruments – for example an ad hoc financial mechanism – aimed at reducing capital costs and risks related to renewable energy projects.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on progress in the field of renewable energy because I believe that the development of renewable energies needs a new approach that transforms them into the fundamental pillar of the European Union's energy model.  Faced with climate change, the EU must reduce its dependence on energy resources in the rest of the world if it really wants to structure its production model and generate quality jobs, as well as guide the development of strategic technologies for the transition to a sustainable energy production model, which is a social priority. This transition cannot be left solely to the market, but must be regulated by the EU so that there is no unfair competition between EU Member States, which would cause harm to citizens, in the form of social and environmental externalities.  I believe that the current combination of binding national targets, national renewable energy action plans and two-year control has been the driving force behind the development of renewable energy capacity in the Member States. It is necessary to create a regulatory framework that respects the principle of proportionality, that recognises a fundamental role in the energy transition to local authorities, communities, families and individuals.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the progress report on renewable energy sources , not because I am against renewable energy. On the contrary. I am in favour of the further, ambitious expansion of renewable energies – they must be the basis of a sustainable energy supply. However, EU framework legislation has not always played a constructive role in this. I would remind you, for example, of the 'disembarkation' of the European biofuel movement. Farmers have been deprived of an important new market segment for no reason.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the expansion of renewable energies. Among other things, it reduces our dependence on fossil fuels. However, national targets and a 30% target are not effective. We must avoid over-regulation here. Instead, in the GROUP's policy paper, we advocated a target of a maximum of 27% at EU level (not the Member States).

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Paloma López Bermejo's report because it lays a good basis for the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive. It underlines the potential for job creation, the benefits to the economy, as well as the centrality of renewable development to combat climate change. It sets ambitious targets and calls for them to be binding. It also promotes self-consumption and the democratization of the energy system.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 My country, Romania, is the first in the percentage of green energy in total energy produced, but consumers have had a high cost and it is not normal to transfer all the pressure to the final consumer. I did not support this report because it does not contain clear provisions on how to protect consumers from rising green energy prices, it is not clear that the EFSI is involved in research for modern technologies for efficiency and decarbonisation. I also do not agree that the specific conditions in each country and the subsidiarity requirements in determining the energy mix have not been taken into account.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees. Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, thereby realising the 2015 Paris Agreement, depends on achieving EU climate and energy policy goals in the field of renewable energy. The report also highlights the fact that the current 2020 energy strategy and energy goals will be insufficient to reach the 2050 decarbonisation target, and it therefore calls on the Commission to present a more ambitious climate and energy package for 2030, increasing the EU target for renewable energy sources to at least 30%, to be implemented by means of individual national targets.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees.
