Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report on the ground that it favours the creation of an integrated strategy for the development and support of renewable energy sources as a fundamental pillar of EU energy policy. It also refers to energy poverty as well as to the support/support of small producers of renewable energy sources.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I have no problems with the outcome.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. This report is an interim review of the implementation of the 2009 Renewable Energy Directive. It contains some good elements, such as.B. the call for closer cooperation across the EU and the need to promote renewable energy in a cost-effective way and to be competitive. However, the report also contains elements that go far beyond the intended scope. For example, the rapporteur proposes fiscal measures to promote renewable energies or greater monitoring and control by the European Commission. In addition, the report raises the renewable energy target adopted by the Council from 27% to 30%. ALFA believes that we should be guided by the objectives adopted by the Council and that decisions on the implementation of decisions should be left to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's commitment to make Europe a world leader in renewable energy. This is not only necessary from an industrial policy point of view, but it can also contribute to reducing the dependence of certain Central and Eastern European Member States on a single supplier of fossil fuels, thereby enabling the energy independence and energy security of Europe, the world's largest importer of energy. In addition, we have a responsibility to take action against climate change, which can be greatly contributed by an increase in the share of renewable energy sources. In the long term, a policy on energy sources based on national objectives guarantees industry and investors the security they need to invest in electricity generation capacity and transport and distribution infrastructure.  It is important that the definition of the energy mix of the Member States remains a national competence, and each Member State can develop its own sources of renewable energy and shape its energy mix. State aid measures have helped to achieve the EU's objectives in many Member States, but a decisive political push is needed if further, even more serious results are to be achieved. In order to create an efficient energy model based on renewable energy sources by 2050, regulation at European level must solve a number of problems that are in the way of development: promoting investment and democratic supervision and creating stable investment frameworks. Against this view, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which encourages the development of renewable energy at European level, which, by supporting the legal framework at European Union level, would encourage public investment, democratic control and facilitate the collective and democratic management of this sector. The aim is to ensure a fully sovereign and effective strategic model for 2050.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, as it focuses on increasing energy efficiency and saving energy as key factors for protecting the environment and climate, strengthening economic competitiveness, creating jobs, security of energy supply and combating energy poverty. Energy efficiency is extremely important for reducing our dependence on imports as well. The European Union is currently making good progress in meeting its 2020 climate and energy targets, which are to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, increase the share of renewables and improve energy efficiency, and should maintain its global leadership. This Directive has encouraged many positive progress in The Member States, but poor implementation is holding back the realisation of its full potential.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The report is relevant because it does not forget users in situations of energy insecurity and devotes almost one paragraph to training. It wants to exclude public investment from deficit targets and plans to involve citizens in national renewable energy plans. In addition, the report repeatedly looks at the situation of consumer-producers, for whom administrative and tax rules should be simplified. However, the Commission's interference in the report is damning. The whole first part consists only of binding objectives, legislative proposals and constraints for states. Although I recognise the value of renewable energy, the binding tone of the report led me to vote against the text.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees. Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament called for a higher ambition level and for a 2030 EU renewable energy target of 30%, in line with the Union’s commitments (the Paris climate agreement, decarbonisation and achieving a 100% RES based economy by 2050). Importantly, this target should be delivered through national binding targets. The EP also called for a consumer-centric approach, strengthened oversight by the Commission and assistance for local operators, as well as targeted measures for low-income consumers. These measures would bring stability for investors and ensure an adequate level of investments; and technological lock-in, incompatible with the EU’s long-term goals, can be avoided. Therefore, I supported the report with my vote.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the EU is well on its way to meeting its 2020 renewable energy targets, it turns out that many Member States should strengthen their policies and instruments to ensure that the targets set are met. The report focuses on the importance of sharing best practices or the need to evaluate the impact of renewables on prices, especially for households. It stresses the need for European legislation on energy market rules, stable and efficient renewable support schemes for long-term investments, which are also adapted to national needs and circumstances. Taking care of the environment is a really global problem. I was happy to support the report calling for more effective cooperation and effective coordination within and between Member States.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the progress made in the renewable energy sector. The report estimates that, as a whole, the EU is on track to meet the 2020 targets (20% greenhouse gas emissions, 20% renewable energy and 20% energy efficiency). If renewable energy continues to grow, the report points out that the EU could eventually save up to 30 billion euros a year.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the progress report in the field of renewable energy sources, as I believe that the development of renewable energy sources requires a new orientation that makes them the fundamental pillar of the European Union's energy model. The transition to a sustainable model of energy production is a social priority that cannot be addressed only by the market.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. While the promotion of energy from renewable sources is important, this report makes demands that go far beyond the EU's competences and technical capabilities. To the end, the implementation of some of the demands in this report would create indirect subsidies for renewables, for technologies that are actually already ready for the market. Linking renewable energy with energy poverty is also a mistake: social policy is a matter for the Member States, while the integration of renewables is a technical problem that is currently being resolved by many levies and subsidies. It is for these reasons, and because of my support for renewable energies, that I am abstaining on this report.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Renewables is a grateful topic of philosophical discussion. Radical demands for 100% coverage of energy needs in the coming years are technically justified by philosophical considerations, and the real technician remains in awe of how simple everything is. If we take seriously the pursuit of security, on the one hand, strict environmental protection and, on the other hand, the provision of 100% of energy needs by renewable sources, we are in difficult contradictions. Wind parks fundamentally change the character of the landscape, wherever they are located. Multi-hectare photovoltaics significantly affect local airflow, as well as large projects of valley water reservoirs. At the same time, the daily and annual distribution of electricity consumption does not correspond in any way with sunlight, wind or precipitation conditions. So we still have biomass and geothermal energy. When comparing the possibilities of individual renewable sources, we find that, on the one hand, there are a large number of administrative barriers (especially when connecting small photovoltaics and installing small hydropower plants) and, on the other hand, there are legitimate concerns of operators of large electricity networks about ensuring the stability of the whole system. Electricity is very difficult to store. However, these problems are not addressed in the report. Since, in addition to overly optimistic perspectives, there are also a number of positive initiatives in the report and I assume that the most fantastic proposals will not be adopted, I support the adoption of the report.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. This report is an interim review of the implementation of the 2009 Renewable Energy Directive. It contains some good elements, such as.B. the call for closer cooperation across the EU and the need to promote renewable energy in a cost-effective way and to be competitive. However, the report also contains elements that go far beyond the intended scope. For example, the rapporteur proposes fiscal measures to promote renewable energies or greater monitoring and control by the European Commission. In addition, the report raises the renewable energy target adopted by the Council from 27% to 30%. ALFA believes that we should be guided by the objectives adopted by the Council and that decisions on the implementation of decisions should be left to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 23 June 2016, at the next plenary session of the European Parliament in Brussels, we voted on a progress report on renewable energy. This was a report by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. However, my Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has also been dealing with this issue for a long time. That is why I had a very critical opinion on the text submitted from the beginning. To begin with, I have to say that I abstained from voting. Although the document ultimately contained some good things, such as mentioning the issue of energy poverty or the pressure to support new generations of biofuels at the expense of the old and flawed one, I could not in good conscience support it. In my opinion, the report is unbalanced, because it significantly adores, for example, the use of biomass, for which we all already know that its mass use in the energy sector is completely unsustainable, both in terms of emissions and in terms of its negative impact on food self-sufficiency. The whole text then assumes that only renewable sources are the only right source for the future of energy, which is unacceptable. The report omers to mention nuclear power in any way, the existence of which it no longer envisaged for the future. It also omes any possible breakthrough in the sector, e.g. in terms of cold fusion.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's commitment to make Europe a world leader in renewable energy. This is not only necessary from an industrial policy point of view, but it can also contribute to reducing the dependence of certain Central and Eastern European Member States on a single supplier of fossil fuels, thereby enabling the energy independence and energy security of Europe, the world's largest importer of energy. In addition, we have a responsibility to take action against climate change, which can be greatly contributed by an increase in the share of renewable energy sources. In the long term, a policy on energy sources based on national objectives guarantees industry and investors the security they need to invest in electricity generation capacity and transport and distribution infrastructure.  It is important that the definition of member states' energy mixes remains a national competence, and each Member State can develop its own renewable energy sources and shape its energy mix. State aid measures have helped to achieve the EU's objectives in many Member States, but a decisive political push is needed if further, even more serious results are to be achieved. In order to create an efficient energy model based on renewable energy sources by 2050, regulation at European level must solve a number of problems that are in the way of development: promoting investment and democratic supervision and creating stable investment frameworks.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report because the development of renewable energy is a key priority to the EU. This is so because renewable energy has the capacity, on one hand, to ensure the normal functioning of the EU energy market and, on the other hand, to secure EU energy supplies. Furthermore, the development of renewable energy will facilitate rational use of Europe’s energy resources, technology development, smart infrastructure, economic growth and job creation. Most importantly, the development of renewable energy will significantly decrease energy cost for Europe’s citizens and businesses. In the light of this, the EU should continue its work to reach the 2020 targets for renewable energy. However, in order to achieve those targets the EU should promote tax cuts for renewable energy and, in particular, reform the Energy Taxation Directive to facilitate further the shift from fossil energy to renewable energy. Furthermore, the EU should promote regional cooperation and coordination including sharing best practices among Member States in order to develop the rational use of renewable energy sources. Last but not least, the EU should work to promote collective and democratic management of renewable energy with a view to ensuring a fully sovereign, efficient and clean European energy model.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, under the pretext of encouraging renewable energy, it seeks to strengthen the European Union and punish recalcitrant states. It also promotes the smoky concept of "energy democracy". Good feelings and empty words in the service of a will for hegemony!

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on progress in the renewable energy sector. As soon as we talk about the environment, the European Parliament enters into federalist delusions. However, the report is interesting on a few points. In particular, it does not forget users in situations of energy insecurity. He wants to involve citizens in national plans for renewable energy. He repeatedly discusses the situation of consumer producers, for whom administrative and tax rules should be simplified. However, the whole first part consists only of binding objectives, legislative proposals and constraints for states. Not to mention the incomprehensible gibberish in which hot water is reinvented, when most Member States had built an affordable and coherent electricity and gas utility.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. The text makes some interesting remarks, such as the importance of training on renewable energy, helping users in situations of energy insecurity, but also of involving citizens in national renewable energy plans. However, these remarks disappear under the rapporteur's integrationist will. In addition, it tends to set out binding legislative objectives and proposals for states. It is impossible for me to agree with this federalist report. I voted strongly against it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees. Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents significant support for the development of the renewable energy sector and an important call to Member States that are not meeting the objectives of the Directive. The report echoes the progress of the sector but also of the problems they encounter in certain member states such as "sun tax", the retroactivity of support measures, difficulties in accessing the network. etc. also refers to the need to generate quality employment and to include trade unions and civil society in the development of these energies. Specific proposals are also made on the definition of prosumers, support for modal change in transport, development of renewable refrigeration technologies, public investment in the sector, etc. This makes the text an important reference for the development of the next directive, which is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. I believe that a new approach to renewable energy is needed to make them the cornerstone of the European Union's energy model. Our main obligation is to combat climate change and reduce dependence on energy resources in the rest of the world. In order to comply with this obligation, I consider it appropriate to apply the Renewable Energy Sources Directive, as it acts as the EU legal instrument for the transition to a sustainable energy production model.  The regulation of the sector at European level aims to solve the various problems that are holding back the development of the sector, promoting public investment, democratic control and a stable framework for investment that facilitate collective and democratic energy management to ensure a fully sovereign, efficient and clean energy model by 2050. For agreeing with these budgets I vote in favour.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. This report is an interim review of the implementation of the 2009 Renewable Energy Directive. It contains some good elements, such as.B. the call for closer cooperation across the EU and the need to promote renewable energy in a cost-effective way and to be competitive. However, the report also contains elements that go far beyond the intended scope. For example, the rapporteur proposes fiscal measures to promote renewable energies or greater monitoring and control by the European Commission. In addition, the report raises the renewable energy target adopted by the Council from 27% to 30%. ALFA believes that we should be guided by the objectives adopted by the Council and that decisions on the implementation of decisions should be left to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of promoting energy diversification, phasing out subsidies on mature renewable energy and encouraging competitiveness in our renewable energy sector.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I am against the European Commission interfering in the energy policies of the Member States. I also do not agree with environmentalist activism leading to energy price increases and subsidisation of inefficient resources. I am opposed to a 'more ambitious climate and energy package by 2030'.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. \u2012 By 2030, half of our electricity will be renewable. By 2035, electricity will be out of carbon dioxide emissions. Renewables produce alternatives to fossil fuels and aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These sources contribute to diversifying energy supply and reducing dependence on volatile and unreliable fossil fuel markets, in particular oil and gas. The development of renewable energy (wind, solar, hydroelectric, ocean energy, geothermal energy, biomass and biofuels) is an EU priority. The report provides specific recommendations for each Member State and perhaps so far more than 5 countries will achieve the proposed Union-wide targets. The old framework for promoting renewable energy - for example the promotion of biofuels in transport - also had a strong negative impact on food production. We need to have global coordination and planning of logistics and urban policies in order to make them truly sustainable.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the 2009 Renewable Energy Directive (2009/28/EC), the Member States of the Union have largely experienced a period of rapid development of renewable energy sources, which is still ongoing and clearly supported in the future. It is understandable that renewable energy should not only be environmentally beneficial, but also economically viable. Against this background, financial support from the EU budget in this area is of fundamental importance and quite welcome. Promoting sectoral transparency, scientific innovation and their integration into practice, exchanging experience and, in principle, international cooperation should be a primary stepping stone to the renewable energy policy covered to a large extent by the Directive. It is regrettable that the recent Commission progress report on renewable energy did not contain specific recommendations to individual Member States on the achievement of the targets set by 2020. It is not really possible to promote effective policies in this sector without a detailed analysis of the situation of the countries concerned and the provision of recommendations. I join in calling for special attention to be given to the transport sector, which is one of the main natural polluters. The development and advocacy of renewable fuels should become another pillar of principle for EU policies and Member States in this area.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Maintaining a balance between the need to ensure the Union's energy independence and self-sufficiency and the preservation of ecosystems and the protection of the environment is one of the greatest challenges with a profound impact on the lives of all citizens. Therefore, the promotion and search for renewable energy sources must always take into account the need to protect the environment and the need, in particular, for a prior evaluation of the possible impacts of each solution. The public interest in safe and clean energy must be a priority.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the progress report in the field of renewable energy sources, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 23/6/2016 and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on renewable energy because a stable long-term regulatory framework is needed. The transition to a sustainable energy system must include efforts in terms of energy efficiency, renewable energy, optimal use of Energy resources in Europe and smart infrastructure. The development of renewable energy should coincide with the development of a functioning internal electricity market that ensures a level playing field for all market participants. Renewable energy needs to involve stakeholders and consumers more in the energy system. The Commission should include in future interim reports on renewable energy an assessment of the impact of renewable energy sources on costs and prices, in particular household prices. Renewable energy production should be linked to the need to ensure continuity of conventional energy production as a prerequisite for sustainability, security of supply and competitiveness. The establishment of the member States' energy mix must remain a national competence, with energy mixes still very diversified. Last but not least, incentives for the development of indigenous energy sources, such as hydroelectricity, as a renewable energy source, remain a priority.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  This report contains several positive points: the consideration of users in situations of energy insecurity, training, the situation of consumer producers who suffer from excessively restrictive administrative and fiscal standards, but also the desire to exclude public investment from deficit targets and to involve citizens in national plans.  However, this report adopts an integrationist, even federalist, vision of the energy sector to which we strongly oppose. It sets a number of binding targets for Member States and aims to strengthen the Commission's role.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the report on progress in the field of renewable energy. While member states' progress in achieving national renewable energy targets attests to the merits of the Union's renewable energy policy, it is necessary to further encourage Member States that have reported slower developments to strengthen their efforts to ensure the achievement of the ambitious 2030 energy and climate targets that allow for a secure influx of investment and funding in the renewable energy sector. There is therefore a need to ensure an ambitious and transparent stable regulatory framework in order to ensure a fully sovereign, efficient and clean energy model for 2050.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The EU is on track to meet the 2020 targets of reducing CO2 emissions by 20%, increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption by up to 20%, and increasing energy efficiency by another 20%. But we must continue the development of renewable energy and ensure that this quota continues to rise over the next decade, reaching the 30% target in 2030, as the report we have approved, with my support, in this House, stresses.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The exploitation of renewable energy sources is the main objective of the Union with the main driving cause of environmental protection. The EU contributes to the fight against climate change and the development of new technologies with a view to the energy transition to renewable energy sources. I believe that the directive on renewable energy sources is a legal commitment for the Union to act in the right direction for a socially acceptable and sustainable energy production that is environmentally friendly and to the health of European citizens.  At the same time, this directive also contains mechanisms to monitor the application of the rules contained in order to achieve as far as possible the exploitation and development of renewable energy sources. I am voting in favour of this resolution in the hope that we will be able to create an efficient and efficient system in this area, through a strengthening of investment and proper control of the management of energy production.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The promotion of 'renewable energy' is of immense importance, but this report is inaccurate on certain points. The European Union is also trying to attract competences. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I realize, not without circumspection, that in the European Parliament, renewable energy, federalism and integration are intimately linked. If I am in favour of the first, I must admit that this systematic association does not allow to thwart common sense. Good ideas are developed in several areas, including the association of citizens with national plans for renewable energy. But there is talk of strengthening the Commission's role and adding more and more constraints to the Member States. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The EU as a whole is in the process of achieving the 2020 renewable energy targets, although further enhanced measures are needed in some Member States.  We must therefore all together continue to contribute to the achievement of the objectives set, to make the planet more sustainable for generations to come. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it is the responsibility of the EU to combat climate change through the utilisation of, and support for, renewable energy. By introducing proper and efficient regulation of the renewable energy market, we are moving forward towards the proposed clean energy model for 2050.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The EU is on track to meet its 2020 targets. This is the result of an ambitious move by the EU and its Member States towards a low-carbon economy based on more efficient use of energy and the tapping of renewable energy sources. In the context of the agreements she made at the Paris climate summit, it is a logical next step that she, together with the Member States, increases its ambitions, invests more in energy technology and strengthens the renewable energy directive.  The cost of renewable energy has fallen sharply in recent years. This creates opportunities to pursue an integrated, competitive and sustainable European energy policy. The optimal use of renewable energy sources, further technological innovations and the roll-out of smart energy networks are the main pillars of an ambitious, competitive European energy market. Citizens should therefore be encouraged to actively participate in this energy market, by generating energy themselves, using it, storing it and selling it. In some EU countries, wood biomass is the most widely used renewable energy form for heating. As forests are crucial to our ecosystem, responsible exploitation and sustainable use of our forests is important.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The development of renewable energy sources requires a new approach in order to become a cornerstone of the European Union's energy model. Our joint efforts and responsibilities are to combat climate change. Leading the development of strategic technologies to improve the energy transition requires strengthening our production model and creating quality jobs. At the same time, we must prevent energy oligopolies from being the ones who will determine the future of energy for Europe. With the adoption of the Renewable Energy Directive, Europe has started the process of transforming the energy mix of the Member States. This legal instrument, with binding targets and clear supervisory and control rules, has created a favourable environment for the development of the renewable energy sector and contributed to it having become a diverse and diversified sector. While public support measures have enabled a considerable degree of success in many Member States, political impetus is needed if we are to meet the targets set for 2020 and beyond. The regulation of the renewable energy sector at European level should solve many of the problems hampering the development of the sector, promote public investment, democratic control and a stable framework for investment in order to facilitate collective and democratic energy management in order to ensure a fully sovereign, efficient and clean energy model by 2050. I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ This report looks at progress towards meeting the EU’s 2020 20% renewable energy target, and also looks forward to the post-2020 framework. I agree with the main objective of the report and that we need to adopt a new approach towards renewable energy at European level. Climate change is a fact and we have the responsibility to combat it, and to solve the social and environmental problems it creates, before it is too late. We need to reduce our dependence on energy resources, and shift towards a sustainable energy production model, if we wish to avoid serious social and environmental consequences. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report, although with reservations on certain passages which, in my opinion, do not fit with the main objective of the report and are not realistic.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The renewable energy progress report assesses the Member States’ efforts in the promotion and use of renewable energy. In the run-up to the review of the Renewable Energy Directive and associated instruments, which will take place later this year, Parliament took the opportunity to show its support for this legal mechanism that has an enormous potential to drive substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. Although we acknowledge the growth driven by the development of renewable energy in various sectors, some constructive criticisms are nonetheless in order, to make the framework sustainable to the fullest degree. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution that seeks to orientate policy towards a cost-efficient and clean energy model for 2050.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy proposes a resolution on the European Commission's 2015 renewable energy progress report. The report agrees that the EU has a historic duty to combat climate change and to reduce its dependence on external energy sources. Renewable energies must be made the main pillar of the European Union's energy model. The report notes that, with the adoption of Directive 2009/28/EC on renewable energies, which sets binding targets, Europe has started to restructure the energy mix of the Member States.  However, while Austria, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Croatia, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania and Sweden have already prematurely or will soon meet their 2020 targets, Belgium, the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Malta and Spain are called on by the report to take further measures to ensure that their 2020 targets are met. It states that a decisive political push is needed if the EU is to achieve and exceed the targets set for 2020. It also points out that capital costs have drifted considerably apart within the EU-28, resulting in a dividing line between north/west and south/east, and therefore considers it necessary to establish an EU financial mechanism to reduce the high cost of capital resulting from the risk of renewable energy projects. I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Even if we are in favour of renewable energy, the tone of the report, which is very openly in favour of strengthening the Commission's powers at the expense of those of the States, does not allow it to be voted on as it stands.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2009/28/EU sets a target for the European Union to achieve 20 % of energy consumption from renewable sources by 2020. In this context, it is essential to ensure that the Commission is strengthened to ensure that Member States not only meet the objectives set out in the Directive, but also adapt measures to that effect. Examples of this are measures to better access funding channels or even the establishment of a financial mechanism at EU level to support the implementation of these measures, as well as to improve administrative procedures to take account of cost-benefit schemes. The combination of renewable energy and energy efficiency policies are key factors that can contribute to reducing the European Union's energy dependency, as the EU imports more than half of its energy consumption, representing 20% of total imports. To this end, I am voting in favour of this report, as I think it is important for the European Union to have a long-term strategy to encourage investment in renewable energies.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Although some of the guidelines are good in terms of renewable energy, the clearly integrationist tone of the report does not allow me to vote as it stands. I'm voting against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. This report takes stock of progress in the renewable energy sector. The European Union, which imports more than 50% of the energy it consumes for EUR 1 billion per day, is heavily dependent on energy, particularly for crude oil, natural gas and coal. The European Union must promote renewable energy through incentives, including tax incentives, in order to meet its 20% renewable energy target for 2020. I therefore voted in favour of this text, while opposing its provisions aimed at promoting renewable energy by coercion.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Faced with a steady rise in global temperature to 1.5°C compared to pre-industrial levels, due to the disproportionate use of non-renewable and unsustainable energy resources, we warmly welcome the proposal. The development of renewable sources through Directive 2009/28/EC has significantly reduced production costs and thus fostered EU technological leadership that will create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy between now and 2020. Therefore, of fundamental importance becomes not only greater cooperation and coordination between The Member States but above all the combination of binding national action plans together with common objectives, verified through biennial controls, in order to comply with the commitments promised by the Paris Agreement (COP 21). This is possible through powerful economic incentives, such as the implementation of tax relief and the promotion of public investment, in order to facilitate a transition to a fully autonomous, efficient and clean energy model for 2050. In order to achieve this, we also believe it is necessary to support research and development activities and to support Member States to take additional measures in order to achieve these ambitious objectives in time.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must set an example to other global actors in the fight against climate change. I welcome the kind of approach that gives renewable energies a greater role, since the long-term objective is to reduce dependence on energy sources outside the European Union. We need to move towards a sustainable model of energy production, because the security of society as a whole is at stake here. I am very confident that, with the support of this report, the 2020 renewable energy targets will be achieved and that the necessary action will be achieved in all Member States.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The development of renewable energies calls for a new approach that entails making them the main pillar of the European Union’s energy model. I voted for this report, which looks at progress towards meeting the EU’s 2020 20% renewable energy target, and also looks forward to the post-2020 framework.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Union must continue and strengthen the policy of developing the renewable energy industry, a policy that is close to achieving its 2020 targets. Thanks to technological advances in recent years, advances in the creation and storage process, the costs of producing energy from renewable sources have decreased significantly. This now allows this energy to be increasingly competitive with fossil energy. I welcome the proposal contained in the report to step up cooperation between the European Commission and the Member States to improve energy performance from renewable sources, energy that consumes few natural resources, having the same qualities and, last but not least, energy that reduces pollution and greenhouse gases.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the progress report on renewable energy because I consider political support for the transformation of the energy network towards the use of renewables to be absolutely crucial. This is not only due to efforts to combat climate change, but also to the issue of energy security and support for the development of new sectors of the economy. I also appreciate the report's critical approach to certain aspects of promoting renewables, such as the promotion of biofuels in transport.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This report was a positive and progressive one, which highlighted the need for a modal shift and for higher energy efficiency of renewables in order to improve the sustainability of transport. Furthermore, it criticises the promotion of biofuels for transport, which competes with the food production sector. The report also analyses how Member States have done in achieving their renewable energy targets. There is currently an EU target of 20%, which is shared by Member States and broken down into national targets. Ireland has fallen short of the heat energy target. While this is not acceptable, the report correctly expresses concern that some Member States may have to revise policies and instruments in order to achieve their targets. For these reasons outlined above, I voted in favour.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The report notes that the EU as a whole is making good progress towards meeting the 2020 renewable energy targets, but that further active action is needed in some Member States. Ambitious renewable energy policies, combined with energy efficiency, are a major driver for reducing the EU's dependence on imports and its overall energy import costs, as well as increasing energy security vis-à-vis external suppliers. The EU imports more than half the energy it consumes and the cost of these imports amounts to more than €1 billion. eur per day (over 50% of total imports). The report recognises that enhanced regional cooperation in the field of renewable energy is key to ensuring the further development of renewable energy sources. I support the proposed resolution.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted neutrally against this report. Promoting renewable energy is one of the greatest challenges of our time. Nevertheless, the report contains aspects to which I am critical. There is also a climate package negotiated among the Member States, which should be implemented first.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with this report, as the development of renewable energy requires a new approach to make it a key pillar of the European energy model. Of course, the fight against climate change is one of the priority priorities for each of us, which is a historic duty that we must fulfil. It is necessary to create a favourable environment for the development of the renewable energy sector, which promotes the growth of the intermodal and diversified sector, public investment, democratic control and a stable investment system that facilitates collective and democratic energy management. There is also a need to make good use of the huge potential for job creation in the renewable energy sector.  I believe that the Commission should present a more ambitious 2030 climate and energy package, which would raise the renewable energy target to at least 30%. In addition, Member States should be more effective in pursuing energy efficiency policies and providing targeted social guarantees that are geared towards vulnerable consumers.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the progress report on renewable energy in plenary, thus welcoming the European Parliament's objective of re-using these sources, making them capable of shaping the European Union's energy model. The outline of a more efficient energy model, which makes renewable energy more manageable, cannot be unassociated with the objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and the subsequent implementation of the recent Paris Agreement 2015. There is the right regulatory framework, as long as it includes a more binding target on the use of renewable energy sources, so that we can talk about an effective path towards the Union's long-term climate targets 2050.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against climate change and the search for alternative methods that can reduce dependence on the European Union's external energy sources are answered in the Renewables Directive (2009/28/EC). The process of transforming the Energy Mix of the Member States allows the creation of a favourable environment for the development of the renewable energy sector. However, I note the concerns raised in the report and support what has been said about the need to resolve these problems. I say that I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ An important part of the European Union's environmental and energy policy relates to the obtaining and use of energy from renewable energy sources. I welcome this report, which shows that European renewables policy has been successful so far. Today, European Union countries, including Croatia, are heavily dependent on energy imports. Europe imports 53% of its energy and pays more than €1 billion a day for these imports. To reduce this dependence, we need to focus on those sources of energy that are locally available to us, and these sources certainly include renewable energy sources.   This report also provides guidance for new EU legislation, which should continue to implement EU policy successfully even after 2020. It is the field of agriculture and forestry that can get a strong boost if the potentials neglected so far are recognized and exploited. Harnessing the full potential of the agricultural and forestry sectors through investments in the production of advanced biofuels can contribute to the creation of 146,000 permanent and another 162,000 temporary jobs in the EU, which would significantly contribute to the revival of our rural areas and the stay of people in the countryside.  I supported this report and hope that Croatia will identify its strengths and do the necessary to ensure that national policy in synergy with EU policies delivers the needs and desired results.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The transition to a sustainable energy production model is a political, economic, social and environmental priority for the European Union. The Renewables Directive has proved to be an effective tool for initiating the process of transforming its Member States' energy mix, with binding targets and clear supervisory and control rules. We are close to achieving the targets set for 2020 and it is now necessary to send a strong political signal for the continuation of this strategy, setting significantly higher objectives than those proposed by the Council. The report states that, by 2030, at least 30 % of energy must come from renewable sources. A more ambitious target (up to 45 %) That would be desirable, but Parliament is still correcting the council's disappointing 27 % proposal upwards. At the same time, the report reiterates the need for these objectives to be pursued by all Member States as laid down in the old directive, and not only at European level as the new Council proposal would like. In order to expect concrete results, the Member States should be made responsible by predicting certain targets. The report promotes the development of renewables as a fundamental pillar of the EU's energy model and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ As ambitious renewable energy policies coupled with energy efficiency are an important driving force for reducing the EU's dependence on imports and its overall external energy cost and for increasing energy security with respect to external suppliers, and as the EU imports more than half of the total energy it consumes, at a cost of more than €1 billion every day , which accounts for more than 20% of total imports and since import dependency is particularly high in terms of crude oil, natural gas and stone carbon, I call for greater use of renewable energy. While I am pleased to note that the EU is well on its way to reaching its 2020 target, I am concerned about the large number of countries that, according to the Commission's estimates for 2014-2020 from the 2015 Renewable Energy Progress Report, may need to strengthen their policies and instruments to reach their 2020 targets. I call on lagging Member States to take additional measures to make up for the backlog. I welcome the fact that some Member States have already achieved or will soon reach their 2020 targets, well ahead of schedule, such as Croatia.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the European Parliament, thanks to my vote, approved this report today. The report assesses the progress made by the EU towards achieving a 20% share of renewables in the EU energy mix by 2020. At the same time, the report looks at the outlook for the post-2020 period. As in the energy efficiency report, I am not happy with the low-ambitious targets that the Commission originally proposed – the Commission has abolished binding targets at national level and has only set a Europe-wide target of 27% by 2030, which is very little. I am therefore very glad that a clear message has been sent to the Commission in the sense that it is precisely because of the binding national targets that the current targets for 2020 have been achieved and that the abolition of national targets is a major mistake. Furthermore, the Social Democrats have long held the view that the EU-wide target for 2030 should be at least a 45% share of renewables, and this requirement has also been made in the report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 One of our key responsibilities is to combat climate change and reduce dependence on energy resources from the rest of the world if we are to generate quality jobs, as well as drive the development of strategic technologies for energy transition. The EU has provided itself with a legal instrument to achieve these objectives with the Renewables Directive (2009/28/EC). This legal instrument has created a favourable environment for the development of the renewable energy sector and has contributed to the growth of a diverse and diverse sector. I believe that the next revision of the Renewable Energy Directive should include measures to promote and encourage investment in these sectors. A more integrated market is essential for the development of renewable energies and the reduction of energy costs. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The progress report of the Renewable Energy Directive adopted in 2009, which is currently being debated, is a mid-term review of the Directive and contains a preliminary refit assessment. The European Commission's report concludes that twenty-five Member States are on track to meet binding renewable energy targets and five have already achieved or are about to meet their targets. The INI report welcomes closer coordination between Member States and regions, which is in line with the Commission's assessment that cooperation mechanisms should be better used if renewable energy targets are to be achieved. While the INI report concludes that the definition of the energy mix of Member States is a national competence, it also makes several references to binding national targets and taxation, criticises the lack of country-specific recommendations, advocates a greater role for the Commission in monitoring Member States' actions by increasing surveillance capacity, and proposes to increase the EU's renewable energy targets. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Today, the European Union imports more than 50% of the energy it consumes and is dependent on oil, natural gas or coal. I voted in favour of this text, which underlines the importance of renewable energy, a sector which represents more than one million jobs in Europe, in order to achieve the objectives that the Union has set itself.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 On renewable energy, the European Union has carried out exemplary work. This report, a true statement of science on the relevant social and environmental externalities arising from today's energy production models, warns of the need for regulation of the sector, ensuring its competitiveness and preventing, for example, energy oligopolies.  Having said that, in my view, which i am an integral to, this report has done well in desecrate renewable energies as one of the most efficient ways of reducing dependence on fossil fuels and, at the same time, contributing to the creation of the so-called low-carbon economy.   Also in this context, the report promotes competitiveness and the best cost-benefit ratio in the renewable energy market, without prejudice to the diversity and safeguarding of member states' competences in this area. And what is not of any importance, the document favours a sustainable energy system, in which dependence on subsidies is gradually met - and suppressed - in a self-sufficient internal market regulated by the Commission, particularly on the price of energy. From what comes to be exposed, my vote is in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Renewable energy is likely to be the world's leading energy source by 2030. The European Union, including Belgium, therefore has a strong interest in focusing on the clean energy sector, if only to reduce its energy dependence. This is roughly what the report of the report, adopted this afternoon, underlines, which more precisely lists the progress made in the renewable energy sector. Some Member States have already achieved or will soon reach their 2020 targets, where others have fallen a little behind. But that would be to ignore the geographical and topographical characteristics that really differ from one European territory to another. Clearly, not all Member States are equal in ensuring their energy transition. Belgium, for example, does not have the mountain ranges of Austria or the forests of Sweden to focus on the development of hydropower or biomass. However, as the European Parliament's resolution points out, all Member States must demonstrate a common ambition, opt for the decarbonisation of their industries and aim for the 30% renewable energy target by 2030.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. Renewable energy is an essential component of the EU's energy policy, both reducing polluting emissions and strengthening the Union's energy independence.   In this regard, while the majority of Member States are on track to meet the EU's ambitious targets in this area (20% renewable energy by 2020), inequalities in achievement between them remain, including France, which is lagging behind in meeting its climate and energy targets. Furthermore, we MEPs have reiterated the need for the Commission and the Member States to ensure a stable regulatory framework for the various players on renewable energy, to ensure coherence between the various EU policies and to strengthen investment in the sector.  In line with these political lines, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes stock of the EU's actions on renewable energy, and lists the efforts to be made to achieve the 2020 and 2030 targets. The energy and ecological transition is an imperative, as the COP 21 agreement recently demonstrated, and it must be encouraged as it has benefits, particularly in terms of improving public health, creating jobs and increasing the comfort of life. That is why it is essential that Member States, in their respective strategies, ensure that they will fulfil their objectives and strengthen their policies for those who are not sure they are achieving them, particularly in key sectors such as electricity, heating and cooling or transport. It is thereby not acceptable to see a decrease in investment in renewable energy in Europe. In addition, citizens should be allowed to be an integral part of this transition and a relevant and equitable framework for self-production and self-consumption should be created.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I share the European Parliament's majority position in favour of 30% renewables by 2030, through binding national targets, more ambitious than that adopted by the Council. An idea that the EPP does not share, as it has expressed with its vote and commissioner Cañete's action, pending to appear because of the scandals that splatter on it. Always with the opposition of the EPP, our amendment to quality employment in renewables has been adopted. However, we must regret that the one that advocated the adoption of specific social guarantees in favour of vulnerable consumers, that is, those in situations of energy poverty, should be rejected.  The report responds to the drama of retroactive measures against renewable aid approved by my country's current government, calling on the Commission to avoid such changes and to ensure the economic viability of existing assets. Surprisingly, once again against the general feel of the House, the PPE's opposition not to penalize self-production and energy self-consumption with additional taxes or fees. Generally speaking, with the caveats made, the result is positive and my vote has been deserved in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. On the eve of the revision of the European legislative framework in the autumn, the European Parliament on Thursday (June 23rd) reaffirmed its high ambitions for renewable energy by 2030. The text of the adopted resolution emphasizes the key role of self-production and self-consumption, decentralised renewable energy production and collective energy management through municipalities, all areas in which the forthcoming revision of the Renewable Energy Directive should encourage investment. I also voted in favour of an amendment which underlines the enormous potential for job creation in the renewable energy sector and calls on Member States to ensure that labour standards are not weakened as a result of the energy transition, which should also be based on the creation of quality jobs.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of renewable energy is a key indicator of the EU's progress towards a sustainable and anti-future economy. Reading the report presented by the Commission is encouraging the achievements of the Member States, at least most of them, in the transition from fossil fuels to local or renewable. At the same time, I believe that the Commission could also emphasise in the report the importance of renewable energy for regional development. After all, the transition to local fuels saves money that would otherwise be spent on the fuel to be transported. In addition, renewable energy creates jobs and, in many cases, stimulates innovation.  At the same time, I would particularly like to highlight the two most important messages that the European Parliament and the Member States are sending in their resolution to the European Commission and the Member States. Firstly, reduce bureaucratic barriers to the development of renewable energy. This is particularly true for Member States, where the dominant large energy companies do not particularly admire the possibility of adopting green energy into the common energy mix. The second message is that many Member States have already achieved the renewable energy targets set for the period up to 2020. And it was not difficult to do this, in most cases it has already paid off. This means that it is time to move towards more ambitious targets, to the requirement to produce at least half of the energy from renewable sources.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The future of the European Union's energy model is fundamentally based on the development of renewable energy sources. In order to achieve this desired model, it is imperative that we combat climate change and reduce our external energy dependence (especially fossil fuels), creating our own production model, more environmentally friendly, generating quality jobs and fostering the creation of a new technological (strategic) era in this area. This model of energy production should be a social priority, regulated and with broad participation of businesses and citizens, which is not dependent on the market for oligopolies and does not imply serious social and environmental externalities.  Directive 2009/28/EC is the anchor legislative instrument on which the entire process of energy transformation to be developed by Member States by 2020 is based, despite the fact that more ambitious targets need to be set in the light of what was recently established in the Paris Agreement. I therefore endorse the rapporteur's considerations on the need to develop this energy production model, to redesign it at European level and to make it an engine of economic growth, capable of fostering public investment, generating wealth, creating jobs and ensuring an efficient and environmentally sustainable energy model in the long term.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the important progress that has been made within the Union in the renewable energy sector, while underlining the many efforts that still need to be made.  This report highlights the need to share best practices in terms of national renewable energy policies and to promote their adoption within the framework of a more convergent European model. It stresses the need to guarantee access to finance, especially for SMEs, and to support research and development in the field of renewable energy. Transparency, convergence of practices and increased investment will enable our environmental policy to progress and become more efficient.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on progress on renewable energy, to which much attention is paid at European level and on which the Commission should present a new proposal by the end of 2016, following the communication published in June last year. The text discussed in the ITRE Committee, of which I am a member, contains many strengths necessary to achieve the objectives set for 2020 in the energy field. These include the cost-effectiveness and competitiveness of renewable energies, the protection of national competences for the energy mix and the promotion of diversification of energy sources. Needless to say, renewables represent an increasingly concrete future in the energy landscape, with a Union increasingly oriented in this direction. However, the project of a 100 % renewable economy seems to me to be frankly unrealistic, especially in the short term. That is why I believe that gas is a resource that should not be underestimated for the EU's energy needs.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Paloma López Bermejo's report because it lays a good basis for the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive. It underlines the potential for job creation, the benefits to the economy, as well as the centrality of renewable development to combat climate change. It sets ambitious targets and calls for them to be binding. It also promotes self-consumption and democratization of the energy system

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ Renewable energy contributes to increased energy independence and reduced greenhouse gases. Some good progress has been made. However, the 2030 targets need to be ambitious enough to send a strong signal for investment in renewable energy projects which are sustainable both economically and environmentally. Sustainability criteria for biomass will be especially important in the coming years.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Renewable Energy Progress Report'.  Some Member States are still a long way from meeting the renewable energy targets by 2020. The report analyses and criticises precisely this and calls on the Member States to develop best practices together and thus to improve their current strategies.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents significant support for the development of the renewable energy sector and an important call to Member States that are not meeting the objectives of the Directive. The report echoes the progress of the sector but also of the problems they encounter in certain member states such as "sun tax", the retroactivity of support measures, difficulties in accessing the network. etc. also refers to the need to generate quality employment and to include trade unions and civil society in the development of these energies. Specific proposals are also made on the definition of prosumers, support for modal change in transport, development of renewable refrigeration technologies, public investment in the sector, etc. This makes the text an important reference for the development of the next directive, which is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Agriculture is a special sector, not only because of its strategic importance in the production and supply of food, but is also an extremely important supplier of raw materials for industry and, increasingly, for the energy sector. This issue is particularly important in the context of the drive to reduce the Union's energy dependency, which covers 50% of its energy needs from imports. Today, the Union is the world's largest energy importer, with around €400 billion a year in expenditure. More addition, in the context of climate challenges, agriculture and forestry are sectors with, in addition to carbon dioxide emissions in production processes, also a huge natural potential for capturing CO2 from the air, which deserves attention when making appropriate conversions. It is therefore worth encouraging research and innovation in the development of bio-energy installations and not creating excessive administrative burdens and obstacles that would hamper the development of this sector, which also has significant potential for job creation. It may be important for rural development now and in the future to be able to sell the energy generated to the electricity grid and to design a system that would primarily purchase energy from such sources. A stable mechanism for individual energy producers, which provides price predictability over the longer term, is also likely to be needed for the proper development of the energy sector.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The renewable energy sector employs more than 1 million people in Europe and is worth over EUR 13 billion per year. It is pleased that today 26% of THE EU's energy is generated from renewable sources and around 10% of the EU's total electricity comes from variable renewable electricity sources (e.g. wind and solar) and more and more people are accepting renewables as a natural source of energy. Although all European countries should achieve the binding 2020 targets for renewable energy, for some Member States that are already slowly making progress, further action is needed. Although some progress has been made in the field of renewable energy (reducing energy costs), the diversity of different policies to promote renewable energy sources risks further wideling the competitiveness gap between EU Member States. I supported the resolution because the proposed measures create additional opportunities for the development of renewable energy sources that can help ensure energy security and sovereignty, eradicate energy poverty and promote the EU's economic development.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I finally supported the resolution on the progress report on renewable energy. The non-binding resolution responds to the Commission's evaluation report last year and provides impetus for the Commission to revise the relevant legislation in the coming way. In its report, the Commission notes that the target of achieving at least a 20% share of renewable energy consumption in 2020 is likely to be met, which is welcomed by the European Parliament. I am pleased that the Czech Republic is recognised in the resolution as a country meeting its objective well in advance. The resolution responds to some of the challenges that the deployment of renewables has brought and calls for an effective solution to them. For example, it stresses that some Member States have neglected their transmission networks and are now unable to accommodate fluctuations in renewable energy – the Czech Republic is also facing the consequences of the shortcomings of the German transmission network. I also consider it important to mention the impact of promoting renewable energy on agriculture. The cultivation of crops for the production of biofuels must not go against the production of food or its safety.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of energy from renewable sources requires a new approach to become a fundamental pillar of the European Union's energy model. The fight against climate change is our basic responsibility and a historic duty that we must fulfil. We also need to reduce our dependence on energy resources from other parts of the world if we are to consolidate our production model and create quality jobs and play a leading role in the development of strategic technologies for the energy transition. The transition to a sustainable energy production model is a social priority that cannot be addressed only from a market perspective. For this reason, we must understand that regulation and democratic participation are necessary to prevent serious social and environmental externalities. We must prevent the future of energy for Europe from being determined by energy oligopoles. It is important that we try to achieve the objective of building the economy 100% on renewable energy. The report supports the importance of binding objectives at national level and the need for a stable political framework. This report calls for more ambitious targets by 2030 and the exposure of those countries that are currently declining in renewable sourcing. At the initiative of the Greens, the report is also strengthened in the area of future energy management and clearly defines the reporting requirements of countries in this area. For this reasons, I supported the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. This report is an interim review of the implementation of the 2009 Renewable Energy Directive. It contains some good elements, such as.B. the call for closer cooperation across the EU and the need to promote renewable energy in a cost-effective way and to be competitive. However, the report also contains elements that go far beyond the intended scope. For example, the rapporteur proposes fiscal measures to promote renewable energies or greater monitoring and control by the European Commission. In addition, the report raises the renewable energy target adopted by the Council from 27% to 30%. ALFA believes that we should be guided by the objectives adopted by the Council and that decisions on the implementation of decisions should be left to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen its production model, the EU must reduce its dependence on energy sources from the rest of the world. The regulation of renewables should avoid impending problems and solve existing ones.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The development of renewable energy can greatly contribute to energy security and sovereignty, as well as to eradicating energy poverty and fostering the economic development of the European Union. Renewables are important for providing stable, affordable and sustainable energy to European citizens who, inter alia, can benefit from their own generation through renewable energy sources.  I support this report, as I believe that the European Union is well on track to meet the 2020 renewable energy targets, but that each Member State must make even more efforts individually. I also believe that a stable and long-term regulatory framework is needed for the European Union to achieve economic growth, create new jobs and maintain a leading role in these areas globally. Finally, in order for the European Union to reduce its dependence on imports and the overall external cost to energy and increase energy security in relation to external suppliers, it is essential that it has an ambitious renewable energy policy and energy efficiency.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ In order for renewables to become a major pillar of the European Union's energy model, a new approach to their development is needed. Today, our main responsibility must be to fight climate change. To strengthen our energy model, we need to create quality jobs, focus the development of strategic technologies and reduce dependence on energy sources from the rest of the world. The transition to a sustainable energy production model is a social priority, so we need to understand that democratic participation and regulation are necessary to avoid adverse effects on the environment and society. Regulation of renewable energy sources at European level would solve a number of problems that hinder their development with a view to achieving a sovereign, efficient and clean energy model by 2050. Support schemes should focus on technologies that have great potential to reduce renewable energy costs and increase the market uplisibility of renewable energy. I support this report because I think the guidelines in it are of quality and highlight the potential that renewable energy development has for Europe. I also think it is of utmost importance to establish a fundamental right to self-generation and self-consumption.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on progress in the field of renewable energy. The European Union's 2020 targets for renewable sourcing are ambitious enough, and the European Union as a whole is well on its way to achieving these, but there is still a lot of reserves in some Member States. It is therefore up to the Commission to ensure that the Renewable Energy Directive 2020 is fully implemented, while ensuring a robust legal framework beyond 2020, with binding renewable energy targets aligned with the most effective way of achieving the Union's long-term climate objectives.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it moves in the right direction to create an integrated strategy for the development and support of renewable energy sources.  Among other things, it is stressed that the development of renewable energy sources must be recognised as a fundamental pillar of our energy policy. It is also noted that in order to combat climate change, to tackle energy poverty and to develop a productive energy model for the benefit of society, it is very important to set binding and ambitious targets.        Equally important are the references to the need to strengthen public investment to promote the necessary infrastructure, to promote measures to support small producers of renewable energy sources and measures to ensure that renewables are boosted at the lowest possible cost to consumers. He rightly pointed out that in this process democratic control and collective management are essential elements in order to better serve the needs and interests of society and to ensure energy as a social good, to which all peoples have equal and cheap access.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. In 1968, researchers warned the American Petroleum Institute that carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels could lead to global environmental changes. 48 years later and while science and technology have made strides, appropriate technologies are still not being applied to make the best use of renewable energy sources. We wondered why?  The conscious concealment of scientific findings, the cover-up of information and the deliberate misleading of public opinion have imposed the short-sighted policy of temporary profitability of large companies at the expense of corresponding viable choices. Oil giants and trade groups spend $115 million a year blocking climate policies. At the same time, they are pushing for natural gas to emerge as the key technology by which Europe will economically reduce carbon dioxide emissions. The European Union is associated with the situation by setting low targets and exercising moderate policies. We're criminal. Not only at the expense of the environment, but above all at the expense of our children. Politics must not be the subject of centres of economic power and obscene profitability. The development and implementation of renewable energy sources must be substantially supported and those responsible for sussing must be punished.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the incentive for renewable energies and that it should be made the main pillar of the EU energy model. I absolutely agree with the statement that we have a fundamental responsibility to fight climate change and a historical duty that we must fulfil.
