We must also reduce our dependence on energy sources from other parts of the world if we are to structure our production model, create quality jobs and be at the forefront of the development of the strategic technologies on which our energy transition is based. I consider it a fundamental problem that the European Council supports such a low target of 27% for the period after 2020 (until 2030). There is also concern that the target is mandatory only at EU level, thus a possibility for some Member States to hide in the shadow of high-performing Member States.  That is why I supported the report, in which we insist on a higher target and its binding nature at Member State level. I believe that the age of energy lobbies intertwined with governments is over, and I agree that energy policy is already a social priority, not just an economic one. I share the view that regulation of the renewable energy sector at European level must solve a number of problems hindering its development, promote public investment and democratic supervision and create a stable investment framework for collective and democratic governance of the energy sector in order to create a fully autonomous, efficient and clean energy model by 2050.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The 2009 Renewable Energy Directive sets a target of achieving a 20% share of this type of energy in final energy consumption by 2020, and also assumes that Member States are free to decide how they will support renewable energy at home. According to the Commission's report, most Member States are on track to meet the 2009 target and more than 15% of energy in the EU comes from renewable sources. However, some EU countries have and will have significant difficulties in achieving their plans due to the nature of their economies. The European Parliament's report points out that the Union needs a coherent long-term strategy to ensure future investments in renewable energy. In addition, the document stressed the importance of access to capital and proposes new financial mechanisms, in particular to facilitate administrative procedures or support schemes.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 As a whole, the report is good and balanced. However, the points on sustainability criteria for biofuels and bio-liquids are problematic for forests. Paragraphs 84 and 85 refer rather negatively to the use of forest biomass as an energy source for renewable biomass. A prepared approach to the use of forests at the beginning of paragraph 84 is not a good starting point. In addition, paragraph 85 provides room for interpretation as to whether or not forest biomass is considered to be sustainable biomass. In europe's forest-intensive countries, forest resources are growing despite the energy use of wood raw materials. The practice of forest management is that forests grow more than they are felled. This makes the forest a truly renewable raw material. Despite the successful report as a whole because of forest references, I voted against the report.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Renewable energy is placed at the heart of the Eu ropean Union's energy model in this report and we have therefore voted in favour of it. As a victory, we find in the report many of our demands, such as the call for a more ambitious target for renewable energy sources to be at least 30 %, to be declined in individual national objectives, as well as the creation of a solid and transparent governance system, which will increase the participation of citizens. Furthermore, among the points presented by the M5S and passed in plenary, is the inclusion in the directive of a specific chapter dedicated to the energy of local communities and citizens, which stresses the centrality of citizens as prosumers and the fundamental rights to self-handling and self-consumption, storage and resale of the energy surplus and therefore also the need to outline a shared definition of the term prosumer. Other important points requested in committee and maintained are the call for Member States to develop a community energy strategy and to define a more favourable investment environment for self-handling and self-consumption together with the creation of single support counters. For transport we have asked and obtained to evaluate the potential inherent in trolley-truck technologies.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Global warming has brought to the fore the need to develop the renewable energy sector. The European Union and Member States have formally supported this process in recent decades, becoming the world's leading promoters of renewable energies. However, the transition to the sustainable energy production model involves an important regulatory effort, particularly at social, environmental and competitiveness level. The beginning was made by the adoption of Directive 2009/28/EC on renewable energy, which contributed to the development and diversification of this sector at European level. However, there is a need for a more ambitious political impetus to achieve the objectives set in the 2020 and the next. There is now a need to regulate the use of biofuels in transport in order to avoid a negative impact on the food industry, a stable investment framework, the creation of new quality jobs in the field and the maintenance of binding targets at national level. Without the latter, it will be impossible to make the progress needed to achieve the targets set for the 2030 horizon. I therefore support the adoption of the current form of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The development of renewable energies requires a new approach that would make them the cornerstone of the European Union's energy model. Our fundamental responsibility is to combat climate change, a historic task that we must carry out. We must also reduce our dependence on energy resources from the rest of the world if we aspire to structure our production model, create quality jobs and spearhead the development of the strategic technologies underlying our energy transition. The transition to a sustainable long-term energy production model is a social priority that cannot be left to the market alone. On the contrary, we must understand that regulation and democratic participation are essential if serious social and environmental externalities are to be avoided. We must prevent energy oligopolies from dictating Europe's energy future.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report on the implementation of the Renewables Directive (2009/28/EC) concentrates on the results achieved, their added value and the opportunities provided for European citizens and businesses, as well as reasons why certain Member States are struggling to meet ambitious targets set in the directive. While most of the Member States are well on track to achieving 20% renewables targets by 2020, and some are even ahead, a few will probably fail to deliver. The European policies on renewable energy and sustainability are very important, especially for our future development. The rapporteur made a number of good points and, even though I do not agree on all the points in the report, I believe it is important to recognise the role of renewables in the EU’s energy market and to support their further integration into the market. Therefore, I supported the report.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The modernisation of the European Union's energy model requires the development of renewable energies. Wind, tides and sun are inexhaustible resources. On the other hand, oil, gas and coal, in addition to their polluting effects, are not infinite resources. The energy transition must overcome climate change and our dependence on imported energy resources, and create jobs. We refuse to give the market the sole transition to this new model. On the contrary, democratic participation and regulation are essential to ensure the social and environmental component. Europe's energy future cannot be dictated by multinationals, at the risk of causing negative externalities.   The left must be at the fore in the energy transition. The Union must accelerate the development of clean energy. The 20% renewable energy target by 2020 is therefore only a first step. Efforts must be maintained to achieve 30% renewable energy by 2030. These are the conditions for a social and sustainable Europe.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Renewable Energy Directive adopted on 23 April 2009 sets a mandatory target that by 2020 20% of energy consumption in the European Union must come from renewable energy sources. Renewable energy sources (wind, solar, hydropower, ocean energy, geothermal energy, biomass and biofuels) are a substitute for fossil fuels and contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, diversified energy supply and reducing dependence on unreliable and volatile fossil fuel markets, in particular oil and gas.  While I support the use of these renewable energy sources, I believe that their regulation should remain the responsibility of states and should not be addressed at European level. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on renewable energy. The European Union is on track to achieve its target of 20% of the share of green energy. The report proves that Europe is good at green energy, and green energy is good for Europe. Renewable energy sources are one of the most effective ways to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and contribute to the creation of a low-carbon economy. In addition, renewable energy sources are cost-effective, increase market competitiveness and promote diversity. However, there is a need to improve national policies, and the Commission must strengthen its role in monitoring and supporting progress in the field of renewable energy.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Paloma López Bermejo's report because it lays a good basis for the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive. It underlines the potential for job creation, the benefits to the economy, as well as the centrality of renewable development to combat climate change. It sets ambitious targets and calls for them to be binding. It also promotes self-consumption and the democratization of the energy system.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. This report is an interim review of the implementation of the 2009 Renewable Energy Directive. It contains some good elements, such as.B. the call for closer cooperation across the EU and the need to promote renewable energy in a cost-effective way and to be competitive. However, the report also contains elements that go far beyond the intended scope. For example, the rapporteur proposes fiscal measures to promote renewable energies or greater monitoring and control by the European Commission. In addition, the report raises the renewable energy target adopted by the Council from 27% to 30%. ALFA believes that we should be guided by the objectives adopted by the Council and that decisions on the implementation of decisions should be left to the Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Our societies are living a transition towards a low-carbon economy, but there are strong vested interests close to national governments that make it difficult. It is thus fundamental that the EU maintains a strong position to ensure that countries make it easy for renewable energies. In Spain, both the PSOE and the PP have adopted policies that have deeply undermined the growth of renewable energy. Auto-consumption of energy and binding national targets are very important to ensure the energy transition.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. In this report, there are a few interesting points: users in situations of energy insecurity; Training (which is a key issue in these policies); The citizens' association with national renewable energy plans; The review of the situation of consumer producers, for whom administrative and tax rules should be simplified. I myself am in favour of renewable energy. However, this text is a veritable summary of integrationist, even federalist, ideology.  So I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union needs to rethink its energy policy thoroughly. Renewable energy sources are a good solution for diversifying energy sources. However, regulation cannot be imposed on all Member States that interfere with their energy mix. Any legislation must be adapted to the capabilities of individual Member States of the European Union. It makes no sense to adopt any directive that does not take this into account. I therefore did not support the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of renewable energies requires a new approach, which makes them the main pillar of the European Union's energy model. We have a fundamental responsibility to fight climate change and a historical duty that we must fulfil. We must also reduce our dependence on energy sources from other parts of the world if we are to structure our production model, create quality jobs and be at the forefront of the development of the strategic technologies on which our energy transition is based. By my vote, I followed the group's position in the final vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Paloma López Bermejo's report because it lays a good basis for the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive. It underlines the potential for job creation, the benefits to the economy, as well as the centrality of renewable development to combat climate change. It sets ambitious targets and calls for them to be binding. It also promotes self-consumption and the democratization of the energy system.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's commitments in the field of renewable energy; In the context of the Renewable Energy Directive, I believe that the current combination of binding national targets, national renewable energy plans and biennially controls has been the main driving force behind the development of renewable energy capacity in the EU.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the renewable energy progress report. The report stresses the importance of simple, accessible, affordable and efficient administrative procedures. The development of renewable energies calls for a new approach that entails making them the main pillar of the European Union’s energy model. The report highlights the significance of an EU legislative proposal on energy market rules, as a more integrated market is key to the development of renewables and to reducing energy costs for families and industry. In addition, the report notes that increased regional cooperation on renewables is key to ensuring the further development of renewable energy sources. I voted in favour because I believe that we have a fundamental responsibility to combat climate change – a historic duty that we must fulfil.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents significant support for the development of the renewable energy sector and an important call to Member States that are not meeting the objectives of the Directive. The report echoes the progress of the sector but also of the problems they encounter in certain Member States such as the "sun tax", the retroactivity of support measures, the difficulties in accessing the network. Etc. In addition, the report refers to the need to generate quality employment and to include trade unions and civil society in the development of these energies. Specific proposals are also made on the definition of prosumers, support for modal change in transport, development of renewable refrigeration technologies, public investment in the sector, etc. This makes the text an important reference for the development of the next directive, which is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. The development of renewable energy requires a new approach that makes renewable energy the central pillar of the European Union's energy model. We have a fundamental responsibility to combat climate change; this is a historic duty that we must not shirk. We also need to reduce our dependence on energy sources from the rest of the world if we want to support our production model, create quality jobs and play a leading role in the development of strategic technology for the energy transition. The transition to a sustainable energy production model is a social priority that cannot be addressed by the market alone. We must assume that regulation and democratic participation are necessary to avoid serious externalities in the social and environmental field. We must prevent the future of energy in Europe from being determined by energy oligopolies. I voted in favour of this strategy.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the situation report on renewable energy is, in principle, a balanced package of the current situation in the EU. However, in paragraphs 84, 85 and 88, the sustainability criteria for biofuels and bio-liquids contain, in my opinion, failed word choices for Finland, which, among other things, call for caution in the use of forest biomass as the EU's main renewable energy source, because it: '... may have potentially adverse effects on the climate and the environment...'. I do not believe that these points contribute to Finland's objectives in the bioeconomy. In view of the difficult whole they have formed, I abstained in the final vote on the report.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In principle, this report deals with the very important issue of 'renewable energy sources'. I agree that in future we need a sustainable and, above all, independent energy model. Unfortunately, however, this report has been used, for example, to see how a proposal can be distorted by non-realistic demands that go far beyond the actual technical possibilities. It is a fact that the energy mix of individual countries cannot be determined centrally because of geographical and industrial differences. Since I am in favour of a path towards more 'renewable energy sources', but I do not think that this report can contribute positively because of its demands, I prefer to abstain.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – It is clear that renewable energy is becoming increasingly important to our Union in two different ways. First of all, we have to safeguard the environment, following up on international agreements such as COP 21, to which we are a signatory. Secondly, we need to safeguard the EU’s energy independence. At EU level, as in Flanders, we are currently working hard on achieving this goal. Although the EU is moving in the right direction, I hope that this resolution will help to speed up the process and can provide extra support to those who are left with the responsibility to make it happen. I agree with the resolution’s point on the necessity of a stable framework for investment. I strongly believe that renewable energy has the best chance of succeeding if we cooperate at EU level.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I was positive in voting in favour of the progress report on renewable energy sources, a text supported by the largest majority of MEPs and most political groups, both in the committee responsible for Industry, Research and Energy and in the associated committees for the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Regional Development and Agriculture and Rural Development.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. 2012 I certainly support this report, as it seems to me vitally important to know the state of production and use of renewable energy in the EU, mainly because the trend of renewable energy continues to rise and are one of the key resources to be able to deal with pollution and curb damage to the environment. In Spain, for example, progress in this area is very positive, taking into account that in 2013 and 2014 there has been an increase in the use of renewable energies that significantly exceeds the minimum indicative trajectory. This progress has also taken place in reference to electricity, heating and cooling, transport and sustainability for biofuels. I am therefore confident that, with proposals like this, all Member States will achieve these results and even improve them.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this message. I believe that our main responsibility is to combat climate change, which is a historic duty that we must accept. At the same time, we must reduce the dependence of energy resources on the rest of the world if we want to not only be at the forefront of the development of strategic technologies for the energy transition, but also to support our production model and create quality jobs. I am of the opinion that the transition to a sustainable model of energy production is a social priority that cannot be addressed solely from a market perspective. It must be understood that regulation and democratic participation are necessary to prevent serious social and environmental side effects.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on progress in renewable energy. The report took stock of the implementation of the Renewable Energy Directive to date and listed states that are approaching or already meeting their 2020 targets in this area. In particular, references to improved cooperation between Member States and regions were positive, as well as confirmation that it is solely their responsibility to decide what combination of resources or energy mix Member States will have. Unfortunately, however, all too often, the report referred to binding targets or called for an ambitious energy package. I also disagree with the articles that foresee increased supervision of Member States after 2020 and its possibility of intervening against Member States. It is precisely for these reasons that I have decided to vote against the whole report.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the López Bermejo report for sharing its conclusions in particular as regards welcoming the European Commission to the proposed renewable energy commitments by 2020 and the need to develop an ambitious legislative framework for the post-2020 period. I would like to point out that it is essential to take on ambitious targets in line with the Paris Agreement and produce more clean and renewable energy, create wealth and jobs and reduce strategic dependence on external suppliers. In this sense, I stress the valorization of endogenous resources in a strategic area such as energy, an appreciation that is possible as the example of Portugal illustrates well.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. This resolution, which I voted in favour of, states that, in order to reduce dependence on EU energy imports, it is necessary to invest in policies for renewable energy and energy efficiency. This is intended to address the challenges imposed by climate change by promoting a renewal of the production model but also by ensuring energy security as a social priority. The EU renewable energy target – 20 % of total consumption by 2020 – has already been achieved by many EU Member States. Others, on the other hand, are lagging behind and need to do more. The report examines the progress made by the EU in renewable energy and shows what ambitious targets the next revision of the Renewable Energy Directive must set.  Importance is attached to self-handling and energy self-consumption, as the role of citizens and consumers is crucial to achieving the energy efficiency targets. Emphasis is therefore placed on building renovation, district heating and cooling systems. The EU is also invited to invest in programmes that promote new technical progress in the field of energy efficiency. I am convinced that the creation of a more integrated market is essential for the development of renewable energies and the reduction of energy costs.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on progress in the field of renewable energy. In accordance with Article 194 TFEU, European energy policy must ensure the functioning of the energy market and security of energy supply and promote energy efficiency, energy saving and the development of renewable energy sources and the interconnection of energy networks. I therefore agree with the report's findings that future legislation and measures must be based on renewable energy, which will allow the technologies for this energy to be fully represented on the market.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the report on energy efficiency because this has been a crucial year for reflections and for the setting of new targets for the environment, energy and climate. It was the year of COP21, which set ambitious targets for an environment that is clearly suffering. Yet it seems that Europe is unable to meet its target of reducing CO2 emissions by 20 % by 2020. So let us ask ourselves what is not working. I believe that, in the field of the environment and energy too, Europe's problem has been the rigidity of its rules and bureaucracy, which are clashing markedly with the economic crisis that Europe must, at the same time, face. The objectives of energy policy, such as those of environmental policy and many others, in order to be effective, cannot ignore the flexibility necessary to make them suitable for changes in the economic scenario and global transformations. The way is to achieve energy efficiency and focus on a green economy as a driving force for the economy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh is tuarascáil fhíorthábhachtach í seo agus bhí sí conspóideach chomh maith. Ag an am gcéanna caithfear moladh a thabhairt don rapóirtéir ó mo ghrúpa féin, an Feisire Pieper, a rinne an-chuid oibre air fad cé nár éirigh leis ag deireadh na dála comhréiteach a fháil leis na grúpaí maidir leis na vótaí go léir. Mar sin bhí vótaí an-tábhachtacha ag ár ngrúpa, agus nuair a chaill siad na vótaí sin mhol an grúpa go vótálaimis i gcoinne na tuarascála ag an deireadh.  Níor vótáil mé i gcoinne na tuarascála ag an deireadh mé féin; chuaigh mé i gcoinne mo ghrúpa. O mo thaobh féin de agus ós rud é go rabhas i bPáras agus go rabhas ag plé leis seo agus go bhfuilim ag caint faoin tábhacht a bhaineann le fuinneamh in-athnuaite agus mar sin de, ceapaim gur ceart vótáil i bhfabhar agus sin é a rinne mé ag deireadh na dála. Tá súil agam go bhféadfaimid an chonspóid a réiteach amach anseo.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – We have voted against both energy reports and it is outrageous that a group of dilettantes and ignorants are speaking out and deciding on matters so vital. Under the occupation of the European Union, Europe is not developing, Europe is lagging behind. How can we grow when gas in America costs four times less than in Europe, when in China it is three times cheaper than in Europe? How can Europe compete in these conditions?  Not only do I believe that the European Union must be destroyed, but I believe that those who so promote this fight against global warming, who are destroying European energy, should, after europe is liberated from the union's occupation, be properly condemned for what they have done to this once leading region in the world.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with European priorities, the 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive has put in place a set of binding measures to achieve 20 % energy efficiency by 2020. Unfortunately, the text has not been fully implemented by all Member States, due to industrial and economic interests, which often undermine the objectives of such policies. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report implementing the directive, considering it a priority to protect the environment and the health of citizens through better cooperation between Member States in the field of energy.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this Report by the majority of the Euro-Camera in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility. As in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is opposed to measures to combat energy poverty which, however, have received the support of the majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures for low-income consumers. The end result is positive so I deserved my vote in favour. I hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always awaiting Commissioner Cañete's appearance in this House because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to demand a 40% improvement in the national efficiency targets by 2030, correcting the Council's down proposal of 27%. This will also require a review of the current functioning of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the non-application of which, excessive flexibility and lack of concreteness is adequately highlighted in the document.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. This report discusses the October 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive (EED) as part of the evaluation of its implementation and in the context of its revision. Considering that "energy efficiency must be considered as a source of energy in its own right, which represents the amount of energy saved in Nw (negawatts), this text calls for optimising energy consumption to make it more efficient. Although the text calls for more binding measures, the emphasis is on the flexibility that must be left to Member States in transposing these directives. Nevertheless, the DEE sets "goals in the form of an absolute level of primary energy consumption and final energy consumption" (Article 3, paragraph 1, point a), of the DEE). However, in the current economic climate, this energy austerity risks further harming our industries. Finally, it should be noted that because of the Stability Pact, it is almost impossible for Member States to make the heavy investments required by the EED itself. I therefore voted abstention on this text.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was an implementation report by Markus Pieper on the Energy Efficiency Directive. The Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU) establishes a framework of measures for the promotion of energy efficiency in the EU and sets a non-binding target of 20% energy efficiency improvements by 2020. The EU as a whole is expected to fall short of this non-binding target, although the Commission and the rapporteur are optimistic and claim we can still reach the target. This report further calls for full implementation of existing legislation, accelerated efforts and the removal of barriers to investment. In the committee phase, my political group, GUE/NGL, tabled alternative compromise amendments with other progressive groups calling for a binding 40% target on energy efficiency for 2030. This is positive, as it displays political will and commitment to the Paris climate change agreement.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation report on the Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU) because it examines how the Energy Efficiency Directive has been implemented by the Member States. In addition, it refers to the progress made on energy efficiency targets by 2020, as well as the framework for the 2030 targets.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Between 1991 and 2014, greenhouse gas emissions in the EU fell by 23%. Over the same period, GDP has increased by 46%. This shows that with ever-lower climate pressure, companies and citizens generate more growth and thus also create jobs and generate tax revenues.  The EU is well on its way to meeting its 2020 targets: 20% less CO2 emissions, 20% increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and 20% more energy efficiency.  However, the high level of red tape in the energy sector, as well as the high energy prices for medium-sized commercial and private households, are worrying. In addition, as various, sometimes contradictory, national and European regulations also meet, I call on the Commission, together with Parliament, to work on a more coherent climate and energy policy and to make additional efforts for a Europe-wide electricity market design.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report is about energy savings to be achieved within the European Union. If this is a good thing in itself, in the current economic context, this energy austerity risks further harming our industries. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ The Energy Efficiency Directive establishes a set of binding measures to help the EU reach its 20% energy efficiency target by 2020. Greenhouse gas emissions in the EU fell by 23% between 1990 and 2014. The EU is making large strides towards meeting the targets set and this is largely in thanks to the ETS system. The complex reporting obligations and special national levies are a cause for concern and are largely impacted by separate national approaches to energy policy. A more coherent climate and energy policy is needed as well as an EU-wide electricity market design. The Energy Efficiency Directive plays a major role in this and the EU will reach its 20% efficiency target for 2020 at this rate. This is a recent directive and the Member States must be given time for the innovations to come to fruition. This report provides a necessary starting point to bring the energy saving aspects together and make a more coherent European wide policy.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The motto of this text is that "energy efficiency must be considered as a source of energy in its own right which represents the amount of energy saved in Nw (negawatts) ( considering F). Presented as fundamental, particularly in order to achieve the climate targets - again - set at the end of COP21, the ongoing search for energy savings is supposed to enable us to strengthen both our energy security and our economic competitiveness. Thus, energy consumption is being optimised to make it more "efficient" (according to the English adjective "efficient"), considering that "energy savings constitute the first and safest source of energy in Europe" (paragraph 33), "in an increasingly decentralised energy landscape" (paragraph 30). Nevertheless, the Energy Efficiency Directive (EED) sets "targets in the form of an absolute level of primary energy consumption and final energy consumption" (Article 3, paragraph 1, point a), of the EED: in the current economic context, this energy austerity risks further harming our industries, especially as the rapporteur welcomes, in the explanatory statement, the , "good results of the ETS system" (or ETS), which is a blatant failure.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This report, which I approved, stresses that while the Energy Efficiency Directive has led to many positive improvements in member states, its implementation remains insufficient, particularly in terms of the creation of quality jobs.  He points out that it is essential to begin the transition to a renewable energy system that allows fossil fuels to be abandoned as quickly as possible. It calls for the definition of plans to phase out fossil fuel subsidies and provide financial resources for energy efficiency projects, in order to achieve the EU's goal of "decarbonisation" of the energy sector by 2050.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Pieper report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. The issues of energy saving and efficiency are crucial not only for environmental and climate protection, in line with the objectives set at COP21 in Paris, but also for the development of European competitiveness and an increase in employment. The 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive and the 2010 Buildings Directive were key tools for giving important innovative impetus to Member States' systems of obligations and incentives. However, many countries have not implemented all the provisions present. The achievement of the 20 % savings target is at risk, which is why efforts must be speeded up and all obstacles to investment removed. States must make full use of the subsidy system. The Commission must take additional action for a coherent climate and energy policy by establishing appropriate standards. The text calls on the EU to prepare a long-term strategy for reducing energy demand, prolonging and making more ambitious the targets set by the existing directives, which will expire in 2020.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because it underlines the need to improve energy efficiency as a way to combat climate change. It proposes country-binding targets. The binding aspect is a key point because it forces countries to meet these objectives while flexibility leaves the door open to insufficient targets. Moreover, it is not content with the 27% target set by the Council and the Commission in 2030 but proposes the most ambitious target of 40%. It also proposes to focus measures on households in energy poverty, which we think is of paramount importance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. Some points are a good move, such as the recognition of the competitiveness problems of our energy-intensive industries compared to third-country competitors or the fact that the energy efficiency target is accompanied by a certain latitude left to the Member States in order to adapt their instruments to the national context. However, binding targets are set by the DEE, including an absolute level of final energy consumption, even as austerity policies imposed by Brussels prevent states from providing the necessary investments.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Pieper report is partisan and not acceptable. It complains about the poor implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive in the Member States, but deliberately never mentions the real cause of this failure on the part of the Member States: the EU-imposed Stability Pact regime, which prevents the investment needed to comply with the legislation. That is why I did not support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this Report by the majority of the Euro-Camera in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility. As in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is opposed to measures to combat energy poverty which, however, have received the support of the majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures for low-income consumers. The end result is positive so I deserved my vote in favour. I hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always awaiting Commissioner Cañete's appearance in this House because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it discusses parliament's report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. Parliament stresses that the European Union is on the right track to achieve its 2020 targets: reducing CO2 emissions, increasing the share of renewable energy sources that are full of energy consumption and increasing energy efficiency. This is largely due to the successful ETS system. It not only provides incentives to reduce emissions, but also encourages investment in energy efficiency technologies. Of course, the objectives were only partially achieved, driven by the economic and financial crisis in some countries. However, there are concerns about energy reporting bureaucracy and high prices for average industrial consumers and households. The resulting price reduction effects of energy savings are disappearing as a result of special government deductions and cost-intensive reporting.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Between 1990 and 2014, the European Union's GDP increased by 46%, while greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% over the period. Businesses and citizens are increasingly under-burdened with economic growth, and EU directives aimed at improving energy efficiency, reducing CO2 emissions and increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption play a major role in this. The European Union is on track to meet its 2020 targets to reduce its CO2 emissions by 20%, increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and improve its energy efficiency by 20%. This is largely due to the successful ETS, which encourages investment in renewable energy and emission reductions.  It is to be welcomed that the Commission is making further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level and to set even more ambitious targets. Nevertheless, the mandatory 40% energy efficiency target for 2030 is excessive, as it would impose difficult burdens on Member States and impose unrealistic expectations on them. For these reasons, I did not support the adoption of the report in the final vote.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Within the framework of the objectives set at COP21 in Paris and the actions necessary to achieve a resilient energy union with an effective and forward-looking climate policy, energy efficiency certainly plays a major role. Nevertheless, the results achieved so far in the Energy Efficiency Directive appear insufficient, with a considerable gap in terms of real implementation between the various European countries. Indeed, some Member States have not fulfilled, or at least not completely, the obligations to establish internal regulations that favour energy efficiency, resulting in a significantly heterogeneous overall framework that outlines a certain difficulty towards achieving the objectives set for 2020.  This trend certainly needs to change, and that is what the European Parliament has asked for today. If, in fact, we want the European Union to continue to maintain its leadership in climate action, while at the same time succeeding in increasing the energy security of its citizens and reducing dependence on external supply, we need a greater and more coordinated effort at European level, based on binding targets and which does not stop at 2020, but looks to 2030 and beyond. , as loudly requested by the Group of Socialists and Democrats.

name: David BORRELLI
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive because, during the vote on the amendments in plenary, calls for ambitious and binding targets at European and national level were not removed. We want the European Union to set binding targets of 40 % for energy efficiency and at least 30 % for renewables, which are always translated into specific national targets. And the role of citizens in the wider process of energy transition towards a decentralised model of energy production based on renewables will have to be enhanced. It is crucial that the energy union really has the citizens at its heart and thus enable all Europeans to escape the constraints and balances of energy geopolitics.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was an implementation report by Markus Pieper on the Energy Efficiency Directive. The Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU) establishes a framework of measures for the promotion of energy efficiency in the EU and sets a non-binding target of 20% energy efficiency improvements by 2020. The EU as a whole is expected to fall short of this non-binding target, although the Commission and the rapporteur are optimistic and claim we can still reach the target. This report further calls for full implementation of existing legislation, accelerated efforts and the removal of barriers to investment. In the committee phase, my political group, GUE/NGL, tabled alternative compromise amendments with other progressive groups calling for a binding 40% target on energy efficiency for 2030. This is positive, as it displays political will and commitment to the Paris climate change agreement.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the world's leading territorial reality for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, which have fallen by 23 % over the past two decades. European businesses and citizens have started to grow, creating jobs and generating tax revenues in an environmentally sustainable way. The EU and its Member States are therefore on the right track but must do more to achieve the objectives of the European 2020 Strategy. There is a need to reduce CO2 emissions by 20 %, to increase the share of renewable energy carriers in total consumption by 20 % and to improve energy efficiency by 20 %. The Commission and Parliament must support efforts to achieve the objectives, in particular by working to reduce bureaucracy in the energy sector and to reduce high price levels for medium-sized businesses and domestic consumers. An important step forward is energy efficiency: the implementation of the directive will be crucial for the savings of citizens and businesses, as well as for achieving the Europe 2020 targets. Wasting energy networks less and improving is the key pillar for an eco-sustainable future.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report assesses the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive in the run-up to its revision. The rapporteur focuses on the potential energy savings to be achieved, in particular those related to the renovation of the housing stock. Although calling for more binding measures, this text stresses the flexibility that must be granted to Member States in transposing European directives. Once is not customary, this text even addresses the problem of the lack of competitiveness of our energy-intensive industries compared to their non-EU competitors, but without ever challenging the widespread free trade that exacerbates unfair international competition. Finally, the text includes a paragraph challenging the current austerity that prevents Member States from financing the investments needed to meet energy efficiency targets. However, I abstained on this text, which calls for more binding measures.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive contains several positive points, such as the importance of energy efficiency in achieving climate objectives, the need for better monitoring and clarification of the definition of SMEs and State aid rules. Excessive reporting obligations are criticised and a stronger focus on energy efficiency instead of energy saving is required. However, there are a number of important provisions, such as the 40% energy efficiency target for 2030, which, in my view, are neither reasonable nor tangible. Thus, I voted against this report, considering that we need much more feasible targets.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. ‒ Greenhouse gas emissions have steadily reduced by increasing the share of renewable energy sources in energy consumption. The Energy Efficiency Directive aims to encourage Member States to invest in energy efficient technologies. While the scheme may aid in starting the transition towards a more sustainable energy system, the Directive is poorly implemented, hindering its full potential.  The unambitious target of 27% for improving energy efficiency in 2030 can only be justified by an extremely unrealistic high discount rate. In light of the Paris climate change agreement, there should be a 2030 target that better reflects the level of cost-effective energy efficiency potential. This high discount rate overlooks the role of public bodies in driving energy efficiency improvements.   There should be new innovative and smart solutions to better utilise renewable energy and to reduce energy consumption. For these reasons, I voted against the resolution on the implementation report of the Energy Efficiency Directive. In devising energy efficiency plans, energy audits based on reducing energy consumption must be conducted to address energy poverty. There needs to be a more comprehensive approach to improving energy efficiency.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this Report by the majority of the Euro-Camera in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility. As in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is opposed to measures to combat energy poverty which, however, have received the support of the majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures for low-income consumers. The end result is positive so I deserved my vote in favour. I hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always awaiting Commissioner Cañete's appearance in this House because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive is crucial to achieving the EU's 20% target for 2020. The Union has made a great deal of progress in this area even though the directive is not yet transposed into the law of all Member States. The first thing to do is to monitor the application of the directive in the Member States. This will ensure that the EU's energy efficiency policy is consistent. I voted against this report because I was not in favour of a binding 40% energy efficiency target by 2030. We must respond appropriately to environmental challenges. It is not by setting binding, unfuleant targets that will undermine the competitiveness of our companies that we will achieve our goals. It is true that we must make significant efforts in terms of energy efficiency, but we must do so gradually. Other components, such as competitiveness, jobs and growth, need to be taken into account.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to ensure that EU legislation on energy efficiency is implemented in full and more quickly and that the EU's key objective of increasing energy saving to 20 % by 2020 is achieved. I also reiterate Parliament's call for binding targets to ensure that renewable energies account for at least 30 % of total energy consumption by 2030. We need to invest more in information and support programmes in the Member States, which could help to increase participation in current mandatory local energy efficiency schemes, as well as promote new technical progress in areas such as cooling, lighting and insulation. In fact, the role of consumers is decisive in achieving energy efficiency targets, for example through building renovation, district heating and cooling systems. I stress that energy-efficient renovation of buildings should be a priority, so as to help residents affected by energy poverty.  Finally, it is essential to achieve our energy efficiency targets by abandoning fossil energy sources and gradually eliminating subsidies for these fuels.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ This report is very positive and brings forward a number of good points, but at the end I voted against this report as it contained a number of measures and targets which I believe would be difficult to achieve. In my view this would put unnecessary pressure on both energy producers and consumers without likely achieving our aim at the end.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. The report takes account of the essential failure of the directive and the failure of many Member States to implement it. I agree with the proposals for better mutual coordination and efficiency of the various Community legislative provisions, as well as the reference to the contribution that energy efficiency policies should make to achieving the objectives of employment and innovation.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We abstain as the report contains both positive and negative points.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation report on the Energy Efficiency Directive concerns a typical issue of analysis and discussion of the progress of the report, but it is a proper effort that promotes procedures related to issues not only energy and economic but also environmental. I think it is moving in the right direction and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I was sorry to vote against this proposal, which I thought was, in part, useful to the Union. I say with regret because I agree with better energy savings on the part of companies, but I do not agree at all with imposing compulsory savings of 40%. In addition to saving energy, what the European Union needs is better efficiency in the sector, but we cannot ask companies to be more efficient if we impose such a high percentage of savings on them. In so doing, we are seriously putting at risk those entrepreneurs who will be forced to reduce industrial production considerably and workers who will find themselves potentially unemployed. I therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which reviewed the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. The EU is on the way to reaching its 20% efficiency target for 2020, which demonstrates that energy efficiency is in the own interest of businesses and households.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% in the EU between 1990 and 2014, with EU GDP increasing by 46% in the same period. The EU is therefore on track to achieve the 2020 targets of a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, an increase to 20% in the share of renewable energy in total energy consumption and a 20% increase in energy efficiency. Increasing energy efficiency and energy saving play an important role in protecting the environment and climate, enhancing industry competitiveness, job creation, security of supply, combating energy poverty. I support this report because I believe that economic, regulatory and administrative obstacles need to be removed in order to allow citizens to participate in the energy system. On the other hand, it is essential to start the transition to a more sustainable renewable energy system as soon as possible. The smooth functioning of an internal energy market, including energy efficiency services, contributes to the optimisation of energy systems for the benefit of all consumers and a substantial improvement in energy efficiency in Europe.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to demand a 40% improvement in the national efficiency targets by 2030, correcting the Council's down proposal of 27%. This will also require a review of the current functioning of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the non-application of which, excessive flexibility and lack of concreteness is adequately highlighted in the document.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 In general, Member States are on track to achieve the 20-20-20 targets. A positive development depended to a large extent on the results of the system of incentives for lower emissions, which could trigger investments in more efficient technologies. As is often the case, however, the picture is not uniform and there are strong pockets of resistance, where targets are at risk.  This, in general, was due to the greater or lesser incidence of the economic crisis, but also to the greater or lesser ability to involve businesses and citizens who, only where they perceive a direct interest in efficiency, are proactive in applying the rules. In general, we must act in two directions. From a regulatory point of view, we must secure the achievements that have been achieved, which could be lost if action is not taken immediately with a revision of the directive extending its provisions beyond 2030.  Secondly, member states in difficulty must act to maximise the availability and sensitivity of consumers and businesses towards achieving the objectives. Without their support and involvement, the rules will only be perceived as punitive and restrictive, which will put the objectives at risk.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the EU, greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% between 1990 and 2014. At the same time, EU GDP grew by 46%. With less and less climate burden, businesses and citizens are achieving greater economic growth, creating more jobs and generating tax revenues. The report calls for the directive to be reviewed with a view to shaping it into a more coherent act of EU law This report offers a starting point in this regard, e.g. the exchange of best practices between Member States and new funding opportunities (e.g. from the Juncker Plan). Although I am able to support these declarations, I voted against the report because of repeated calls for binding energy efficiency targets at EU and individual eu level.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The report outlines how the 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive, which sets rules and obligations to help the EU reach its 2020 energy efficiency target, is being implemented by the Member States.  The Commission should revise the text and prioritise and address energy poverty.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Between 1990 and 2014, the European Union's GDP increased by 46%, while greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% over the period. Businesses and citizens are increasingly under-burdened with economic growth, and EU directives aimed at improving energy efficiency, reducing CO2 emissions and increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption play a major role in this. The European Union is on track to meet its 2020 targets to reduce its CO2 emissions by 20%, increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and improve its energy efficiency by 20%. This is largely due to the successful ETS, which encourages investment in renewable energy and emission reductions.  It is to be welcomed that the Commission is making further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level and to set even more ambitious targets. Nevertheless, the mandatory 40% energy efficiency target for 2030 is excessive, as it would impose difficult burdens on Member States and impose unrealistic expectations on them.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. The cheapest energy is the one you don't use. Therefore, energy efficiency must be seen as a source of energy in its own right, which represents the amount of energy in Nw (negawatts) saved, as the recent history of the world and Europe has demonstrated irrefutably. In this sector, as in others, citizens' initiatives and those taken at the community level are most relevant and European legislation must accompany and facilitate them. Together with the drafters of this resolution, I believe that the potential for energy savings at the local level should be much better exploited, given that local and regional authorities have a central role to play in achieving energy efficiency and in general in the energy transition. It is also at this level that we can better deal with the issues of equal access and energy insecurity for which we must be extremely vigilant, so that the resulting savings from "energy efficiency" are not reserved for those (individuals and companies) who have the means to make the necessary investments.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report on the implementation of the October 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive (EED) focuses on the ongoing search for energy savings, with the aim of strengthening both our energy security and our economic competitiveness. In particular, it encourages the renovation of the poorly insulated housing stock, with public administrations having to lead by example, while allowing Member States flexibility in transposing the directives. It highlights the competitiveness problems of our energy-intensive industries compared to their non-EU competitors. Nevertheless, the DEE sets "goals in the form of an absolute level of primary energy consumption and final energy consumption". Such energy austerity risks further harming our industries. For this reason, I abstained.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive because I believe that energy efficiency should be a priority of the Member States and not of the European Commission, which creates an additional bureaucratic burden. I think the market would regulate energy efficiency the most.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote in favour. The report concerns the implementation of an existing directive and its improvement. It certainly does not avoid some verbal excesses and the usual hostility against Russia, but it is generally necessary for Europe and beneficial for the environment.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Between 1990 and 2014, the European Union's GDP increased by 46%, while greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% over the period. Businesses and citizens are increasingly under-burdened with economic growth, and EU directives aimed at improving energy efficiency, reducing CO2 emissions and increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption play a major role in this. The European Union is on track to meet its 2020 targets to reduce its CO2 emissions by 20%, increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and improve its energy efficiency by 20%. This is largely due to the successful ETS, which encourages investment in renewable energy and emission reductions.  It is to be welcomed that the Commission is making further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level and to set even more ambitious targets. Nevertheless, the mandatory 40% energy efficiency target for 2030 is excessive, as it would impose difficult burdens on Member States and impose unrealistic expectations on them.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% in the EU between 1990 and 2014. In the same period, EU GDP increased by 46%. The European Union is on track to achieve the 2020 targets of reducing CO2 emissions by 20%, increasing the share of renewable energy in total energy consumption to 2020, increasing energy efficiency to 20%.  The concerns that have arisen relate to the bureaucracy of reporting and the high levels of energy prices for average industrial consumers and households. The implementation of the Directive is also important. In this regard, it should be noted, first, that the European Union will achieve its efficiency target of 20 % for 2020, even if most Member States have not fully implemented the Directive. This demonstrates the strength of the market.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. Because of the Stability Pact, it is almost impossible for Member States to make the heavy investments required by the EED itself.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Energy efficiency is a huge issue, particularly for countries such as Portugal with a huge energy deficit and significant dependence on the outside world. The report addresses the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. It points out interesting and relevant measures aimed at saving energy. It does so, however, always in the strict and reducing framework of the so-called "Energy Union" and the liberalizing and deregulatory vision that governs it. This is a fundamental reason for divergence from its content. The report notes that greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% in the EU between 1990 and 2014. It does not, however, mention the contribution to such an economic crisis, more than any transition of energy paradigm. It collateralises the market and its perversities. It criticises high energy prices for average industrial consumers and households. It states that the effects of reducing costs through energy savings are eroded by state taxes. And it passes alongside the fabulous and scandalous profits of the monopolies and private oligopolies operating in the sector. Just as, of course, it also goes hand in hand with the need for public, democratic control, of the sector. Signifying your public ownership and management. As an indispensable means of achieving desired and proclaimed economic, social and environmental objectives.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, as the data show, greenhouse gas emissions within the European Union fell by 23 % between 1990 and 2014. We are therefore moving towards achieving the targets set for 2020, the 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, the 20 % increase in the share of renewable energy carriers in total consumption and the 20 % improvement in energy efficiency.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the world leaders in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The European Union is on a very good track in achieving the targets set for 2020, which include a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, an increase in the share of renewable energy in total energy consumption to 20% and a 20% increase in energy efficiency. This is largely due to a successful emissions trading scheme. However, there are also negative aspects in the area of energy reporting, which undoubtedly include the loss of energy savings as a result of various state charges and costly reporting. In fact, the European Union currently has some conflicting and climate protection legislation. The European Commission should therefore make efforts in the future to create a European electricity market and energy policy legislation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because it does not take account of the facts.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation report on the Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU), as it concerns the implementation of an existing directive and its improvement. It certainly does not avoid some verbal excesses and the usual hostility against Russia, but it is generally necessary for Europe and beneficial for the environment.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Increased energy efficiency and energy saving are key factors for, among others, environmental and climate protection, strengthening economic competitiveness and job creation. The fact that the EU is not on track to meet its 2020 energy efficiency target due to poor implementation of the EED, excessive flexibility and too many loopholes is extremely disappointing. The Commission projects on which we are on track reach 17.6% instead of 20% for 2020. We must keep calling on the Commission to propose a revised text eliminating loopholes and taking into account a target for 2030 of 40%. The 2030 target should be significantly higher and more ambitious than the one set by the European Council, which is only 27%.  Finally, I believe that the energy efficiency directive should prioritise measures to alleviate energy poverty.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the report on the Energy Efficiency Directive. Between 1990 and 2014, the European Union's GDP increased by 46%, while greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23%. Businesses and citizens are increasingly under-burdened with economic growth, and EU directives aimed at improving energy efficiency, reducing CO2 emissions and increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption play a major role in this. The European Union is on track to meet its 2020 targets to reduce its CO2 emissions by 20%, increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and improve its energy efficiency by 20%.  This is largely due to the successful ETS, which encourages investment in renewable energy and emission reductions. It is to be welcomed that the Commission is making further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level and to set even more ambitious targets. Nevertheless, the mandatory 40% energy efficiency target for 2030 is excessive, as it would impose difficult burdens on Member States and impose unrealistic expectations on them.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this report by the majority of the European Parliament in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency by 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against a European People's Party (EPP), which wanted to limit it to 30% non-binding. Moreover, in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is against measures to combat energy poverty. However, these measures have been supported by a majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures that favour low-income consumers. The end result is positive. I therefore hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always pending Commissioner Cañete's appearance before the European Parliament because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy efficiency is a key objective in achieving the environmental sustainability targets solemnly set in Paris a few months ago, targets that are in line with the EU's commitments of many years internationally. It is therefore very important to be able to monitor the implementation of one of the most important directives of European environmental legislation today. The report we are voting on today recognises the positive effect that the directive has had but at the same time recognises the obstacles still encountered in its full implementation. I therefore support the report's call, in particular, on local authorities to make greater efforts in this direction.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU), because I believe it is very important to send a signal to Member States that they continue to commit to achieving the EU's energy efficiency targets – saving 20% by 2020 – and fully implement existing EU legislation more quickly. Greenhouse gas emissions in the EU fell by 23% between 1990 and 2014. At the same time, EU GDP increased by 46%. With an ever-greater impact on the climate, businesses and citizens are creating growth, creating jobs and generating tax revenues. The European Union is on track to achieve its 2020 target of reducing CO2 emissions by 20%, increasing the share of renewable energy carriers in total consumption by 20% and improving energy efficiency by 20%. This development was largely due to the positive results of the ETS. It not only provides incentives for lower emissions, but also triggers investment in technologies with greater energy efficiency.  Surely the achievement of the targets also depends in part on the economic and financial crisis in some countries.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. The European framework is too rigid, it does not promote measures for greater energy efficiency – it hinders it. This is not taken into account in the report presented.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I abstained from voting on this report. I would like to point out that Poland - yes - has agreed to a 20% increase in energy efficiency by 2020. However, I think Polish the President, when he signed up to this political goal, did not know how this effectiveness would be counted. I do not believe that he can agree that it will be determined for the whole country by a physical method, as if it were some kind of device, and yet the economy is a "dynamic mechanism" that is developing. The use of energy per capita in Poland is among the lowest in the EU. It is well known that the prosperity of EU countries is proportional to the rate of use of energy per capita. I ask: is this policy of reducing living standards in Poland? The reduction in energy use also after 2030 as an efficiency indicator could only be applied to the then-current and unchanging economy. It was and still is a gross error introduced into the Efficiency Directive. The best way out of this trap would be to refer the efficiency growth rate to the initial and final GDP in the form of an appropriate quot%quot% quot%.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The left-wing parties are blocking the common EU goal of using energy more efficiently by 2030, with binding and unrealistic targets to save energy by up to 40% by 2030. Energy bans will have a negative impact on the objectives of greater energy efficiency. Instead of banning energy consumption, we should instead rely on positive incentives through tax relief. This is the only way to achieve realistic energy savings.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because it underlines the need to improve energy efficiency as a way to combat climate change. It proposes country-binding targets. The binding aspect is a key point because it forces countries to meet these objectives while flexibility leaves the door open to insufficient targets. Moreover, it is not content with the 27% target set by the Council and the Commission in 2030 but proposes the most ambitious target of 40%. It also proposes to focus measures on households in energy poverty, which we think is of paramount importance.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this Report by the majority of the Euro-Camera in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility. As in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is opposed to measures to combat energy poverty which, however, have received the support of the majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures for low-income consumers. The end result is positive so I deserved my vote in favour. I hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always awaiting Commissioner Cañete's appearance in this House because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The Commission called for additional efforts towards a coherent climate and energy policy and a Europe-wide electricity market design. The implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive plays a major role here. It would demonstrate the power of the market. If businesses and citizens recognise that energy efficiency and energy saving are in their own interest, there is no need for European Union regulation. At the same time, however, the directive provides further encouragement for significant innovations in relation to obligations and incentives in the Member States.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this Report by the majority of the Euro-Camera in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility. As in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is opposed to measures to combat energy poverty which, however, have received the support of the majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures for low-income consumers. The end result is positive so I deserved my vote in favour. I hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always awaiting Commissioner Cañete's appearance in this House because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 We abstained on this report, because on the one side of the text there are positive references to the need for this directive to be in line with the climate protection objectives and the need to promote measures to combat energy poverty and support vulnerable groups. However, it is clear that the policies proposed and promoted are within the framework and serve the implementation of the Energy Union, for which we have been highly critical. The aim is to have a strong internal market to make the EU more competitive on the world market. So the policies promoted do not serve the needs and interests of society but energy is used as a tool to serve the needs of the market.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections to the results of the review.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Between 1990 and 2014, the European Union's GDP increased by 46%, while greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% over the period. Businesses and citizens are increasingly under-burdened with economic growth, and EU directives aimed at improving energy efficiency, reducing CO2 emissions and increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption play a major role in this.
