The European Union is on track to meet its 2020 targets to reduce its CO2 emissions by 20%, increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and improve its energy efficiency by 20%. This is largely due to the successful ETS, which encourages investment in renewable energy and emission reductions.  It is to be welcomed that the Commission is making further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level and to set even more ambitious targets. At the same time, the mandatory 40% energy efficiency target for 2030 is excessive, as it would impose heavy burdens on Member States and impose unrealistic expectations on them.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I support the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. Increasing energy efficiency and achieving energy savings are key factors in protecting the environment and climate, improving the competitiveness of the economy, creating jobs. They also ensure security of energy supply and the fight against energy poverty. The investments and energy efficiency measures provided for by the Energy Efficiency Directive will help to improve living standards by reducing fuel poverty, increasing productivity, improving human safety and health.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the important role of energy efficiency, that of achieving the European Union's target of a 20% increase in production and a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2020. This Directive represents an opportunity to optimise and increase energy consumption efficiently in a way that is sustainable for the economy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Renewable Energy Progress Report report, as Europe is well on track to reach its 2020 targets in this area. The combination of binding national targets, national renewable energy plans and biennial monitoring reports has proven to be a key driver of renewable energy capacity development in the Union, as the cost of renewable energy has decreased significantly over the past few years. Renewable energy is increasingly competitive with conventionally produced energy, opening up a unique opportunity to create a genuine European energy policy that would boost competitiveness and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report discusses the October 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive (EED) as part of the evaluation of its implementation and in the context of its revision. The motto of this text is that "energy efficiency must be seen as a source of energy in its own right which represents the amount of energy saved in Nw (negawatts). The text stresses the "flexibility" that must be left to the Member States in transposing the directives, "so that the combination of tools and instruments is adapted to the national level".  Because of the Stability Pact, it is almost impossible for Member States to make the heavy investments required by the EED itself. I have therefore decided to abstain on this text.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by the majority of the Eurochamber in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. ‒ Ahead of the revision of the directive in question, I supported the report in which the European Parliament has highlighted the role of energy savings and improved efficiency in achieving the EU’s energy and climate goals, including the mitigation of energy poverty.  The EP has sent a strong signal to Commission and called for the continuation of the framework beyond 2020. The EP has called for the EU’s 2030 energy efficiency target to be brought in line with the commitments made in Paris, thus to be increased to 40% with the introduction of binding national targets. As for the existing directive, the implementation should be improved by removing loopholes, especially in Article 7. Synergies with the development of renewables must be exploited to the fullest. These would ensure predictability and stability for investors, an adequate level of investments and thus we can avoid technological lock-in incompatible with the EU’s long-term goals.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Energy Efficiency Directive has started positive developments in the Member States, the lack of implementation undermines its potential. Member States have been invited to promote smart meters and transparent accounting as a way of promoting more responsible customer behaviour with regard to consumption and investment in energy efficiency. A lot of joint efforts are still needed to achieve the objectives set, so I have supported with my voice a report which highlights shortcomings and encourages both the Member States and the Commission to take effective and timely action in the implementation of the directive.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. The text stresses that the EU is on track to meet its targets (20% energy efficiency by 2020), but nevertheless calls on Member States to better implement the directive, as the EU still imports more than half of its energy.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, as I believe it is necessary on the part of the Union to adopt a strategy for greater energy efficiency. It is very important that the European Union achieves the 20% target for 2020, even though the directive is not fully implemented in most Member States. The 40% target for 2030 is quite ambitious but, depending on the state of the economy in the Union, it may be possible.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report contains some very supportive demands that would be useful for strengthening energy efficiency in Europe and helping consumers to save electricity and money. However, certain demands go far beyond the target and involve high costs and effort in implementing them. In addition, this report mixes energy efficiency with energy saving, but at the same time calls for increased production from renewable sources, which is contradictory in that the share of this energy can only be a substitute for energy from conventional sources under certain conditions. It is for these reasons that I am abstaining on this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 23 June 2012, at the next plenary session of the European Parliament in Brussels, we voted on the ITRE committee report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. Although the ITRE Committee has been designated as the main committee for this report, the ENVI Committee, of which I am a member, has also issued a report on the issue of the forthcoming Energy Efficiency Directive. I was then shadow rapporteur for this report. Already in the ENVI Committee, we have faced a great deal of pressure from the outset to set binding, new and very ambitious targets for the new energy efficiency period. I personally agree with the view that energy efficiency is an energy source in itself, but, given what the whole emissions falsification scandal in the automotive industry – dieselgate – is currently teaching us, I strictly insist that any further determination of emission ceilings or energy targets should always be based on real and firm data, predictions and, above all, that member states are practically feasible and feasible. And that is exactly what I have been missing from the negotiations on the text of this report. The text of the report sets a very ambitious target, but there is very little interest in the problem of how to achieve it successfully and, above all, in a timely manner. That's why I couldn't support him in good conscience.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Between 1990 and 2014, the European Union's GDP increased by 46%, while greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% over the period. Businesses and citizens are increasingly under-burdened with economic growth, and EU directives aimed at improving energy efficiency, reducing CO2 emissions and increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption play a major role in this. The European Union is on track to meet its 2020 targets to reduce its CO2 emissions by 20%, increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and improve its energy efficiency by 20%. This is largely due to the successful ETS, which encourages investment in renewable energy and emission reductions. It is to be welcomed that the Commission is making further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level and to set even more ambitious targets. Nevertheless, the mandatory 40% energy efficiency target for 2030 is excessive, as it would impose difficult burdens on Member States and impose unrealistic expectations on them.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The undoubted virtue of this report is its somewhat supportive support for peripheral countries and consumers in need, as well as legitimate criticism of highly air-polluting biomass and coal-fired heating. At the same time, there is concern about violations of subsidiarity, gushing, poorly edited material. It wants to renovate at all prices, even where there is a simpler solution, such as limiting winter overheating and summer overcooling of public and public institutions. It overdimensizes renewable energies, which are important but are not suitable for replacing environmentally friendly core power plants.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The Energy Efficiency Directive is key directive for the EU which recognises the importance of energy saving, strengthening environmental and climate protection, facilitating economic competitiveness, promoting job creation, providing security of energy supplies and last but not least tackling energy poverty. However, in order to fully implement the directive, the EU should promote better and smart management of energy consumption. To achieve this, the EU should conduct information campaigns as well as provide access to financial schemes to households, regional and local authorities. Another important step will be further improvement of the transparency and clarity of energy bills by establishing high-level principles for bills at EU level so that key information is available to consumers in a comparable format in order to help them adjust their consumption.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained because this report certainly encourages energy transition and technological innovation, but seems unrealistic in several respects. For example, he advocates the abandonment of fossil fuels, which seems impossible in the short and medium term.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive (EED). The motto of this text is that energy efficiency must be seen as a source of energy in its own right, which represents the amount of energy saved. Presented as fundamental, especially in achieving climate goals, the ongoing search for energy savings is supposed to enable us to strengthen both our energy security and our economic competitiveness. However, the DEE sets "goals in the form of an absolute level of primary energy consumption and final energy consumption". In the current economic context, this energy austerity risks further harming our industries, especially since the rapporteur welcomes, in the explanatory statement, the 'good results of the ETS system', which is a blatant failure. Finally, because of the Stability Pact, it is almost impossible for Member States to make the heavy investments required by the EED itself.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Energy efficiency is the watchword of the text. It looks at the October 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive (EED), and assesses the consequences and changes to be made. It advocates efficient energy consumption, which is therefore more efficient. To do this, it presents many measures that can be more restrictive and austere. It imposes, for example, stringent measures on Member States, such as heavy investments, which are currently unachievable. However, the rapporteur also calls for more flexibility and flexibility for governments to implement this programme and to resume more realistic energy efficiency targets... So I ABSTAINed.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this Report by the majority of the Euro-Camera in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility. As in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is opposed to measures to combat energy poverty which, however, have received the support of the majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures for low-income consumers. The end result is positive so I deserved my vote in favour. I hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always awaiting Commissioner Cañete's appearance in this House because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to demand a 40% improvement in the national efficiency targets by 2030, correcting the Council's down proposal of 27%. This will also require a review of the current functioning of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the non-application of which, excessive flexibility and lack of concreteness is adequately highlighted in the document.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Union is well-targeted for its 2020 targets for environmental protection measures. This development owes much of its success to the progress of the Emissions Trading Scheme. I believe that the concern on this subject should be focused primarily on the bureaucracy associated with reports in the energy sector and on high energy prices, because the reduction in energy savings costs is neutralised by excise levies imposed at the national level and by complicated reporting obligations.  In order to solve these problems, I hope that the Commission will redo its efforts to develop a coherent climate and energy policy and design an electricity market of European scope. I am voting in favour of this report because, moreover, the implementation of the Directive will also provide other important innovative stimulus in relation to obligations and incentives in the Member States.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this report as it does not respect the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree that lowering fossil fuel prices is a negative phenomenon. On the contrary, it means more money saved for citizens and businesses and the growth of the economy. I do not agree at all with the statement that 'lower fuel prices and prospects for economic growth could further jeopardise the achievement of the 20% target'. Only a rich economy can afford to invest in innovation, so I am not opposed to lowering prices. It can be seen that the European Commission wants to pursue its policy even at the cost of impeding the population and with absolutely uncertain or no result.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 greenhouse gas emissions in the EU have decreased by 23% over the period 1990-2014, which leads largely to the conclusion that the targets for a 20 % reduction in CO2 emissions, an increase in total energy consumption of renewable energy sources to 20 % and a 20% increase in energy efficiency will be achieved by 2020. Logically, it is not possible to guarantee the transparency of the area without providing the necessary information and preparing and further compiling national reports at transnational level. However, I share the idea that the level of bureaucracy in this respect is too high, which makes it somewhat difficult to achieve the objectives of the Energy Efficiency Directive and the relevant strategies. In parallel, I also share the conclusion that transnational cooperation in this respect should be as active as possible, which also concerns the need to increase the coherence of legislation. I would like to note that, to a large extent, it was precisely because of the EU's energy efficiency policy that it was possible to renovate thousands of homes in my country – Latvia – thus reducing the costs of citizens and consuming [often non-renewable] fuel resources. I am very pleased that there is a relevant policy at Union level and I am convinced that much more will be achieved in the coming years.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The emissions trading scheme and the promotion of investments in efficient and efficient energy technologies help the Union to meet the EU's targets of reducing CO2 emissions by 20% by 2020 and increasing the share of energy produced from renewable sources. Nevertheless, there are still significant differences between countries in achieving these objectives. I support the proposal for the Commission and the Member States to increase their attention in the implementation of climate and energy policy and to increase their control mechanisms in complying with them.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 23/6/2016 and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. As part of the evaluation and the prospect of revising the October 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive (EED), this report envisages the ongoing search for energy savings to enable us to strengthen both our energy security and our economic competitiveness. There are many positive points in this report which stresses the 'flexibility' that must be left to The Member States in transposing the directives, 'so that the combination of tools and instruments is adapted to the national level'. It also mentions the competitiveness problems that our energy-intensive industries face compared to their competitors outside the European Union, which we agree with.  Nevertheless, we oppose the energy austerity set by the DDE, as it risks further harm to our industries. We also do not support the position of the rapporteur who welcomes the 'good results of the ETS system' (or ETS), which is proving to be a resounding failure.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. We have taken steps, but we still need to take courageous action and decide to achieve greater energy efficiency. Even our citizens find themselves at odds, such as sometimes conflicting climate protection regulations, the complexity of legislation in the field of energy efficiency and the different national approaches to energy policy, factors that can have a massive influence on European policy.  I therefore believe it is necessary and I am voting in favour of our call from this Parliament to the Commission to step up its efforts to develop a coherent climate and energy policy and to design an electricity market of European scope. We must strive to ensure that the Energy Efficiency Directive is implemented effectively, making those changes to the text that make it easier to overcome the work that has been found in its implementation.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's objectives by 2020 are to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, make better use of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption and increase energy efficiency. At the same time, the main objective is to invest more in new energy efficiency technologies. I believe that the current bureaucracy in the energy sector as well as the high prices in its consumption by small and medium-sized enterprises together with the complexity of energy efficiency legislation reduce the efficiency of the system. The Energy Efficiency Directive, which aims to simplify legislation and achieve coherence, is therefore a positive step in the right direction. At the same time, the Directive promotes and encourages innovations and offers new incentives to Member States for full compliance and modernisation in the energy sector.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Energy efficiency is an important issue for a sustainable future for Austria and it is not possible to deal with it enough. However, some of the demands in this report are simply not feasible. In addition, various terms are mixed, which is due to the quality of the report. That is why I abstained.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report discusses the October 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive as part of the evaluation of its implementation and in the context of its revision. Energy efficiency, in other words energy saving, must be seen, according to the text, as an energy resource. In calling for constraints, the text stresses the flexibility to be left to the Member States in transposing the directives. In short, the weighting of the report from several points of view, from a realistic perspective, is to his credit. While it does not ignore the difficulties of industries, the report sets out as absolute the objectives of energy expenditure reductions, which are likely to further harm them. As a result, I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is overall meeting its 2020 climate and energy targets – according to projections that assume full implementation of all relevant legislation by 2020 (reducing CO2 emissions, increasing the share of the use of renewable energy sources, boosting energy efficiency) – and should maintain its role as a global pioneer.  We must therefore all together continue to contribute to the achievement of the objectives set, to make the planet more sustainable for generations to come. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The efficient use of energy is crucial to achieving our climate and energy objectives. Although the EU is broadly on track to achieve its 2020 targets, we note that the Energy Efficiency Directive and the Buildings Directive have not yet been fully implemented. However, energy efficiency is the most necessary step towards a sustainable energy market that will make us more independent of energy imports, stimulate innovation and help create new jobs. Moreover, both citizens and businesses have an interest in lower energy bills.  In the context of THE EU commitments at the Paris climate summit, it is desirable for the EU to strengthen its energy saving targets by providing new and innovative solutions that, on the one hand, reduce energy consumption and, on the other hand, aim at a more rational use of renewable energy. For example, the construction sector still has many opportunities to transform itself into an energy-efficient sector. It is therefore desirable for the Commission, the EIB and the Member States to provide technical assistance and support to residential projects implementing thoughtful insulation techniques, more modern heating systems and the use of private renewable energy sources.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this implementation report, which looks at how the Energy Efficiency Directive (agreed in 2012) is being implemented by the Member States, and the progress to reaching the 2020 20% energy efficiency target, as well as looking forward to the 2030 framework and target. However, I had reservations and did not support some parts which in my opinion are too restrictive, not very realistic and do not take into account the particularities of the different Member States.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This report has shed some light on a series of problems regarding cost reductions achieved through energy savings. I supported this motion for a resolution that calls upon the Commission to generate clever solutions to problems such as increased energy prices for households and small businesses or complex reporting obligations. In view of a coherent climate and energy policy, the Commission needs to make additional efforts to detect any ambiguities, inconsistencies or inadequacies between EU-wide rules on climate protection, legislation linked with energy efficiency and national approaches to energy policy.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission published its report on the implementation of Directive 2012/27/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on energy efficiency on 18 November 2015. The Committee on Industry, Research and Energy proposes to adopt a resolution on this report. The draft states that greenhouse gas emissions in the EU decreased by 23% between 1990 and 2014. Over the same period, EU GDP increased by 46%. It notes that the EU is on track to meet the 2007 targets of reducing its CO2 emissions by 20%, increasing the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20% and improving its energy efficiency by 20%.  At the same time, it is concerned that the cost-cutting effect of energy savings is often eliminated by state special taxes and a complex reporting system. This is due to the partly contradictory EU climate legislation, the complexity of energy efficiency legislation and national energy policy steps, which have a significant impact on some aspects of the European approach. It therefore proposes to ask the Commission to make further efforts to develop a single climate and energy policy and an electricity market at European level. I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2012/27/EU on energy efficiency establishes a common framework for promotion measures in the European Union to ensure the achievement of the Union's target of reaching 20 % in energy efficiency by 2020. Achieving good levels of energy efficiency is also essential to achieving the climate targets outlined at the Paris Summit in December 2015 and reducing the European Union's energy dependence on imports.  Although the implementation of the Directive has triggered a number of positive changes in the Member States, the shortcomings in its implementation call into question its full effectiveness and the achievement of the objectives outlined in this area. To this end, the Directive should be revised in some respects in order to promote a transition to a more sustainable and secure energy system, as well as to ensure that consumers have access to information on energy supply conditions and sources, including through greater transparency and clarity in billing.  To this end, I am voting in favour of this report in that I consider it essential to revise and fully implement the Directive in order to achieve energy efficiency objectives.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Heavy investments are requested in this report. If we can subscribe to this need to invest more, this is made impossible by the absurd austerity policy pursued in Europe. I therefore abstain against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which proposes a binding target of 40% on energy efficiency by 2030. Energy efficiency is an important lever to consume less energy and combat global warming. We need to strengthen it with incentives, including tax incentives, and reasonable, realistic and achievable targets. As with renewable energy, energy efficiency should not be promoted by constraint.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Weighed up the importance of new, renewable and more efficient energy sources in a global context characterised by major climate challenges, we welcome the committee's proposal. It should be stressed, however, that The Member States comply with the climate and energy objectives set, which are currently threatened by obstacles such as lack of investment, ineffective implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive and the fall in fossil fuel prices together with the subsidies for them. Following the EU's participation in the Paris Climate Conference, we set out to reduce Europe's energy insecurity, exemplified by an annual expenditure of EUR 358 billion on energy imports in the medium term. This will be possible through greater efficiency, particularly in the construction sector, which accounts for almost half of final energy consumption and 36% of CO2 emissions, so that there is 40% energy de carbonisation by 2030 and a total by 2050, which will bring about a strong improvement in living standards and an overall increase in employment.  As a result, we suggest to the Commission a revised text in which priority is given to the energy targets for 2030 and to more ambitious directives against European energy poverty.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as energy efficiency and energy security are investments in the future. I am convinced that the European Union's achievements so far , with a 23% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions between 1990 and 2014, encourage us to continue down this path to set flexible and realistic targets. It is necessary to help the energy market to invest in sustainable growth and job creation. We have a huge task ahead of us.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this implementation report that looks at how the energy efficiency directive (agreed in 2012) is being implemented by the Member States, and the progress to reaching the 2020 20% energy efficiency target, as well as looking forward to the 2030 framework and target.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote, because I am convinced that energy efficiency is a common point of interest for all the Member States of the European Union and aims at a goal that we are all pursuing: reducing energy dependency on various other states. We are also facing, and speak on behalf of all Member States, extreme climatic phenomena, which can no longer be ignored. Building on this issue, the report adopted today promotes energy efficiency and calls on the European Commission, together with the Member States, to strengthen and promote new technologies that reduce energy losses, encourage energy renovation programmes for buildings and, last but not least, the use of renewable energy.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which highlights the importance of energy efficiency for the EU's sustainable economic development and calls for the adoption of an ambitious binding energy efficiency target of 40% for 2030. I believe that the objective set in this way represents cost-effective energy efficiency, which will benefit both companies and consumers. The report also rightly points out that seven Member States have not carried out energy audits. I am glad that the Czech Republic is not among these countries.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was an implementation report by Markus Pieper on the Energy Efficiency Directive. The Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU) establishes a framework of measures for the promotion of energy efficiency in the EU and sets a non-binding target of 20% energy efficiency improvements by 2020. The EU as a whole is expected to fall short of this non-binding target, although the Commission and the rapporteur are optimistic and claim we can still reach the target. This report further calls for full implementation of existing legislation, accelerated efforts and the removal of barriers to investment. In the committee phase, my political group, GUE/NGL, tabled alternative compromise amendments with other progressive groups calling for a binding 40% target on energy efficiency for 2030. This is positive, as it displays political will and commitment to the Paris climate change agreement.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted neutrally because the basic approach to energy efficiency is fully supported, but some of the demands go far beyond that. Above all, the concept of energy efficiency is partly mixed up with energy saving. In addition, a refurbishment of Austria's entire local building stock would create an enormous, barely resilient, economic burden.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted.  As we know, reducing energy consumption and eliminating energy losses are very important objectives for the EU. Energy efficiency is at the heart of the transition to a resource-efficient economy.  It should be emphasised that rational and economic use of energy resources is essential for reducing the EU's dependence on energy imports, creating jobs, reducing energy poverty, ensuring convenience and health, boosting the economy and combating global warming. I believe that the Commission should consider setting a binding energy efficiency target of 40% for 2030. It should be noted that the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive is unsatisfactory, but provides a basis for saving energy, while energy savings not only help to reduce costs, but also contribute to the conservation of the planet's resources.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is well known that the European Union has committed itself, by 2020, to achieving the target of a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, a 20% increase in the share of renewable energy carriers in total consumption and a 20% improvement in energy efficiency.  Given that greenhouse gas emissions fell by more than 20% between 1990 and 2014, while, at the same time, GDP grew by almost twice as much, I can assume that these aims are achievable.  However, although I consider my colleague's analysis to be useful, I believe that it is not entirely in line with my thinking. Therefore, while I support the call for the Commission to implement actions to manage a coherent climate and energy policy, I cannot support what is set out in this document and I am voting against it.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU target of achieving 20% energy efficiency by 2020 was an ambitious but achievable target. If we achieve this, it will only be because of the economic and industrial crisis that has hit the EU over the last eight years. Some sectors, such as construction and transport, need more effort.  The Commission should guide the Member States in the application of the directive and act promptly with reasoned requests to adapt national plans. In the amendments tabled in the ENVI Committee, I expressed the need to set a binding target of 40% energy efficiency by 2030 to be implemented through national targets and called for binding energy efficiency targets to be set by 2050 in line with the ambitious commitments set by the Paris Agreements to keep the global temperature increase below 1.5°C.  I have also repeatedly reiterated my concerns about the increasing pollution caused by domestic heating systems powered by solid biomasses which produce large quantities of fine dust, nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide and dioxins which are extremely negative for air quality and therefore harmful to human health.  The implementation of efficient and environmentally friendly alternative solutions must be in synergy with the transition to a low-carbon circular economy. My vote today reflects this position.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ This Report contains very good elements such as valuing the importance of energy efficiency in achieving the EU's energy and climate policy objectives, advocating for the flexibility of this system to make this policy as easy as possible in the Member States, highlighting the importance of reducing unnecessary bureaucracy, simplifying reporting rules and harmonising European legislation more effectively. However, in addition, and in particular in the segment of setting a binding target of 40% energy efficiency, the required flexibility is being undermined.  Personally, I wish this goal could be achieved, but we must always bear in mind that European legislation applies to Member States spanning different geographical regions and climate zones, from one Finland in the north to Spain and Malta in the south of Europe. It is precisely the possibility of flexibility through the choice and combination of different measures that best suit a Member State and its comparative advantages to achieve its energy and climate objectives that makes this policy more meaningful.  Because of these inconsistency, I was unable to support this resolution because it sends the wrong message to union citizens, Member States and investors.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy efficiency and saving are important factors for environmental and climate protection, for strengthening economic competitiveness and job creation, for security of supply and for addressing energy poverty.  This report on the implementation of the 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive recognises that we lag behind the 2020 targets and at the same time calls for a much more ambitious approach for 2030, reiterating Parliament's position on the need for a 40% target, instead of the modest 27% proposed by the Council. It also calls for these targets to be considered binding on the Member States, so as to make their achievement more certain. The report also provides for a number of measures to address energy poverty, such as the priority that Member States will have to give to the energy redevelopment of social housing or buildings belonging to the most vulnerable households. The S&D Group has done an excellent job, greatly improving the text in committee and leading the coalition of political groups that ensured its adoption in plenary. I would therefore like to thank my colleagues and vote in favour of this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒in 2012 EU greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% from 1990 to 2014. Over the same period, EU GDP increased by 46%. With a decreasing impact on the climate, businesses and citizens are growing more, creating jobs and generating tax revenues. I agree with the opinion of the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, which considers that the EU, following the agreement at COP 21 in Paris, is more than ever obliged to reach its climate targets, and energy efficiency is one of the most effective ways to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. The 20% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions target is at risk. By 2020, only 17.6% of primary energy savings are expected. Unfortunately, the 20% target will not be achieved unless existing EU legislation is fully implemented, more efforts are made and investment barriers are not removed. I regret setting a target of at least 27% improvement in energy efficiency by 2030 adopted by the European Council and which, if compared to the binding in Parliament adopted by the 40% target that must be implemented in the form of individual national measures, is unmbitious. I call on the Commission to carry out a comprehensive cost analysis and adopt a perspective of social interest in line with its own Better Regulation Guidelines.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for this report, I very much welcome the resulting form, as it has succeeded in reinforcing a number of elements that the original proposal neglected. The current Energy Efficiency Directive is a good basis for achieving Europe's climate and energy targets, including the cop 21's ambitious commitments. However, this will only be achieved if some of its shortcomings, in particular excessive flexibility, are eliminated. As a result, we are lagging behind the targets set and, if nothing changes, we will not increase energy efficiency by 20% by 2020. In the report, we call for a binding 40% energy efficiency target, because if we compromise on this requirement, we will close the way to higher savings, to promote innovation and to strengthen our independence from imports. Furthermore, the report pays close attention to the fight against energy poverty.  Last but not least, it draws the Commission's attention to the need to urgently address competing legislation, which concerns, in particular, energy efficiency legislation, the promotion of renewables and the emissions trading scheme. In this respect, I consider it absolutely essential that the mutual effects are analysed and that the Commission come up with a proposal that will effectively address this situation.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is on track to achieve its 2020 target of a 20 % reduction in CO2 emissions, a 20% increase in the share of renewable energy carriers and a 20% improvement in energy efficiency. Achieving this objective could be put at risk if Member States do not fully implement current EU legislation.  The EU should therefore invest more in information and support programmes in the Member States, which could help increase participation in current mandatory local energy efficiency regimes, as well as promote new technical progress in areas such as cooling, lighting and insulation. For all this, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the EU, greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% between 1990 and 2014. At the same time, EU GDP grew by 46%. With less and less climate burden, businesses and citizens are achieving greater economic growth, creating more jobs and generating tax revenues. The report calls for a revision of the Directive with a view to turning it into a more coherent act of EU law. This report offers a starting point in this regard, e.g. the exchange of best practices between Member States and new funding opportunities (e.g. from the Juncker Plan). Unfortunately, there have been repeated calls for binding energy efficiency targets at EU and individual eu level. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I generally support efforts to protect the environment. However, I could not support this report because, unfortunately, the vote on the amendments was dosed by a radical stance that does not take into account the impact of climate targets on the European economy at all. Unfortunately, the compromise supported by me was rejected and I could not therefore support the resolution as a whole. Such a proposal would weaken the competitiveness of European businesses compared to countries that are not at all concerned with environmental protection. However, it would not be good for the environment for industry in countries with respect for the environment to disappear and move to countries that are among the main polluters.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which indicates that the European Union is on the right track, above all, it is important to see that it is mainly businesses and households that have seized on this energy need, as the directive is not yet fully implemented in most Member States. They are therefore asked to apply it fully and to do everything possible to fulfil the objectives of the European Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union today has a key role to play in promoting intergenerational responsibility, in particular by fostering an energy system in which current generations are committed to the fight against climate change for the benefit of generations to come.  In this line of reasoning, this report rightly stresses the importance of energy efficiency in meeting so-called climate targets, as well as the need for a flexible and unbureaucratic energy system that monitors and clarifies the definition of SMEs and State aid.  However, I am of the understanding that the report sins by default. On the one hand, it desates an unsatisfactory solution to the 40% energy efficiency target for 2030 (moreover, in the resolutions of 5 February 2014, 26 November 2014 and 15 October 2015). At the same time, the document is sparse as to the terms of decarbonisation in 2050, because in this area one could have gone much further. Finally, and what is not less, the report does not cover the minimum funding targets which, in my view, should be imposed at Member State level.  In that sense, my vote is unfavorable.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. This report is to be compared with the progress made in the renewable energy sector. In view of the 20% target, which is unlikely to be achieved if the Member States continue to build on this momentum, we MEPs have reiterated the need to make the transition further within the Union to an energy system based on renewable energies, in particular to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels.  As such, we have called for reducing as much as possible the excessive administrative burdens on households, but especially on businesses, thus limiting the potential for growth, job creation and innovation in this sector.  Furthermore, we reiterated the need for the Commission and the Member States to ensure a stable regulatory framework for the various players with regard to renewable energy, to ensure consistency between the different EU policies and the need to strengthen investment in the sector.  In line with these political lines, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the implementation of the 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive, which is the centrepiece of the EU's energy strategy in this area. Energy efficiency and the energy savings it entails have many advantages for the protection of the environment and the climate, the strengthening of the competitiveness of our economies, the creation of jobs, the fight against energy insecurity or even energy independence. However, the 20% energy efficiency target by 2020 is not being met. That is why we call for the directive, which constitutes the European framework of reference, to be fully and properly implemented, particularly in terms of the compliance of the national plans put in place by the Member States. This is not the time to lower the level of ambition. Finally, we call for more coherence in energy legislation as well as appropriate measures for the most modest households.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I share the approach taken in this Report by the majority of the Euro-Camera in favour of a binding target of 40% energy efficiency in 2030, as advocated at the recent Paris Climate Summit. This, despite the Council's position and the vote against the EPP, which wanted to limit it to a non-binding 30%. From what we consider to be a misguided perspective in the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in pursuing a target of 17.6% instead of the 20% stipulated by 2020, we do not share the rapporteur's approach to greater flexibility. As in the Bermejo report, also voted today, the EPP is opposed to measures to combat energy poverty which, however, have received the support of the majority of Parliament. In this regard, we call on States to ensure measures for low-income consumers. The end result is positive so I deserved my vote in favour. I hope that the report will be taken into consideration by the Commission, always awaiting Commissioner Cañete's appearance in this House because of the scandals that splatter on it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. On the eve of the revision of the legislative framework, which will take place in the autumn, the European Parliament on Thursday (June 23rd) reaffirmed its high energy efficiency ambitions for 2030. The energy efficiency resolution stresses the need for full implementation of existing EU legislation to achieve the EU's energy efficiency target by 2020 (a 20% gain by 2020). In addition, Parliament reiterated its ambition for a 40% energy efficiency target by 2030, with binding national targets for Member States to redouble their efforts. What I'm looking forward to! The adopted text also calls on the European Union to invest more in information and support programmes in Member States to encourage the participation of local actors in energy efficiency programmes and to promote new solutions in refrigeration, lighting and insulation...

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 In addition to the transition to renewable energy sources, energy efficiency remains another major energy problem in Europe. This is important for both the North and the South. I am pleased that the Commission takes this issue seriously, that it exists as a horizontal priority in many structural programmes, and that the indicators set out in the Energy Efficiency Directive are gradually being met. I am very pleased with this report. At the same time, I would like to highlight a number of remaining problems. The introduction of energy efficiency measures in many Member States should start with difficulties. Difficulties caused by both a lack of administrative capacity and financial support. At this point, the Wheat Commission should take this problem more seriously, in particular mr President- In the context of the implementation of the Junker Plan. After all, more efficient energy consumption, lower energy costs, especially those that still rely to a large extent on fossil and imported fuels, can have a huge added effect on the development of the economy as a whole. I also call on the Commission to pay more attention to the promotion of energy efficiency and to the external policies of the European Union, in particular in relations with our eastern neighbours, where these issues are severely neglected.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The text discussed in the ITRE Committee and presented in plenary by Mr Sy committee on be it was presented to the Committee on The Environment, External Security and Health Policy. Pieper covers the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive 2012/27. This directive establishes a strategic framework for promoting energy efficiency in the EU and imposes a non-binding 20% target for energy efficiency to be achieved by 2020. Although much remains to be done to iron out the differences between Member States in the energy sector, the Commission has recognised the efforts and efforts made to improve energy efficiency.  The text presented and discussed in the ITRE Committee, of which I am a member, contains interesting ideas related to the implementation of the legislation, with particular attention to the period that will follow 2020 and the strategies to be put in place on how to ensure the stability and security necessary for investors.  The report also refers to the measures contained in the European Commission's text, but makes changes with which I do not agree. In line with the positions I have always held on energy efficiency, such as the achievement of ambitious but flexible targets, and in line with the PPE Group, I voted against the Pieper report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because it underlines the need to improve energy efficiency as a way to combat climate change. It proposes country-binding targets. The binding aspect is a key point because it forces countries to meet these objectives while flexibility leaves the door open to insufficient targets. Moreover, it is not content with the 27% target set by the Council and the Commission in 2030 but proposes the most ambitious target of 40%. It also proposes to focus measures on households in energy poverty, which we think is of paramount importance.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ Much more work is needed on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. Energy dependency and energy poverty remain huge challenges, both of which can be partly addressed by improved energy efficiency. I applaud the work of my S&D colleagues on this report and their efforts to provide an analysis of the current situation with an important focus on energy poverty.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted against the 'Report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive', as we in the GROUP unfortunately were unable to enforce important points for implementation. The EU is well on its way to achieving its efficiency target, and energy efficiency will help us achieve our climate targets. However, we still have to work on many things, for example improving our cooperation on renewable energy sources and setting clear targets.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to demand a 40% improvement in the State efficiency targets by 2030, correcting the Council's down proposal of 27%. This will also require a review of the current functioning of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the non-application of which, excessive flexibility and lack of concreteness is adequately highlighted in the document.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Increasing energy efficiency by 20% by 2020 is one of the EU's important energy policy objectives. Action in this direction is important in view of the economic aspect of energy generation prices, environmental and trade issues (half of the EU's energy needs come from imports). The development of energy efficiency systems stimulates the search for new and innovative solutions, which in turn stimulates the European labour market and brings climate and environmental benefits. One area where efficiency gains are particularly important is the housing sector. Investments are needed to modernise existing buildings and to encourage energy savings for heating and cooling systems. In the longer term, such changes also entail better and more efficient resource management, which also translates into real savings. Increasing energy efficiency should be an attractive opportunity for small and medium-sized enterprises to increase their competitiveness by reducing spending on different energy sources. In a social context, on the other hand, better use of energy resources and the provision of energy at reasonable prices is a key element in the fight against energy poverty within the EU. However, it should be borne in mind that increasing energy efficiency is aimed at reducing energy consumption while maintaining living standards and production, but is not intended as a pretext for its waste.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report presented on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, which has resulted in many positive changes for the EU and the Member States. I see very positively that the EU is on track to achieve the 2020 targets, which include a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, an increase in the share of renewable energy in total energy consumption to 20% and a 20% increase in energy efficiency. Nevertheless, I am concerned about the information that, if the current pace is maintained, the EU will not reach the 20% energy savings target by 2020, and that the actual rate will be 1 to 2%. I believe that Member States that do not achieve the required results should swiftly implement existing legislation and remove barriers to investment. I expect the EU and the Member States to do their best to address as soon as possible shortcomings, such as energy reporting bureaucracy and high energy prices for medium-sized sole traders and private households. I believe that by taking effective measures at EU Member State level, we will be able to meet the European target of achieving 20% energy savings by 2020.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution on the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. The resolution responds to the Commission's report, which assesses member states' progress in implementing measures to achieve the energy efficiency target by 2020. The European Union has set itself a non-binding target of 20% savings in energy consumption, with the Energy Efficiency Directive being instrumental in achieving it. The resolution welcomes the flexibility of the directive – Member States can choose the best energy efficiency instrument for them. However, the Commission and the EP itself (EP in the resolution) regret to note that this target will not be met by 2020. The resolution also points out that the instruments for achieving individual energy-climate targets by 2020 are often in competition and are therefore inefficient. It also rightly points to the problems arising from the addition of additional requirements by Member States, in particular bureaucratic ones, to businesses and consumers, which are not required by European legislation. But the main problem with the resolution is that left-wing factions have pushed through a reference to climate targets by 2030. Member States agreed in October 2014 to a non-binding target of increasing energy efficiency by 27% by 2030 (with a possible increase to 30%). However, the resolution calls for a binding target of 40%. This wording was unacceptable to the PPE Group, which is why I and my colleagues did not support the motion for a resolution.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In the European Union, greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23% between 1990 and 2014. Over the same time, GDP in the EU increased by 46%. Businesses and citizens are creating ever-increasing growth, jobs and tax revenues, while at the same time the climate impact is shrinking, which is positive news. The European Union is on a very good track to meet its 2020 targets, which can be largely attributed to a successful emissions trading scheme. It not only encourages emissions reductions, but also to invest in energy-efficient technologies. However, the economic and financial crisis in some countries has undoubtedly contributed in part to the achievement of the objectives. The European Union's success in reducing greenhouse gases is commendable, but that does not mean that we could not do more to improve energy efficiency. The report under consideration is good because it calls on the European Commission to set a binding target for reducing greenhouse gases to 40% by 2030, thus setting the paris targets for COP 21. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 It should be noted that citizens need to be aware of the importance and efficiency of energy savings without the energy efficiency directive being implemented.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒The Energy Efficiency Directive recognises the importance of energy saving. The European Union is meeting its 2020 climate and energy targets, which include reducing carbon dioxide emissions, increasing the share of renewables, improving energy efficiency, and maintaining a leading role in this regard.  To protect the environment and climate, as well as to strengthen economic competitiveness, create jobs and combat energy poverty, it is essential to increase energy efficiency and ensure energy savings. Furthermore, it is important to recognise the importance of including citizens' initiatives, such as cooperatives and community energy efficiency projects. In order to make it easier for citizens to actively participate in the energy system, it is important to remove economic, regulatory and administrative barriers.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. This is an extremely important report, and rapporteur Pieper has done an excellent job of reaching a compromise. However, I voted against the report, as there have been a few votes in favour of amendments within the vote on the amendments calling on the Commission to set a binding 40% energy efficiency target for 2030, reflecting the potential of cost-effective energy efficiency, which I cannot agree with. It would be much better to set a target of at least 30% for improving energy efficiency by 2030 in order to achieve a higher, 40% target that reflects full economic potential.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the text there are positive references, which we have supported, to the need for this directive to be in line with the climate protection objectives and to the need to promote measures to combat energy poverty and support vulnerable groups.  However, it is clear that the policies proposed and promoted are within the framework and serve the implementation of the Energy Union, for which we have been highly critical. Despite the individual positive objectives mentioned, the aim is therefore to fully implement the third package of measures, in order to have a strong internal market, in order to make the EU more competitive on the world market. In this context, therefore, the policies promoted do not serve the needs and interests of society but turn energy into a tool that is called upon to serve the needs of the market. For these reasons we have abstained.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. In 1968, researchers warned the American Petroleum Institute that carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels could lead to global environmental changes. 48 years later and while science and technology have made strides, appropriate technologies are still not being applied to make the best use of renewable energy sources. We wondered why?  The conscious concealment of scientific findings, the cover-up of information and the deliberate misleading of public opinion have imposed the short-sighted policy of temporary profitability of large companies at the expense of corresponding viable choices. Oil giants and trade groups spend $115 million a year blocking climate policies. At the same time, they are pushing for natural gas to emerge as the key technology by which Europe will economically reduce carbon dioxide emissions. The European Union is associated with the situation by setting low targets and exercising moderate policies. We're criminal. Not only at the expense of the environment, but above all at the expense of our children. Politics must not be the subject of centres of economic power and obscene profitability. The development and implementation of renewable energy sources must be substantially supported and those responsible for sussing must be punished.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the issue of energy efficiency can be put at the centre of the eradication of energy poverty. I believe that a 20% improvement in energy efficiency should not be a problem for Member States, and even a more ambitious target (40%) we can reach you in the future. Of course, this can be achieved if the Member States really put this objective at the heart of their strategy. As a first step, I consider increasing energy efficiency in the public sector to be the most important way to reduce energy poverty. I agree that the role of the ETS is important both in terms of output and efficiency gains. I believe that reducing greenhouse gas emissions also encourages investment in energy-efficient technologies.  Instead of a policy of punishment and incapaation, we must prioritise a policy that encourages innovation. I agree that the cumbersome achievement of the objectives can be partly explained by the fact that several countries are in economic and financial crisis. Order needs to be made of partially contradictory EU climate legislation, the complexity of energy efficiency legislation and national energy policy actions, which have a significant impact on certain aspects of the European approach. I consider the report's finding that 61% of imported natural gas is used in buildings (mainly residential buildings) as an interesting element, and therefore an ambitious building renovation policy could reduce it by 60% in the short term. It's time to put an end to energy waste and fossil fuels.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Consumers must be prepared for a huge increase in energy prices if the Union goes down the fast track suggested by left-wing political groups in the European Parliament on energy efficiency policy. The 40% energy savings these parties expect are extremely costly and difficult to achieve in a short period of time. The Efficiency Directive has already generated significant progress. I strongly support a policy of higher energy efficiency, but it should be a policy that motivates energy efficiency. However, I am against the ban on energy in general, which would have happened if we had blindly followed the unrealistic provisions of Parliament's report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. Furthermore, in order to achieve greater energy efficiency, in addition to prohibitions and prohibitions, there is a need for better coordination and cooperation between Member States. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against the European Parliament's report.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it includes many of our demands made in committee. The report considers energy efficiency to be key to achieving the EU's climate and energy targets. Stresses that efficiency is of paramount importance in reducing our dependence on energy imports, creating jobs, reducing energy poverty, improving well-being and health, and stimulating the economy; calls for the gradual elimination of fossil fuel subsidies and the channelling of released resources to improve energy efficiency and the process towards decarbonisation. Important victories of the M5S were the inclusion in the report of the 40% binding EU target for 2030, with specific national targets, and the call to consider energy efficiency as a priority to increase the resilience of the energy system. We have also asked to consider the energy saved as a separate source, expressed in 'negawatts'. In this report, too, we have passed on our request to the EU and the Member States to recognise the importance of local authorities and citizens as essential players for energy efficiency towards the transition to a more sustainable economy. So in general the report is ambitious and progressive, although it still includes some conservative approaches.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has undertaken a wide-ranging process of combating greenhouse gases over the past three decades with a view to slowing global warming. Thus, between 1990 and 2014, greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23%, while EU GDP increased by 46%. By 2020, the EU-wide targets involve a 20% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions, a 20% increase in the share of renewable energies in total energy consumed and a 20% increase in energy efficiency. However, at the moment, the Commission's estimate is that an energy efficiency level of only 17.6% will be reached, which seriously jeopardises the achievement of the 40% target set for 2030. The causes of this situation include red tape in energy reporting, high energy price levels for SMEs and households and special provisions at national level. In these circumstances, there is a need to clarify the European energy efficiency framework, but also a number of measures aimed at boosting the replacement of renewable energy-polluted energies at Member State level, outside the framework already created by ETS certificates. I therefore support the current form of the present report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the text. Energy efficiency is key to meeting our climate targets as part of the goals endorsed by COP21 in Paris. It is of paramount importance in reducing our dependence on energy imports, creating jobs, reducing energy poverty, improving comfort and health, and boosting our economy.  I point out that the Energy Efficiency Directive has led to many positive improvements in the Member States, but that insufficient implementation hinders its true potential.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of this implementation report is to assess implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive (2012/27/EU). The issue of energy efficiency is also closely related to development in the field of renewables. While the Energy Efficiency Directive entered into force relatively recently, some conclusions can be drawn. While many Member States are on track to achieving 20% efficiency target for 2020, full implementation is highly unlikely. The report further highlights the need to focus on improvements in the building sector, which accounts for 40% of total energy consumption and 36% of CO2 emissions in the EU, the need to protect vulnerable consumers, improve conditions and provide technical support to those who wish to become prosumers. The rapporteur has pointed out that energy efficiency should be treated as an energy resource, thus decreasing EU dependency on energy imports from third countries, especially gas imports. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Energy efficiency is the European Union's priority in combating global warming. Improving energy efficiency by 20% - with a 20% increase in the share of renewable energy and a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions - is one of the European targets for 2020 in terms of sustainable development.  Between 1990 and 2014, greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 23%. At the same time, the EU's GDP grew by 46%. This is proof, if one were needed, that by reducing their impact on the environment citizens and businesses have generated a surplus of growth. Contrary to the claims of the proponents of the less environmental, the ecological transition and energy control are not a hindrance to economic growth, but an adjuvant. The 40% efficiency target by 2030 set by Parliament - instead of the 27% originally planned - is therefore beneficial. A cheap environmental policy cannot satisfy the will to build a sustainable and prosperous Europe. It is by taking the path of ecological transition that Europe will effectively meet its economic, social and environmental objectives.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. The Energy Efficiency Directive entered into force in December 2012. It commits Member States to setting indicative national energy efficiency targets by 2020 based on consumption or primary or final energy. The Directive also lays down legally binding rules for end-users and energy suppliers. Member States may tighten these minimum requirements to save as much energy as possible. However, I consider it unacceptable that the European Union establishes a binding energy efficiency policy and that energy efficiency regulation should be the responsibility of the Member States and I voted against the Report on the Implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Energy policy is very important for the European Union. We are on track to achieve our target of a 20% efficiency rate by 2020, despite the fact that the directive has not been fully implemented in most Member States. This proves that energy efficiency is in the interests of businesses and households. The report contains a number of positive points such as the importance of energy efficiency for achieving our climate targets, flexibility in Article 7, the need to better monitor and clarify the definition of SMEs and state aid rules. Nevertheless, I rejected the proposal for a directive. However, the directive places too much emphasis on energy saving rather than energy efficiency. Because of the key elements that have not been adopted, I too cannot support this report.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because it underlines the need to improve energy efficiency as a way to combat climate change. It proposes country-binding targets. The binding aspect is a key point because it forces countries to meet these objectives while flexibility leaves the door open to insufficient targets. Moreover, it is not content with the 27% target set by the Council and the Commission in 2030 but proposes the most ambitious target of 40%. It also proposes to focus measures on households in energy poverty, which we think is of paramount importance.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report because I have long disagreed with the setting of binding targets for energy efficiency. In addition, the report calls for a further increase to 40%.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Our societies are experiencing a transition towards a low-carbon economy, but there are strong vested interests close to national governments that make it difficult. It is thus fundamental that the EU maintains a strong position to ensure that countries make it easy for renewable energies. Moreover, all countries should put in place policies that protect the most vulnerable of our citizens, particularly those who suffer from energy poverty.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This text makes a realistic observation of the competitiveness problems of our energy-intensive industries compared to their non-EU competitors, but it advocates energy austerity that risks further harming these industries. So I chose abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Greenhouse gas emissions in the EU decreased by 23% between 1990 and 2014. Over the same period, EU GDP increased by 46%. Businesses and citizens are expanding growth less and less burdened by the climate, thereby creating jobs and generating tax revenues. By my vote, I followed the group's position in the final vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because it underlines the need to improve energy efficiency as a way to combat climate change. It proposes country-binding targets. The binding aspect is a key point because it forces countries to meet these objectives while flexibility leaves the door open to insufficient targets. Moreover, it is not content with the 27% target set by the Council and the Commission in 2030 but proposes the most ambitious target of 40%. It also proposes to focus measures on households in energy poverty, which we think is of paramount importance.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Welcomes new innovative and innovative solutions to combine electricity supply and demand. Notes that the Commission is developing guidelines for the implementation of Articles 9 to 11 of the Energy Efficiency Directive in order to help consumers better control their energy consumption; considers that technical feasibility and the installation of smart meters – taking into account cost-efficiency and cost transparency – are an essential condition for energy saving

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the implementation report on the Energy Efficiency Directive. The report emphasises that improving energy efficiency is crucial to achieving our climate targets. The report stresses that this is essential to start the transition towards a more sustainable energy system based on renewables and away from fossil fuels as soon as possible. The report recalls that the transition towards a more sustainable energy is also vital to job creation and sustainable growth. I voted in favour of the report because I strongly believe that the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive is a major progress towards achieving the EU’s climate and energy targets.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to demand a 40% improvement in the national efficiency targets by 2030, correcting the Council's down proposal of 27%. This will also require a review of the functioning to date of the Energy Efficiency Directive, the non-application of which, excessive flexibility and lack of concreteness is adequately highlighted in the document.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. In the EU, greenhouse gas emissions fell by 23% between 1990 and 2014. Over the same period, EU GDP increased by 46%. With ever-deer impacts on the climate, businesses and citizens are generating more growth, creating new jobs and generating tax revenues. The European Union is well on track to meet the targets set for 2020, i.e. 20% less CO2 emissions, increase the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption to 20%, and 20% increase energy efficiency. This is largely due to the successful ETS scheme. This scheme not only encourages reductions in emissions, but also to invest in energy-efficient technology. I voted in favour of this report and I am also pleased that Flanders is stepping up its new policy measures.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the implementation report of the Energy Efficiency Directive is to be supported because it pays attention not only to increasing energy efficiency, but also to saving energy. Taking into account national specificities and ambitious climate targets are also the right measures for the EU. On a couple of points, I deviated from my group's line, among other things, because I am not in favour of increasing additional reporting to the Member States. For these reasons as a whole, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report deals with the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. Sustainable energy production, as well as the optimal use of existing resources, is one of the greatest challenges for the 21st century. However, this report mixes different concepts and therefore does not differentiate. The report also forgets to refer to the various regions of the European Union. Energy efficiency means something very different in Finland than in Spain. That is why I abstained.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – Ensuring the future of energy in the EU requires a combination of approaches. While renewable energy plays an important role in this future, we also have to work on energy efficiency. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. It sends a positive message, stressing the progress that has been made and recognises the role of ETS and the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive herein. It also recognises some problems, such as the complexity of the relevant legislation. I therefore strongly welcome its call on the Commission to work towards a coherent electricity market design for the EU.  While the EU plays an important role as legislator, in the end it is the market itself that will be the key to the solution. As long as we ensure that energy efficiency is in the industry’s interest, the market will become more energy efficient by itself. I agree with the resolution that the correct incentive is very important in this regard.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Energy efficiency is one of the key parameters in ensuring energy supply.
