Both European and national policies in this area should therefore create an environment in which investments in increasing resource efficiency pay off. This own-initiative report offers a large number of policy recommendations based on a review of existing measures at European level. Common policies in this area are essential because of the high and further increasing level of interconnection of distribution networks and interdependence. The emphasis on efficiency is therefore in the interest of all Member States and is a prerequisite for reducing the EU's energy dependence on Russia. That is why I supported this report in the vote.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Energy Efficiency Directive of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Mr Pieper's text takes into account important positive, but also insufficient points, particularly in its implementation.  In any event, the content has been welcomed by most members of the committee responsible.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I am very much in favour of this report, as I believe that it is very important to keep in mind the energy levels used in the EU, which should not exceed certain maximums, so that pollution and damage to the environment are reduced.  It is therefore necessary to create a clear and consistent legislative framework in this regard, reflecting energy efficiency regulation, so that efficiency levels are common to all EU states and, thus, we can all contribute to the same extent to a common objective such as improving the environment. In Spain, for example, during 2014 primary and final energy levels were reported below target levels by 2020, indicating that we are well aware and supporting my support for this report.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support Mr Pieper's report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive. The report itself understands energy efficiency as a source of energy and defines it as a way of protecting the environment and helping to reduce the European Union's energy dependency. Of course, at the moment, when it is important to look for ways to reduce the European Union's energy dependence on resources from abroad, it is also necessary to work with the positives of improved energy efficiency. On the other hand, however, the report also contained a number of calls for binding targets for energy efficiency, both at European and national level, which I do not support. Likewise, I do not share the calls for ever more ambitious targets, as Member States do not face the same domestic situation and therefore setting binding ambitious targets, for example as regards the renovation of buildings, could thus cause problems in some Member States, especially in poorer areas.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Pieper report for agreeing with this balance sheet report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, in particular the finding that much is still to be done in the context of the energy performance of buildings and the call for a strong regulatory framework consisting of the adoption of objectives and measures to encourage and enable investment in energy efficiency and the reduction of energy costs and consumption while supporting competitiveness and sustainability.  As I advocate in the field of renewable energy, it is also essential to take ambitious targets in line with the Paris Agreement and produce more clean and renewable energy, create wealth and employment and reduce strategic dependence on external suppliers. To this end, I believe that energy efficiency should be understood as the most sustainable measure under the obligation to reduce our energy consumption.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, within the framework of the EU's energy and climate policy, it is of great importance by establishing a set of binding measures to guide the EU in achieving the targets of 20% increase in energy efficiency, a 20% increase in renewable energy production and a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, all by 2020. Unfortunately, the directive has not been fully implemented in the various Member States and although it is possible that the emission reduction target will still be met, the credit will be for the economic and industrial crisis that has hit the EU over the last eight years more than the work done by the various Member States. The EPP rapporteur had tried to approach the reading of this failure of the directive with a perspective that would put industrial interests against climate and environmental objectives, requiring repeated deregulation and flexibility in the revision of the directive expected in the autumn. However, the political and amending work of us and the other more progressive and green forces has made it possible to make a more critical assessment of the problems of implementing the directive, such as the lack of binding targets, by outnumbering the most conservative forces and greatly improving the text.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. Greater energy efficiency and energy savings are important for protecting the environment and climate, strengthening economic competitiveness, creating new jobs and security of energy supply. This can be achieved through a policy that promotes the efficient use of energy through reductions in appropriate taxes and additional funding. However, the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive, as advocated by the Left (with a binding target of 40% savings by 2030 for individual Member States), is unrealistic and does not contribute to a more efficient use of energy. Such a binding target could result in a significant increase in energy prices and the establishment of building quotas that neither local authorities nor residents can afford.
